debateinfo.title: VETERANSâ ENTITLEMENTS AMENDMENT (2005 BUDGET MEASURE) BILL 2005

subdebate.1.para: Bill presented by Mrs De-Anne Kelly, and read a first time.

talk.start.para: âI move:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

speech.para: I am pleased to present legislation to give effect to a federal budget initiative that will benefit up to 44,000 Australian veterans, war widows and widowers.

This bill will amend the Veteransâ Entitlements Act 1986 to extend eligibility for the Australian governmentâs seniors concession allowance to holders of the gold card who are over veteran pension age and who are not otherwise eligible for the seniors concession allowance or the utilities allowance.

The seniors concession allowance was introduced by this government in December 2004, carrying through an election commitment to assist self-funded retirees in paying the costs of water, sewerage, electricity, rates and motor vehicle registration.

The allowance is currently available to DVA and Centrelink Commonwealth seniors health card holders as a non-taxable payment of $200, paid in two instalments in June and December each year.Â The amount of seniors concession allowance is indexed twice yearly.
The bill also provides for the seniors concession allowance to be paid to eligible gold card holders if they are temporarily absent from Australia for no more than 13 weeks.
With passage of this bill, the first payment of seniors concession allowance to eligible gold card holders will take place in December 2005.

This legislation broadens the governmentâs support for our older veterans.Â In 1999, we extended the gold card to Australian veterans and mariners aged 70 or over with qualifying service from World War II.
In 2002, we further extended eligibility for the gold card to include all Australian veterans aged 70 or over with qualifying service from any conflict.
This yearâs budget increases funding for the care of the veteran and Defence Force communities to more than $10.8 billion, a rise of $278 million on 2004-05.
The 2005-06 budget includes $4.6 billion for health careâan increase of $203 million on 2004-05âand $6.1 billion for compensation and income support, up from $6 billion last financial year.
Veteransâ Affairs funding has risen under this government from $6.5 billion in 1996 to more than $10.8 billion in this budgetâan average annual increase of 5.8 per cent.
Over a decade, the government has committed more than $86 billion in recognition of the special needs of our veterans and war widows.

Through our commitment to working with the ex-service and defence communities to identify and address key priorities, the government has delivered a repatriation system that continues to be highly regarded around the world.

The 2005-06 budget builds on our hard work to ensure that our veterans, whether they served in the world wars or in more recent deployments, will receive the care they need and the support the community expects for this important group of Australians.
This initiative recognises the needs of our older gold card recipients and continues this governmentâs strong commitment to the Australian veteran community.
I commend the bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Mr Gavan OâConnor) adjourned.

debateinfo.title: SUPERANNUATION LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (CHOICE OF SUPERANNUATION FUNDS) BILL 2005

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 31 May, on motion by Mr Brough:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

subdebate.1.para: upon which Mr Fitzgibbon moved by way of amendment:

motion.para: That all words after âThatâ be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
âwhilst not declining to give the bill a second reading, the House:

item.para: condemns the Government for the poorly designed choice of superannuation fund regime which is too complex and unsafe; and
calls on the Government to:

item.label: (a)
item.para: exempt small businessâ20 employees or less from this new red tape burden;

item.label: (b)
item.para: remove the two year gaol term and the $22,000 fine on employers if they provide advice to their employees; and

item.label: (c)
item.para: keep the Superannuation Holding Accounts Reserve Account openâ.

talk.start.para: âIn continuing the remarks I was making last night on the Superannuation Legislation Amendment (Choice of Superannuation Funds) Bill 2005, I take the opportunity to remind members that I have a background in small business. I understand how small business feels when it is confronted with a new system and new paperwork.

speech.para: Prior to the adjournment last night, I was saying that after reading the details of the superannuation choice scheme I was wondering what position I would have been in come 1 July. It is likely that I would have been in a position to sack my single employee without explanation as one of the businesses that would have been exempted from the unfair dismissal laws. That would be a particularly brave move on my part, given the fact that I have been married to my single employee for 29 years! Leaving that aside, it would seem that, come 1 July, I will not be able to discuss her superannuation choice or our future savings for retirement because that could be considered subject to sanctions.

Government members may scoff at the suggestion that small business is concerned about the introduction of choice but, to assure themselves that this is indeed the case, they need go no further than the Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia. In early May this year the council issued a media release titled âPenalties for super choice too harsh!â The council expressed the deep concerns of its membership about the penalty regime imposed under the super choice scheme. I can understand their concerns. I do not know that anyone would like the prospect of a couple of years in jail for a few misplaced words in a conversation. The councilâs media release said:

quote.para: The Shadow Small Business Minister Mr Tony Burke is right when he calls for exemptions for small business.

speech.para: It is not that I think that the Council of Small Business Organisations could be confused with the ACTU but it is interesting that the Council of Small Business Organisations does emphasise that Laborâs position of calling for an exemption is supported by small businesses across the country. It would seem that small business is genuinely concerned by the introduction of super choice and wants an exemption.

Naturally the media release prompted me to wonder about the governmentâs motivation for not granting the exemption. I would have thought that, with a group such as the Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia supporting Laborâs calls, there must be a sound reason for the government to ignore them. I dug through old statements by the minister to try to gain some insight as to why the government would not accede to the request of small business and grant an exemption, but the closest thing I found in my research was a statement by a spokeswoman for the Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer. It said:

quote.para: Exempting small business from offering choice would just create a competitive disadvantage for small business in a tight labour market.

speech.para: As a small business person, I do not know what that means and neither do the very small business operators in Liverpool who I had the privilege to address recently. While calls from COSBOA may not be enough to convince members opposite to support Laborâs amendments, there are a number of other concerns that must be raised about this scheme.

Most people are well aware that the superannuation industry is a multibillion dollar industry. Recently I saw reports that estimated the assets of the superannuation industry to be in the order of $750 billion, which is a considerable sum by anybodyâs standards. The handling of those considerable assets requires management and funds management brings with it fees and charges. Annual revenue from these fees and charges on the management of superannuation funds has been estimated to be between $5 billion and $10 billionâanother significant sum.

Superannuation choice introduces a new dimension to retirement savings in Australia. The government has managed to bring together the finance and funds management industries and employees to make decisions on considerable financial holdings of workers with less than full information available to them. It was not all that long ago that people were very concerned because their superannuation funds had fallen. If things go bad again, I am sure government will wash its hands very quickly of this situation and hide behind the excuse that, after all, it was the employeesâ choiceâthat they had the right to choose where their funds went and that whether or not they chose a successful fund was in their hands.

Small businesses must be exempted from super choice. They are concerned about its impact on their business and they are concerned about what might happen to their employeesâ retirement savings. Small business operators will be overwhelmed by paperwork as a consequence of this scheme. That is what I find so amazing about the governmentâs refusal to exclude small business from the choice provisions. This governmentâthe self-appointed best friend of small businessâis going to increase the pressure on small business owners. Owners who are already spending many hours every week trying to comply with the âsimplified tax systemâ will have to deal with this as well.

Some time ago I reviewed the governmentâs document titled âCommitted to small businessâ. This document, released last year, outlined the governmentâs commitment to small business and what it had done to free up small business owners and operators so they could concentrate on growing their businesses. The document went to great lengths to praise the work of small business, to inform us of their contribution to the economy and to report that the governmentâs commitment to small business had not diminishedânoble sentiments that have not been borne out by the governmentâs position on superannuation choice. The document reported that it has been a priority of the government since its election in 1996 to reduce red tape and that it has made inroads into improving regulatory oversight applying to small business. It included the following statement:

quote.para: The Government is committed to streamlined, cost effective regulation that does not impose unnecessary paperwork or other compliance costs upon small business. The Government will continue to be responsive to small business needs and concerns on these issues.â

speech.para: I guess that along with super choice has now come a super change in policy. Super choice is the essence of unnecessary paperwork for small business. The governmentâs small business policy has undergone somewhat of a change. I guess the great friend of small business owners has now seen fit to abandon them.

Small business owners can handle a fair bit. We have to. In the main we do not enjoy the luxury of having finance departments to take care of the bookwork. We do not have human resource departments to take care of occupational health and safety, or superannuation departments to fill in and comply with the distribution of superannuation forms. For the most part, doing all this in a small business is the sole province of the small business owner and operator. Small business owners can handle having a relatively simple three-step process replaced with a 34-step process, if they have to. Small business owners can handle the extra paperwork associated with superannuation choice and the various aspects of superannuation funds, if they have to. But they do not have to. Government members have a choice. They can live up to their commitment to reduce unnecessary paperwork and compliance burdens on small business by supporting the oppositionâs amendment. Members opposite must support the small business call and the call of the opposition to exempt small business from superannuation choice.

talk.start.para: âI am pleased to have the opportunity today to speak on the Superannuation Legislation Amendment (Choice of Superannuation Funds) Bill 2005. In my electorate of Canberra I have many opportunities to meet with small business owners throughout my community. I find they are unique. They run businesses of very different strengths and sizes and they are all very hard-working men and women who have taken the risk of setting out on their own to start and continue with their own enterprises. I have a great amount of admiration and respect for those Canberrans that take this step. They are the powerhouse of our local economy and I believe that they deserve our support and our encouragement. I am aware that many small businesses, begun in Canberra over the years and decades in the past, have grown and prospered and led Canberra to the developed stage it is today. I pay absolute respect to the background of that business economy in my community.

speech.para: It is for all these reasons and for all of that local history and local commitment from the small business people that I was horrified to learn of the extraordinary burden that is about to be placed on all of those small businesses by this government. The compliance burden that the government wishes to place on small business through its super choice regulations is as astonishing as it is complex. The government has turned a simple three-step system for superannuation into a complex maze of 34 steps. And if Canberra small business owners take a wrong turn in the governmentâs superannuation maze, there are unbelievable penalties.

One of the pitfalls in the superannuation maze could see employers pay multiple fines of up to $500 per employee if they simply fail to navigate this government maze. Also, small business owners could face significant legal liabilities for just giving advice to employees even if they are asked by employees to give a view. This could see Canberra small business owners face two years in jail or fines up to $22,000 if they advise employees outside the terms of the choice of super law. On top of the prospects of facing massive fines and possible jail terms, Canberra employers must now cop an extra layer of Howard government inspired red tape.

Does this government have form on creating more red tape for small business? For employers Australia wide there are now an extra five million forms to be handed out to existing employees and over one million each year thereafter, thanks to this amazing piece of policy. Ongoing records will have to be kept and made available to the tax office for inspection and enforcement. We all remember very clearly the Prime Ministerâs laudable boast in 1996 that his government would commit itself to reducing red tape for small business by 50 per cent. In a media release in July 2004 the then minister for small business made the following statement:

quote.para: In addition to cutting red tape the Federal Government is also working to help empower small businesses.

speech.para: Then the current Minister for Small Business and Tourism, who constantly claims in this House that the government has reduced red tape, had the audacity recently to make this claim:

quote.para: Australiaâs 1.2 million small businesses continue to benefit from this Governmentâs very strong economic management and we are committed to reducing red tape.

speech.para: It becomes a bit repetitive when you look over the history of this government in relation to red tape and small business. First there was the GST and now there is super choice. We can see that these promises on red tape and helping small business were just another example of non-core commitment from a government that in fact seems to be obsessed with regulation and therefore the creation of red tape.

I was so concerned by this change in policy in relation to super choice and the effect it would have on Canberraâs small businesses that I, along with my colleague Senator Lundy, recently wrote to small businesses in my electorate making sure they were aware of and prepared for the governmentâs plans. We included in this letter a petition for small businesses to sign and send in. The petition urges the government to exempt small business from the nightmare compliance regimes of these super choice laws. The response from small business in my electorate reflects their concern. The petitions continue to flow into my office from very concerned and very worried small business owners in Canberra. This is because Canberraâs small business owners understand these plans and they are concerned. They are also disappointed at the hypocrisy of this government. They are disappointed by the constant promises made, such as the promise to cut the mountain of red tape they face each day, and they are disappointed that the government continues to disregard and even break those commitments. This can be clearly shown in the response to that petition that I am receiving from small business in my community.

That is interesting, because in the world of politics it is very easy for people to take up the mantra that small business and Labor do not have much in common, that small business is not Laborâs natural constituency. That is said often. I dispute that; I always have. I do not believe in the claim of natural constituencies. I believe that you win constituencies by what you do with and for them. I understand very clearly how the small business community in my electorate are feeling about the impost that this ridiculous policy is going to place upon them.

We on this side of the House understand those problemsâI know I do. My community are talking with me and telling me what they think of it. We care enough to try and implement considered and practical policies and legislation that will help make small business flourish. We are not interested in ideologically driven policies based on division. We are interested in trying to do the right thing to encourage and see bloom even more the small business economy in this country. We do not believe that the introduction of more red tape is going to benefit anybody. In fact, we believe the opposite.

I am interested in supporting policies that are going to see the Australian economy grow. I am interested in seeing policy that is going to encourage and support the powerhouse of our economic base and my economic base in my electorate of Canberra, and that is small business. As I said earlier, the whole of the Canberra economy has grown from a very small beginning with a lot of dedicated people putting money, effort and hard work into developing businesses that began small. They have invested back into this community; they have not been enticed to go elsewhere. Some of these people have been working in this community for decades. They have built themselves into a viable economic community in my electorate and I do not want to see that damaged.

The government constantly claim that they are the best friend that small business has ever had and that they have nothing but the small businessesâ interests at heart. I cannot see how this super choice law and the implications of it for small business can sit beside those statements. I believe that it is a bit of a sad joke. The government are failing small business if they think that they can get away with putting this amazing set of regulations onto the small business in this community through the super choice laws. I am speaking in this debate because I think this is wrong. I think this is bad policy. There are simpler ways for it to be done. I implore the government to look at it very carefully. Putting this sort of regime onto small business while boasting of cutting red tape proves that that is a fallacy. It is just so illogical that I become almost wordless. I cannot understand how they can possibly boast that their policies in this regard are going to help small business. All I can see is small business in my community drowning in the red tape of the super choice regime. I speak very strongly against it and I will continue to represent the small businesses in my community who are telling me how they feel about it until it is changed.

talk.start.para: âI would like to say a few brief words in relation to the Superannuation Legislation Amendment (Choice of Superannuation Funds) Bill 2005. Rather than go back through many of the issues that various speakers have raised, I would like to place on record that I support the basic principles of choice in superannuation. I would encourage the government to move in some other areas as well where the legislative arrangements in relation to superannuation have actually sent the wrong message. When superannuation was originally set up it was designed to encourage people to save for their own retirements. Over the years there have been a number of legislative amendments that have essentially led to superannuation funds being used as fundraisers for other matters, not the least of which has been government. I am pleased to see that in recent months there are some positive changes in relation to that and I do congratulate the government.

speech.para: But the compliance burden that the shadow minister and the previous speakers for the opposition have raised is of concern to many small businesses within my electorate. I am pleased to see the Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer here. I ask the minister, when he is making his response, to spend some time, if he could, on the arrangements that are in the legislation in relation to the two years jail and the $22,000 fine that small businesses could face by inadvertently being in breach of the legislation. I ask the minister if he would address that particular issue because it is outside the bounds of politics and I think we are hearing that loud and clear from the opposition.

Small businesses are concerned about this particular issue. Small businesses are not saying to me that there should not be choice. They agree with the basic principle. Individuals are saying to me that they are pleased to see that there is some choice because they have been shifted around from various funds. They have had money in some funds that they agreed with and other funds that they did not agree with. The fees and general administrative charges of some of the funds were different and they felt as though they were not getting a return out of some funds. This legislation, as I understand it, overcomes that. I think most people would applaud that. But there is this very real issue of red tape and the fines and possible jail sentences that could accrue to people in business who, in a sense, would only be giving advice that they thought was appropriate.

Obviously, in many small businesses, particularly where there are young people, employees will go to their boss, whom they hopefully regard with some respect, and ask for advice rather than have the additional expenses of going to financial planners, accountants et cetera to seek advice on what they should and should not be doing. I think that is the good part of small business: it is small enough to be, in a sense, a family in most casesâI am not saying in every caseâand there are opportunities for people to help one another within the business. That grows the integrity of the business and focuses people in the right direction: towards achieving in their part of the business for the business as a whole, and everybody wins. I think philosophically the government would agree with that but, as I said, I would ask the minister to address that issue specifically and make it very plain to the small businesses out there that this will not be the burden of red tape that it seems to be on reading the legislation. If it is going to be the burden of red tape that the legislation indicates, I would ask the minister to support the second part of the amendment that the opposition has moved in relation to the removal of those constraints.

talk.start.para: âThis is an important issue and I want to intervene in the debate in support of the oppositionâs amendment. The debate we are having today concerns one of those ridiculous ham-fisted things that governments do in their late stages as they get increasingly out of touch with the people who put them there. Some people might say that the issue of super choice regulation cannot be that important in itself, but it is emblematic of a government that increasingly has a tin ear for criticism and that, as a result, is making more mistakes and errors of judgment day by day.

speech.para: Several members of the government have spoken on the Superannuation Legislation Amendment (Choice of Superannuation Funds) Bill 2005 and on the Labor amendment in the past day. Each has extolled the virtues of the new super choice regime. They have all attacked Labor for daring to call that regime into question, but none of themânot oneâhas come to terms with the substance of this amendment. None has acknowledged what a red tape nightmare the super choice regime has become. None has explained just why a small business person should face a jail term for helping an employee. None has taken seriously the concerns of small business that the government is about to throw yet another layer of red tape onto themâyet another pesky set of regulations to add to the pressures and the uncertainties of running a business.

I draw your attention, Mr Speaker, to this newspaper advertisement put out by the government to get something of the spirit of the flat panic that the government is obviously now getting into: âEmployees and super choice: time is running outâ. What a way for a government to address an important part of its constituencyâor what it likes to claim is its constituency. What an extraordinary way to start speaking to them about this ideological obsession of yours, for which some of them are going to go to jail. Then, of the several points that are put down in the advertisement, there is this is one: âDonât provide financial advice.â Listen to what the government is saying: âYou may explain the choice process to your employees, but you should not give financial advice unless you are licensed to do so. If your employees want help about how to decide which fund is best for them, they can download the super choice booklet from www.superchoice.gov.au or they can request free copies by calling 13 28 64.â

What an extraordinary situation for employers to find themselves in. Just what constitutes financial advice in these circumstances? Why should an employer who is running some jobbing shop in the back blocks of the western suburbs of Sydney know exactly what that means in legal terms? And why would any employee who spends most of their lives just organising their families, moving to and from work and getting out to the weekend footy and the rest of it feel that they can, without any form of assistance, sit down and work their way through the complex problems of superannuation choice? There is only one person for them to speak to who they know might know something about itâand that is the bloke who pays their wages.

It is precisely for these reasons that we are moving this amendment. The amendment provides for two important changes to the super choice regime. It exempts small businesses from the regimeâs requirements. That means small business owners employing fewer than 20 staff will not be required to comply. It ensures that no small business owner acting in good faith and with no other financial incentives need fear penalties or jail terms if they answer questions from their employees about superannuation. These are sensible reforms. We are proposing them because we have been listening to small business concerns. The amendment addresses specific glaring problems with the operation of the super choice regime, and there is absolutely no reason not to pass it today.

I will start with the jail terms. I accept that there should be serious penalties for employers who get secret kickbacks for pushing their employees into choosing particular super funds. There are rogue employers out there and we must protect employees from people who would trick them into making bad financial decisions about their retirement income. But I do not think that employers should face jail for trying to be helpful. Surely the government should be listening to businesses on this issue. Surely it is too heavy handed to threaten a small business operator with a $22,000 fine or time in jail. Surely it is nonsense for them to be caught in the Corporations Act definition of âcarrying on a financial services businessâ just because they answer an employeeâs question about super.

Let us pause for a moment to reflect on how a small business workplace operates. Relations between employers and staff in many small businesses are relaxed, informal and close. Employers often go out of their way to support their staff, just as employees show a strong loyalty to their boss. Small businesses thrive on a relationship of trust. They do not have all the formal structures of big workplaces because they do not need them. That is why it does not make sense to impose big organisation solutions onto small business.

When it comes to complex legal issues like tax and superannuation, it is natural that employees will look to their boss for guidance. It is natural that some employees will ask their boss for advice about what to write on the super choice form and what fund to choose. That is how small businesses work. So the fact that an employer could face a jail term of up to two years for helping out and answering an employeeâs question is absurd. This is bureaucratic lunacy. This is nuts.

The government has made it inevitable that thousands of small business operators will inadvertently break the law. I cannot understand why the government will not do something about it. It is no use arguing that the courts will be reasonable and a judge will take all these things into account. Why not just fix the law? Why have the threat of these penalties hanging over small businesspeople? Doesnât the government think they have enough stress in their lives already? There is one simple thing the government can do: take them out. Amend this legislation and let employers across Australia breathe a little easier tonight, because I can assure you, Minister Brough, that small businesspeople are now getting worried, which is why you are putting out advertisements like the one I have here. Small businesspeople are getting worried about what it is that they are confronting. Amend this legislation and let employers across Australia breathe a little easier tonight. Just get it done.

We are giving members of the government an opportunity to do that today. But if you will not, let me say this to every member of the government in this chamber: your names will be recorded. Your vote will be on the record and it is you who will need to go back to your electorates and explain yourselves.

talk.start.para: âOrder! The Leader of the Opposition will desist from using the word âyouâ.

âMembers of the government will need to defend their decision to vote in favour of jail terms for small businesspeople, and they will need to explain why they voted against giving them a break from the burden of one more piece of bungling bureaucratic stupidity.

speech.para: We are proposing a sensible amendment. It does not open the floodgates to employers exploiting their staff, and it does not allow bosses to get secret kickbacks for misleading advice. It simply says if any employer gives an employee advice about their superannuation at their request and they have no pecuniary interest in the advice given then they will not be subject to the penalties of a fine or a jail term. Why wouldnât the government accept it? Why wouldnât you accept that as a simple proposition? I cannot understand why members of the Liberal and National parties plan to vote against this. I cannot imagine how they are going to explain it to their local chamber of commerce next time the issue comes upâand it will come up.
Local businesses will not take much comfort from the Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer in this House last Wednesday, when he argued:

quote.para: ... there are no jail terms prescribed in the superannuation choice legislation.

speech.para: This is a typical example of this governmentâs deceptivenessâit is technically correct, but totally misleading. It is true there are no jail terms in the superannuation choice legislation. But there are jail terms in another piece of legislation, and the superannuation choice law activates the provisions relating to penalties and jail terms. It is highly deceptive to argue these jail terms are not in the super choice laws without admitting they are a consequence of them. What really matters: the location of a clause that imposes a fine of up to $22,000 and a two-year jail term for helping an employee, or the penalties themselves? It is no comfort to employers that the threat of a $22,000 fine is based on the Corporations Act and not the super choice legislation.

These amendments also exempt small businesses from the super choice laws. It is tough enough for small businesses without the extra burden of the super choice laws. Small businesses are already on the front-line of the economy, and more than anyone they have to cope with the effects of the Howard governmentâs neglect of Australiaâs long-term needs. Small businesses are suffering the most from the skills shortage, because they often have a much harder time luring talented staff. They cannot offer the same career progression, and often they cannot offer the same rates of pay as bigger enterprises.

Small businesses are also losing out from our ageing, creaking infrastructureâlike unreliable communications systems, difficulties in accessing high-speed broadband connections, and bad transport links. While they are paying a price for the governmentâs policy failures, small business owners still have their shoulder to the wheel, playing an important role as unpaid tax collectors for the government through the GST and business activity statement system. After all, for the 56 per cent of small businesses who have no employees other than the operator, when the paperwork lands on your desk you cannot pass it on to someone else. For many of them, paperwork is what they have to do outside of normal business hours when they are not doing the hands-on management of the business. So more layers of red tape just means more time buried in paperworkâand, for many of them, more time away from their families. Small business operators do not need more of the Treasurerâs dead hand of regulation. They need relief, and they deserve an exemption.

If their need for an exemption is not clear enough, just look at some of the detail of the implementation of the super choice regime. Look also at the burdens on employers when a fund merges with another. This is significant because it is very likely the next few years will see a big shake-up in super funds management. We can expect a lot of mergers and consolidations. Why then does the law require small business owners to know about every merger and change of fund name, and why should they be in breach of the act if they do not get their employees to fill in a new form within 28 days? What if the business owner is on holidays? How is this provision reasonable?

Look at another aspect of the implementation of the super choice regime: while the government imposes rigid 28-day deadlines on small business owners, it is much softer on itself. It is now less than a month before the super choice regime comes into effect and the government is still making amendments to the act. The Assistant Treasurer flagged this legislation back in March, but it took him another two months to bring these changes into parliament.

While business must jump through hoops to comply with the rules, the government shows a cavalier disregard for business concerns with its tardiness in finishing changes to this law. It is hard not to see this is as another example of where there is one rule for them and another rule for the rest of us. Small business operators will have to print the forms, distribute the forms, make the payments to multiple funds, upgrade their software where necessary, and then go through the whole process again if someoneâs super fund merges with another.

Take just one more example of the high-handed, arrogant attitude behind the implementation of these laws. It concerns the forms that must be handed out to employees within 28 days of 1 July. Five million of these forms need to be returned, but guess what? They have only bothered to print 1.2 million. They advise small business to print the forms themselves. It is quite a different practice, for example, to the Australian Taxation Office, which freely provides tax file number declaration forms. Perhaps this is just a small thing, but perhaps it says something more about their attitudeâthey cannot even be bothered to provide small business people with copies of the forms that must be filled in.

Small business people have long since tired of government ministers chattering about their concern for them and then loading them up with extra burdens. This government has sent enough bureaucrats scurrying off to write reports about compliance burdens. It has made enough flamboyant promises to make things better, like its promise to cut red tape in half, made in 1996. After almost 10 years in power it is about time it delivered, or at least stopped making things worse. But instead of taking these concerns seriously, it thumbs its nose at them. As small businessesâ burdens build, the government blithely ignores their cries.

Its response to Laborâs proposed amendments is a case in point. We are told that small businesses are not concerned about the legislationâit is only a two-page form once per year. We are told that these laws really do not bother small business owners and we are told that, if people are concerned about them, then it must be Laborâs faultâthat Labor must be running a scare campaign. All we are doing is talking about what they have put in their legislation. It was not Labor that invented this regime. It was not Labor that created the 34-step process to comply with the governmentâs super choice regime. It was not Labor that created the 55 pages of explanatory notes, the five million forms to be handed out this year, the extra million forms to be filled in every year afterwards, the need to keep records of the businessâs compliance for tax office inspection for a period of five years and the fines of up to $500 per employee for not complying with the super choice laws.

We did not dream up the idea of threatening mums and dads who run small businesses with jail terms, when they are only trying to be helpful to an employee, because we do not believe in quenching the flames of the entrepreneurial spirit that fire up small business people. Even if they dismiss what Labor is saying, why doesnât the government listen to other voices of small business? Listen to the Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia. It says that the super choice regime is complex and expensive, and small businesses should be exempt. I quote from the media release of CEO Tony Stephen dated 4 May 2005:

quote.para: The Shadow Small Business Minister Mr. Tony Burke is right when he calls for exemptions for small business.
â¦Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â â¦Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â â¦

... informal conversations in the small business workplace could very easily lead to advice being provided which in turn could potentially see the harshest penalties being applied, for a breach of the regulations. A possible two year jail term for giving advise to an employee is a more substantial penalty than courts often impose for more serious crimes, such as shoplifting, most break and enters etc. Iâm sure the community would view these types of crimes as much more serious than offering some advice to an employee/friend within a small business workplace.

speech.para: Or listen to columnist Peter Switzer in yesterdayâs Australian, who wrote of the âmadness that super choice has createdâ, describing it as a ânightmare for employersâ. Listen also to John Hanrahan, the specialist commentator at the Small Business Centre on the popular ninemsn web site, who recently commented:

quote.para: It was the major platform of the Howard government when in opposition in 1996âcut red tape by 50 percent. They either lied or have deliberately ignored small business pleas. Today, small businesses estimate red tape has between doubled and tripled.

speech.para: I say this to the government: stop blocking your ears to anyone who disagrees with you. You might only be weeks away from the ability to exercise unchecked power. You might now think you can get away with anything. But you should still listen. If the government were listening, they would never have come up with this ham-fisted scheme, but instead we have this red tape mess. Usually, late-term governments go in one direction or another: they either freeze up altogether with sclerotic bureaucracy or they run away with ideological excess. Only the Howard government could do both, with this indulgent, ideological, bureaucratic bungle. Just two simple amendments today could put away the worst of the super choice scheme and let small business operators sleep a little easier tonight. Labor stands by Australiaâs hardworking small business operators today because they deserve a better deal from this government. We invite all members of the House to join us.

I am very proud of the small business spokesperson that we have in this place. He has one thing in common with a large number of the people newly elected to our Labor Party backbench. Almost all of them at one point in their lives have been engaged in small businessâalmost all of them. All of them have a thoroughgoing understanding of this, including our spokesman, who was himself a small businessman. Unlike those on the Liberal Party front bench opposite, they know exactly what goes on inside a small business and they know exactly what confusion, difficulty and fear this is going to create in the hearts and minds of many small business people. So for just once in your lives listenâlisten to somebody who knows something about what goes on in small business and respond decently and amend the proposed legislation in the way in which we have suggested to you.

talker.name: Brough, Mal, MP
talker.role: Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer
talker.name: Mr BROUGH

talk.start.para: âin replyâThe Superannuation Legislation Amendment (Choice of Superannuation Funds) Bill 2005 has its origins in 1995. This is not new policy from the coalition; this is something that we took to the people in the election of March 1996 and that we were elected on. This is the end of a process that the Labor Party has stymied for nine long years. Today the very last speaker in the second reading debate on this bill, the Leader of the Opposition, made a last-ditch attempt to fight a rearguard action to prevent many Australians from having the opportunity to decide where their second largest investment is going to be placed. Why? Because Labor are ideologically opposed to giving Australians the choice, the capacity and the benefit of being able to decide where their own money is invested. That is the basic principle and you have to ask yourself why that is.

speech.para: The reason for that is that the Labor Party do not think the workers in the small business community, who they are aligning themselves with today, have the capacity to decide where this money should be invested. The Labor Party know who is best placed to make that investment for them! They do not believe it is financial advisers, small business people or individuals; they think it is the unions. The bottom line is that the Labor Party are all about carving out nearly 50 per cent of the private sector employees in this country from deciding who invests their retirement incomes, what fees they pay and what returns they get, and from having the security that is gained by being involved.

If you take away all of the trappings, the rhetoric and the longwinded explanations of the Labor Party for their somehow newfound love of small business, it comes down to one thingâthat is, preventing 50 per cent of private sector employees from having this opportunity so that the unions can decide where their money goes. That is purely and simply what this is all about. The Labor Party have denied Australian workers this opportunity. We heard them last night and again today in this place saying how this is going to be too confusing. How belittling they are of Australian workers. I am not going to belittle Australian workers. The government have faith in their capacity to make these decisions and, in doing so, we will provide the information that they need. When you take away the rights of people and you say, âYou are not capable but weâbig brotherâare,â you alienate them from one of the most important decisions they make in their lives: the sort of retirement they wish to have.

Before going on to some of the amendments I would like to deal with a couple of the issues that were raised, particularly by the honourable member for New England, who has expressed a genuine concern about the penalties that apply should business people provide advice to an employee who is seeking to make a choice. As has finally been recognised by the Leader of the Oppositionâwhen he stood up in this place to give his budget reply speech he clearly did not understand itâthe laws that apply to penalties are not part of this legislation. They are a separate issue. They were strongly supported by the Labor PartyâI think it was in 2000-01. The point of those laws is to prevent individuals profiting in an unreasonable fashion by giving misleading information or by not declaring that they have a pecuniary interest et cetera.

No small business needs to fear that legislation. Let me put the scenario to you in this way. The employee says to the employer of two or three people in Tamworth, âBoss, this super choice thingâwhat do I need to do about it?â The employer can tell him a number of things quite openly. Firstly, he can say, âThis is a choice that you have. Youâve never had it before.â There is no penalty for that. Secondly, he can say, âThere is a booklet that the government has put out. We have it here for you and you can take it.â This is the book that the opposition have been railing about. It is entitled Super Choice. Think about your future. This is the book about which the opposition has said, âThey have to go through 54 pages.â

Let me walk you briefly through some of the things the booklet talks about. It talks about getting super before your preservation age. That is stuff that we, as local members, hear about quite regularly. This book explains how you can get it and what you need to do. The booklet covers how to complain about your fund should you need to do so. It covers what to do if you want to recover lost superannuationâanother issue that is important to a lot of small businesses.Â The booklet covers keeping track of your own superannuation and what you can do when you make job changes. It also goes into how to make a worthwhile investment. It explains to employees things such as pre-tax contributions and salary sacrificing. These are not things that we expect small business people to be giving lengthy advice about. These people want to get on and do their business. So the best advice a small business person can give an employee is to provide them with this booklet and say to them, âThe ASIC web site shows every fee of every super fund. Have a look at that and compare the one we have as our default fund with one that perhaps someone else is touting to you.â

There is nothing wrong with any of that sort of advice. What is wrong and what this government stands ready to ensure that people are penalised for is when the small business person says, âListen, mate, what you should be doing is going into this fund because it does this, this and this,â when it turns out that that person is receiving kickbacks or has some other association, maybe a loan, through an associated business. That is improper behaviour and we do not believe that that should be carved out in any way, shape nor form. So the bottom line is that the employer has nothing to fear other than the fear that has been placed on the small business community by the press releases of those opposite. I will read the words, for the member for New England, of ATO and ASIC, who will be in charge of this particular regime.

quote.para: Although there are penalties for breaching the legislation, both the ATO and the ASIC have made it clear that during the bedding down period they will exercise a sense of balance where employers are making a genuine attempt to comply.

speech.para: They are referring to two things there. Firstly, they are referring to the fine of up to $500 for not providing choice. If someone has inadvertently done the wrong thing, just like when the GST came in, we will make people aware that there are periods of time during which people can become used to the new process. This is a substantial change and the ATO and ASIC have made it abundantly clear that they are not out to punish employers who are genuinely attempting to do the right thing. Secondly, they are saying that no-one in this place should, for one moment, run away from the proposition that we should somehow give comfort to an individual, whether they be an employer or some other body, if they try to pull the wool over the eyes of en employee or if they try to benefit from it. The legislation that is before us today reinforces that by stating that an employer cannot charge an employee for any of the services that they provide in providing choice to them.

Let us go to a couple of the other charges made by Labor Party here today. The Leader of the Opposition was fundamentally wrong in so many things that he said. Firstly, you are not required to print off the five million forms he spoke of. The ATO will send them out. They continue to send out the forms. Secondly, overwhelmingly the superannuation companies are filling out this two-page form with their own information on it, giving it to the employers and the employers are passing that on to the staff so that it is there. That is all they have to do. Then they say, âWhat happens when the 20 employees I have all want to make a separate contribution to 20 different funds?â I grant you that that would be an onerous thing to do, if that were the caseâexcept for one thing. Under swimEC, and many other software operations, they will be required to write out one cheque for 20 employees to 20 different funds and deliver it to one fund which will distribute it for them.

talk.start.para: âWho pays for the clearing house?

âI welcome the interjection from the shadow minister. If he had read the legislation he would know they are not one of the things included in the kickbacks. They are provided free of charge by the super funds. swimEC is a protocol that has been developed by the ATO and the industry over many years, and that is free as well. So there is no charge for that. There is no requirement to send cheques to everyone, as has been made out. The legislation is quite clear about penalties. They are for misleading behaviour which tries to defraud your employee. Quite frankly, if your employer is that way inclined that they want to defraud you, God help you with everything else you are doing with that particular person. Your superannuation is probably not even being paid, let alone anything else, and that is the sort of issue you need to take up.

speech.para: The indignation and railing of the shadow, the deputyâ

talk.start.para: âThe leader.

âThe Leader of the OppositionâI always get confused when I refer to him, because I never know whether he is Leader of the Opposition, sitting on the back bench, here today or gone tomorrow. We have had Simon Crean, Mark Lathamâand Kim Beazley again. Who is it going to be next week? I am sorry I get confused on that issue. The Leader of the Opposition talks about the confusion for small business. He rightly pointed out that, some time ago, I highlighted and made sure the industry was aware of the amendments that are before the House today. What the small business community does not know today, 29 days before the end of the month, is whether or not they will have to deduct withholding tax, and at what rates, after 1 Julyâbecause the Labor Party cannot make a decision. If the shadow minister for revenue, the shadow minister for small business and the Leader of the Opposition were genuinely concerned about small business they would get out of the way and make a decision on that issue today. But they simply cannot.

speech.para: I come back to where we are at. The Labor Party is fighting a rearguard action on this issue not because of a newfound fundamental respect for small business but because they are trying to protect the unionsâ right to choose. Because they lost the main battle, they are now trying to regain a little of the ground that was given up earlier on. I have faith in the capacity of the Australian worker. I have pointed out and made very clear that this is not an onerous process for small business, and if the shadow ministers wish to ask the superannuation funds who have been going around the countryâI am talking about ASFA, the industry funds and the retail fundsâthey will tell them their experience with small business was not shock horror at all. It was quite the contrary. The only concerns raised have been the press releases put out by the Labor Party with their typical scaremongering tactics of threatening people that they will end up in jail.

The bill before us today takes into account many of the concerns that small business raised with us. This government does listen to small business, and as a result has made amendments to the legislation to make sure it is not onerous on them at all. Once again the Leader of the Opposition got it wrong in his final address. He said that every 12 months they are going to provide a form to employers. That is not correct. If he is going to come in here and give a speech on such a fundamental issue, which we have been fighting on as a matter of principle on behalf of workers for nine years, he could at least get the facts right. The facts are that you are required to give eligible employees a form within 28 days of 1 July and within 28 days of them joining your firm, not annually. The employee has a right to change funds should they wish to. Labor says they can change only once a year. The facts are considerably different.

This brings us to a confusion within the Labor Party that still has not been cleared up. Every time we have a debate on super choice I ask them if they can please clarify what they mean when they rail day in and day out about superannuation choice being too confusing for employeesâthat they should not have the right and that we should carve these people out. How can they reconcile that with their position prior to the last election, when the shadow spokesman stood up on the Gold Coast in front of the ISFA conference and stated unambiguously that it is Labor Party policy to require the states to fall in line with the federal jurisdiction and offer choice to their employees. If you have not run away from that you should embrace it, and if you are going to embrace it then embrace it for what it is.

The Queensland Labor government have not only maintained the status quo on super choice but have also reduced the rights of employees. Laborâs fundamental opposition to this is that the unions know better than employees. No wonder they languish in the polls and no wonder the public has rejected them at the last four elections. Not only are more Australians workingâwhich means more Australians are having super guarantee paid into their accountsâbut more Australians are earning more because they are paying lower rates of tax. They will pay even lower rates of tax from 1 July, and therefore will have more take-home pay and will be making more contributions to superannuation. We say to the Australian work force: âIt it is your right. If you are engaged in this process then more Australians will take up the very generous offer under the superannuation co-contribution of $1.50 for every one dollar they contribute to their super. You will be taking up the most tax-effective investment you can make. You can make provisions for your own retirement, and you can do it with security.â

The small business community has absolutely nothing to fear. The shadow ministers and those opposite rail against a booklet which asks you to think about your super choice and gives you clear and concise information about choosing investment strategies. This is a booklet you can look at in your own time. It tells you how to look at growth options, what the risks are and whether you should be looking at insurance. It is all there.

talk.start.para: Mr Fitzgibbon interjectingâ
âYou want to walk two sides of the street and have an argument both ways. The Labor Party says: âGet off the backs of small business. Donât have this impost on them.â

speech.para: Let the employee sit down and go through what is very detailed information. We do not want one Australian to take this decision lightly. We do not expect every Australian to take super choice on 1 July. It is not only for one moment in time that people will have this option. This option will remain open for as long as this policy remains in place and the coalition remains in government. Therefore, the Australian public can take their time. They can read these booklets and decide at any time that they want to make a change.

Let us not forget some of the positives that have already flowed from this policy: fees are coming down and funds are now engaging with the people who invest their money with them. Funds are keeping phone lines open and giving people advice. Glory be, they get nine per cent of their payâday in day out, week in week out, year in year outâand in the past the poor old employee hardly had any connection with them. As a result of this positive initiative those super funds are engaging with them and getting them involved, and as such we have a sounder financial basis going into the future.

Let us not forget that we have an ageing population. The Australian population is growing older and living longer. It is incumbent upon all of us as policymakers to ensure that we engaged with the public to ensure that they are making provisions to have the lifestyle they want with security into their future. All the measures in this bill are appropriateâthey respond to the needs of small business but most importantly they empower the Australian worker. That is what the coalition stands forâproviding workers with incentives and empowerment to make decisions for themselves.

The Labor Party says that employees get their advice from small business people. I wonder how many employers sitting out there provide detailed advice to employees when someone is about to take out a mortgage. Do they go along and ask them which is the best? I do not think so, and we would not expect them to and we do not expect them to do this. That is why the government has provided such comprehensive information to the business community, to the employees and to the super funds. I commend the bill to the House.

talk.start.para: âI invite the minister to table the glossy but complex booklet from which he was reading.

âI am only too delighted to. It is available on the web site and, as the Leader of the Opposition said, on the 13 phone number, so you can ring and get it. It is called Super Choice. Think about your future and is provided by the Australian government.

(Mr Jenkins)âThe original question was that this bill be now read a second time. To this the honourable member for Hunter has moved as an amendment that all words after âThatâ be omitted with a view to substituting other words. The question now is that the words proposed to be omitted stand part of the question.

Original question agreed to.
Bill read a second time.
