speech.para: What an interesting summation from the Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer, Mr Brough. I invited him last night to give the opposition and the more than one million small firms in Australia an ironclad guarantee that they would not face jail terms and penalties for inadvertently giving advice under the FSR Act as it relates to the Superannuation Legislation Amendment (Choice of Superannuation Funds) Bill 2005. I invited him to do so and he did no such thing. Instead we got the sleight of hand once againâthe trick we get from this government all the time, the doublespeakâwhich gave us no assurance at all. It certainly did not give any assurances to the small business community in this country.

I move this amendment to protect small business employers. This is the point the minister missed; he obviously did not take the time to read the amendment, which I generously circulated earlier than was planned for his benefit. The amendment makes it quite clear that the small business employer is only exempt from the FSR rules, that is, from the heavy fines and jail penalties, if he or she has no pecuniary interest and only if he or she was asked for the advice by the employee. We make that quite clear. Let us not have the government say that we are opening up some opportunity for an employer to abuse the laws and receive kickbacks. Nothing could be further from the truth. We are saying that if an employer, when asked and without a pecuniary interest, inadvertently gives advice about which super fund might be best for an employee he will be protected. That is eminently reasonable.

The minister kept avoiding the question. The obvious simple situation is when the employee has been given the glossy bookletâalthough probably not; he has probably had to download it if he has access to the internet because no doubt, like the forms, not many glossy booklets will be printedâand typically says, âThatâs all great, boss, but just between you and me, really, which fund should I sign up to? I donât understand all this stuff? This is all new to me.â It is probably just as new to the employer. âItâs all new to me, boss. Which fund should I sign up to? You know more about this than I do.â Of course, under the ministerâs proposed law, if the employer gives that advice he is in breach ofÂ the FSR Act.

Let us be clear: the bill we are seeking to amend today has been brought in to amend an act which is not even law yetâit does not come into effect until 1 July this year. This is the complexity that is involved in this super choice area. The government brings in a bill and, before it even becomes law, here we are with government amendments to make that bill more efficient and, I assume they would argue, to ease the red tape burden.

They are not doing a very good job of it. I am disappointed that the member for Greenway has now left the chamber. When she wandered in here I thought that just maybe, for the first time, she was going to stand in this place and defend the small businesses in her electorate. She has already, since coming into this place, given them interest rate rises. She has already given them rises in their private health insurance premiums and she has already presided over record high petrol prices. I thought she might have come in here just once and given them something elseâjust simply have given them a break. That is what we were hoping for from the member for Greenway. I am not sure whether the minister just bored her to tears and she could not sit there any longer, but unfortunately she chose to leave the chamber before she was given the opportunity to participate in debate over these important amendments.

This government went into the 1996 election promising to cut red tape for small business. Indeed, it promised to cut red tape by 50 per cent. What a laugh that now is. As the Leader of the Opposition says, maybe we could simply ask it to stop adding to the burden. If you are not capable of reducing it, Minister, how about considering just stopping adding to the burden? That is all the opposition is asking of you today. (Extension of time granted) By supporting the amendments I have just moved and by supporting the amendment that will be moved by the member for Watson in a little while, the government could take the opportunity to do so.

The Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer stood here and made a very weak attempt to assure small business owners they would not be in breach of the FSR laws. He made a very ordinary job of it indeed. The Leader of the Opposition referred to the âEmployees and super choice: time is running outâ advertisement in todayâs newspaper. Why else would they be making it so clear in this advertisement if they were not prepared to now concede the risk there is for the small business owner in giving advice? The FSR makes it quite clear that, if the small business owner is not a registered, licensed financial adviser, he cannot give that advice. If he does so, he could be subject to heavy penalties up to $22,000 and two years in jail.

I ask the Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer: why would you not support Laborâs amendment, which is quite clear, obviously free of any technical difficulties and could not be any plainer? Why would you not send an assurance to small business owners in the Australian community that you will protect them? Is it because it is a Labor amendment? If that is the case, we are happy to withdraw it on the ground that you give a written guaranteeâand you can do that now; your handwriting will be fine, although I would of course expect it to be signedâthat you are prepared to move a government amendment to this effect. We do not mind giving it over to you. We are not precious about these things at all. We will withdraw this amendment if you are prepared to give that written guarantee, and at some time in the very near future you can stand up in this place and move the amendment. You do not have to draft it. I can just hand it over to you. It is all correctly and perfectly done. We will be happy to support it. We do not care, Minister, who moves the amendment. We do not care who corrects the law. At the end of the day, we do not care who it is that gives the assurances and protection to small businesses that they require. If you want to do it, we will be more than happy for you to do it, Minister.

You talked about rogue employers. Gee, that is the first time I have heard a government minister admit that such a thing as a rogue employer exists. I seem to recall those on this side talking about rogue employers for a whileâand they do exist out there. The overwhelming majority of small business employers and employers generally are good employers who invest in their employees and like to take care of them because, financially and economically, it is good for them to do so, but there are rogue employers out there. That is why we have opposed the exemption for small business for the unfair dismissals law. It is pure and simple. We know the overwhelming majority of small business employers do the right thing. But there are some rogue employers out there who, given the opportunity, will do the wrong thing.

I will not speak on the amendments at length now. I will wait until the member for Watson goes to them in detail. But this brings us to the inconsistency. The government will not support a carve-out from FSR under this Superannuation Legislation Amendment (Choice of Superannuation Funds) Bill for businesses with 20 or fewer employees but will support an exemption for small businesses with 20 or fewer employees. We did not take this arbitrary figure of 20. It is not an arbitrary figure. We copied itâ

talk.start.para: Mr Farmer interjectingâ

âOh, it is 100 now. I am a bit a behind the times. I forgot for a moment the Prime Ministerâs statement of last Thursday. It is about to get a whole lot worse, so I appreciate the intervention of the parliamentary secretary. We did not take 20 as an arbitrary figure just plucked out of the sky. We took the governmentâs original figure of 20 employees, acknowledging that they do not have a human resources department and those other resources to handle these matters. We say that under super choice those with 20 or fewer employees should be carved out, consistent with what the minister has been saying for almost the last 10 years. So here is your opportunity, Minister, to get up in this House. I will withdraw the amendment; I am happy to do that. You can take ownership of it. You can do a media release claiming all the credit. Just do it, Minister. We are giving you the opportunity to just do it.

âI had been listed at one stage to speak in this debate and, having already spoken in the public servant debate, I thought it was appropriate to let the House get on with its business. Having discovered that that is not going to be the caseâand even the Leader of the Opposition has entered the debateâI return to look at these amendments which are being dealt with at the consideration in detail stage. I was interested to hear the member for Hunter make the point in his speech that there are many good employers in small business. I have repeatedly said in this place and at doorstops over the years that most, if not nearly all, small business people do not wake up in the morning thinking, âI wonder who I can sack this morning.â They see their staff as a very valuable asset in their business operations. For example, I had in my electorate a machinery dealer with tears in his eyes explaining how he and his wife would carry on their business in the drought but not knowing where he would get his staff from when things turned up again because they would all have to leave.

speech.para: I am astounded at the debate on issues such as unfair dismissal. Let me overcome a myth: an employer of 100 people in this day and age of casual employment is not a big employer. The average farmer in my electorate would not have one full-time employee but in a year would have 20, 30 or 40 casual employeesâshearers and others who come in at different times of the yearâand they would be subject to this superannuation requirement. If a shearing team comes onto a farmerâs property and it is not run by a contractor who is a full-time employer and who sends your money into a single account, the farmer is obliged to, amongst other things, pay superannuation to each and every one of the workers involvedâbe they shed hands, shearers or whatever.

I have taken a great interest in this aspect of the responsibility of an employer to provide choice. As I said the other day when I spoke about the first union super, the issue of portability was not considered. Shearers wrote to me, saying: âI shear this time of the year; I am a truck driver that time of the year. I have now got three or four super funds and I have no control to insist that it be aggregated to one fund.â

There is no need for these amendments. As the Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer pointed out, having heard the rhetoric of unfair dismissal when every employer was a crook, we suddenly heard the Leader of the Opposition come in here and say words to the effect, âEmployers and employees get along so well in small business.â Of course they do, but the opposition better make up its mind. Either they are a mob of crooks or they are very decent people, and I am of the second position.

My wife is a small business person. Having sighted the documents she has received and havingâas I am sure the minister is prepared to admitâquestioned the minister in the party room on some of the administrative details, the minister satisfied me that, for instance, you do not have to send a cheque to five, 10 or 50 different superannuation funds when the shearing team comes on your property. You can send one cheque to a nominated insurer, who will have the responsibility, on receipt of a list, to distribute the funds.

The opposition has not been standing up in here saying, âLook, there might be other minor administrative arrangements you should consider under regulation, such as the issuance of a plastic card.â I think the super funds might find it good idea in due course to send their contributors a card. But we cannot look past the simple fact that union super is a huge area; it originated in award super. The 50 per cent of preselection voters have sent a message to these people, âFor a short period, we would like you to like small business,â and use that as the excuse to protect our big business operation. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer referred during this debate on the Superannuation Legislation Amendment (Choice of Superannuation Funds) Bill 2005 to the situation where he thought prison terms were a fair go and ought to apply. If these amendments are carried, the exact scenario referred to by the Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer would still apply. The employer who acts to its pecuniary interest is not carved out of jail terms by our amendments. The employer who is pushing a super fund onto employees is not carved out by our amendments. These amendments before the House are simply so that a request for advice can come from the employee and the employer can give advice with no pecuniary interest. In that scenario it is outrageous to say a possible prison sentence and a maximum $22,000 fine should be on the table at all. That is the precise wording of the amendment. All that is carved out from this is the question that we know will be asked.

speech.para: The minister used the line âOh, look, do people go to their boss? Do they ask the butcher about their mortgage?â Yes, they do. Employees regularly ask their employer for financial advice. Interestingly, on the precise example given by the Minister for Revenue, if the advice they asked for was about a purchase of property and the employer had a financial interest in itâa pecuniary interest that they did not discloseâand they gave advice, it would be completely legal. Jail terms do not apply to that. But, if the employer says, âI reckon this is the best fund of the ones that you are looking at there,â the Corporations Act is activated.

This is the great disappointment. I could only be impressed with the spin but, as a fair dinkum argument, to argue that there is nothing in the super choice legislation that carries jail penalties is about as dodgy as this debate could be. Of course it is not in the super choice legislation; it is in the Corporations Act. When we had the system where the employer simply put forward a default fund and that was the end of the matter, the only time there would be the choice to have a different fund would be at the instigation of the employeeâand some small businesses would do it voluntarilyânot because material had been given to them by the boss or they had been told it was time to make a choice. When there were simply default funds, the employer was not going to be asked the question. In the present situation, we know that the employer will be asked, âWhat do you reckon I ought to do?â If the employer answers that question to their own pecuniary interest, I agree that serious penalties ought to prevail. If the employer pushes an opinion onto employees without them even requesting it, I agree that serious penalties should be there.

But the scenario of this amendment is that the advice is given at the request of the employee and with no pecuniary benefit to the employer. When that is the situation I want to hear from the minister why, in the scenario that the amendment refers to and not in the scenario we agree on, a criminal penalty should be on the table at all. If we all agree that it should not be there, then why do we say that we will just leave it to the courts and let them sort it out? It should not be hanging over the head of the employer at all when it is at the request of the employee and there is no pecuniary interest in the answer given by the employer. I want to hear from the Minister for Revenue, when he pops up a little bit later, why in that scenario those penalties ought to prevail. I am quite happy to lose traction on this issue if the government just fix it. I am surprised this issue has survived as long as it has. When we first put out the media statement I said to Senator Nick Sherry, âI suppose this will have a run for about a week and then it will all be over.â I am amazed that the only issue standing between a very reasonable policy position and a draconian alternative appears to be the pride of the minister opposite. Maybe just swallow that pride, Minister, and decide that it is not too big a call to say that when someone acts fairly on a question that we know they are going to be asked criminal penalties should not prevail. Do not force your backbench to come in and vote otherwise.

talk.start.para: âI am still struggling with the differences here. I would like to ask the minister a fairly simple question, because I think it might get to the nub of the issue and the fine line that exists between the two arguments. Minister, if the employer does not have a pecuniary interest in giving advice to an employee and does give advice, is the employer in breach of the Financial Services Reform Act?

talker.name: Brough, Mal, MP
talker.role: Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer
talker.name: Mr BROUGH

talk.start.para: âI would like to answer that question and I will do it in full. Firstly, the whole principle behind this is that we took the position that employers should not have an imposition placed on them so that they felt they had an obligation to provide advice; hence, the actual law as we have stated it reassures them that they do not. Secondly, the reason we are having this debate today is that, as the shadow minister alluded to, he put out a press release trying to heat the issue up a bit and now he has to try to defend it. So let me put it on the table for the member for New Englandâand I hope you two members across the table listen so that you understand exactly what is required. Firstly, the instance that was given by the member for New England is that a staff member asks for advice and the employer provides that advice.
âGuilty!

âThere you go being judge and jury. That is pretty typical of the shoot-from-the-hip reaction that you get from the shadow minister, who quite clearly does not understand what happens. There would then need to be a complaint to ASIC. I guess it would have to be from the person that actually asked for the advice in the first place. Secondly, with the person having provided that information to ASIC, ASIC then has to actually conduct a criminal investigation and at the end of that investigation, if they find that there has been no criminal intent, they have to decide whether or not to provide that information to and refer the matter to the DPP. So the discretion is with ASIC.

speech.para: Let us go through it again in the absolute terms as provided by the member for New England. A person, as the shadow minister has alluded to, asks for some advice. The person does not realise they are breaching the FSR. The employer provides the advice. In the event that the individual complainsâI imagine that is the only person that is going to be involved here; I do not know who else is going to complain but let us say someone complainsâASIC then has to go and investigate the matter and deal with a criminal investigation and deem whether or not there has been a fundamental breach. It then has the discretion to determine whether or not that has to be referred to the DPP, and then the DPP decides whether any further action is to be taken.

So, from all of the examples that have been provided by the shadow minister and through the information that has been sought by the member for New England, it is quite clear that this law (1) protects the business person in general, (2) does not water things down or carve out people who may find themselves using those loopholes for their own interests, and (3) also takes away from the employer the obligation, whether it be stated or presumed, that they somehow have a duty and obligation to provide advice. That is one of the things that comes back to me from time to time. If I am asked to provide advice to my employees I will have to say, âNo; in fact, I am not allowed to.â It will give them great comfort to know that they do not have to and that they can point to it. That is why it is on the two-page form and in the adsâso everybody is clear that the person you do not go troubling about these issues is your employer and that there is advice available via ASIC, advice available on the 013 number and advice available on a web site. You can also go out and get financial advice as well. I hope that answers the question of the member for New England.

talk.start.para: âI thank the minister for his answer. So I understand what he said, in that situation where an employer who does not have a pecuniary interest gives advice to an employee, the employer is in technical breach of the Financial Services Reform Act. I think the minister is saying that it is an extremely unlikely event that, when that inadvertent advice is given, because of the processes that the minister talks about, the small business owner would be pursued. But it is an event that could occur. My question now to the minister is: if that event could occur why can the government not accept the amendment of the opposition and remove that possibility and all of the red tape and time that would be consumed if in fact it was pursued through ASIC and the various channels and then, on the advice of the DPP, dropped? If the parliament seems to be that close to agreement on this issue, why not remove that aspect of the red tape from the legislation of choice and there would be no argument?

talker.name: Brough, Mal, MP
talker.role: Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer
talker.name: Mr BROUGH

talk.start.para: âIt is probably my fault that I have not made it clear enough. The fact is that the advice has to be on a specific financial product. I put the scenario to you that, if the person who has sought that information feels so dudded by that advice, because the advice provided is on a specific financial product and not in general terms such as, âYes, that looks like a pretty good company,â then there is technically a breach and the processes come into play. Let us be realistic about this: a person seeking advice would only go to the trouble of contacting ASIC and the appropriate authorities if they felt absolutely aggrieved, in which case there is potentially an issue.

speech.para: I come back to the point about putting holes and carve-outs in the legislation. I will take you in good faith, against my better judgment. You talk about direct pecuniary interests. What about financial products they may have elsewhere, through third entities that are unrelated? There are so many ways in which people can influence it. They do not have to have a direct interest in it to make it worth their while. Why create that when we have absolute certainty? A uniform code was agreed to by everyone in 2000 or 2001. This means that small business is protected from having to provide advice. The advice small business gives to me constantly is this: âPlease, I am not in a position to do that.â

The member for Werriwa is a small business man and I listened to him carefully. The last thing an employer would want to do is to try to provide advice to their staff that they are not qualified to give. You used an example of a butcher. Employers do not want their staff to think that the boss does not want to help them. They can say: âHey, listen. I am not allowed to help you; it is clear-cut. Besides, I really donât have the capability. The best advice I can give you is to read this booklet. There is a 13 number, which you can call and talk to someone who understands. If you have access to the web, here it is.â Employers can say: âGo and talk to a financial adviser. Talk to your superannuation fund.â That is not a breach of the law. It would only be a breach of the law technicallyâand then those other processes come into playâif an employer provided advice about a specific financial product. You would have to be awfully aggrieved to go through those processes.

talk.start.para: âWhat an extraordinary contribution from the minister at the table. I would like to thank the member for New England for his sensible and reasoned approach to this matter. The minister at the table said, in effect, that the law does not matter: âYes, we are making it illegal but nobodyâs ever going to enforce it, so donât worry about it. Itâs okay.â I am sure the honourable minister will be happy to give evidence on behalf of anybody who is charged in coming years. He will be subpoenaed regularly to give evidence: âI was the minister when we passed this, but we didnât actually mean to catch people. Itâs all very technical. I would have accepted the Labor Partyâs amendment but for their thinking of it first. Then I was painted into a corner. Iâm sorry, Your Honour, itâs all a big mistake.â If the minister really believes that, why is the government advertising in todayâs newspaper that you must not give financial advice unless you are licensed to do so? That is what the governmentâs advertisement says. Now the minister is saying that if somebody asks for the advice and nobody gets upset about it that it is all okay: âASIC wonât prosecute and the DPP wonât prosecute. Donât worry about it.â That is a fine approach. It is most extraordinary for the government of the Commonwealth of Australia to say, âItâs the law; donât worry about it.â

speech.para: If this bill is passed unamendedâwhich I suspect it will beâwe will have an extraordinary situation. Somebody who gives dodgy property investment advice will not be covered by the Financial Services Reform Act or the Corporations Act, but that is okayâyou can give dodgy property investment advice but you cannot help out your employee, in good faith, by giving them advice when asked. The minister at the table said that people would only make a complaint if they were upset. Advice can be given in good faith but still be bad advice. An employee can go to their employer and ask which fund they should join. An employer may say: âIâve been a member of this fund for a long time. I have had very good returns and I would recommend it,â but something could go wrong, such as the fund giving very bad returns. If the employee gets very upset and someone says to him, âYour boss shouldnât have given you that adviceâthatâs wrong,â he may then lodge a complaint with ASIC. But it is okay. The Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer said: âDonât worry. Nobody is ever going to prosecute you. Nobody is ever going to chase up the law.â That is an extraordinary situation. As I have said, there is a massive inconsistency. Property investment advice can be shonky but that is not a problemâno penalties, no prosecutions.

talk.start.para: Mr Brough interjectingâ

âI am not sure whether the Assistant Treasurer is denying that property investment advice is not covered by the FSR. If he is, that is a very interesting development in public policy. This is an extraordinary situation. I commend the member for Hunter and the member for Watson for their amendments. I genuinely thank the member for New England for his interest in this matter and the very sensible approach that he has taken.

âFollowing on from the member for Prospect, I think it is important for us to ask the minister specifically the circumstances in which employers may well be liable for jail or a fine in the event that they provide advice, wittingly or otherwise, to their employees. When the minister gets an opportunity to respond, I would like an answer to my question, which follows on from the questions that were asked by the member for New England. I am trying to get to the nub of the concern that the amendments seek to fix. If an employer provides advice to his or her employees on a particular fund they may ultimately choose to place their superannuation contributions and if that employee subsequently complainsâthat is, the employee is not happy with the choice that he has made on the advice of his employerâwill that complaint attract the provisions of the FSR Act and then set in motion the capacity for that employer to be fined or jailed? That is the central point, and that is why the member for Hunter has moved the amendments.

speech.para: If the minister can give an unqualified answer in this place that there would be no possibility that, upon providing advice to an employee and upon that employee subsequently complaining about that advice, an employer could be imprisoned or fined then we would be satisfied. If that is the ministerâs answer we would be satisfied. But I really need to know specificallyâand I am sure that all members and, more importantly, all small businesses wish to knowâexactly what the situation is. If this bill is enacted without the amendments being proposed, is there a possibility in those circumstances that I outlined that an employer could go to jail or be fined?

talk.start.para: âI welcome the amendments to the Superannuation Legislation Amendment (Choice of Superannuation Funds) Bill 2005 proposed by the member for Watson and the member for Hunter. This is the opposition attempting to do our job and improve as best we can from this side of the House a very bad piece of legislation. Welcome to another small business red tape nightmare courtesy of the Howard government! On behalf of the many thousands of small businesses in Geelong let me register my strong opposition to this super choice legislation which is going to swamp them in red tape.

speech.para: This red tape burden is being imposed for one simple reason: the governmentâs ideological obsession with the issue of super choice. It is now a matter for the public record that the Howard government has turned Geelong small businesses into unpaid tax collectors for the government. Under the Howard government the tax act has doubled to over 9,000 pages. Now we have an extra burden being placed on businesses that are struggling to remain competitive in a very highly competitive environment. This particular bill will impose extraordinary burdens. It is costly and complex, and it is unsafe. For 400,000 employers it represents a massive new compliance burden, with some 34 steps needed to comply, including five million forms to be handed out to existing employees and over one million each year thereafter. It requires ongoing record keeping for five years to be made available for tax office inspection and enforcement; payments to multiple super funds, with thousands of them in existence and funds nominated able to be changed every 12 months; and fines of up to $500 per employee for employers if they get it wrong. And, of course, there is the subject of this particular amendment we are discussing: employers will face significant legal liability if they give advice to employees even if they are asked. Small business forms the backbone of the Geelong economy. It is a major employer. It does not need this burden at this time. I commend the amendments that have been moved. They have been moved in good spirit to advantage small business in the light of the very bad piece of legislation now before the House.

talker.name: Brough, Mal, MP
talker.role: Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer
talker.name: Mr BROUGH

speech.para: Members of the government have just come into this chamber to vote specifically on the issue of jail terms for employers who try to be helpful in giving advice. We have had extraordinary arguments run previously as to why you could not have a carve-out of small business. A spokesperson for the minister at the table, the Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer, said previouslyâand I have quoted it beforeâthat the problem with carving out small business from the super choice legislation would be that you would âcreate a competitive disadvantageâ for small business in taking on extra employees. A competitive disadvantage! As though exempting them all from unfair dismissal and allowing employees to be hired and fired at will did not in some way create a much greater competitive disadvantage for small business in employing people. The real issue here is one of paperwork. The issue is not about a competitive advantage or disadvantage in getting staff on.

The minister has acknowledged that, at first, most employees will not be exercising choice. Most employees will not choose to. They have already introduced a scheme starting on 1 July.
