debateinfo.title: ASBESTOS-RELATED CLAIMS (MANAGEMENT OF COMMONWEALTH LIABILITIES) BILL 2005

cognateinfo.title: ASBESTOS-RELATED CLAIMS (MANAGEMENT OF COMMONWEALTH LIABILITIES) (CONSEQUENTIAL AND TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS) BILL 2005

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 25 May, on motion by Mr Dutton:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: âThe Asbestos-related Claims (Management of Commonwealth Liabilities) Bill 2005 and the Asbestos-related Claims (Management of Commonwealth Liabilities) (Consequential and Transitional Provisions) Bill 2005 deal with asbestos, which is a tragic and emotional subject. I start by indicating that Labor supports these measures with one very serious reservation, which I have raised directly with the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, Mr Andrews. I will come to that in due course. I will start with a neutral explanation of the bills to the House and an examination of their content.

speech.para: The purpose of these bills is to ensure a more efficient handling of asbestos related condition common law claims against the Commonwealth. These bills centralise the management of asbestos related condition common law claims against the Commonwealth within Comcare. To achieve this, the legislation would make Comcare rather than the Commonwealth, Commonwealth authorities or government business enterprises liable for all asbestos related condition common law claims, provide Comcare with the additional function of assuming and managing all Commonwealth asbestos related condition liabilities and provide financial arrangements for Comcare to meet all its assumed liabilities.

The Asbestos-related Claims (Management of Commonwealth Liabilities) Bill 2005 will allow Comcare to manage all asbestos related claims brought at common law against the Commonwealth. It will achieve this by transferring the liability for such claims from the Commonwealth and Commonwealth authorities to Comcare. This bill will give Comcare the legislative authority to manage common law claims against the Commonwealth. Comcare will also have the authority to manage claims from former waterside workers whose asbestos claims are currently managed by the Stevedoring Industry Finance Committee, which is the subject of the serious issue raised by these pieces of legislation.

The majority of common law asbestos claims against the Commonwealth are currently managed by the particular agencies against which the claims are made. Inefficiencies and inconsistencies in case management across portfolios have arisen as a result. Comcareâs current legislative authority allows it to manage asbestos related disease claims only from current and former employees of the government and their dependants.

The Commonwealthâs asbestos liabilities over the next 50 years have been estimated to be nearly $1 billion, the majority of which will be common law claims and Comcare will be fully funded for the cost of managing these claims. The legislation is not expected to have any significant effect on the level of asbestos liabilities.

Integrating the management of asbestos claims against the Commonwealth will lead to more consistent decision making and more equitable and efficient outcomes. It will result in a standardised approach to management of asbestos claims. Transferring the liability for such claims from the Commonwealth and Commonwealth authorities to a single body, Comcare, will facilitate a better understanding of the nature of asbestos claims through improved knowledge and experience.

It should be noted, however, that the government has proposed that defence related common law asbestos claims continue to be managed by the Department of Defence as delegated to by Comcare. These arrangements will be reviewed by July 2006. It is this aspect which is of particular relevance to the issue I have raised with the minister and will raise with the House.

Statutory claims made under the Safety, Compensation and Rehabilitation Act 1988, the Veteransâ Entitlements Act 1986 and the Military Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 2004 are not included in the application of these bills, and claims made under these acts will continue to be managed by Comcare and the Department of Veteransâ Affairs.

From that neutral analysis members of the House can see that, so far as claims are concerned, there are three specific or specialised areas which the Commonwealth and the parliament have previously drawn attention to. One is in respect of asbestos claims in the stevedoring industry, another is asbestos claims in respect of the defence department and the third is asbestos claims in respect of veterans. For good reasons in the past the Commonwealth has treated these areas as specialised and separate areas and it is proposed that two of them continue.

The bills were presented to the House a week ago todayâon 25 Mayâby the Minister for Workforce Participation, Mr Dutton, representing the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations. As I indicated at the outset, the substance of these bills is positive and is welcomed by Labor. As I have indicated, I will raise a serious reservation concerning asbestos related claims in the Stevedoring Industry Finance Committee.
The stated aim of the Asbestos-related Claims (Management of Commonwealth Liabilities) Bill 2005 is to:

quote.para: ... allow Comcare to manage all asbestos related claims brought at common law against the government. It will achieve this by transferring the liability for such claims from the Commonwealth and Commonwealth authorities to Comcare.

speech.para: This is in effect a simple implementation of a recommendation made by the Asbestos Related Diseases Interdepartmental Committee that was established in 2002 to review the management of asbestos related compensation claims against the Commonwealth. The explanatory memorandum for the management of the Commonwealth liabilities bill says:

quote.para: The Inter-Departmental Committee recommended the establishment of a central asbestos claims unit within Comcare to manage all ARC common law claims against the Australian Government. The IDC made this recommendation based on the view that the decentralised approach was resulting in some inefficiencies and inconsistencies in case management across portfolios, including inconsistent admissions of liability.

speech.para: In principle then, there are obviously clear benefits in centralising common law asbestos related disease claims against the Commonwealth. Under the current system common law asbestos claims have been managed by each particular Commonwealth agency against which the claims have been made. As the explanatory memorandum and the second reading speech by the minister indicate, this has often led to extra administrative cost, but perhaps more importantly, has resulted in some inefficiencies and inconsistencies across the range of portfolios.

Centralising the Commonwealth liabilities under Comcare potentially offers an alternative, consistent, equitable and sensible approach to the management of these liabilities. That is the administrative or public policy upside, and there are safeguards against any downside risks for asbestos victims who make a claim in the future. This is why in the explanatory memorandum we see:

quote.para: The Bill would not alter the fundamental ARC liability of the Australian Government. The Bill should have no impact on the ability of a current or prospective claimant to recover damages for an ARC from the Australian Government.

speech.para: On my reading of the legislation, that is certainly its intention. I cannot see anything in the legislation which would have an adverse impact upon that fundamental position. So it is a change which allows greater consistency of settlements and does not alter the rights of asbestos related disease victims, current or future, to pursue their claims.

The area, as I have indicated, where I do have a serious reservation is the proposed repeal of three pieces of legislation which support the Stevedoring Industry Finance Committee and the proposed abolition of the Stevedoring Industry Finance Committee itself. Those three pieces of legislation are the Stevedoring Industry Finance Committee Act 1977, the Stevedoring Industry Levy Act 1977 and the Stevedoring Industry Levy Collection Act 1977. The Stevedoring Industry Finance Committee currently resolves common law claims from waterside workers or their widows which arise from exposure to asbestos related cargoes. It is proposed under the legislation that these claims would become the responsibility of Comcare.

It is here that I think there is a serious issue for the parliament and the Commonwealth to consider. It is whether the stevedoring industry and the Stevedoring Industry Finance Committee are dealing with claims of such a specialised nature that they should continue to be so conducted. As I have indicated, the legislation carves out an ongoing specialised attention for claims in the Department of Defence and an ongoing specialised role for claims in the veterans area. There is a serious issue as to whether good public policy grounds remain for continuing specialised attention in the stevedoring industry.

When one goes to some of the work that was done in the run-up to the preparation of these pieces of legislationâand I refer to the interdepartmental committeeâTrowbridge Deloittes prepared a report on Australian government asbestos liabilities for the Department of Finance and Administration which led to the establishment of the interdepartmental committee. That report made it clear that stevedoring related claims are a very specialised case of asbestos claim. That October 2003 report at page 55, attachment 1, states:

quote.para: ... the vast majority of the Australian Governmentâsâ

speech.para: or the Commonwealthâsâ

quote.para: claims costÂ is managed in ... two places â the Defence Asbestos Litigation Cell (ALC) and the Stevedoring Industry Finance Committee (SIFC).

speech.para: The government has obviously found good reasons to keep the Defence Asbestos Litigation Cell, or the defence area, compartmentalised and specialised. I am not sure that the Commonwealth government has put its mind carefully enough to whether that should also be the case for the Stevedoring Industry Finance Committee. It is estimated in the Trowbridge Deloitte actuarial report that the ongoing potential liability to the Stevedoring Industry Finance Committee is over $230 million. That is out of a total estimated cost of $900 million to $1 billionâeffectively a quarter of the Commonwealthâs liability. As I have indicated, this is an issue which I have raised with the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations for him to give some consideration to. I made the point that these bills were introduced a week ago, and I did so because what has come to attention in the last couple of days is that there has not really been adequate consultation with the stevedoring industry or with the Stevedoring Industry Finance Committee on this point.

It is worth while paying some attention to the history of the Stevedoring Industry Finance Committee to seize in the mind of the House some of the reasons why this may well be an area for ongoing specialised activity. The Stevedoring Industry Finance Committee was established as a statutory committee in 1977 under one of the bills I referred to earlier. That coincided with the winding-up of the Australian Stevedoring Industry Authority, the ASIA. The Stevedoring Industry Finance Committee, under that transfer, also inherited obligations from the Australian Stevedoring Industry Authority. Those obligations included obligations that had been vested in or imposed upon the Australian Stevedoring Industry Authority by the High Court in the Crimmins case and by the courts of appeal in New South Wales and Victoria in the Gibson and Crimmins cases respectively. So this is a specialised area which has been the subject of High Court attention.

As a result of those cases, the Stevedoring Industry Finance Committee inherited the liabilities of the former Australian Stevedoring Industry Authority. The High Court and those courts of appeal cases effectively determined that the Australian Stevedoring Industry Authority had a liability and an obligation as a result of exposure to asbestos related disease by stevedores and former stevedores. The Stevedoring Industry Finance Committee is made up of an independent chairperson, representatives of both stevedoring employers and stevedoring employees, and a representative of the Department of Transport and Regional Services. So, essentially, it is what I would describe as a tripartite committeeâemployer, employee and government. The Department of Transport and Regional Services provides secretariat support on a cost recovery basis.

The predominant function of the committee is set out in sections 6 and 7 of the act, which provide that the committee is responsible for resolving common law claims from waterside workers or their widows on fair, just and responsible terms arising from exposure to asbestos related cargoes. In the course of its activities, the Stevedoring Industry Finance Committee attempts to recover contributions from industry third parties or their insurance companies. The record of the committee is well regarded and it has established a well-earned reputation, amongst both employers and employees in the stevedoring industry, of resolving claims quickly and fairly. This is one of the great strengths of the specialised nature of activity in this area.

In our former lives, some of us in this House had experience with asbestos related diseases and take an ongoing interest in the legislation, public policy and common law which surrounds these issues. I was Principal Private Secretary to the Attorney-General of Western Australia when we had to grapple with the aftermath of the Wittenoom asbestos disaster. I was intricately involved in the drafting of legislation to remove the statute of limitations from asbestos related common law claims in that state. I make that point because one of the great tragedies and traumas of asbestos related diseases is that the incubation period is long but, once the adverse consequences of the disease come to light, it is a terribly debilitating disease and affliction. We have learnt over the years to, firstly, bring to those victims a degree of certainty, and, secondly, do our best to ensure that liability and damages are assessed by negotiation, by agreement or by settlement rather than by having ongoing adversarial claims. In the case of Western Australia and the Wittenoom disaster, it became pretty clear after one or two test cases that liability had been established. Very many of the casesâif not the vast majorityâfrom the Wittenoom disaster are now effectively settled by negotiation and settlement. Liability having been assumed long ago, the matter is simply one of calculation of damages.

The great strength of the activity of the Stevedoring Industry Finance Committee is that it deals with these matters quickly, fairly, equitably and in a way which minimises the ongoing trauma for the victims of these terrible diseases. It has become clear in the last couple of days that, when the legislation was introduced a week ago, there had not been any appropriate consultation with the Stevedoring Industry Finance Committee or its respective constituent bodies. I do not mention that to score any points. The minister, to his credit, when I approached him on this matter, quite happily agreed to put his mind to this issue and consider the fundamental and substantive question as to whether there remained good reasons in public policy and public policy administration why this area should be carved out for special treatment, as Defence is. Whilst I am sure the Stevedoring Industry Finance Committee would want to be carved out ad infinitumâforeverâI am sure that if the government put the Stevedoring Industry Finance Committee on the same basis as the defence department it would be regarded as sensible progress.

The minister and I discussed an approach he had received from the Maritime Union of Australia and which had been copied to me. I think it is worth while to read into the record the substance and the thrust of that approach. This is from a letter from the National Secretary of the Maritime Union of Australia to Kevin Andrews, the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, dated yesterday:

quote.para: The Bills have only been brought to my attention quite recently and I have consequently held discussions with senior executives of the two major national stevedores who presently nominate an employer representative to the Stevedoring Industry Finance Committee (SIFC) in conformity with the legislative requirements pertaining to that Statutory Authority.

The stevedores advise me that they were totally unaware that the Commonwealth were proposing any alteration to SIFC and they are not aware of any discussion or correspondence with or from the Government proposing to repeal legislation (SIFC Act 1977) and abolish the Committee.

speech.para: â¦Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â â¦Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â â¦

quote.para: I am sure you are aware of the work the Committee undertakes in dealing with Asbestos Related Claims. SIFC provides Annual Reports and Audited Accounts to the Minister for Transport and Regional Services.

speech.para: The secretary then makes the point that the work of the committee constitutes a specialised forum:

quote.para: ... it is essential that the accumulated knowledge acquired over many years is retained to continue to assist claimants to achieve prompt, just and reasonable treatment in the processing of claims.
You would appreciate the nature of the illnesses that sustain such claims and the importance of responding in a manner that treats these workers with care, dignity and respect.

speech.para: â¦Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â â¦Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â â¦

quote.para: In the absence of prior consultation with the Stevedoring Industry Participants, we request that you take steps to withdraw the above named Bill currently before the House to enable tripartite consultation ...

speech.para: He calls on âa cooperative and bipartisan approachâ and makes the point that it is understood that âstevedoring employers endorse this approach and support consultation with all relevant stakeholdersâ.

I am sure that neither the minister nor the government would want to withdraw the bill, but I do think it is absolutely essential that the minister, in the cold light of day, puts his mind to that point. It is a serious public policy and there is no attempt here at political point scoring. It is a straightforward question as to whether, given the ongoing specialised nature of the stevedoring industry and the well-regarded success of the Stevedoring Industry Finance Committee in dealing with these claims in a prompt, efficient and just manner, the same arguments for specialised treatment for Defence and veterans claims will apply to this industry. The lack of consultation, the oversight, makes it all the more important for this issue to be considered seriously. Having raised the matter with the minister, I am confident that he will do precisely that.

Given that very serious reservation, the central thrust of the legislation is supported by Labor. We support the central principle that asbestos related common law claims be consolidated, as far as the Commonwealth is concerned, into Comcare so that there is one entry point for those claims and one treatment of those claimsâall of which is expected to bring greater efficiencies and greater consistencies. But I do urge the government to respond to the representations it has received directly and the representations that I have made on behalf of the stevedoring industry. Just as it has carved out Defence, even if only for a subsequent review in 2006, it should do this for the stevedoring industry. I commend the bills to the House.

talk.start.para: âI have read the second reading speech relating to the Asbestos-related Claims (Management of Commonwealth Liabilities) (Consequential and Transitional Provisions) Bill 2005, which the concluding remarks of the member for Perth drew attention to. He highlighted the fact, not putting it in strong terms, that there may have been a discourtesy arising from the ministerâs office not consulting the Stevedoring Industry Finance Committee. But the reality is that the Minister for Workforce Participation made it clear in the second reading speech:

quote.para: As the committeeâ

speech.para: the Stevedoring Industry Finance Committeeâ

quote.para: will no longer perform any other functions after the transferral of liabilities for asbestos related claims to Comcare, it is appropriate to repeal the relevant legislation. The stevedoring industry levy collection actsâ

speech.para: which are also being dealt with under this legislationâ

quote.para: have been redundant for several years.

speech.para: In other words, there seems to be a very good reason to repeal this legislation and dispose of a committee which possibly has costs to the stevedoring industry or the taxpayer that will perform no functions. What is more, the funding processes under the levy acts have not been applicable for years. I note they have $24 million in the bank, which will be recovered to consolidated revenue. That also seems to be a practical and sensible solution.

While I express sorrow that there was not some appropriate consultation as a matter of courtesy, I would not suggest that there needs to be any opposition to repealing the two acts that become redundant simply because of the governmentâs decision, under the principal act, to transfer common law liability to Comcare. If I were somebody who might be making a claim some time in the future, I would like to have the comfort that Comcare, with its virtually bottomless pockets backed by the taxpayer, was an appropriate place to go. The explanatory memorandumâand this is the matter that I really came to this House to raiseâindicates that the taxpayer funded operation, which is quite necessary for workers compensation, anticipates claims in the order of nearly $1 billion over the next 50 years. So it is a very significant cost and it is a very significant issue.

I have spoken in this House before on asbestos and have attracted some criticism as to my views on it. Asbestos remains in my mind as a wonderful product which served the community well but which was eventually proven to be unsafe to people who might be in contact with it in various ways. I am interested to know, as compensation under common law progresses, at what stage the Commonwealth might be held responsible for the regulations it requires on brake parts on imported vehicles, which until quite recently had brake linings containing asbestos. They are wearing parts and quite clearly asbestos fibres must have been found in any busy intersection where vehicles stop for red lights. So one can only worry. But this bill deals typically with workers compensation, although I am not sure that is entirely so. If I remember correctly, there is a list in the explanatory memorandum which is more extensive than just covering the role of a worker. It covers properly spouses and others. I think it also talks of secondary causes that might arise.

I chose to come here to speak briefly on this issue because I think it is a classic example of government accepting responsibility and creating an opportunity for compensation to be paid. I sincerely hope that will be compensation for appropriate losses, although it seems that some of the common law claims will not be for clear lossesâthe loss of a breadwinner and people of that nature, which is frequently not the occurrence with asbestos related diseases. They typically occur in later life at a time when, for instance, oneâs dependants have gone their separate ways. It is one of those things that can be judged on that basis. It is clear from looking at the people on the list that there can be claims other than in relation to employees. The explanatory memorandum for the prime bill, the Asbestos-related Claims (Management of Commonwealth Liabilities) Bill 2005, says:

quote.para: Apart from claims in relation to employees (or former employees) it is predicted Comcare would manage ARC common law claims from:

item.para: former waterside workers;
contractors and sub-contractors;
tenants of Australian Government owned and/or constructed premises;
family members of employees who were themselves exposed through contaminated clothing or other means;
visitors;
bystanders; and
dependants of persons in any of the above categories.

speech.para: I think my example of brake linings is quite significant when one reads that list. It is a hysterical approach to occupational health and safety when state governments, egged on by unions, talk about putting directors in jail. Given the role of this parliament and state parliaments in imposing the regulatory requirementsâfor instance, brake liningsâwould there be a case, if that were taken to the nth degree, for members of this House, as the directors of âAustralia Inc.â, to be called upon to show cause why they should not go to jail because of their negligence? It is a form of negligence that is totally beyond the capacity of the people and/or company directors to know or to understand. Asbestos is a classic example. The debate about James Hardie probably focuses on that intervening period after it became apparent that their product could deliver these outcomes. However, for many years asbestos was considered to be not only benign but very valuable. Even in this town of Canberra, which was technically a remote area, I would imagine that thousands of houses were built out of asbestos and weatherboard.

I think we have allowed this issue to go a little too far. I have said publicly many times that, if somebody with young children loses a supporting spouse as a result of an asbestos related disease, clearly there is a role for compensation. I am not sure that I agree with compensation being awarded after a person is deceased which then passes to quite healthy relatives. That is my criticism.

In closing, the Commonwealth has admitted that it has a liability under various acts associated with its employmentâfor example, the construction of buildings and the operation of ports. It is expected to cost nearly $1 billion, which the taxpayer must provide. The legislation quite sensibly transfers future liabilities for common law claims to Comcare. It makes separate arrangements for Defence, which is quite a significant area. In the Navy, huge amounts of asbestos were used so as to avoid other injuries, such as very severe burnsâalbeit unwisely, as we now know. This is an excellent piece of legislation in that regard. However, when we had an understanding of a productâs safety and we did not believe it presented a risk to others, I think it would be very unwise to revisit the issue and suggest negligence was involved. I make that point because of the occupational health and safety penalties that are constantly proposed by state governments. There are some very large businesses, and to talk about the role of directors or senior management in a workplace that could be quite remote from their point of operations is silly and unfair. If that is going to be concluded then this is a classic example of how everybody in this House would be liable in that regard, and I do not think any of us would think that is a good idea. I support this legislation. The repeal of the other legislation is sensible, particularly when one considers that the only function that councillors have had for some years was dealing with a matter they will no longer have to deal withâin fact, the levy support they had for other purposes has been redundant for several years.

talk.start.para: âI rise this afternoon to speak on the Asbestos-related Claims (Management of Commonwealth Liabilities) (Consequential and Transitional Provisions) Bill 2005 because of the importance that we as a community must place on ensuring that the victims of asbestos have access to fair compensation. With respect to the member for OâConnor, I wish he would stay in the House for a minute. He raised the issue of directors, but perhaps he should acquaint himself with the James Hardie agreement in New South Wales which is supported by the New South Wales government, asbestos victims, community groups and the trade union movement. That agreement is now being criticised by some business groups, by ASIC and by the federal Treasurer. Unlike what the member for OâConnor suggested to the House, it is on the basis that indemnities were included in this agreement that people such as the Treasurer are seeking to open the door with respect to civil penalties against directors and executives that, potentially, had been closed. It is not on the heads of the New South Wales or any state government to pursue directors. That initiative is being pursued by the Treasurer, the member for Higgins. Maybe the member for OâConnor should acquaint himself with the full details of the New South Wales agreement.

speech.para: The government suggests that the bills before the parliament today will streamline the handling of common law asbestos-related claims against the Commonwealth by centralising these claims with Comcare. Under the new arrangements it is expected that Comcare would manage claims by former and current employees as well as those from former waterside workers, contractors and subcontractors. It would also correctly cover tenants of Australian government owned or constructed premisesâfor example, there is a major question mark about a former Australian government building in Melbourne. It would also cover family members of employees who were exposed through contaminated clothing et cetera, visitors, bystanders and dependants of persons in any of these categories.

Under existing arrangements non-employee claims are managed by portfolios requiring a case management capability in each portfolio. Claims by former waterside workers are managed by the Stevedoring Industry Finance Committee, details of which were touched on by the member for Perth, Mr Smith. This decentralised approach is thought to lead to inefficiencies and inconsistencies in case management between agencies including inconsistent admissions of liability. The bills before the parliament today will mean that Comcare will also have the authority to manage claims from former waterside workers whose asbestos claims are currently managed by the Stevedoring Industry Finance Committee, which will be abolished.

The legislation does not propose changed arrangements for defence related common law asbestos claims, which will continue to be managed by the Department of Defence at the delegation of Comcare, subject to a review of these arrangements to be completed by July 2006. Importantly, the bill also has no effect on statutory claims made under the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988, the Veteransâ EntitlementS Act 1986, and the Military Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 2004. Claims made under these acts will continue to be managed by Comcare and the Department of Veteransâ Affairs.

In addressing the bill the government suggests that integrating the management of asbestos claims against the Commonwealth will lead to more consistent decision making and more equitable and efficient outcomes, resulting in a standardised approach to the management of asbestos claims. The government also claims that the new arrangements will facilitate a better understanding of the nature of asbestos claims, and improved knowledge and experience.

In the background material provided for these bills the government claims that its asbestos liabilities over the next 50 years are in the order of $900 million, the majority of which will be common law claims. This is something I want to touch on and I am seeking further clarification from the government as a result of this debate. Under this legislation Comcare would be fully funded for the cost of managing claims, and rightly so. While the governmentâs 2005-06 budget proposals provided $86 million to the Employment and Workplace Relations portfolio over a five-year period for the cost of asbestos claims, this bill is not expected to have a significant effect on the level of asbestos liabilities.

As we all appreciate, asbestos claims are a serious matter in this country and cannot be taken lightly. Last year the Commonwealth was forced to bring in legislation to protect James Hardie victims. That legislation was about ensuring that mechanisms are in place to force corporate Australia to take responsibility for its actionsâin essence, to ensure that everyday Australians are protected from the damage done by large faceless organisations. The community is now well aware of the actions of James Hardie. It has been an issue out there in the public arena and very much at the front of debate concerning James Hardie, especially over the last 12 months. The problem was that, in an attempt to absolve itself from financial responsibility for the pain and suffering that would result from its products, James Hardie engaged in a complex corporate restructure. That restructure was clearly about separating subsidiary companies with liabilities and transferring assets offshore to a Dutch registered legal entity. At the same time, as history will show, James Hardie established and underfunded a medical research foundation. This foundation was ostensibly established to deal with the claims by innocent victims of the asbestos related diseases against the various companies that made up the James Hardie operation.

It is now clear as a result of the debate in the Australian community and the discussions occurred between the parties that this foundation was unfortunately underfunded to the tune of $1.5 billion. That is a significant amount that James Hardie was basically seeking to walk away from with respect to its responsibilities to asbestos victims and their families. It was a shame in terms of what was once a proud companyâs corporate standing in the Australian community. I am aware of that proud history because I actually dealt with the company as a trade union official over many years. Rather than facing up to its corporate responsibilities, James Hardie moved offshore, leaving only $293 million to fund estimated compensation costs of some $2.3 billion. I raise these issues because such an abrogation of corporate responsibility is clearly unacceptable.

The James Hardie company, as the record will show, was regarded as producing good products. History shows that those products damaged Australian workersâ health and also had a major impact on standard of living and lifestyle over many years. Putting that aside, history also shows that the James Hardie company made good profits in this country for over 80 years. It might have produced and sold potentially deadly products but it made good profits. These products, as we now know, produced an insidious form of cancer, mesothelioma, which has no cure and kills its victims within 12 months of diagnosis. To date, mesothelioma has killed almost 7,500 Australians since 1945. This number is unfortunately expected to rise to some 18,000 by 2020. More than 500 Australians contract this disease every year and the peak of its incidence is not expected to hit until around 2010. In addition, the incidents of other asbestos related cancers are estimated to be around 30,000 to 40,000 by the same time.

The member for OâConnor is right about the use of asbestos in Australia. Australia had the highest use of asbestos in the world from the 1950s until the 1970s on a per capita basis. It was regarded at the time as a safe product and used in a range of activities, not just in the building industry but also, as the member for OâConnor referred to, in brake linings. I can personally remember, when I was thinking about doing an apprenticeship, willy-nilly drilling off brake linings that contained asbestos because we were not instructed in any other way.

It is estimated that, prior to 1982, approximately one-third of domestic buildings in Australia contained asbestos. It is not surprising therefore to hear that Australia has the highest per capita incidence of mesothelioma in the world. However, it is the perseverance and determination of the union movementâsomething that, unfortunately, the current government is not prepared to give credit toâthat actually brought the Australian government to the fore in facing up to its responsibilities to act to bring James Hardie to account. The union movement through the ACTU and the leadership of its secretary, Greg Combet, was successful in negotiating an agreement with James Hardie management to ensure that the company accepts its responsibilities. I simply say that the House should be commending the ACTUâas is the view of the Australian communityâfor its leadership and good work on the asbestos fight in bringing James Hardie to heel.

The union movement correctly was committed to the fight to ensure that justice is done. I think that is important. The union movement is not an organisation with two heads and neither does it have its head in the sand. It is an organisation which is about getting justice for the community. It is about guaranteeing that proper compensation was made available by the company that is in essenceâ

talk.start.para: âMr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. We have indulged the member for Batman for some time on the issue of James Hardie and the union involvement but I remind him that the substantive matter in this bill pertains to Commonwealth handling of Commonwealth employees only. I ask him to direct his points to that bill.
(Mr Lindsay)âI thank the member for Bowman. The member for Batman will link his comments to the bill.

âIn coming to that issue, we should note that the Australian government is now involved in legal action with James Hardie with respect to seeking to reclaim some of the compensation that it has been forced to pay as a result of the actions of James Hardie. I intend to deal with these issues so, with respect to the honourable memberâs intervention, patience will bear fruit.

speech.para: As I was saying, it is about proper compensation being made available by the company that was responsible for the pain and suffering of many innocent Australians. The record shows that the federal government was prepared to sit on its hands and let thousands of innocent people suffer, while the company was let off its obligation to offer compensation for their injuries. Following its own commission of inquiry into the James Hardie affair, the New South Wales government announced legislation aimed at allowing asbestos victims to take legal action against related corporations, including the Dutch registered entity. This goes to the potential reclaim of revenue paid by the Commonwealth with respect to these bills and their operation.

In light of the importance of asbestos claims in this country and the need to ensure that we as a society protect the innocent victims of asbestos, I have a number of questions that I would like the minister to answer in his response to this debate. I call on the government to address these concerns, lest it disadvantage a group of Australians who are in no position to protect themselves. As those who have participated in the debate have indicated, the intent of the bills appears to be straightforward. The legislation is simply about centralising the defence of all asbestos claims within one government agency, Comcare.

At the very least, this is likely to have defence cost implications. The Commonwealth has already spent a considerable sum on legal costs, preparing third-party claims against a range of parties in an effort to limit the total payout of the Stevedoring Industry Finance Committee to waterside workers and their families. Will the passage of this bill today result in additional legal costs being incurred by Comcare to rerun this exercise? I am looking for a response from the government on that issue.

I am also concerned about the actuarial assumptions used to underwrite the governmentâs reforms. I understand that there is concern within the industry that these assumptions have been overstated. The predicted future cost of asbestos claims for the Commonwealth has a net present value of some $850 million, based on a Commonwealth Auditor-Generalâs report which in turn was based on a report done by actuaries. Those same actuaries, Trowbridge Deloitte, were discredited by the Jackson inquiry set up by the New South Wales government to look into the liabilities of James Hardieâa rather pertinent point. What is of major concern to me and many in the community is that, at the time of the Commonwealth Auditor-Generalâs report, those actuaries were also part of James Hardieâs lobbying team seeking to convince state and federal governments that the rights of victims should be sacrificed.

The basis of the Hardie strategy was to claim, based on the actuarial forecasts, that the combined liability of those state and federal governments was so large that it exceeded that of Hardieâs, meaning that therefore it would be uneconomical to sustain payouts of all claims. At the same time as the assessments were made, a large number of waterside workersâ claims were being settledâmany of which had been in the system for some 20 years. This settlement of a bulk number of claims had come about as a result of the Crimmins High Court decision and the subsequent change to the statute of limitations.

Clearing of these cases eliminated a significant defence cost against the Commonwealth. It can now be reasonably expected that there will be a relatively small number of mesothelioma cases emerging from the wharves and, further, that the number is likely to decline over the next 15 years, given the containerisation of the wharves that took place in 1969-70, thereby reducing dramatically the asbestos risk. It is also likely that, given the profile of waterside claims and claimantsâthat is, their ageâthe net present value for these claims is in the vicinity of some $103 million, assuming five per cent interest. In addition to the claims related to the waterfront, the remaining claims against the Commonwealth ought to have a similar age and claim profile to the waterside workers.

In contrast, James Hardieâs claims continue to grow. James Hardie continued to manufacture products containing asbestos until 1987, many of which were for domestic and commercial applications. These products remain in place in many Australian homes and workplaces, and unsuspecting tradespeople and renovators remain at risk. Despite this, the most recent estimate of liability against James Hardie is $1.685 billion. Can the minister therefore explain how the Commonwealth would have a liability that equals some 60 per cent of the projected Hardie claims, despite their significantly different profile?

In closing, I would like to again touch on the historic agreement struck by the ACTU which brings the Hardie corporation to account and, importantly, ensures that victims receive the compensation that is due to them. This agreement was, I noted in the media, recently criticised by business groups, ASIC and the federal Treasurer on the basis that indemnities were included in the agreement. Those indemnities effectively exempt the directors and executives from civil liabilities. These groups have also seen fit to criticise the unions and the New South Wales government for their role in the agreement. In responding to these criticisms, I would simply like to quote the vice-president of the Asbestos Diseases Foundation of Australia, a man suffering from asbestosis. That man, Mr Bernie Banton, with whom I agree wholeheartedly, recently stated: âAs much as I would like to see all the Hardie people crucified, the payment to the victims is of the utmost importance.â

I am sure many of the listeners would agree with Bernie Banton with respect to his objective of looking after the victims who have suffered the end result of asbestos production in Australia. Sadly, whether we like it or not, the only way to look after those victims and the only way to get an agreement from James Hardie so that it would voluntarily meet its obligations was to put the victimsâ interests first. I commend all those involved in the negotiation of that agreement because, without it, many Australians would have been worse off over time. I commend the bill to the House but also seek a response from the government with respect to the issues I have raised during this debate.

talk.start.para: âIn supporting the Asbestos-related Claims (Management of Commonwealth Liabilities) Bill 2005, I firstly want to draw an analogy between asbestos and a topic that we have already discussed this weekâand that is, HIV. It is probably not well understood that the number of people affected are fairly comparable. I am glad that the member for Batman provided some of those epidemiological figures, because the number of people affected by asbestos is in fact very close to the figure we see quoted for HIV in Australia. The number of deaths is fairly similar, as is the number of new cases. With cases in the hundreds every year, it is interesting that asbestos often does not receive the attention that it deserves, and particularly so because so many people affected were from the construction and other industries from the 1950s onwardsâas late as the 1970s and, in some cases, through to the 1980s. That was a time when, in many cases, there were no protective avoidance or occupational health and safety policies in place for those who were ultimately affected.

speech.para: This bill today goes a long way to doing what those people affected could only ask from the Commonwealthâand that is, to take a very streamlined and efficient approach to the processing of claims that are currently under their control. Those who have been affected by the bill are waterside workers, contractors and tenants of government owned buildings and their dependants, but it even extends to those in clothing manufacturing, those who visited or even those who were bystanders. In simple terms, three things are being done with this bill: there will be a more streamlined approach, more consistency with the handling of claims and a more equitable and efficient approach.

I want to very briefly compare this approach with what we are seeing at the moment with the clearance of asbestos from Queensland schools. It is quite the opposite. We are seeing a protracted and delayed time line, which I raised earlier this week, in a plan to remove asbestos from Queensland schools over 10 years. I do not regard that as a streamlined approach. Nor is it consistent, in that I have 26 schools in my electorate and only one of them will be cleared of asbestos in the next 12 months. I regard that not only as inequitable and inefficient but as taking way too long to get us to the point where we can say there is no asbestos in Queensland schools.

To get back to the bill before us today, what we hope to have with the establishment of a central management unit is, firstly, a single point of contact for families that are currently having their cases considered. Secondly, there should be better management of those cases because of the increased level of experience that will be found in the unit. Thirdly, we can hope for prompter settlement because of the dedicated work of this unit. There will be a better understanding of the nature of claims because this group will be working full-time in that area, and that also means more transparency around the cost of asbestos claims and better understanding for those who are having their claims processed.

I note that there were some comments made in the media by the Greens and I was concerned that they really had a limited understandingâor perhaps they made a mistakeâof how the bill functions. I have the press release here. There appears to be a misunderstanding by the Greens regarding the interaction between the provisions of the bill we are debating today and the operation of the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation ActâI will refer to it as the SRC Act. For Commonwealth employees and their dependants, should they choose to sue at common law and the date of injury is prior to 1988, as it almost always will be, there is no cap except for any particular cap that may exist under state law. For non-Commonwealth employeesâand former waterside workers are an exampleâthe cap in the SRC Act does not apply.

If a dependant does in fact make a claim under the SRC Act it should be noted that they can expect to receive in the order of $320,000. That is divided up into a permanent impairment payment, a death benefit and, in addition, there are funeral and health benefits as well. That figure compares very favourably with what would be received through common law. I wanted to make the point that the cap is not necessarily relevant to claims made by dependants, and obviously a dependant can choose to sue at common law and they will not be limited to that $110,000 cap for non-economic loss under the SRC Act. My final point is that the cap will only apply if the estate chooses to sue for non-economic loss in lieu of accepting statutory benefits for permanent impairment. That is probably a fairly unlikely scenario, given that the current statutory benefits are quite generous.

There are very good reasons for this bill. We have already pointed out how important it is to have a centralised process for all of these claims. Obviously, the Department of Defence will be running their own cell for handling these claims. Australia Post and Telstra will not be included under the bill. It is my hope that, with the creation of a centralised claims management unit, we can do everything we can in the processing of claims to make them efficient, equitable, streamlined and consistent. Comcare will be managing asbestos related common law claims from non-employees. At present, Comcare can only manage those from current and former government employees and their dependants. The problem with that has been that managing these claims has been spread right across a range of Commonwealth portfolios and authorities. It is my hope that this legislation will be passed with the strong support of all speakers.

talk.start.para: âin replyâI thank those members who have made a contribution to this very important debate, and I particularly thank the member for Bowman for his considered words. The Asbestos-related Claims (Management of Commonwealth Liabilities) Bill 2005 will enable Comcare to manage the governmentâs asbestos liabilities, which is an essential component of the governmentâs decision to centralise management of its common law asbestos claims. Comcare already has responsibility for managing statutory asbestos claims from current and former government employees under the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988. Under this bill, Comcare will also manage common law claims from former waterside workers, contractors, subcontractors, tenants, visitors and bystanders in relation to government premises.

speech.para: Centralised management will lead to more consistent decision making and more equitable and efficient outcomes for both the government and claimants. There will also be benefits for the claimants. They will no longer have to identify which government agency is currently responsible for their asbestos exposure, which in some cases may have occurred 40 years ago. Centralised management will bring about efficiencies which will result in quicker processes and prompt settlement. That is important for those claimants who, sadly, are close to death.

The Asbestos-related Claims (Management of Commonwealth Liabilities) (Consequential and Transitional Provisions) Bill 2005 provides for the repeal of the stevedoring legislation, as it will become redundant with the transfer of asbestos liabilities to Comcare. Amendments to the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation Act will take account of Comcareâs new function.

In conclusion, I note the several points made by the member for Batman and others in relation to this matter and, in particular, to the Stevedoring Industry Finance Committee. There are coherent reasons for the repeal of the stevedoring legislation. With the transfer of SIFCâs asbestos liability to Comcare, SIFC itself will become redundant. At present, its only remaining function is to manage asbestos claims from former waterside workers.

Integration of management of the SIFC claims with management of other asbestos claims will be an essential component of achieving the goals of centralisation. It will of course mean less duplication of effort and more consistent outcomes for the government and the claimants. The SIFC board comprises a chair and one representative each from the Department of Transport and Regional Services, stevedoring employers and the Maritime Union of Australia. SIFC provides policy advice for the management of claims. That role is not compatible with the establishment of the new policy unit within DEWR. Whilst it was appropriate for SIFC to manage claims when its liabilities were funded by industry levies, SIFCâs liabilities are now funded directly by the government. Therefore, it is appropriate for the government to be fully accountable for expending its own funds as a matter of good governance.

DEWR already has a statutory tripartite consultative bodyâthe National Workplace Relations Consultative Councilâshould there be a need to seek industry advice. SIFC currently utilises a settlement protocol, which has contributed to the efficiency of its management of asbestos claims. This protocol has similar principles to the Commonwealthâs model litigant guidelines. I am advised that Comcare and my department will be developing an asbestos litigation policy statement which will also have similar principles to those of the model litigant guidelines.

In response to honourable members who have raised concerns in relation to previous matters concerning asbestos claims in this country, the Australian Government Actuary has looked at the Trowbridge assumptions and has deemed that those assumptions are appropriate and provide for an adequate assessment of the liability of the Commonwealth. On that basis I commend the bill to the House.
Question agreed to.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Governor-General recommending appropriation announced.

motion.para: That this bill be now read a third time.
