cognateinfo.title: CUSTOMS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (IMPORT PROCESSING CHARGES) BILL 2005

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 26 May, on motion by Mr Ruddock:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: âAs we understand the position, the regime to be implemented by the Import Processing Charges Amendment Bill 2005 and the Customs Legislation Amendment (Import Processing Charges) Bill 2005 must be up and running by 20 July this year, which means that there is some urgency in the passage of the legislation through the parliament. Labor will certainly do everything in our power to pass the legislation, subject to some points of clarification that I understand we are obtaining from the ministerâs office. We understand that the reason for the deadline is the cut-over date for the start of the integrated cargo system for imports. The integrated cargo system is an electronic portal through which importers and exporters can make their declarations and generally conduct business with Customs.

speech.para: The integrated cargo system is a product of the cargo management re-engineering project, which has been the subject of some controversy, though it must be said that as a system it is to be welcomed. Obviously, it is in the interests of all participants to avoid excessive paperwork. Indeed, we understand that there was also a rationale of trying to cut costs for industry participants and public servants engaged in the work on behalf of the deputy of Customs. But it is hard to see how these cost savings could eventuate. The reason is simple: the cost has increased tenfold from an original guesstimate of about $20 million to somewhere in the order of $200 million. It appears that the increases keep coming. Not only is this project over budget but also the news of the consequences for industry is late.

Industry have been wringing their hands for about three years now, waiting to test the final product so they can integrate their own information technology systems and train staff. To those importers who went out and invested in the new IT hardware in anticipation of this system being available sooner, I hope that they will be able to compensate by the depreciation that they have already been able to claim. But, despite three years of depreciation when the system should have been up and running earlier, obviously we would have liked to have seen things happen in a timelier manner.

The Minister for Justice and Customs has tried to portray what can only be described as quite a disastrous administration as the fault of the service. We now have a tenfold budget blow-out and the system is three years late, and the minister is yet to acknowledge responsibility. Regarding the latest delay, the system is supposed to be up and running by 1 July with a transition or cut-over period until 20 July. However, it now looks as though the Australian Customs Service may be unable to meet even this date, and who does the minister blame? Not himself, of course, but industry. The minister says industry has clamoured for an increase in the length of the transition period, and perhaps he is right. What he has not told the Australian public is why there is this call for an increased cut-over period. The reason is that the minister did not have a finished product for industry to test.

To reiterate, the product will not be ready for industry testing until it is too late. The minister has got the timing completely wrong. It now looks as though special legislation may be required to allow an extended cut-over period, and, of course, the final date for crossing to the new system is up in the air to a considerable extent. When can industry be confident the final cut-off date will beâSeptember, October, November? They cannot be sure but they have to run at these potential deadlines as hard and as furiously as they can, with all the required overtime and stress that is involved. We do not know precisely and the minister cannot give us answers. It is an issue of tremendous concern, as I have indicated, to the industry.

I would like to move to the technical matters contained in the bills. The bills deal with legislative change and appropriation to bring about the revenue measure outlined in the 2005-06 federal budget. In the coming financial year, it is estimated that approximately 222,000 importers will generate 3.6 million customer declarations, 99 per cent of which will be electronically lodged. Each of these declarations will attract a processing charge, as they currently do. These bills provide the legislative authority for the structure of the import declaration and the warehouse declaration processing charges contained in the Import Processing Charges Act 2001. Under the existing legislation, these charges are calculated with reference to the value of the goods. Currently, imports valued at less than $250 are self-assessed by the importer. The bills will amend the Import Processing Charges Act so that the charges will be assessed by mode of importationâair, sea or postâwithout reference to the value of the goods. Further, the bills modify the Customs Act 1901 and the Import Processing Charges Act to remove references to the old system of self-assessed clearance declarations and charges. Considered together, the bills remove the self-assessed clearance declaration charge from lower-value imports of below $250 in value. Instead the revenue will be collected through increases in the processing charges.

As I understand it, industry has been consulted quite extensively on this matter and generally supports the move as a way of freeing itself from unnecessary red tape. Labor will therefore support passage of the bills in the House, but not before saying that we have some further queries concerning the amount of revenue that will be collected from industry. As I have indicated, we understand that the bills will be the subject of a further briefing from the minister tomorrow and, while we will be assisting in the expeditious passage of the bills, we will reserve the right to perhaps move amendments to the bills in the Senate, subsequent to the briefing that we receive from the minister.

talk.start.para: âIn recent times the importation of goods into Australia has become an increasingly sensitive issue for this country. In the government publication Trade 2005 it was revealed that imports continue to grow. In fact, last year, 2004, total imports into Australia were valued at $178,000 millionâa rise of eight per cent over the previous year.

speech.para: The need for effective inspection of goods and quarantine safety measures has been, and always will be, a vital aspect of importation, to ensure that our laws are adhered to and that dangerous and unwanted items are kept out of our country. After all, importation that potentially has a negative impact on our way of life will also have a greater cost for this country in the long run.

The Import Processing Charges Amendment Bill 2005 has a simple aimâthat is, to further streamline the cost recovery measures related to those government services devoted to imports. It will also have a somewhat positive spin-off in relation to the paperwork associated with importing. The bill is designed to repeal two customs charges. The first is the self-assessed clearance declaration charge. This is an amount of $3.60 that relates to an importerâs function whereby he or she is responsible for assessing their compliance to import regulations and requirements. The self-assessment is essentially based on an honour system: the importer is given that responsibility by the Australian government. The government monitors the reliability and accuracy of those self-assessments.

The second charge is a fee of $67.50 relating to screening of imports. The screening charge is made up of various costs involved with import processing, inspections and quarantines. Both of these charges apply mainly to low-value consignments into Australia. The majority of these low-value consignments come into the country by air. While the bill facilitates the removal of both these charges, the costs incurred by the government in the provision of its various services will still be recovered. They will instead be collected through the restructuring of charges imposed on processing electronic import declarations and charges for warehouse declarations.

It is appropriate to note that upwards of 98 per cent of import declarations are now carried out electronically. Under the Import Processing Charges Act 2001, the customs fees required from importers are based on the value of the imported goods rather than the method used to get them into the country. It is clear that logistics and the costs involved with physically importing goods in a container by sea will be much greater than those involved in importing an item by air. The value of the actual items becomes somewhat irrelevant. It follows that customs and quarantine inspections for a container load of imports brought in by ship will, on the whole, be more time consuming and costly than for those brought in by air or through the mail.

It is important to have effective customs and quarantine barriers. The quarantine barriers prevent the spread of disease and also aid in the protection of Australian native animals and plants. We have seen, from mistakes in the past which have resulted in the proliferation of the myna bird and other imported species, that we have to be extremely wary of exactly what is allowed into our country. In that context I also mention the problem we have particularly in Queensland, but increasingly also in other parts of the country, with the presence of the cane toad.

The bill will see anomalies rectified. The cost recovery method will be returned to that of the Import Processing Charges Act 1997, whereby charges for government services are based on the mode of importâwhether it be sea, air or through the postage system. The changes reflect the logistical and administrative differences in the various import methods. A streamlined charging system will bring some welcome relief to importers, as the changes will bring with them a reduced administrative burden.

The government consults widely in the community and has kept in touch with the import sector, and it is important to note that the suggested changes to the import processing charges cost recovery regime are supported by the import industry. The Customs Legislation Amendment (Import Processing Charges) Bill 2005 and the Customs Legislation Amendment (Import Processing Charges) Bill 2005 are non-controversial legislation. I am pleased that we have the support of the opposition. I commend the bills to the House.

talk.start.para: âIn rising to speak in the second reading debate on the Import Processing Charges Amendment Bill 2005 and the Customs Legislation Amendment (Import Processing Charges) Bill 2005 I note that the member for Fisher has been an excellent minister in all respects and some of the problems that are occurring in his old portfolios demonstrate how enormously and awesomely capable he was. As I understand, these bills abolish small item charges. It is difficult to oppose bills that take away small and petty charges which are costing more money to raise than the money we receive from the charges. By itself, that sounds like a very good argument and one we should supportâand I suppose I do support it.

speech.para: Having said that, there is a philosophy here that seems to say we should make it easier for goods coming into the country. I remember asking why we were building the railway line from Adelaide to Darwin. At the time I was at a table with members of parliament who were also members of the government. They told me that it would cut dramatically the amount of the demurrage time at southern ports after taking goods off at Darwin. I said that there are no export industries in Adelaide or anywhere along that route. They said: âNo, itâs for imports. You understand it dramatically reduces the cost of imports.â I represent an exporting electorate and I know the business of the Europeans is to dramatically increase the cost of imports. Time after time, and in case after case, the Europeans, the Americans and the Chinese do everything humanly possible to put hurdles up in front of you if you try to get imports into their countries.

I cannot help but go sideways for one moment and bring to the attention of the House one of those cases, which occurred in my hometown area of Mount Isa-Cloncurry. A man called Russell Peters, by the strength of his own hand and his own intellect, put together a game meat processing plant that concentrated on pigs. Wild pigs are a terrible pestilence throughout western Queensland, and a very dangerous pestilence too; they are very destructive animals in respect of flora and fauna, and to the landscape itself. It was a very worthwhile project from every point of view and it created 20 to 30 much-needed jobs in Mount Isa at the time. After years of activity in putting this $2 million or $3 million plant together, he sent two containers over and they were rejected because the wash down watersâwhich do not touch the carcasses of these animalsâhad a high pathogen level. I emphasise my point that while we are reducing the difficulties of getting items into this country, other countries are in the business of increasing the difficulties of getting items into their countries.

Returning to the story, the containers were rejected because the wash down water had too high a pathogen level. I said to Mr Peters, âBut itâs town water, isnât it?â He said, âYes.â So I said: âThe town water that we drink in Mount Isa doesnât meet their requirements for wash down water? This is ridiculous.â He said, âWe know it is.â I said, âBut thereâs a second point here: the wash down water is not allowed to touch the carcass.â He said, âAbsolutely.â I tell this story to indicate to the House the enormous difficulties created for a great Australian, Russell Peters. But that is not the importance of the story. The importance of the story is to illustrate the lengths to which other countries go to keep product out.

I do not wish to denigrate the minister in any way, nor what he is doing in this bill, but I use the bill to highlight and illustrate a most serious problem that we have in Australia: we have a culture of making it easy for people; we are the great advocates of free trade. Free trade means that everyone can bring everything into the country, but when we try and get anything out then people like AQIS and Customs drive us crazy. For example, there is the ridiculous case of flowers. Those flowers coming into the country were not inspectedâthis is AQIS; the quarantine is supposed to be protecting usâbut those flowers going out of the country were inspected. There are thousands of cases like that. If you put a charge on things coming into the country then why not charge primage? The great Billy Wentworth, one of the finest people who ever went through this parliamentâand Billy came back and had another shot after he had left parliament; I think he was in his 80s at the timeâput forward the idea of primage. He wanted charges on everything coming into the country. I ask the minister to consider this, because it was not put up by an intellectual lightweight; it was put up by an intellectual heavyweight, and a great Australian to go with it. Billy used the word primage, but that is simply an across-the-board charge on everything coming into the country of, say, 10 per cent.

If we have a coastline larger than any other country on earthâI think that is correct; most certainly it would go close if it was notâthen we have got to look after that coastline. The cost of protecting our Customs duty and our quarantine services and protecting that entire coastline is ginormous. Australia is not spending even four or five per cent of what it should be spending if it were serious about protecting that coastline. When we talk about Customs, we are really talking about defending our country. That is what Customs are about. Customs say: âThis cannot come into this country unless you pay this amount of money upon it.â But the greatest protection for a country is to occupy the country. I represent many hundreds of kilometres of the coastline of Australiaâmaybe 1,000 kilometres or moreâand the part of it in the Gulf of Carpentaria is almost completely unoccupied and totally undeveloped, except for a few heroes at Karumba and Normanton and a few little towns. Really there is no population there at all. It is a huge landmass with 1,000 kilometres of black soil plains stretching back from itâit should be the farm bowl of the worldâand massive river systems.

In this country we keep trying to do all of our farming in the Murray Darling, where 50 per cent of our farming takes place with only a tiny little bit of Australiaâs water, and yet we leave the Gulf Country, with all of Australiaâs water and all of Australiaâs arable land, alone. At the moment the government of Queensland, in a massive piece of disastrous decision making, has declared that wild rivers will always stay wild. The only wild thing here is the wild fantasies of the Queensland government, and this comes back to our Customs issue of protecting Australia and Australians. If you think that you can sit upon resources that can feed, quite literally, 100 million peopleâI am not plucking that figure out of the air, but I have not got time today to go into the detail of why that figure is correctâand you are determined to do nothing with it or, if you are the government of Queensland, you are passing laws saying that no-one will ever be allowed to do anything with itâ

talk.start.para: âUse it or lose it, I say.

âIf ever there were a truism in history, it is the one used by the opposition spokesman: âUse it or lose it.â Not so very long ago, in our last international stoush of significance, we decided in our wisdom that there would a golden boomerang, and only Melbourne, Sydney, Brisbane and Adelaide were to be protected. All the rest of Australia was to be given over to the enemy. After all, if nobody is living there and you are not using it, why the hell would you ask your kids to fight for it? It was fairly logical. Also, strategically, there was so little infrastructure there that it would have been very difficult to defend it anyway.

speech.para: Nothing much has changed. In fact, the population of 90 per cent of the surface area of Australia is much the same as it was when Captain Cook arrived in 1770 or whenever it was. There were about 300,000 or 400,000 Australians here thenâmaybe fewerâand we have about 500,000 people living in that area now, so we are not in any way in occupation of this continent. I ask the ministerâand he has been a very fine one; one of the most excellent ministers I have seen in this House while I have been hereâto consider Billy Wentworthâs proposition seriously. I think he knew Billy Wentworth, but it was not only Billy Wentworth who put this forward; I have heard the proposition put forward many times.

A 10 per cent charge on everything coming into this country would enable us to provide 100 patrol boats with guided missile capacity and interception capacity, and helicopters with radar that can see a great distance. That would protect us from people-smuggling and from smuggling of any type, including smuggling of arms. It would protect us from people who are violating Australian fishing laws, wrecking our Great Barrier Reef and bringing disease in by landing on Australian shores without authority. All of those things could be overcome by an adequate system of protection.

The Americans call theirs the Coast Guard. They have no necessity for it really, because all of their coastal areas are protectedâbut ours are not. But where will we get the money to do this? I venture to submit that a 10 per cent charge would also greatly assist Australian industry by providing some protection. I think everyone in this House is beginning to realise that tariffs are about picking winners. A base charge on everything is not about picking winners. That is about your balance of payments, and I think there are very few people in this place now who are not conscious of that.

That money could be used for patrol boats which are small enough for it to be economically viable for them to go out and intercept people smugglers and people violating our reefs and fishing waters. There are a thousand other reasons why we need people to police these areas, and there are national parks people and fisheries inspectors out there. But these jobs are being done by small and inadequate boats, entirely unacceptable for the purposes. In a lot of cases, people are simply dodging customs and tariffs charges. While some of these people are involved in drug running, a lot of these people who are coming in by boat are simply bringing in materials and dodging customs charges. So there is great logic in looking at a proposal for an across-the-board charge on everything that comes into this country. Yet, while I understand and probably back the proposal being put here, it is in sharp contrast to other countries that are lying awake at night trying to figure out ways of keeping Australian products from coming into their countries.

We also have the potential to do a really marvellous job of protecting Australia from disease through our customs and quarantine inspections. Australia is unlike any other country on earth. In 1788 we had no agriculture in this country. The nearest thing we had to it was farming with fire to get wild animals to come in. You picked up the wild animals when they came in with the fire. But there were no domesticated agricultural products. We were not growing wheat or maize or anything like that, and Australians also had no domesticated animals that they ate. They had dogs, but they did not eat the dogs. So we did not have that and consequently we did not have any of those pathogens, bacteria and diseases that exist in other countries. To our north, there is spiralling white fly, foot-and-mouth disease, bird fluâthere is everything known to man in South-East Asia, and we really have to be very proactive.

I have received and I think many other people have receivedâand the honourable member for Leichhardt has probably receivedârepresentations by Indonesian interests wanting to open up fish processing and prawn and fish farming.

talk.start.para: Mr Entsch interjectingâ

âWell, I have. You must not be as important as I am, because I get them coming to me. They come and ask for this, and I feel very embarrassed. One of them, a very clever fellow, spread out a map of Australia and said: âWhat part of this coastline of Northern Australia are you not using that maybe we could use? What part of it are you not using?â If you draw a line from Cairns around the Australian coastline all the way to Broome, there is nothing there. Yes, there is Darwin and Weipa and maybe 100 kilometres showing some signs of civilisation, but for thousands of kilometres there is nothing there at all. And our nearest neighbour has 100 million people going to bed hungry of a night, and let me tell you that they are not particularly well disposed towards us, for a number of reasons that do not need to be put on the public record here.

speech.para: If you came from one of the countries in South-East Asia and you looked down here and saw the resources of the Gulf Country that could feed 100 million peopleâ126 million megalitres of water, when we are trying to do all of Australiaâs farming on 20 million megalitres of water in the Murray-Darlingâthen you would say: âWhat are these people? Are they dogs in the manger?â I do not wish to be moralistic, but the good Lord did talk about talents. He talked about the bloke who went out and used his talents and made a lot more and he talked about the bloke who hid them under a rock because he might lose them. That is what the Queensland government are doing. They are saying, âWe do not want to use these rivers because we might damage them, so weâd better hide them under a rock called the wild rivers protection legislation.â

If you were an Indonesian, you would find it very hard to live on your $800 annual income. It used to be an annual income of $2,000 until the intervention by the American banks, which we participated in. None other than Rupert Murdoch himself took a page in his own newspaper to castigate the Australian government for backing the intervention by the international banking fraternity under a number of guises into the Indonesian economy. These poor people saw their own incomes cut clean in half. Understandably, they are not friendly or disposed to people that participated in the destruction of their economy to this extent and they would not be happy that the resources of the Gulf Country could feed 100 million people. It is a giant black soil plain stretching all the way down to Blackall with 126 million megalitres of water, versus 20 million in the Murray Darling, where half of Australiaâs agricultural production comes from now.

You have to ask how you overcome these problems. Funnily enough, the Customs charge is a way of looking at those problems. I tell many great and wonderful stories about Billy Wentworth. That great and wonderful man used to passionately commit himself to try and convince the Australian people of the necessity for an across-the-board charge on everything that was coming into the country. Not only would this be a tax that would help our government revenues, but it would also be a disincentive for people to import and an incentive for them to produce those same commodities here in Australia. More importantly, and relevant to this debate, it would enable us to have a fund of money from our Customs charges for the protection of our country, to properly protect the people of Australia.

The current minister, wearing another hat, would be well aware of the enormous difficulties in trying to keep out of this country people who have no right to come into this country. The way to do that is by a policy that I cannot remember the technical name for, but it is a policy with respect to pigs and cattle. If we put pigs and cattle in the Torres Strait and Cape York Peninsula then there will be no necessity for pigs and cattle to come down from New Guineaâcattle do not, but pigs do. That is a strategy that was put forward. It was not a strategy that I agreed with but, all the same, one can see the logic in saying that if you occupy an area and you have people living there then you have a right to own that territory. If you do not have people living there and it is a big empty wilderness and people are going hungry then they most certainly have some moral justification in looking with hungry eyes over the backyard fence. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âin replyâI thank the members for Barton, Fisher and Kennedy for their comments during this debate on the Import Processing Charges Amendment Bill 2005 and the Customs Legislation Amendment (Import Processing Charges) Bill 2005. In thanking the member for Kennedy for his contribution, I recognise his very polite references to me. I thank him for that. I also recognise that he spoke of the late William Charles Wentworth in very favourable terms. I knew the late Bill Wentworth very well. He was a very close and dear friend. I took a great deal of notice of much of what he had to say, particularly in relation to the need for a standard gauge rail in Australia. He was a person for his time in relation to mineral developments and the use of nuclear power. He was a man of great foresight.

speech.para: As I have often said in commending other individuals and organisations, they can be very estimable in their qualities and their contributions but they do not always get it right. I am not sure that imposing upon the Australian community as a whole a very substantial increase in the overall cost of living is something that I would be keen to advance. In this legislation we are dealing with something that is much more narrowly based than the member for Kennedyâs comments might have suggested. It is a package of legislation which restructures the cost recovery regime for import related services that will operate once new management and processing of inward cargo by Customs are in place.

The Import Processing Charges Amendment Bill 2005 provides the legislative authority to restructure the import declaration and the warehouse declaration processing charges contained in the Import Processing Charges Act 2001. The second bill in this package will repeal two cargo reporting charges relating to low-value consignments which will be incorporated into the restructured import declaration and warehouse declaration processing charges. Industry representatives support the requirement to restructure the charges as proposed and strongly support the amalgamation of charges for low-value consignments into the import declaration and warehouse declaration processing charges. The bills ensure that import processing charges are equitable in their application to users of import processing services.

The honourable member for Barton raised some other issues in relation to both the cargo management re-engineering program and the integrated cargo system, particularly in relation to costs and implementation. I will outline some of that for the sake of completeness. The cargo management re-engineering program is a major re-engineering project that has spanned several years. It involves the modernisation of Customs legislation, business processes and cargo-related IT systems. It incorporates not only an integrated cargo system to replace the range of legacy systems but also a new and sophisticated electronic corporate gateway, known as the Customs connect facility, and a range of internal IT modules supporting Customs business processes. The technical development of these separate components in parallel and their subsequent integration and testing is one of the largest IT undertakings of its type in the country at the moment. It was first announced in 1996 and it was seen as a means of streamlining importing and exporting.

In December 1997 outsourcing was approved and Customs entered into a contract with the firm EDS. Significantly, Customs believed the project was modest enough not to require budget appropriationâthat it could absorb the expense involved. In March 1999 mention was made of $30 million for a cargo computer application and hardware and the development of migration costs. In 2000 legislation was passed allowing the new cargo management re-engineering scheme to be implemented. By March 2001 the estimate had risen to $55 million, reflecting the realisation that this was an extraordinarily ambitious and complex project. This cost estimate did not include other non-system development costs associated with organisational re-engineering, communications with industry and development of the trade modernisation legislation. In February 2002 a further contract of $29.7 million was signed with Computer Associates for the ICS component of the project. In February 2003 there was a contract variation of $15.4 million in relation to that componentâagain, a reflection of the immense complexity of the project. Neither Customs nor the consortium could have foreseen at the time of tender the complexity which resulted in a doubling of the expected size of the application.

The cost of the cargo management re-engineering project in June 2004 was $149 million, and next financial year will see further development and transition activity. The total development and implementation costs to the point of the import cut-over will be close to $188 million. This represents about $133 million for the ICS development, including contract payments, staff costs, industry training, publications and infrastructure support, and $55 million in CCF infrastructure development and contract costs over the six-year life of the project. To gauge the complexity of such re-engineering projects one can look at the United States, where a similar re-engineering project is being undertaken. The project will cost no less than $1.7 billion and will have taken seven years to develop and implement.

The government has decided not to change the commencement date for the international trade modernisation legislation. It will remain 19 July. The exports part of the legislation and the exports module of the integrated cargo system were successfully implemented in October 2004. Industry and its software developers have now asked for a longer transition time for reporting in the current Customs legacy systems, until it needs to report in the imports part of the ICS. This is because the majority of the industry software developers will now be delivering their systems in July 2005. Industry has asked for three months to fully test that software, to train staff and to adjust the business processes. All sectors of industry have agreed that the existing implementation dates threaten to compromise the quality of the final product.

At a roundtable meeting the Minister for Justice and Customs told those present that he wanted to keep the pressure on finalising the systems in preparation for the legislated transition period. From the limited testing done so far, industry is unsure if they and Customs will be ready for the cut-over to the new system at the planned time of 28 August. They have therefore asked for an extension. There is a need to strike a balance between producing a world-class, well-tested, user-friendly cargo-reporting system and ensuring that the system is delivered in a timely fashion. At the recent roundtable, the minister advised industry that the government would take into account their concerns and would respond formally to their request. We have considered that request and the minister has issued a press release stating that the government has announced that it will provide an extension of the transition phase for the integrated cargo system in response to industry concerns that insufficient time was available for its introduction.

The imports component will be available for use by 19 July 2005 under existing legislation, but industry will not be required to report in the ICS until just before the cut-over time. However, if, in further industry consultation in June, Customs and industry believe that more time is needed, legislation will be introduced during the spring sittings to extend that transition period. The minister will be convening another meeting with industry in June to check readiness. If the government then decides that a longer period is critical for all parts of industry to achieve compliance and a stable business setting, the government will introduce an amending bill, as I mentioned earlier. I commend the bill to the House and thank the opposition for the support that has been offered.
Question agreed to.
Bill read a second time.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 26 May, on motion by Mr Ruddock:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: âI rise to speak on the Crimes Amendment Bill 2005. My comments will be brief. The bill is straightforward but nonetheless very important. It seeks to amend part 1AC of the Crimes Act 1914 that deals with assumed identities. Assumed identities are vital for police and law enforcement work in controlled and undercover operations. The reality is that while those who are engaged in crime can, through the very fact of engaging in that activity, represent to some extent how naive they are, they are not entirely naive in wanting verification of the identity of those who may impact on their operations. In that context, fake identification is occasionally necessary to substantiate before those criminals that an undercover officer is the person that they are purporting to be.

speech.para: This is not something that is used lightly, and there is a reporting mechanism in place and criminal punishments for the misuse and abuse of the system of assumed identities. For the financial year 2003-04, for example, only 71 authorisations were issued. Perhaps in the coming year we may see a more widespread use of these identities as security issues come to light. In particular, the controversy that was before the parliament and the media yesterday concerning controlled operations at our airports is perhaps a continuing trend and a situation where we will see these assumed identities being necessary to assist those officers who are operating under cover. However, that is obviously going to be an operational matter for the Australian Federal Police to determine.

The measures relating to assumed identities were passed, with Labor support, under the Measures to Combat Serious and Organised Crime Act 2001. This bill does not seek to modify either the existing requirements for authorisation or the offences, reporting or accountability measures of that regime. There are already provisions in the act that criminalise the misuse of assumed identities under section 15XR of that act. We believe the provisions introduced in this bill will strengthen the regime that is already in place.

Previously, requests by the Commonwealth for false identification for the purpose of assumed identity were handled in an informal manner. However, the states are now formalising this process through their own legislation. Accordingly, the Commonwealth must now clarify its legislation to recognise the new state regimes and to ensure, for instance, that there is not a situation where an officer operating under an assumed identity is, as a result of oversight, subject to some liability under the new state regimes. Therefore, the bill introduces definitions of âstate agencyâ and âterritory agencyâ and a new section 15XMA to ensure that any request for this type of false-identification assistance from a state or territory issuing agency must be complied with at the request of the Commonwealth to the extent that the laws of the state or territory require that to occur.

Importantly, these arrangements are reciprocal. The states and territories police authorities can also gain access to federal documentation for the purpose of undercover law enforcement work. That is something that I think all Australians will recognise as cooperation that is certainly highly desirable. In summary, this bill is relatively straightforward. While it is straightforward, it is nonetheless important and Labor is pleased to be able to assist the government in securing its passage through the houses.

talk.start.para: âI too will speak briefly on the Crimes Amendment Bill 2005. This is, in some respects, a tidying-up exercise. Part IAC of the federal Crimes Act deals with assumed identities and permits officers of a number of Commonwealth agenciesâthe Australian Federal Police, the Australian Customs Service, ASIO, ASIS, the Australian Taxation Office and any other agency specified in the regulationsâto obtain documents establishing an assumed identity from Commonwealth agencies. These assumed identities are designed to facilitate intelligence and undercover operations and are a vital part of our continuing battle against crimeâin relation in particular to organised crime and more recently the battle against terrorism. They are a vital part of the law enforcement exercise and a vital part of the governmentâs commitment to defending the security of all Australians. On that note, I welcome the member for Bartonâs remarks and the oppositionâs support for the bill.

speech.para: However, the most common form of identification document, the sort of document that people typically produce to prove their identity or, in this case, to establish an assumed identity, is of course a drivers licence. They are issued by state governments for the most part, and the current legislation does not provide a legislative framework for those to be obtained by Commonwealth officers. They have been obtained with a degree of informality in the past, as the Attorney-General said, in the absence of a legislative framework. That obviously is no longer feasible, as each state is now passing and debating in its respective parliamentâin great detail in some casesâthe regulation of the provision of assumed identities.

This bill will enable duly authorised Commonwealth officers to obtain documents establishing assumed identities from the states. The legislation already enables state participating agencies to obtain such identity documents from the Commonwealth. This bill will provide the link that completes the chain and will ensure that those officers who are undertaking undercover workâand, in doing so, need to have evidence of their assumed identityâwill be covered by legislation both on the Commonwealth side and on the state side. Those officers will be duly indemnified and protected from any suggestion that they may be incurring any liability or committing any offence simply because of their use of an assumed identity. This is an important bill. It is an important part of our continuing battle against crime and terrorism and our continuing defence of the security of Australia and its people. I commend it to the House.

talk.start.para: âI rise to support the Crimes Amendment Bill 2005, a bill to amend the Crimes Act 1914. I support the bill because it formalises arrangements and long-established operating protocols with respect to state, territory and Commonwealth law enforcement agencies. The provisions of the bill will act to strengthen the regime that governs the assumption of an identity. As the Attorney-General noted in his second reading speech:

quote.para: Assumed identities are false identities adopted to facilitate intelligence and investigative functions, or the infiltration of a criminal, hostile or insecure environment with a view to collecting information and investigating offences.

speech.para: The ability to assume a false identity is a necessary condition for police to conduct their daily investigations, particularly targeted operations, required to combat crime and improve community safety.

As I noted earlier, this bill formalises arrangements between the states, territories and Commonwealth agencies. The bill contains amendments necessary due to the introduction of state based regimes for assuming identities. State governments throughout the country have been going through the process of formalising and codifying their practices through legislation and, as a result, consequential amendments are being proposed in this place.

The bill introduces definitions for âstate agencyâ and âterritory agencyâ. It also includes a requirement that any request for false-identification assistance from a state or territory issuing agency must be complied with at the request of the Commonwealth to the extent that the laws of the relevant state or territory require the agency to do so.

The bill does not alter existing provisions that control the use of false identities. Authorisation requirements, offences, reporting and existing accountability requirements remain the same. This is an important aspect of the bill. All other provisions surrounding the acquisition and use of false identities remain the same, and this merely formalises a longstanding but informal arrangement between law enforcement agencies at different levels of government.

It is important because often people suspect that, hidden in the detail of minor or technical amendments, there is some more malicious agenda. Given the circumstances we face in a modern society, people suspect that hidden in the amendments, particularly in national security and policing bills, is an attempt to extend police powers or to erode civil liberties. That is not the case with this bill.

This bill is about equipping police with the necessary tools of their trade. It is about formalising arrangements at a Commonwealth level so that the actions of state and territory governments in formalising their processes through legislation do not impinge on the ability of law enforcement officers to go about their business. These are consequential but nevertheless necessary amendments.

As members would be aware, I have some background in working with the various police agencies throughout Australia. As I outlined to the House in my first speech, I have worked as an adviser to the Police Federation of Australia, representing both the industrial and professional interests of police. It gives me great pleasure to rise here today to support the professional interests of our police once more.

Police need the assistance of tools to do their jobs, just like any other tradesmen or members of a profession. While many would have in their minds that the main tools for police are handcuffs, firearms and possibly a paddy wagon, there is much more to policing than that. The certainty that police can obtain assumed identitiesâwhen justified and when requiredâis just as important a part of policing as ballistic vests or purpose equipped vehicles.

When Mark Burgess, the Chief Executive Officer of the Police Federation of Australia, heard that the amendments to the Crimes Act 1914 were being introduced into the House, he contacted me. He hoped that I would be rising in support of this bill and in support of making sure that his members would be able to go about their business with certainty and with greater legal clarity.

I pointed out in my first speech in this place that crime knows no boundaries, whether they be physical or technological. Crime is a serious issue for our society and a concern for all our constituents. I know that certainly crime is a concern to my constituents in Werriwa, as I have commented on in the past. My constituents want the police to have all the necessary tools to combat local crime. They want to be certain in the knowledge that the law-makers are allowing police to keep up with criminals.

As many members would be aware, one of the fastest growing areas in criminal activity is identity theft. In an electronic age where personal information is traded over the netâwhether it be as the result of purchases on eBay or through international credit card scamsâthe protection of identities is becoming more and more important. As the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Economics, Finance and Public Administration heard in 2002 when attempting to quantify the extent of identity theft, the use of electronic commerce increased the level of identity fraud and increased the difficulty in identifying and apprehending culprits. In evidence to that committee, the Australian Federal Police reported that, at that time, 25 per cent of frauds reported involved the assumption of a false identity. I do not bring these matters to the attention of the House to scare the public, nor am I suggesting that Australian police officers will commit identity fraud by assuming false identities. I am making the point that, as criminal activity becomes more sophisticated, police operational procedures need to keep pace.

Australian policing agencies are involved in a vast number of different areas of law enforcement including local crime, fraud, the domestic and international trade in drugs and national security. They also play a part in preventing international organised crime in association with the police agencies of other countries. As you would expect, they do not necessarily mix with the best in society. As a result, their lives are often put in danger when they are on duty. Accordingly, this bill is as much about equipping police as it is about protecting police. It will not protect police officers who are injured trying to settle a domestic dispute, it will not protect police officers who are injured in a car chase and it will not protect police officers who are the victims of random acts of violence. However, it will protect police officers who live and mix intimately with alleged criminals while accumulating sufficient evidence for charges to be laid. Police need any additional protection that we can afford them in such circumstances. Assumed identities are required by law enforcement agencies for the purposes of conducting targeted undercover crime operations. I believe that this bill provides all the necessary requirements to protect the officers conducting such sensitive operations. Without reservation, I support the bill.

talk.start.para: âin replyâI thank the members for Barton, Wentworth and Werriwa for their support for the Crimes Amendment Bill 2005. The support has been fulsome. That is something that I appreciate; it is not always the case, obviously. In this matter state and territory governments are seeking complementary legislation at a national level to support the measures that they have in place to enable the investigation of very serious criminal offences. I think it is incumbent upon us to do our part to ensure that the legislation that will support those efforts is put in place quickly.

speech.para: This bill has been developed with state and territory officials to meet their needs, as outlined during the course of the debate and in my second reading speech, and it is important that the bill is able to be implemented before 30 June. We would like to see the bill secured not only in this place but also in the Senate. I hope that those who have spoken so fulsomely in the passage of this legislation will ensure that their colleagues in another place give the same support to this measure.

As I have said, the bill aims to enhance the ability of our law enforcement and national security agencies to combat serious and organised crime. It will amend the Crimes Act 1914 to enable Commonwealth agencies to request evidence of identity from state and territory governments in accordance with legislation in force in those jurisdictions. This means that law enforcement and national security agencies will be able to obtain state based evidence such as birth certificates and drivers licences in order to support their undercover operations. Previously, there was no need to have a legislative framework to address the issue because of the absence of state and territory legislation, except in New South Wales. Now that the states and territories are in the process of implementing assumed identity legislation, the proposed amendments make necessary consequential changes to the Crimes Act so that the Commonwealth agencies can take full advantage of those schemes as well. I commend the bill to the House and wish it a speedy passage in another place.
Question agreed to.
Bill read a second time.

motion.para: That this bill be now read a third time.
