motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: âI rise to state the position of the opposition on the Aged Care Amendment (Extra Service) Bill 2005. This bill removes the requirement for aged care providers to reapply for each extra service place they have every five years. This will decrease red tape for aged care providers and increase their ability to obtain capital for building and refurbishment. It also gives people going into aged care facilities more choice about the type of service they wish to receive, although obviously there is a question of payment and what people can afford.

speech.para: This legislation should not affect disadvantaged older Australians, because the current maximum of 15 per cent of extra service places in each state and territory will remain. The extra service status allows aged care consumers in residential aged care facilities increased choice. Consumers can pay for hotel type services such as enhanced accommodation and a greater range and quality of food, as well as the provision of non-care services, including recreational and personal interest activities. An example of that may be the daily provision of newspapers so that people can follow current affairs.

The government and the aged care sector claim that the regulation of the extra services program has constricted the expansion of services and that by removing the need to reapply every five years providers will be saved excessive and expensive paperwork. Additionally, aged care providers say that the expansion of extra services will enhance longer term planning and capital-raising capabilities. I think it follows from what I have said that this bill is viewed as noncontroversial from the point of view of the opposition. This bill is directly within the purview of my colleague Senator Jan McLucas, the shadow minister for ageing, disabilities and carers. It is the intention of the opposition for Senator McLucas, when this matter comes before the Senate, to make a substantive contribution in the debate. It is not the intention of the opposition to in any way delay passage of this matter before the House today. On that basis, that concludes the oppositionâs remarks in relation to this second reading debate.

talk.start.para: âI too support the Aged Care Amendment (Extra Service) Bill 2005. I have had a number of calls from my electorate about the importance of what this bill will deliverâthat is, an improvement in the range and quality of services that can be purchased individually by those who are living in aged care. I think the bill demonstrates once again without doubt the governmentâs strong commitment to ensuring a truly robust and viable aged care system. I recently opened the Netherlands Retirement Village extensions and a major component of that opening was extra services. There was a great deal of excitement at that opening about the provision of those services, and this bill goes towards ensuring that these things are possible. Expansion of that service will also allow the sector to respond to rising community and consumer expectations.

speech.para: This bill provides extra choice around hotel servicesâthe range of food and other accommodation services that are available. It includes recreational and personal interest activities as well. That delivers for residents extra certainty. It allows them to know that, in their own places of residence, the same levels of recreational serviceâfood and other servicesâthat they expect will be continued. So there will be no change in that respect. Importantly, as far as red tape goes, this legislation removes the requirement that every five years providers be able to access capital for rebuilding and refurbishing. That renewal requirement existed up until the introduction of this bill. At the same time, the expansion of extra service programs will allow the sector itself to deliver increased choices around hotel type care. The removal of that renewal requirement occurs on 1 July 2005.

The extra expansion of services does not make it any more difficult for pensioners or anyone else who cannot afford those extra services. In fact we had a situation where additional places were provided in one of the aged care facilities in my electorate. There was a concern that they were filled by those who were not necessarily paying for extra services and that it was possible in these situations when new extra service positions became available that people taking up those positions could slowly fill those beds as that became possible. So it is important that we state here today that those who cannot afford the additional cost of service will continue to receive access to quality aged care. That really has been a change that we have witnessed between today and prior to the term of this governmentâthe consistent high quality of aged care through an absolute focus on quality assurance and accreditation.

A maximum of 15 per cent of all aged care places in each state and territory can be used to provide extra services. Socioeconomic profiles of each region are taken into account by the groups that make those determinations. That really means that for those who live in areas where access to aged care by the less affluent is required that will not be impeded by this bill. Obviously there are opportunities for those who are interested in extra services to learn more directly through the departmentâs web site. Prospective residents and their families should be encouraged to go and learn more about those extra services. This bill can have a significant impact upon the services that are available to those who choose those places. All residential aged care services that are granted extra service and have extra service status in operation will be listed on the web site so consumers can find that information directly.

In the three minutes that I have left I want to emphasise how extra services fit into a greater package of aged service delivery. As I said before, we are seeing rising consumer expectations for the provision of services for aged care residents and, in Bowman in particular, for a greater range of hotel type services. This comes at a time when many facilities are having to renew their extra service status after five years. The removal of that red tape was warmly welcomed in Bowman. The individual needs of older Australians are this governmentâs priority and that is why this bill has been put forward to further broaden their opportunities. Those extra status positions allow residents to pay for, if they choose, a higher than average level of hotel type services. There are restrictions around how that is done. These units have to be self-contained parts of larger aged care facilities. I know that that is not proving any difficulty for those in my electorate who are choosing to access those positions. Aged care providers have long felt that the level of regulation was high. I think this removal of red tape demonstrates the governmentâs commitment to lessening the burden on aged care providers. In particular, the reapplication for extra services on a regular basisâeven though it was only every five yearsâwas causing an additional burden.

Considerable investment in infrastructure is obvious. In Bowman, doing the basic calculations for the number of aged care placesâeven though calculations for aged care facilities are done over a broader south Brisbane areaâreveals that the number of aged care places is very close to the federal governmentâs objective of 1.08 aged care positions per 1,000 people over the age of 70. I congratulate both the Department of Health and Ageing and the minister for achieving those objectives for my seat and the region of south Queensland. That region is probably the fastest-growing area of Queensland. For that reason it is one of the hardest areas in which to ensure that those ratios are achieved. That does not mean that we are not going to need substantial extra investment in infrastructure over the coming decade. I join with the federal member for Bonner, Ross Vasta, in pushing hard for those additional services so that we keep up with the rapidly growing population. I remind members that the bayside suburbs of Queensland have the highest intra-state migration within Queensland. That means there are a large number of people looking for aged care places, and that really does stress some of the local ratios. I congratulate aged care providers in my seat for meeting those ratios and bringing those beds forward so that they are available for the aged and their families seeking those positions. I support this bill.

talk.start.para: âOrder! It being 2.00 pm, the debate is interrupted in accordance with standing order 97. The debate may be resumed at a later hour and the member will have leave to continue speaking when the debate is resumed.

âMy question is to the Prime Minister and relates to the Treasurerâs claim yesterday that our record foreign debt poses no threat to interest rates. Is the Prime Minister aware of reports today that Australiaâs snowballing foreign debt could pose a threat to the governmentâs credit rating? Credit rating agency Standard and Poorâs says Australiaâs foreign debt is âpretty high for a AAA-rated countryâ and our foreign debt is â50 to 60 per cent more than any other country with a AAA ratingâ. In the light of these warnings, how much longer will the Prime Minister allow Australia to sink into unsustainable debt?

âI thank the Leader of the Opposition for his question and point out that, as a proportion of the economy, foreign debt actually fell yesterday, which means the premise of his question is completely wrong. The Leader of the Opposition is running off a story in todayâs Australian with credit rating agency Standard and Poorâs. If he had read the full report he would know that the spokesman from Standard and Poorâs said that, with the strength of its government finances and with nearly all its foreign debt held by the private sector, Australia gives reassurance to international lenders and its government has the capacity to support the private sector if there are any problems. That says precisely what I said yesterdayâthis government, almost alone amongst the economies of the developed world, has a budget surplus.

answer.para: In his sotto voce interjections the Leader of the Opposition says this is complacent. No, it is not complacent to run a budget surplus. Let me tell you what is complacent. It is complacent to have a finance minister who has a deficit of $10 billion, or nearly three per cent. That is what complacent is. I remind the Leader of the Opposition of his own record when he was finance minister. Almost alone amongst the developed economies of the world, the Australian government runs a budget surplus. On projections in the budget, it will have net debt to 0.7 per cent of GDP by the end of the next financial year. That means that the Commonwealth government will be carrying nearly no debt. The OECD average is around 40 to 50 per cent, putting Australia in a very strong positionâa point that was noted by Standard and Poorâs.

talk.start.para: âMy question is addressed to the Treasurer. Would the Treasurer advise the House of the results of the March quarter national accounts released this morning by the Australian Bureau of Statistics? What do they indicate about the Australian economy and the importance of consistent and careful economic management?

âI thank the member for Bowman for his question, and I can tell him that the national accounts released today for the March quarter show that the economy rebounded in the March quarter, growing at 0.7 per cent. That comes off a lower than expected growth rate, which was revised up to 0.3 per cent for the December quarter, and means that, through the year, the Australian economy has grown at 1.9 per cent.

answer.para: Although consumption remains solid at 3.4 per cent, it is in fact lower than it was last year, which shows a moderation in consumption. The dwelling sector continues to experience a mild downturn, with dwelling investment falling 3.8 per cent through the year. This is not unwelcome. I have said on a number of occasions that the kinds of price rises we were seeing in 2001, 2002 and 2003 were unsustainable and that the government would welcome a moderation in the housing sector. We see clear evidence that this is now occurring. Business investment continues to be supported by strong profit growth. The profit share of the economy is at nearly an all-time recordâI think it is within 0.1 per cent of the all-time record.

The worrying part of the national accounts is the rural sector. It is clear that farm incomes have not returned to where they were before the 2002-03 drought. We had the fourth quarter of downturn, and agricultural production is 16.1 per cent lower through the year. I am sure that those in rural Australia know the heartbreak that is occurring at the moment, particularly on the east coast. We are now seeing that in agricultural production feeding through to the national accounts. But, overall, we have a rebounding economy with low inflation, good business investment, unemployment at 30-year lows, interest rate lows, a budget in surplus and the prospect of the Commonwealth freeing itself from net debt in 2005-06. We should not be complacent about this. We need to continue economic reform in this country. As I have said on a number of occasions, no economic reform is more important to Australia than labour market reform. This parliament has the opportunity to accomplish it, and we should accomplish it.

talk.start.para: âMy question is to the Treasurer. Does the Treasurer recall his comments in this House yesterday to the effect that Australia, now AAA-rated for foreign currency bonds, no longer pays any premium in relation to interest rates? Does the Treasurer still stand by that statement? Can the Treasurer explain why Australians are paying some of the highest interest rates in the worldâhigher than the US, the EU, Japan, Canada and Britain? Is it a fact that Australian homebuyers are paying higher interest rates than other countries because we have consistently high current account deficits and foreign debt?

âThe answer is no. If the current account were the cause of domestic home mortgage interest rates, why would they today be 7.3 per cent when under the Labor Party they were 17 per cent? Why would they today be 7.3 per cent when under the Australian Labor Party they were 17 per cent? Why would they today be 7.3 per cent when at the time the government was elected they were 10.5 per cent?
Mr Kelvin Thomson interjectingâ

âLet me make this point: there is one clear difference between now and 1996. It is this: in 1996 the budget was in deficit nearly three per cent of GDP and today it is in surplus. In 1996 Australia owed $96 billion and by 2005-06 we could have that as low as $6 billion. This is the government that took $96 billion of Labor Party debt and will retire $90 million of itâ
Mr Kelvin Thomson interjectingâ
âThe member for Wills is warned!

âforever taking that load off future Australians. Let me make this final point: all other things being equal, if a government is borrowing, it is driving up interest rates; if a government is saving, it is driving down interest rates. When Labor was in office Labor was borrowing and driving up interest rates. Interest rates peaked at 17 per cent and in 1996 they were 10.5 per cent. This government has not borrowed a dollar in net terms since 1996 and by paying off $90 billion of Labor Party debt this government has put downward pressure on interest rates, which are now at 7.3 per cent, a level which was unheard of under the Australian Labor Party.

âMy question is addressed to the Treasurer. Would the Treasurer outline to the House what steps are under way to deliver hardworking Australians their tax cuts? Would the Treasurer explain if there are any obstacles to delivering these tax cuts?

âI thank the honourable member for Hasluck for his question. As a recently elected member he, along with the other members on this side of the House, is supporting a tax cut for every Australian on 1 July, and that is a month away. There is no reason why within a month every Australian cannot have an income tax cutâexcept for one person. One person stands between now and every Australianâs income tax cut on 1 July, and it is the member for Brand, the Leader of the Opposition, I regret to inform the House.

answer.para: The schedules which deliver these income tax cuts were tabled in this House last Thursday. Thursday has passed, Monday has passed, Tuesday has passed and Wednesday has passed and the Labor Party is yet to announce whether it will be moving disallowance. They will be tabled as soon as the Senate sits on 14 June. If the Labor Party does not disallow then every Australian will have their tax cut. But the Australian Labor Party, I regret to inform the House, still refuses to disclose to Australian business whether it intends to proceed with its sabotage attempt on these tax cuts.

I have come into possession of a letter from MYOB to the member for Lilley dated 31 May 2005. MYOB is a provider of software that is used by a very large proportion of Australian small businesses to do their payrolls. This letter reads as follows:

quote.para: As you know, the ATO recently responded to a looming crisis for small business by gaining approval for the release of two tax tables. The fact remains that releasing two schedules to the business community is far from ideal. Businesses who insert the MYOB payroll upgrade will automatically install the tax tables approved from the 2004 budget. They will then need to manually override this automatic process and insert the password to access the 2005 tables should they be approved.

I must emphasise this is a solution of last resort for our customers. In our experience accurate payment of employees is a role business owners take seriously. It is highly sensitive. Mass frustration will be felt not only by business but by their 1.5 million employees if this cannot be worked out. MYOB begins producing upgrades for our customers on 6 Juneâ

answer.para: Listen to this: today is 1 Juneâ

quote.para: MYOB begins producing upgrade CDs for our customers on 6 June. Unless the ATO is in a position to authorise delivery by this date we cannot make the 2005 tax tables the default option. This is the last chance for all involved to eliminate imminent confusion for small business owners around the nationâ

answer.para: Listen to thisâ

quote.para: I implore you to take the required steps to avert an unnecessary and far reaching quandary.

answer.para: This is from MYOB.

talk.start.para: âTable it!

âI will table it; of course I will table it. This is the organisation that is advising small businesses on their payrolls. MYOB says that unless the Labor Party announces by 6 Juneâtoday is 1 Juneâthere will be, in its words, âa looming crisis for small businessâ. Those schedules are in the House. If the Labor Party wants to disallow them it can move in this House today to disallow them. It will not succeed but at least we will know where the Labor Party stands on this issue.

answer.para: I say this to the members of the Labor Party backbench, now held hostage by the member for Lilley and his failed strategy: Labor lost the last election because it did not understand the economy and it did not understand business. The argument which the member for Lilley and his compatriot the member for Perth put forward as to why they should be entrusted with economic policy on behalf of the opposition, rather than the member for Lalor, was that they could build responsibility and relationships with business. They said they could put aside Laborâs untrustworthiness on economic issues.

Today, as their first step, they are holding to ransom 850,000 Australian businesses. I want to say this: do not let it ever be said that the Labor Party can build a relationship with business when it engages in a stunt like this. MYOB is writing to the member for Lilley asking him to avoid a looming crisis. All he has to do is walk to that despatch box and say: âWe will not hold them to ransom. We will let businesses get on with employment. We will give employees their tax cuts. We the Labor Party have turned over a new leaf. We will try and show some understanding.â Until they do thatâLabor do not understand businessâLabor will never be trusted by business.

talk.start.para: âMy question is addressed to the Minister for Education, Science and Training. Is the minister aware that university and TAFE staff around Australia are today taking action because the Howard government is holding them to ransom over $800 million in university funding and $4.4 billion in TAFE funding for coercive industrial relations conditions that have nothing to do with university and TAFE core functions of education, training and research? Can the minister guarantee that no university or TAFE will strip back working conditions like paid maternity leave or redundancy pay as a result of this governmentâs interference in tertiary education employment arrangements?

talker.name: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP
talker.role: Minister for Education, Science and Training
talker.name: Dr NELSON

talk.start.para: âI thank the member for Jagajaga for her question. The first thing I can say to Australiaâs universities is that had there been a change of government last year they would have lost $1.4 billion over the next four years. The second thing is that the responsibility of those of us in government is to do what is right for Australia. It is critically important that we invest an additional $11 billion in universities over the next 10 years, which is what this government is committed to doing. But before we hand over that hard-earned taxpayersâ money we are saying that two things will happen in universities. The first is that there will be changes to the way in which they are governed and administered, and I thank the states and territories for their cooperation in reforming their enabling acts in that regard. The second thing is that the working arrangements in Australian universities and TAFEs should be no different from those enjoyed by working Australians right throughout the country.

answer.para: The last bastion for industrial relations reform exists in Australiaâs TAFEs and universities. Just so it is absolutely clear to the average Australian what the government requires, before an extra $838 million is given over three years to Australiaâs universities we are requiring that the university management will offer to its employees an Australian workplace agreement and that every employee in a university or a TAFE should be free to join and be represented by a unionâif they want to. These are intelligent, educated people. If they want to, they should have the right to say that they do not want to negotiate an individual agreement, and they should only have a third party involved in industrial relations negotiations in relation to their working arrangements if they want them involved. There is nothing so remarkable about that. The average, everyday Australian would ask, âWhy is it that these people have been so cloistered for so long?â and one of the reasons is they have been protected by the people right across the benches of the Australian Labor Party.

talk.start.para: âMy question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Would the minister inform the House about the process of negotiating a prisoner transfer agreement with Indonesia?

âI thank the honourable member for McPherson for her question and tell the House that the Australian delegation, with officials from both the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and the Attorney-Generalâs Department, will be in Jakarta next week to discuss a bilateral treaty on the transfer of prisoners between Australia and Indonesia. We have arrangements with a range of states of this kind. We have 57 countries we have arrangements with through the Council of Europe Convention on the Transfer of Sentenced Persons and we have recently finalised a bilateral agreement with Thailand. It is important to recognise that, in the case of the other agreements we have, transfer of prisoner arrangements allow for a citizen convicted of a crime overseas to serve their sentence in Australia. They do not permit the offender to be released on return to Australia. Such agreements also require that all appeals processes must be exhausted before a transfer can be considered.

answer.para: Indonesia currently does not have any bilateral prisoner transfer treaties, not with any other state, so it is important to recognise that these negotiations may be complicated and it may take some time to reach agreement. But it also worth remembering that, once that agreement is reached, assuming it is, between the Australian and Indonesian governments, it is likely that that agreement will require some amendments to legislation, including in Indonesia, and it is certain that that agreement would have to be ratified by the Indonesian parliament. I say that because I know a lot of people in Australia are upset about the Corby verdict. But I would say this: to continually attack Indonesia and denigrate its institutions and leaders will build up a good deal of anti-Australian sentiment in Indonesia and it will make it very difficult to conclude agreements of this kind, particularly through public institutions like the Indonesian parliament.

I am aware that today the Australian Federal Police and the ACT Fire Brigade are investigating a possible suspicious package that was received this morning by the Indonesian embassy. The embassy has been closed. It is surrounded by fire engines and other emergency services equipment. This is a matter of great concern and it is the sort of thing that is very unhelpful, to say the least. I make the point that as a government we condemn this sort of behaviour, we condemn this sort of abuse and we would urge people who are concerned about Schapelle Corby to ensure they put their energies into supporting the legal defence team and not put their energies into abuse and denigration of Indonesia, its institutions and its leaders and not to undertake these sorts of activities which, at least, are potentially threatening to Indonesian staff working here in Australia.

talk.start.para: âMr Speaker, on indulgence: can I, on a bipartisan basis, say that the opposition shares with the government the condemnation of any threat of violence towards any Indonesian diplomatic or consular office in this country as unacceptable and un-Australian.

âMy question is to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Does the minister recall telling the Australian people on 16 May this year, in relation to the Vivian Alvarez Solon case, âI can only say to you that as far as my department is concerned we didnât know anything about her case until the end of last month,â meaning the end of April 2005? Is the minister aware of a letter from the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and tabled in Senate estimates today that says that the immigration department has now âlearned of an exchange between the Queensland police missing persons unit and DFAT in September 2003â and that the papers we have received from DFAT relating to this exchange show that Queensland policeâin providing DFAT with the context of their requestâindicated that Ms Alvarez was actually an Australian citizen? Minister, is it not the case that, at the height of the public debate in this country on the Vivian Alvarez matter, on 16 May you misled the Australian people about when your department first knew that Vivian Alvarez was an Australian citizen, and why have you not corrected the record?
âOrder! Before I call the Minister for Foreign Affairs, I remind the member for Griffith that use of the word âyouâ is to be desisted.
âYou miss Keating, donât you!
âYou think this is a laughing matter!

âWhat is a laughing matter is the way the opposition do not provide the full quote. What I actually did was make it perfectly clear in the interviews that I did on this subject that this was according to the advice I had been given by my department. It might come as an enormous surprise to the Labor Party, but bearing in mind that my department receives in Canberra 140,000 cables a year plus infinite emails I personally do not read every single piece of material that comes into my department. Actually, no minister since January 1901 ever has done.
âJust answer the question!

âThe fact is that I provided the information that had been provided to me in a written submission from my department at that time. I have asked my department to scour through their files and see whether they could find anything, and as they have found two or three pieces of information they have passed them on to the Palmer inquiry. There is nothing less and nothing more to it than that.
âWhy donât you read it out?
âOrder! The member for Griffith!
âBut to try to sex up a story like this as thoughâ
âWhy didnât you correct the record?
âThe member for Griffith has asked his question.
âsomebody has done something terribly wrong, or DFAT were involved in some sort of conspiracy to send Vivian Alvarez Solon back to the Philippinesâcome on; grow up.

âMy question is addressed to the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations. Is the minister aware of any survey results on attitudes to the governmentâs plans for a new workplace relations system? What is the ministerâs response?

talker.name: Andrews, Kevin, MP
talker.role: Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service
talker.name: Mr ANDREWS

talk.start.para: âI thank the member for Tangney for his question and can indicate to him that the response from business groups, including those many small businesses that operate in the electorate of the member for Tangney, has been overwhelmingly positive. We have also seen this deliberately misleading campaign run by the ALP and the ACTU against these reforms. Last Friday, as I told the parliament recently, we had Fran from Lane Coveâa supposed battler, who pretended to be on the minimum wage. Then, last Sunday, the ACTU released the results of a survey which showed apparent opposition to the reforms. There are some interesting things about this survey. The first thing is that the reforms were announced on 26 May. The survey was conducted from 23 to 26 May. So this was a survey showing results about reforms that had not yet been announced.

answer.para: One will also notice from the ACTUâs press release that the questionnaire used in the survey was developed by a firm called Essential Research. Essential Research is a business name for a company by the name of Essential Media CommunicationsâEMC Pty Ltd. I looked into this a bit further, and what I discovered was that EMC in Victoria operates out of a building in Carlton which is also occupied by the Communications Electrical and Plumbing Union. This union group includes the well-known Electrical Trades Union and such well-known characters as Dean Mighell. In Sydney, EMC operates out of a building in Sussex Streetâthe same building that is occupied by not just the Labor Council of New South Wales but also the New South Wales Labor Party. A search of the ASIC database reveals that EMC is owned and operated by four people. One of these people formerly worked for three unions: the ANF, the FSU and the AEU. Two of them previously worked as media officers for the Victorian Trades Hall Council; one of them, Mr Lewis, is currently a media officer for the Labor Council of New South Wales; and all four are shareholders of a company by the name of Auspoll Pty Ltd, which has been accused in the past of push polling for the Victorian ALP.

In addition to this, EMCâthe company that has conducted this surveyâhas donated money to the Australian Labor Party, it has worked on a number of ALP campaigns and it has received over $100,000 in consultancies from the Bracks Labor government. I invite members to go to EMCâs web site. They can find it at www.essentialmedia.com.au. If they are looking for a job, they will find this job description for a job which is currently going for a journalist/media relations personâsomeone, according to the job ad, who has demonstrated âa commitmentâ to social campaigning. The job ad also says:

quote.para: You will also have the opportunity to learn strategic skills including researching attitudes into social issues and developing long-term media strategies to shift public opinion.

answer.para: Honourable members interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âOrder! The House will come to order!
Mr Crean interjectingâ
âOrder! The member for Hotham is warned!

âLast week we said that the ALP and the ACTU would engage in a misleading campaign about the changes that this government proposes. What we have seen over the last few days is clear evidence of that misleading campaign.

âMy question is to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer to the fact confirmed today by the immigration department that the ministerâs own department had been advised by the Queensland police missing persons unit in September 2003 that Vivian Alvarez was actually an Australian citizen. If the minister has since discovered that his department had known for 18 months that Ms Alvarez was an Australian citizen, why didnât the minister choose to correct the public record? Minister, what action did the department take, following receipt of this information in September 2003, in order to locate Ms Alvarez in the Philippines following her illegal deportation and return her to Australia, the country of her citizenship?
âThe mock indignation is quite alarming. Actually we have set the record straight, I would have thought, becauseâ
Ms Gillard interjectingâ
âYou are still here too, are you? They are jabbering away over there in opposition, shouting away day in and day out. If I may be permitted to answer the questionâoh no, I may not.
âMr Speaker, on a point of order: could you ask the idiot minister to answer the question.
âThe member for Griffith will withdraw that. The member for Griffith will come to the microphone and withdraw.
âMr Speaker, I withdraw that reference in relation to the minister and his state of mind.

âHe seems to have lost his temper a bit today. I would have thought, bearing in mind the two questions the shadow minister has asked, that it is kind of obvious that we have made the material available. The letter from the deputy secretary of the department of immigration was actually cleared with me. It was on my desk there, I read it and I said, âYes, thatâs absolutely fine, and that letter can go out.â The opposition has got hold of itânew conspiracy theory, abuse, denigration. Look, honestly you cannot take these guys seriously.

âMr Speaker, on a point of order on relevance: the minister was asked what action he took to return Ms Alvarez Solon to Australia in the 18 months since he first knew that she was an Australian citizenâ
âThere is no point of order. The member will resume his seat.

âAs I was saying, this material has been passed to the Palmer inquiry. All of that will be looked into by the Palmer inquiry and when the Palmer inquiry reportsâwe are not doing the Palmer inquiry here; the Palmer inquiry is being done by Mick Palmerâand when it is complete even the member for Griffith will be able to read it.

âMy question is addressed to the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry. Would the minister inform the House of the importance of the governmentâs recently announced drought assistance package in sustaining farm families and rural communities in my electorate of Riverina and other drought affected areas?

talker.name: Truss, Warren, MP
talker.role: Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry
talker.name: Mr TRUSS

talk.start.para: âThe honourable member for Riverina, like all other representatives of rural electorates in Australia, is receiving positive feedback about the governmentâs $250 million boost to exceptional circumstances assistance. It has certainly been widely appreciated by rural and regional communities. It provides improved access to EC business support, a more generous assets test for the relief payment and better payments for those people who are eligible to receive this support. But the package also includes significant additional help for people in rural communitiesâ$4 million towards the family relationships program, $3 million to help the CWA with their aid program to families urgently in need and $2 million to boost financial counselling services.

answer.para: Another important part of the announcement that was made by the Prime Minister earlier this week was the commitment of $1 million a year to continue our Young People in Rural Industries Program. That is a very important initiative that has now been in operation for a few years to support young people who have in mind a career in agriculture, to help support them to develop the skills that they need to be leaders in rural communities into the future. I am delighted to welcome in the gallery today 40 participants in the fifth Young Rural Leaders Course, which is being held in Canberra at the present time. These are some of the young people whom we can expect to lead rural industry organisations in the years ahead.

I have no doubt that through this program and some of the other elements of our youth support arrangements, such as the study scholarships and the capacity to participate in projects to benefit their industry around the world, we will have a generation of young people who can drive agriculture forward. I think that young people can make a contribution to agricultural policy now. It is not just a matter for the future. They can provide a lot of the innovation and the good ideas to help build a progressive rural sector. For that reason, two young people have been included in the reference group that is looking at rural policy at the present time. In September I will convene a national forum of rural young people to talk about issues of significance and to help plan a future for agriculture in this country.

Next week is Future Farmers Week. I hope this will provide an opportunity for people to think about the contribution that young people are already making towards vibrant rural communities and about what more can be done to assist them to achieve their objectives. Our investment in drought relief is very much an investment in the future of farming. Certainly it will provide an opportunity for the next generation to achieve their objectives.

talk.start.para: âMy question is to the Prime Minister. I refer the Prime Minister to his personal representations to the Maldives president on behalf of Mr Mark Scanlon, an Australian citizen jailed for drug possession. Given that this matter was first raised publicly on 28 April 2005, can the Prime Minister advise the House which member of Mr Scanlonâs family sought his intervention in this matter and how that request was made?

âI thank the member for Canberra for her question. I will investigate that. I cannot tell you offhand, because I made those representations in September 2002. I was on my way to Nigeria for a meeting of the then Commonwealth of Nations troika, to meet the President of Nigeria and the President of South Africa to talk about Zimbabwe. I stopped off at the MaldivesâI am going on recollection hereâand I met the president. I will find out. Because there is a context to this, I make the point that, as I recall it, the manâs situation was that all avenues of appeal had been exhausted and it seemed appropriate that these representations be made. Lest anybody think that it is odd to make representations after all avenues of appeal against the death penalty have been exhausted, it is quite common for the government of this countryâthrough me, the foreign minister or the Governor-General on adviceâto make representations for a pardon.

answer.para: Without labouring the point, because I do not think it is constructive, you do these things after all avenues of appeal have been exhausted. To talk about doing them in other circumstances is clearly counterproductive. If I have got the dates wrong, I will freely acknowledge that, but that is my recollection of that case. I thought what I did was proper. From recollection, when I was asked the question last night on Lateline, I said that representation had been made by the manâs family. I will find out whether that is correct but, whether it was by his family, his friends or somebody else, not a lot turns on that. I think what turns on it is that he had exhausted all avenues of appeal and I properly made representations. I stand by that. Is the opposition suggesting I should not have done it?

talk.start.para: âMy question is addressed to the Minister for Education, Science and Training. Would the minister update the House on the governmentâs plans to ensure parents will receive plain language report cards and more information about school performance? Would he advise the House on any alternative policies?

talker.name: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP
talker.role: Minister for Education, Science and Training
talker.name: Dr NELSON

talk.start.para: âI thank the member for Hughes for her question and for the way in which she goes about promoting the very high performance of the Illawong Primary School in her electorate. Of all of the things that parents of the 3.3 million children in Australian schools want, the two that are most important to parents are standards and values. For the very first time, before this government hands over $33 billion of taxpayersâ money for the next four years to all government and non-government schools throughout the country, the conditions of that funding will have to be met. One of the conditions is that there will be plain language reports to parents. Parents are sick and tired of getting politically neutered reports from schools about the performance of their children, written in language that they cannot understand. From next year, it will be a government requirement for all Australian school reports, however information is reported to parents, to be reported in A, B, C, D and E. Parents can expect know which 25 per cent, or which one-quarter of the class, their child falls in.

answer.para: I was quite disturbed today when I read in the Daily Telegraph a report of what is happening in New South Wales government schools. It seems that the only people in the state of New South Wales that cannot find out how state schools are performing in that state are parents. It seems that the ideological bureaucrats in the education department, the hardworking public servants, the principals, the teachers unions and just about everybody else in the state of New South Wales know how every school is performing, but one group of people who are apparently cut out of the equation are the parents. The Daily Telegraph said:

quote.para: In some government agencies, operatives work in secret environments where information is shared on a âneed-to-knowâ basis and confidentiality may mean the difference between life and death. We think of organisations such as ASIO and ASIS or, internationally, Mi5, CIA and KGB.

answer.para: That is precisely the culture in New South Wales government schools. I say to the member for Hughes, to all members here and to the parents of Australia that conditions of funding for Australian schools by the Howard government will include a requirement for the performance of the school to be published.

A schoolâs performance in literacy and numeracy in years 3, 5 and 7 and teacher attendance at school will be available to parents in the broader communityâone state minister asked, âWhatâs a teacherâs attendance at school got to do with the education of children?ââas well as teacher retention rates, student attendance rates, median year 10 and year 12 results, the value added score that the school delivers and the career leaver destinations. This government is determined to see that Australian schools have high, nationally consistent standards, that the performance of the school will be known to the broader community, that parents will not be treated as mushrooms by state education departments and that parents and their children will be at the centre of the educational experience.

talk.start.para: âMy question is to the foreign minister and follows the last asked by the member for Griffith. âOrder! I again remind the Leader of the Opposition to desist from using the word âyouâ.

âFirstly, let me say in relation to the member for Griffith, I guess he got off to a bad start by not providing the full quote of what I said on the Lateline program. Secondly, I make the point that material has been referred to Mick Palmer and his inquiry in relation to Ms Alvarez. He is handling that issue and, as I understand itâand you can check with the immigration ministerâhe is looking into her case. But in terms of further cases, which he does not believe he has time to deal with, he is going to make recommendations for how they should be dealt with.
âMy question is to the Minister for Health and Ageing. Has the government increased funding for medical research? What results are being delivered?

âI thank the member for Lindsay for her question and for her strong support for the Westmead Millennium Institute for Medical Research at Westmead Hospital in Western Sydney. answer.para: The Howard government has increased health and medical research spending from $127 million in 1996 to $487 million this year. That is why we have commissioned a task force to look into how we can achieve greater commercialisation of our research, but our research output is still twice the OECD average. Good research ultimately translates into better clinical practice. And that is whyâ
Opposition members interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âTheyâve got it over there!âthe money we have spent on medical research makes the Howard government most definitely the best friend Medicare has ever had, the best Prime Minister Medicare has ever known and the best Treasurer Medicare has ever known, and I want to thank them for their support.

âMy question is to the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Transport and Regional Services. Is the minister aware of last nightâs allegations on Seven news that airside security checkpoints at Sydney airport are rarely staffed and access by a person with ill intent can be obtained by merely swiping another personâs security card? Is this is an example of the security the minister claimed yesterday puts us at the âabsolute cutting edge internationally of aviation securityâ? Minister, why arenât Australiaâs travelling public entitled to the same standard of security that protects Australian politicians at Parliament House?

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services
talker.name: Mr ANDERSON

talk.start.para: âI thank the honourable member opposite for his question because it gives me the opportunity to take the objective assessment of the security of our airports out of the political realm and draw peopleâs attention to independent experts who know more about this than the Labor Partyâand, dare I say it, perhaps a little bit more than one or two people in the mediaâand are able to offer an objective opinion.

answer.para: This morning on Radio National Fran Kelly introduced what she described as a âleading international security analystâ and said that that person had largely dismissed a classified Australian Customs report which claims that Sydney airport is a security shambles. That person is Mr Neil Fergus. Mr Neil Fergus ran the intelligence unit for the Sydney Olympics, and I think it would be said that the world looked on at the way in which the whole thing was conducted and congratulated Australia for its security arrangements. He works internationally as a consultant with his firm, Intelligent Risks. That consulting firm has carried out security analysis for at least 40 major international airports worldwide. That is not a bad record. He says that, while no airport can ever be 100 per cent security tightâa point that I acknowledged in this place yesterdayâAustraliaâs comes fairly close. He said:

quote.para: I am hard-stretched to think of another airport internationally that is of a similar standard to Sydney or Melbourne in relation to these matters.

answer.para: In the current climate, where there is always the risk of sensationalism and politicisation of aviation security, I think it is relevant to hear from a respected international observer.

I would furthermore note that the United States transport security agency reviewed antiterrorism arrangements at Sydney airport last year and gave it a clean bill of health. Later this year ICAO will undertake another audit at Sydney airport. Because I think it is important, in the context of community concerns, to address those issues that might be worrying people and to do so in a way that is objective and transparent, I indicated this morning on the John Laws program that I intend to engage an internationally respected aviation security expert to provide us with a comprehensive overview of security arrangements at our airports over coming weeks. I do not believe that anything could be more transparent or more reasonable than that.

Yesterday in this place I charged the Leader of the Opposition and the shadow minister, who asked the question with what I believe is an entirely legitimate point, that, while ever they come into this place ahead of seeking the briefings that we freely offer on aviation security they are guilty of the charge that they seek to politicise rather than to address security issues. Yesterday, after question time and after the MPI when they said they did not want a briefing, they wrote to me saying that they do want one. I am glad about that. We have set it up for four oâclock this afternoon. Everyone who could be relevant to this will be there, including Customs, and I am awaiting an indication from the shadow minister and Leader of the Opposition as to whether they will actually take up that offer.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services
talker.name: Mr ANDERSON

talk.start.para: âI thank the honourable member for his question in relation to the Customs report. I want to make a couple of points about that. He said that the document reported in yesterdayâs Australian newspaper was an assessment of potential high-risk areas and employee groups that was carried out in late 2003 and completed in early 2004, confirming what I said in this place yesterday that the research was carried out at a time when we were indeed respondingâ

âThe Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat. The Deputy Prime Minister is coming to the question.

answer.para: On the claim overnight in relation to an individual at Sydney airport with a previous drugs conviction, I am advised at this point in timeâand I seek to make the point clear that I am advised and I can only report to the best of my knowledgeâthat there are potentially two individuals who might have fitted that category. One no longer has an ASIC. The other does. It relates to an offence committed in about 1980. The individual involved served his time and a number of years lapsed, resulting in that conviction having been spent. In those circumstances, under state and Commonwealth lawâas I think the Leader of the Opposition and, I hope, the shadow minister who asked the former question would knowâtheir previous misdemeanours must be overlooked. I think the Leader of the Opposition tacitly acknowledged this morning that there are very real issues here that go to the heart of our justice system and the way in which we regard people who have served time for misdemeanours. In those circumstances, I pose this question now to the Leader of the Opposition: can we look forward to support from the union movement and from the Labor Party if it becomes necessary to change that legislation?

talk.start.para: âMy question is addressed to the Attorney-General. Would the Attorney-General advise the House of the governmentâs policy initiatives to boost volunteer organisations and communities involved in emergency management?

âI thank the member for Macquarie for his question because, like many of us, he is acutely aware of the sacrifices and commitment of emergency volunteers in protecting the lives and homes of people, particularly in bushfire prone areas. The government has taken major steps in delivering on its election commitment to support volunteers and local councils involved in emergency management across Australia.

answer.para: Following extensive consultation, today I have released the guidelines for two new funding programs under the governmentâs $49 million Working Together to Manage Emergencies initiative. The funding available in this program will include $33 million under the local grant scheme, and that assists local councils to take a strategic approach to disaster management by developing risk management and community safety strategies. There is also a $16 million national volunteer support fund to provide grants directly to volunteer organisations working at the front-line of emergency management to assist with training, equipment and recruitment.

The new funding programs will be managed by Emergency Management Australia. More information, including the guidelines, is now available from the EMA web site. Applications for the first round close on 29 July. I would simply say that this practical support from the government demonstrates the value that we place on local governments and volunteers in building capacity in our community to respond to emergencies of all types. I am sure that members will join with me in encouraging hardworking emergency volunteer organisations and councils committed to keeping our communities safe to see how these initiatives can help them in their very important work.

talk.start.para: âMy question is to the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry. The member for Calare and I have had numerous concerns raised concerning farmers in their second year of exceptional circumstances who have had approval for the 50 per cent interest subsidy being ineligible for the 80 per cent subsidy as announced on Monday. Apparently, contrary to the ministerâs web site, the Rural Assistance Authority have been advising farmers in those circumstances that they are ineligible. Can the minister publicly remove the confusion and inform the House of the real position?

talker.name: Truss, Warren, MP
talker.role: Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry
talker.name: Mr TRUSS

talk.start.para: âThe honourable member has referred to what will be a relatively small group of people who are in their second or third year of EC declaration and who have already claimed an interest subsidy and received a 50 per cent subsidy according to the old guidelines. I can confirm to the House that those people will be entitled to a supplement, so they will receive an extra 30 per cent interest subsidy under the arrangements that the Prime Minister announced earlier this week. I will need to prepare for each of the states a new set of guidelines so that they are able to administer the new arrangements under the more generous conditions. Naturally, that has not been completed as yet, but that will be done as quickly as possible so that any doubt can be removed in the minds of those who are administering the scheme. But I can confirm to all members in the House that that small number of people who have received a 50 per cent payment in the second and third year are eligible for a top-up.

âMy question is addressed to the Minister for Workforce Participation. Would the minister inform the House of the benefits of Work for the Dole to job seekers and the wider community? Are there any alternative views?
âThe interjections have started already about Work for the Dole.

answer.para: Opposition members interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âThe Labor Party hate Work for the Dole, donât they! What they hate about it is that it has been one of the most successful programs the Howard government has ever run, and that is a fair claim because there have been plenty. But can I say thank you very much to the member for Braddon for his question. He is already helping to lift participation rates in his electorate and helping forestry workers stay in their jobs. He is helping local communities to work with Work for the Dole projects. The member for Braddon was very pleased, as I was, with the result of the Work for Dole team who renovated playground equipment at the Leighland Christian School in east Ulverstone. Participants there learnt formwork, concreting and paving. I am told that the kids at the school were absolutely rapt with their renovated play gear.

answer.para: This program provides young people and mature age people with an excellent opportunity to increase their work experience to show employers that they are genuine about getting a job. I cannot for the life of me understand why it is that the Labor Party now are up to 330 times where one person or another on the other side has criticised the Work for the Dole program.
Opposition members interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âYou should be serious about helping Australians into work. So why donât you get out of the way of blocking Work for the Dole and adopt it as an excellent program and follow in the footsteps of this government?
âMr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.
âMr Speaker, I seek the indulgence of the chair to add to an answer.
âThe Prime Minister may proceed.

âI have sought some further information on the answer I gave to the member for Canberra. It does not fundamentally alter what I said, but perhaps I can supply a bit more information. It is true, as I have recollected, that during a stopover in the Maldives, in fact at Male International Airport in September 2002, I raised Mr Scanlonâs case with the Maldives foreign minister. Subsequently, a pardon was granted and, on 24 October 2002, I wrote to the President thanking him for the pardon for Mr Scanlon. In that letter I said:

quote.para: I am in no way sympathetic towards drugs and consider it important that countries take effective measures against them. The Australian government and I supported Mr Scanlanâs application for a pardon, however, because of the severity of the sentence and because he has expressed remorse for his actions.

speech.para: The background is that on 12 September 2000 Mr Scanlan was sentenced to life imprisonment for the importation of 57.1 grams of hashish oil. The government sought independent advice from the Judicial Commission of New South Wales, who told us that a likely sentence for the offence in Australia was not more than 12 months. The government took the view that, once that period had elapsed, it was appropriate for a pardon to be sought. Representations were made by the Department of Foreign Affairs on Mr Scanlonâs behalf. I have checked the files, and I in fact did receive a personal letter in 2002 from the manâs wife. So my recollection was correct that she had written to me. Prior to that, I understand that the lawyers for Mr Scanlon, on request from Mr Scanlonâs familyâhe had an elderly mother as well as a wife; I am not sure about childrenâhad made representations to the Department of Foreign Affairs.

All I can say is that broadly the recollection of the events that I gave last night was, to the best of my knowledge, accurate. As to its comparison with other casesâand I will use the genericâI simply make the point that these representations were made after there had been admissions of guilt and remorse expressed and a comparable sentence in Australian terms had been served. I think it is important to make the point that, if the pre-condition of an approach for a pardon or for an exercise of presidential or royal clemency is an admission of guilt, that ought to be borne in mind if people call on the government in particular cases to make applications for clemency.

talk.start.para: âI ask the Prime Minister to table the documents from which he is quoting.
âI am perfectly happy to do that and to table the foreign affairs paper too. I do not mind. I will show them to the Leader of the Opposition.
âCan I briefly add to a question that was asked of me by the member for McPherson in relation to Indonesia. I said during the answer to the question that we had been concerned about an attackâ

speech.para: Opposition members interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âOrder!

âI said during the answer to that question that we were concerned about a suspicious parcel which had been received by the Indonesian embassy. I can advise the House now that an envelope was taken to a laboratory at the Canberra Hospital for further analysis at 12.25 today. The initial analysis of the powder has tested positive as a biological agent, though further testing will need to be carried out to determine what that substance actually is. As such, there is a possibility that the Indonesian embassy will be shut down for quite some period of time and that the 22 staff will remain in isolation for the next 48 hours.

speech.para: I would like to extend the Houseâs concernâall of usâabout this, our condemnation of this action and our hope that none of the staff will have in any way been harmed. We give our assurance that Australian authorities, be they federal or ACT authorities, will do all they can to provide assistance to the Indonesians.

talk.start.para: âOn indulgence, the Labor Party completely support the remarks and the tone of the statement by the Minister for Foreign Affairs on the incident that has occurred at the Indonesian embassy. This is a disgraceful act to be condemned by all Australians. It is very necessary, I think, to learn from this, and people should view the circumstances now surrounding the particular case which may have generated this incident with a bit of calm, dispassion and commonsense. There is no doubt at all that this is a very serious thing to have happened.

speech.para: If the circumstances are that a biological agent was sent to the Indonesian embassy, it would be the first instance of that occurring in this country and would amount to an extremely serious development indeed. This is a situation which no doubt the government will want to keep the House apprised of as time goes by; but, in the meantime, there should be absolutely no doubt in the public mind at all that the House is of a combined and united view that this sort of outrageous behaviour must not be encouraged and that an atmosphere which encourages it must not be sustained.

talk.start.para: âI have received a letter from the honourable member for Lilley proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

quote.para: The failure of the policies of the Treasurer to improve the international competitiveness of the Australian economy as measured by the failure to narrow the current account deficit and control spiralling foreign debt.

subdebate.1.para: I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their placesâ

talk.start.para: âThe complacency and the arrogance of the Howard government and the Treasurer were on display today and yesterday for all Australians to see. We are now living with the consequences of their failure to invest in the future and their failure to ensure that prosperity will continue for generations to come. There is an old saying that luck never gives, it only lends. The problem we have now is that this country has borrowed too much and we are mortgaging our future. We are mortgaging our future because of the complacency of the Treasurer and the Prime Minister and their failure to admit that we have a serious problem with our current account deficit and with foreign debt.

speech.para: The growth that this country has enjoyed over the last 14 years has been the product of extremely good work by past Labor governments. The reforms of the Hawke-Keating period provided the productivity that was required for wealth to double. Labor made the investments in the future, which have now been run down by this government. What is evident to all when we look at the national accounts and at yesterdayâs current account deficit and foreign debt figures is that this government is now surfing on the benefits of the best terms of trade in 30 years. In that environment how do we actually secure an outcome where we have a record current account deficit and record foreign debt? This complacent government has been living off the legacy of the past reforms of the Hawke-Keating government and is now living off the legacy of the very favourable terms of trade and squandering opportunities to invest in the future. The results of that are out there today for everybody to see.

In the last 12 months we have had an economic growth rate with a one in front of itâa full two percentage points less than the average growth rate of the last decade. Productivity growth has declined by 2.4 per centâthe worst figures in 19 years. Exports continue to detract from economic growth, with the last successive positive contribution coming in June 2001. Household savings still remain negative and now foreign debt has surged by a massive $46 billion to $425 billion. On top of that, we have a current account deficit which has widened from six per cent to 7.2 per cent of GDP.

These astonishing results have occurred at a time when we are really experiencing what you could call a 21st century gold rush, with the best terms of trade in 30 years. In that environment we can only manage a growth rate with a one in front of it and we are still borrowing more from the rest of the world to get by. Only a Treasurer as complacent, as smug and as out of touch as this one could stand up like he did today and say that that was a good result. But Labor says it is not good enough. We ought to be achieving better growth rates. Productivity growth should be growing strongly, not falling. Exports should be contributing to economic growth, not detracting from it. Household savings should be in the black, not in the red. Foreign debt needs to be brought under control and, most certainly, the current account deficit needs to be narrowed. Our future prosperity depends on these things, yet this Treasurer and his government continue to leave their heads in the sand.

In the last two days we have seen two releases from the ABS: the national accounts and balance of payment. As I said before, we are enjoying a historic terms of trade boom. The figures today have confirmed that, in the last 12 months, the terms of trade have lifted by 7.6 per cent. This has meant that income is growing at twice the rate of production. Despite these extraordinary positive external conditions, the economy has these extraordinary imbalances. Consumption is running well ahead of production; consumption continues to run ahead of income; and, despite the resources boom, imports continue to outstrip exports and detract from growth, taking something like 0.3 per cent off growth in the last quarter. In this period the Australian manufacturing sectorâs output has shrunk by 0.9 per cent.

Productivity growth has been going backwards every quarter for the past year. Productivity growth fell by 2.4 per cent in the year to Marchâthe worst result in 19 years. Yesterday we also had the announcement of the biggest current account deficit and the biggest foreign debt in the history of this country. Think about thatâthe biggest ever. Nothing highlights the lack of competitiveness of this economy as much as the external accounts. But donât take my word for it; letâs see what the Treasurer and the Prime Minister have had to say about this in the past. In 1995, John Howard told Alan Jones:

quote.para: You see, foreign debt is a direct consequence of the fact that our economy is not functioning in a modern efficient manner.

speech.para: Very true, Treasurer, it certainly is. All of those imbalances are there for people to see in the national accounts today. When the Prime Minister made that comment, net foreign debt was $180 billionâless than half of the $425 billion that we see today. That foreign debt of $425 billion represents $21,056 for every man, woman and child in this country. Donât we all remember the Prime Minister and the Treasurer at the launch of the âdebt truckâ? Just imagine how big that truck has to be today. It is going to be a road train today. It is more than twice what it was when we heard these comments from the Treasurer and the Prime Minister.

Of course, the problem is not just with our exports or just that our imports are surging; we are borrowing more and more every year just to pay interest on our debt, with nothing from this government to fix the problem. The fastest-growing parts of the economy are increasingly being owned by overseas companies. While improved exports will help to rebalance net goods and services, the flow of profits from foreign owned exporters is worsening the income deficit all of the time. This is very clearly a serious structural problem in our economy.

Where does it take us? When you have a current account deficit like this and a foreign debt like this, both of which are continuing to grow, they put upward pressure on interest rates. We saw the complacent and arrogant denial of that by the Prime Minister and the Treasurer in this House today. But back in 1996 they said, absolutely, that a current account deficit of those levels would produce upward pressure on interest rates. You might recall talk about a banana republic when the current account deficit was at six per cent of GDP. Well, Treasurer, who is the chimp with the banana now? You have a current account deficit at 7.2 per cent of GDP and there is not the slightest doubt that interest rates in this country are far higher because of your neglect and your head-in-the-sand approach towards the current account deficit and foreign debt.
It gets worse. Let us look at what the Prime Minister had to say in February 1995. He said:

quote.para: Six per cent is a ... very bad figure. Itâs an extremely bad figure. Our foreign debt exposure is alarming. There can be no other description for it. It is alarming.

speech.para: Today foreign debt is at 7.2 per cent of GDP. Listen to this one. On 10 May 1995 he said:

quote.para: If you really want to fix Australiaâs current account deficit problem over the long term, you have got to fix the supply bottlenecks in the Australian economy and make us more productive and competitive.

speech.para: Those who have a memory that goes back longer than a few weeks would understand that the Treasury and the Prime Minister have continuously denied in this House that there has been a problem with supply bottlenecks or capacity constraints in the economy. They could barely utter the word âinfrastructureâ until recent weeks, when they were put under considerable pressure by Labor. We heard that word, probably almost for the first time, pass the lips of the Treasurer here yesterday.

Of course, Treasurer, productivity is being held back by infrastructure bottlenecks in the economy and by the skills crisisâand your government fails to act. The government continually puts its head in the sand. Let us judge your actions by your previous standards. Here is another quote from the then Leader of the Opposition, the current Prime Minister. He said:

quote.para: But look, the Government has been there for 12 years, and they and they alone, have to wear the responsibility for the mess that the current account is in, and the fact that Australian borrowers pay the highest real interest rates in the Western world.

speech.para: It was good enough for you to say then that the former Prime Minister ought to bear responsibility for the highest interest rates in the Western world and a high current account, but you will not accept responsibility for it today. Treasurer, you are always happy to claim credit when there is good news around but when there is bad news around, you are missing in actionâjust as you were missing in action yesterday.

talk.start.para: (Hon. IR Causley)âThe member for Lilley will address members by their titles.

âI must compliment you, Treasurer: for the first time in three years you have come into the House for an MPI. That is a welcome move towards some form of accountability. This government is responsible for the current account. It is responsible for its bad shape and it is responsible for the upward pressure that it is putting on interest rates. You are absolutely responsible, Treasurer.
âThe member for Lilley will address members by their titles.

âThe Treasurer is absolutely responsible, but the problem goes further. I want to talk a little bit about debt servicing. We saw the hypocrisy of the Prime Minister when he came into the House yesterday and lectured us about the current account deficit and how foreign debt could be dismissed because we could afford to service it. We have done a bit of research on the claims that the Prime Minister made yesterday. We went back to his previous statements. On 28 February 1996 he said of the then Prime Minister:

quote.para: And Paul Keating has entered the denial phase about the foreign debt. ... He now says foreign debt really doesnât matter. ... He thinks he will define the problem away by pretending that it doesnât exist.

speech.para: Who is doing that now? The problem is that the Prime Minister cannot tell the truth.

talk.start.para: âThe member for Lilley will withdraw that.

âHe cannot get his facts straight about the state of our foreign debt. Let us put the Prime Ministerâs denial to one side. The debt servicing ratio on our stock of foreign debt is around the same today as it was in March 1996 when the present Treasurer and the Prime Minister were asserting that there was a foreign debt crisis.

speech.para: The facts are these. In the March quarter 2005 interest payments on our stock of foreign debt amounted to $5.2 billion or 13.2 per cent of goods and services credits. In March 1996 interest payments on our stock of foreign debt amounted to 13.4 per cent of goods and services credits. So the truth is, in the Prime Ministerâs own terms, the serviceability of the debt is no different to that time when the Treasurer was shredding the Keating government for their alleged failure to deal with a current account crisis and record foreign debt.

The comments today from Standard and Poorâs expose the government. They expose the governmentâs complacency towards the risk to interest rates and the economy posed by the current account deficit. On top of this we have the government coming into the House and claiming that somehow they are friends of the workers. The Treasurer over there claims that he has blue denim in his veins and that he is a working-class man. On radio in Brisbane he admitted that workers on $40,000 to $46,000 are struggling. Treasurer, if they are struggling why donât you give them a decent tax cut? Why are you not prepared to do something about it? You are so embarrassed by that imbalance.

talk.start.para: âThe member for Lilley!

âThe Treasurer is so embarrassed by that imbalance. He drags this dead cat of procedural issues across the tax debate because he does not want to debate the substantive question. He is running away from it all the time. The government is no friend of the worker. The truth is this: no Prime Minister in Australian history has done more to create the battlers, and no Prime Minister in Australian history has done less to help them. This fact has been exposed day in and day out in this parliament, particularly by the member for Perth and the Leader of the Opposition, when they rip to shreds your proposals on industrial relations. Your attack on the minimum wage says much more about where you sit and the governmentâs values than anything else. The government is prepared to rip the guts out of the minimum wage and get rid of the no disadvantage test. The government is prepared to take away the bargaining power of the Australian work force and rip away the capacity of organised labour to stand up for those who need some help.

speech.para: What follows from that is your misuse of NATSEM data. The truth is that, under your government, those on very high incomes have done very well and are doing better all the time; those on middle incomes are being splitâsome are doing well and some are going backwards; and the poor are getting poorer all the time. No amount of misuse of NATSEM data can obscure that. When you go to the Australian Bureau of Statistics, the tax statistics and the NATSEM reports you can see that this government is very strong on controlling the weak, very weak on controlling the strong and failing to invest in the future. talk.start.para: âThis is a discussion of a matter of public importance which alleges failures of policy to improve international competitiveness. The one thing the member for Lilley did not talk about was international competitiveness. He referred to no index of international competitiveness; he gave no benchmarking of Australia against other countries; he gave no analysis of where Australia is now, compared to where it was; and, of course, he put forward no policy to improve international competitiveness. The member for Lilley read out a written text which had obviously been prepared for him. It was one of those diatribes that you might get away with at the Lilley FEC in front of undoubtedly the very few branch membersâif there are anyâwho attend the Lilley FEC. They would sit there and say: âDidnât he reaffirm our prejudices today. What can we take out of that speech? He does not like Mr Howard and he does not like Mr Costello. That is what we wanted to hear.â

speech.para: People in the press who may be asking whether the member for Lilley will cut it as a shadow frontbencher might actually be asking a different question. They might ask: if the member for Lilley wanted to raise a matter of public importance on Australiaâs international competitiveness then surely, since he got to write the motion, he would raise questions of competitiveness, he would benchmark Australia on the international competitiveness index, he would find out where Australia is falling behind, he would offer policies as to how Australia could move up, and he would lay out the Australian Labor Partyâs blueprint for what should happen with the Australian economy and economic management. That is what people in the press would have been asking themselves when they were listening to his speech today.
