The second thing they would be asking is: why was the matter of public importance today on the balance of payments and current account when those figures came out yesterday? If this was such a great crisis, if this was a matter of absolute urgency, would we not have been discussing this yesterday rather than today? I can disclose that the Labor Party tactics committee is concerned that the member for Lilley is squibbing question time. He has not asked a question about the budget since the budget was delivered. There is so much concern in the tactics group of the Australian Labor Party that the member for Lilley was virtually ordered to put the MPI on the agenda today and get down to the House to try and recover some of the Australian Labor Partyâs lost credibility.

Five shadow Treasurersâone with two incarnationsâhave been put up by the Australian Labor Party in the time that I have been Treasurer. I know that comparisons are odious. I do not want to compare the member for Lilleyâs performance to that of his predecessors, but I will say that not one of them failed to asked a question after a budget. I have delivered 10 budgets. This is the first time the shadow Treasurer has failed to asked a question after the budget. This will undoubtedly go down as something of a record.

Let me come to the essence of the diatribe that was put forward by the member for Lilley. It began with this proposition: âThe Australian economy is strong and is run well, and that is all to the credit of Bob Hawke and Paul Keating, but if it is not strong and not running well, if the current account deficit is too high, that is all to the credit of the Prime Minister and the Treasurer. So weâve got you covered both ways. If itâs good, itâs all the Labor Partyâs good work, but if it is bad, itâs all the coalitionâs work.â I think that is the essence of it. Once you state that proposition, you see immediately the inherent contradictions of the whole thing.

The member for Lilley was full of quotes and had a preplanned joke in relation to banana republics. I remind the member for Lilley that âbanana republicâ was not this governmentâs expression, it was not the current Prime Ministerâs expression and it was not an expression of mine. It was in fact the then Labor Treasurer Paul Keatingâs description of the state of the Australian economy under his watch and his management. He was at least more honest in his assessment of how things were going when he was there than the member for Lilley is nine years after the event. Banana republic was a description which the then Treasurer Mr Keating applied back in 1986. Let me remind the House that in 1986 the budget was not in surplus; it was two per cent in deficit. In todayâs terms that would be a budget deficit of around $18 billion. We did not have inflation at two per cent in March 1986. The inflation rate in March 1986 was 9.3 per cent. Inflation! I am not talking about a mortgage rate.

The member for Lilley today wants to complain that interest rates are high because the standard variable mortgage interest rate is 7.3 per cent. Let me remind the House that in March 1986 the mortgage interest rate was not 7.3 per cent; it was 13.5 per cent. At least the then Treasurer, Mr Keating, was forthright in his analysis. But his analysis would not have been the analysis of the member for Lilley that he was a brilliant economic manager who nine years after the event is responsible for low inflation, low interest rates, a growing economy, a balanced budget and net debt which is close to zero. No, he was much more forthright in his analysis. The description that he gave is the one that the member for Lilley now repeats.

The critical point here is that when this government was putting in place the measures which locked in low interest rates, which locked in budget surpluses and which retired debt, the Australian Labor Party did not say in genuine bipartisanship, âThe Australian Labor Party will support you.â We were fought every step of the way. Let me go through it. In 1996 the budget was in deficit by two per cent of GDP. I announced that this government would balance the budget. The Australian Labor Party opposed the balancing of the Australian budget. They said that if we balanced our budget Australia would go into recession.

I well remember that in 1996 the opposition were not just in here; there was a riot led by building workers who stormed Parliament House after a rally addressed by the Leader of the Opposition, who fired them up. They came down to the House, they broke down the front doors and they came into the House. Why? They were protesting against the balancing of the Australian budget. That is why. Nine years after the event the Labor Party say, âWe were always in favour of a balanced budget.â You are always in favour of it after it is done, but during the work the Australian Labor Party opposed it.

Let me go to monetary policy. In 1996 I announced, in an agreement with the Governor of the Reserve Bank, that we would inflation target our monetary policy, with underlying inflation at two to three per cent over the cycle, and that we would put monetary policy on a new basis. When I appointed the new Governor of the Reserve Bank and entered into that agreement, did the Australian Labor Party support that? Let me remind the member for Lilley that the then shadow Treasurerâsomebody who was perhaps of a standard different from him, and I do not speak favourably of the member for LilleyâGareth Evans, announced that this was an illegal agreement contrary to statute and that the Australian Labor Party would take legal action against the government to undo it. That is what the Australian Labor Party said in relation to inflation targeting for an independent monetary policy. As it turns out, I am still waiting for the writ to be served on me. They are legal proceedings that have never been taken. After it was done, the Australian Labor Party appeared on the scene of the crime and said, âWe were always in favour of inflation targetingâand the fact that it has worked and brought interest rates down is all the good work of Paul Keating.â

Let us go through the unemployment record in relation to the Australian Labor Party. I hear the Australian Labor Party say, âOur economic position is all the good work of Mr Keating and Mr Hawke,â but there is one fact that appears to have been completely airbrushed out of the record. What has been airbrushed out of the record is that in 1990 Mr Keatingâs great legacy to this economy, as he said himself, was giving it the recession it had to haveâputting a million people out of work. You never actually hear that. Let me ask the member for Lilley this question because it has always puzzled me: if the low unemployment that we enjoy today is all the good work of the Hawke-Keating government, if they could produce low unemployment under a coalition government, why did they not produce low unemployment under a Labor government?

That was a cunning plan, wasnât it? They were always capable of producing low unemployment but they decided to withhold it from their own record and bequeath it to the Liberal party. We really do owe the Hawke-Keating government a lot. It was another one of their cunning plans. But of course the reality is that they would have produced low unemployment if they could have kept the economy out of recession in 1990. They may have been able to do it. But they could not keep the economy out of recession. In fact, they now boast that they wanted it to go into recession and produce the recession we had to have. It was not that the Keating government was against producing low unemployment under Labor; it was because they could not. It was not some cunning plan to delay all of the fruits of good economic management; it was an inability to produce these outcomes under their economic management. If you really want to go to the druthers of Mr Keating, he now says it was a good thing to produce a recession. We on this side of the House have never believed that a recession is a good thingâthat it is a good thing to put people out of work.

Let me come to real wages. I was in this House then. I used to sit on the opposition benches and see the then Treasurer walk to the dispatch box. His proudest boast under Labor was that they had reduced real wages. That was his proudest boast. He used to say, âWe have restored the profit share and we have reduced real wages. This will make the Australian economy a better economy.â Real wages have increased under this government by 14 per cent. Again, the member for Lilley will say that that is all the good work of Paul Keating. Wasnât that a cunning planâto delay increases in real wages until they occurred under a coalition government? They fell under Labor.

I do not know whether the member for Lilley actually believes these propositions. When he went to white bread training school they said to him, âRepeat endlessly a proposition even if you do not believe it until everybody else thinks that you doââas he did in relation to the $600 payment. Recall the $600 payment? It did not exist. It was not real money. After he had repeated that enough times he may have believed it himself, but the families of Australia do not believe it because they are getting that $600 on an annual basis. This is the government that increased real wages. It was not the Labor government. This was, presumably, again some cunning plan by Labor to be in favour of real wage increases, produce real wage decreases and then allow the coalition government to take the credit for that policy after Labor had left office.

The reality is this: that the Hawke and Keating governmentsâand I have always said itâdid some good things. The first thing they did was to reduce tariffs. But, of course, the moment Labor went into opposition and I tried to decrease tariffs the Australian Labor Party opposed it and voted against it, including the tariff cut which occurred on 1 January. The second thing that they did was to allow the Reserve Bank to float the dollar. One of the consequences of that is the dollar goes up and the dollar goes down. One of the difficulties that the exporters of Australia have at the moment is that the Australian dollar is high. Nonetheless, that is a difficulty for the Australian exporters; it does not mean we should reverse the policy.

In wrapping up this debate, I say that the member for Lilleyâs contribution was diatribe and sloganeering but showed no real understanding of economic policy. Labor lost the last election because they did not understand economic policy. At this rate they are well on their way to losing the next election if they do not pick up their economic policy. There is one big test for the member for Lilley: to let those tax cuts through if he wants to get credibility on the Australian economy. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âVirtually on his own admission, we have just heard from the Blackadder of the Australian parliament, supported by, in arguing as he did about cunning plansâ
(Hon. IR Causley)âThe member for Blaxland will withdraw that comment.
âMr Deputy Speaker, it is hardly unparliamentary.
âThe member for Blaxland will withdraw the comment.

âI will withdraw the comment that the Treasurer is the Blackadder of the Australian parliament, despite the fact that he quoted from that show at length about cunning plans in relation to the former government and the way it operated. I would also point out that this is one of the very few occasions, if not the only occasion, when he has come to the dispatch box on an MPI to defend his government and his record supported by a group of people behind him that you could fit into a police callbox. That was about all there were. Where is the rest of the support from the government for this Treasurerâs attempted defence of his governmentâs record and what it has done economically?

speech.para: The Treasurer attempted to give us a historical but gave us a somewhat hysterical overview of what his government has done and where the Keating and Hawke governments were supposed to be wrong. Treasurer, sorry, I was not in the House prior to 1996, but from 2 January 1985 I did in fact work in the then Treasurerâs electorate office, I did have a fairly close view of just what economic problems this country faced and I did note, given that I have been around the Australian Labor Party since the age of 15 or so, what we had to contend with as a government when we came to office. The problem with real wages, which you absolutely distortâ

talk.start.para: âThe member for Blaxland will refer to members by their titles.

âI have used Treasurer, but not generically. The problem with real wages, which you, Treasurer, have distorted, is one that flowed directly out of the Howard and Fraser period. In 1982-83 there was a massive surge in wage inflation, and that surge was led by the strongest unions in Australia, and the then government allowed it to take off. That pushed Australia, firstly, into a great inflationary period and, secondly, into a massive recession. We also know that there were great problems faced as a result of debt created by the Fraser government with the member for Bennelong as the then Treasurer. By the end of his term he achieved something that no-one would ever want to achieveâthe trifecta in economic performance: double digit interest rates, unemployment rates and inflation rates. Not only did he achieve that trifecta to the detriment of the Australian economy and drive Australiaâs economy into recessionâsomething which the Treasurer points out as often as he can when dealing with this issue at question timeâbut also he created a situation where, with $9.6 billion worth of debt in one year, which is equivalent in todayâs terms to $35 billion, the Australian economy was crushed and the problems compounded.

speech.para: We, on coming into government, had to deal with it. The Treasurer was disingenuous in all the points of his arguments on what the core problems, as he sees it, were in the Hawke and Keating period. But what did the Treasurer attempt to do and succeed in doing by dealing with that catalogue of complaints that he hadâwhat he called cunning stratagems and so on? What he succeeded in doing was to move away from the key elements of this MPI. The key element is not international competitiveness. The key elements are the current account deficit and foreign debt. It is impossible for any Treasurer of this country to walk away from the fact that the current account deficit has spiralled out of control. To add $15.6 billion in just one quarter this year leads to a concern not just from this opposition but also from Standard and Poorâs, the rating agency, which indicated in yesterdayâs Australian that we should worry about that fact. Allied to that is the fact that not only have we gone to a record 7.25 per cent in the current account deficit but also we have a record $424.6 billion in foreign debt.

The Treasurer tells us: âDonât worry about that. There is only about $6 billion left in net Commonwealth debt.â Let me tell you, Treasurerâyou should know because you were here when last we were in governmentâthat we had it down to about $17 billion of net Commonwealth debt. When you get yourself into a precipitous situation, where you are not really careful about what you are doing, where you just blithely say, âAll care but only a little responsibility,â and where you say that no government should really be concerned about the impact of the current account deficit and foreign debt and there are not really any measures that you can take to fix it, you have to worry. Standard and Poorâs are somewhat worried about this. Their analyst Sharad Jain said that Australiaâs foreign debt is now about 2Â½ times the size of its total international earnings from exports and investments. He said:

quote.para: This is pretty high for a AAA-rated country ... It is 50 to 60 per cent more than any other country with a AAA credit rating.

speech.para: There is your international comparison, Treasurer. The other international comparison which you, as Treasurer, are wont to give us is here as well. Which two countries does Australia compare with in current account deficit? They are Bulgaria and Hungary. The current account deficit will go to 7.3 per cent of gross domestic product next year. Bulgaria will be out and you will have only Hungary left. With Bulgaria out of the action, there will be no other countries with worse current account deficits than Australia and Hungary.
What did the current Prime Minister say all those many years ago on 28 February 1996 about the former Treasurer and Prime Minister?

quote.para: He began to enter the denial stage about foreign debt. He now says foreign debt - debt really doesnât matter. He said debt is not so bad as long as you can service it. I mean that is the classic response that somebody who has been there so long and has been so unable to find a solution to something. He thinks he will define the problem away by pretending that it doesnât exist.

speech.para: At question time today, Treasurer, that is exactly what you did. There are two key things that you have not done. In all that catalogue of complaints about what we supposedly did not do when we were last in government, there are two things you have not done.

talk.start.para: âThe member for Blaxland is straying again.

âYou have not concerned yourself as Treasurer to the key problem of how you increase Australian skills through the training of Australia people. This country could combat the current account deficit if we had trained enough people in the skilled trades area to make up for the current shortfall. Instead of this government importing people en masse from overseasânot just through the immigration program but through a specific program using the four-year temporary entry permitsâto cover that gap, this country could not only cover that problem but export our capacity, export our people into the region and earn income from overseas to balance our account. That is one key thing that this government could be doing. It has been missing in action since 1996.

speech.para: The second key area that this government could be attacking is the broader problem it has in manufactured goods coming out of Australia. Part of the problem with the current account, our foreign debt and dealing with this countryâs economy is that we are coming off the back of a significant increase in commodity prices in Australia. That means a commodity driven Australian dollar has been driven up and added to those problems. One of the ways in which you can fight back against that is to produce more in this country and to sell it overseas.

From 1983 to 1996 the increase in elaborately transformed manufactures from Australia was dramatic. It formed the core of Australiaâs increased productivity and increased export capacity. It is not enough to flog off raw materials to China at higher prices and say, âIsnât it wonderful that we are getting products back that mean that Australian people pay less.â We should be training Australian tradespeople to work and produce in Australia so that we do not have to bring in more from overseas. We should be training those people so that they can earn foreign income to cut back the current account deficit and reduce the massive foreign debt of $424.6 billion. This Treasurer and this government stand condemned because they have not dealt with these key and fundamental problemsâand they deserve the censure of this House. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âThis afternoon I follow the member for Blaxland with an element of trepidation. His record as an electorate officer for the former Prime Minister leaves me under significant pressure to come up with meaningful economic data to match the record of the previous Labor Prime Minister and the legacy he left behind. I will do my best. I will do three things today. The first is an attempt to disentangle this somewhat clumsy MPI into comments on the current account deficit and comments on foreign debt and then to finish with a few international comparisons, because I think that they have been sadly lacking today.

speech.para: Hearing the two members from the other side, a term came back to me from my former career in medicine when I would sometimes examine fairly frail medical cases. There was a condition known as âshifting dullnessâ. What we are seeing today from the other side is evidence over the last few months of picking and choosing one or two pieces of economic data in isolation and attempting to build a case around it. That form of shifting dullness simply is not going to stick. What we heard from the first speaker on the other side, the member for Lilley, was effectively an attempt to clutch at economic terms such as âincome debitsâ, âproductivity being held backâ, âabsolute growth okay but growth rates fallingâ, âgoods and services creditsâ, âexternal accountsââterms that do not mean very much to Australians, terms that do not cause any real sense of concern in the household. What the other side have lost sight of in this debate, and the MPI in general, is that they really have failed, as they did in their term in government, to truly engage the issues that really matter to families. That is what I intend to do here today.

I begin with the current account deficit. It is divided into two portionsâand I know that reading out economic data is sometimes lost on the other side but I will try one more time. That $7 billion of goods and services is, in many ways, evidence of strong international confidence, of strong standards of living and of the ability with a higher dollar to afford imports. They are decisions being made individually by households. They are decisions to invest, as much as they are decisions not to saveâand it is a relative balance of the two. Until we can actually see exports ramping upâand we know there are delays in thatâwe can expect that there will be a larger goods and services component to that current account deficit.

The second part is actually largerâthat is, the income debits and credits. There were not many references to this made by the other side. That amount of $8.4 billion is, effectively, strong profits being made by companies, particularly international companies. There is the other side, which is not being mentioned, of strong tax takes and the opportunity for tax breaks for Australians. These are all the positive flow-on effects of a strong economy and strong international confidence. That is borne out by our AAA credit rating and the level of our currency.

The second part of the MPI goes to the notion of âspiralling foreign debtâ. It is worth noting that most of the household debt that we often refer to is household lending. What we are now talking about is the ability of a small to medium sized economy to go out and find the capital that it needs to feed a growing economy and to take advantage of the endowments this country has. We already know that the drought has slowed down a portion of our export market. But the minerals sector is extremely strong. Many mining companiesânot all of them are domestic companies; some are internationally ownedâwill be borrowing resources to optimise our use of those mineral resources, and that will be reflected. That is no surprise.

I will look at the current account deficit in greater detail. The figure released yesterday was primarily driven by the $224 million increase in the net income deficit that I was just referring to. That is simply a reflection of the strong profitability of Australian companies, some of which have been repatriated by foreign investors. It reflects an increase in profits of mining companies in particular. That is a very strong subsector of the economy, and we have already talked about the flow-on obstructions to exports of minerals and resources, particularly given the comments we have made about ports, including those in my own home state of Queensland. It is worth noting that when you actually take away that net income deficit there is in fact a very small nominal trade deficit improvement of $22 million. So I think it would be wrong to frame this debate as an example of imports rapidly outstripping our exports. But what we can expect over time is that there will be ramping up of exports and an amelioration of those figures. In addition, as has already been mentioned, terms of trade have improved by 1.1 per cent over the last year. That indicates a strengthening in the relative value of our exports.

In concluding my comments on the current account deficit, I should probably make the important point that this is very close to what is likely to be a peak in the level of the current account deficit once the effects of our mineral and bulk commodity exports flow through. Of course, export prices are increasing dramatically. We have the early upstream evidence that is occurring. We have seen coking coal contracts achieving prices of 120 per cent higher levels, we have seen iron ore contracts up and thermal coal contracts up as well. I expect that data will start to flow fairly soon. We should be watching the monthly trade data for the month of April, which is coming out this Thursday. Also outlined is the fact the export volumes themselves are increasing. That is underpinned by strong resource growth and the minerals industryâs investment of $27 billion over the last few years. This will flow through in time. But the key questions today as far as the current account deficit goes should be: are we seeing higher export prices? The answer is yes. Are we seeing increased export volumes? The answer is yes. Are we seeing moderating import growth? There is a good chance of that. That is where we will see those first pieces of evidence of a narrowing current account deficit.

I move to foreign debt. While we may talk about absolute figures, it is important to note that if you actually look at it as a proportion of the national economyâas a percentage of GDPâthe foreign debt figure has actually fallen since the last figures were released, down to 50 per cent. It is often forgotten that the debt that we are talking about today, the net foreign debt, is a considerably different debt picture from the one that we were left with in 1996. The proportion of government debt is very small. The ability to service it is far stronger. What we simply see now is that there are very large levels of foreign debt created by investment and a strong corporate sector.
Opposition members interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âThe debt servicing ratio is very important. In fact, it is vitally important and relevant. I appreciate the interjections. That debt servicing ratio, at 9.7 per cent in the March quarter, is considerably better than it was at 20 per cent back in 1990. Of course, with the revision of history that the other side have been so effective in achievingâhistory told from their side of this chamber at leastâthose sorts of figures are not even raised.

speech.para: Household credit has moderated. It has been below the 10-year average throughout this year with a growth rate of 14.2 per cent. The fact that the member for Lilley cannot hide is that unemployment is 5.1 per cent and not in double figures and that home loan interest rates are 7.3 per cent and not in the high teens or in some cases even higher, as they were in his time in government. A household with a $400,000 mortgage would be today $1,000 a month better off than they were in March 1996. Those are the figures and those are the indicators that are truly relevant to families in Australia.

In the time I have left, I will move to some meaningful comparisons. Let us pick a time in history that you would rather have been in in this country. Whether you look at the deficit, inflation, interest rates, unemployment or the budget balance, you see they are all far superior now. Take any time under a government of the now opposition. Take the government of 1995 or 1990 or even 1986. Let us make an international comparison, because such comparisons have been lacking on the other side. Take the enormous US budget deficit: the government is held responsible for three-quarters of that. In Australia the government amount is only a very small portion of our total national debt. Let us have a look at some figures produced from taxing wages in 1996 and compare them to those in 2004. Take a family with no children. Where did they rank in 1996? Behind Belgium, Canada, Luxembourg, Switzerland and the United States. They now rank No. 1. We rank No. 1 for married families with two children with household incomes of 100 per cent of average weekly ordinary time earnings. Let us take a family with earnings even higher. In fact, we can take any cut we want of the figuresâsingle, married or otherwise, children or no childrenâand Australia is ranking No. 1 or No. 2 in the OECD. They are the figures that I think would really matter to families. They are very meaningful evidence of improvement over the nine years of a coalition government.

Australia has faced numerous challenges. We know of those. We have performed well against the OECD. We have a strong minerals sector that is looking to turn around the current account deficit. This opposition failed to translate improvements to Australian families and it failed to lift living conditions for Australian families. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: (Hon. IR Causley)âThe discussion has concluded.

âOn behalf of the Parliamentary Joint Standing Committee on Public Works I present the fourth and fifth reports for 2005 of the committee relating to the development of on-base housing for Defence at Puckapunyal, Victoria, and a Defence Science and Technology Organisation Ordnance Breakdown Facility, Port Wakefield, South Australia.

speech.para: Ordered that the reports be made parliamentary papers.

talk.start.para: âby leaveâThe first of the proposed works is intended to provide 80 on-base houses to meet current and future Defence Force accommodation requirements at the Puckapunyal military area. The Defence Housing Authority intends that delivery of the new homes will occur progressively between February and November 2006. The estimated cost of the project is $19.6 million. The proposed works will comprise the construction of 80 houses and associated stormwater drainage, communications, sewerage reticulation, gas and electrical services.

speech.para: The committee visited the site of the proposed works and conducted a public hearing at Puckapunyal on 20 April 2005. After exploring a variety of issues relating to the need for the new homesâconsultation with stakeholders, the provision of services and amenities and the environmental management of the projectâthe committee was satisfied that the works would meet all stated project objectives and would represent an improved level of amenity for defence families. The committee therefore recommends that the works proceed at the estimated cost of $19.6 million.

The committeeâs fifth report of 2005 addresses works required to enhance defence research capability in respect of explosive ordnance and weaponry. This research is necessary to support the work of the Australian Defence Force and associated organisations in ensuring national security. At present, research into weapons and ordnance is conducted at the Defence Science and Technology Organisation facility at Edinburgh, South Australia, and the Proof and Experimental Establishment at Port Wakefield. Safety requirements at these sites currently limit investigations to small-size ordnance. The proposed work would address this deficiency by enabling research into a wider range of explosive ordnance and weapons.

Work elements to meet Defenceâs objectives consist of a control room for the remote monitoring and operation of ordnance breakdown equipment in other areas of the facility; a cutting building for the radiography and remotely controlled cutting of ordnance; a disassembly building for the safe radiographic examination and breakdown of explosive ordnance; two explosive ordnance storehouses; a storage building to house general equipment; engineering services, including power, water, sewerage, communications and sealed roads; and security provisions comprising fencing and a type 1 security system.

In the course of its inquiry, the committee was assured that the proposed works would take account of all necessary occupational and public safety requirements and would also entail appropriate security measures. The committee was also satisfied at the level of consultation conducted by the department with the community and other stakeholders, including the execution of land acquisition procedures. In respect of environmental impacts, members were pleased to learn that the works would result in improvements to the habitat of an endangered local bird species and, further, that the Proof and Experimental Establishment site had met four of the eight criteria for inclusion on the Ramsar list of wetlands of international importance. Having thoroughly examined the proposal, the committee recommends that the construction of an ordnance breakdown facility for the Defence Science and Technology Organisation at Port Wakefield, South Australia, proceed at the estimated cost of $8.4 million.

I would like to extend my thanks once again to my committee colleagues, the secretariat, the Hansard staff of this parliament and all those who helped with the inquiries. I commend the reports to the House.

talk.start.para: âby leaveâI rise to supplement the comments made by the Chair of the Public Works Committee on the two proposals put before the parliament: the development of on-base housing for Defence at Puckapunyal, Victoria and the Defence Science and Technology Organisation Ordnance Breakdown Facility, Port Wakefield, South Australia. It is important to note that the Public Works Committee has a very heavy schedule. The members of the committee work hard to ensure that the expenditure of the Commonwealth in this area is properly examined. I was fortunate to act as chair, in the chairâs absence, and to preside over hearings on both these projects. The statement outlined by the member for Pearce is a proper reflection of the committeeâs findings on these proposals. The member for Pearce may have mentioned the members who were directly involved but I thank the member for Scullin and Senator Ferguson and Senator Forshaw, who attended Puckapunyal with me and had a good opportunity to see what was going on there in terms of the new housing. The proposal will ensure that the defence personnel have better accommodation.

speech.para: On the other matter, I again thank the member for Scullin and Senator Ferguson, who attended Port Wakefield with me to examine the plans. Although these two projects were not particularly controversial, the departments undertook a lot of planning and due process to ensure that these projects will be done properly. On both occasions the committee found that the departments had put together reasonable proposals that the committee was in a position to accept. Therefore I support wholeheartedly the comments made by the chair of the committee, the member for Pearce. I also thank Vivienne Courto and Ray Knight from the secretariat, who attended on both occasions, and Hansard, who again did an excellent job.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed.

talk.start.para: âI rise to support the Aged Care Amendment (Extra Service) Bill 2005. The measures contained within it give effect to announcements made in the recent budget. It addresses two very important factors in the aged care sector: the desire for greater choice and the need for us to alleviate unnecessary red tape. Caring for the elderly in our community is one of the most important responsibilities of government. I remember visiting nursing homes in the late 1980s and my memory recalls dark and unhappy places. Under the reforms that have been instituted by this government aged care facilities have been vastly improved.

speech.para: I spend a lot of time visiting aged care facilities in my electorate of Stirling and I have been very pleased to host the hardworking Minister for Ageing on many occasions at those facilities as well. The facilities I have visited have been vastly different from the facilities that I would have visited 15 or so years ago. I have been heartened by the variety and standard of accommodation and the commitment of the work force within the industry to provide the highest standards of care. One provider summed it up for me when she said she always judged the standards in her aged care facility by thinking how she wants her parents to be treatedâand I think this is testament to her and to the facility that she runs.

I can sense a very similar attitude in many of the facilities I have visited where I have enjoyed talking to the residents and to the hardworking staff who look after them. A fortnight ago I attended the blessing and opening of a new wing at the Hellenic Community Aged Care facility in Dianella. It is a place I have visited many times. As the name suggests, the facility caters forâalthough not exclusivelyâthe Greek community. It is a facility that is heavily supported by that community and one of which they are very proud. A large group of prominent members of that community had contributed substantially to the upgrade of the facility and I would like to acknowledge their efforts here today. It is a real testament to the strength of the Greek community in my electorate of Stirling and it is also a good indication of their commitment to caring for one another.

The staff at Hellenic Community Aged Care are a prime example of the commitment that can be shown by workers in the industry to the highest standards of care which I spoke of earlier. They create a friendly and caring environment that is evident to anyone who has taken the time to visit. It is a commitment that I have noted in other visits to aged care facilities in my electorate that I made before and after the election. I was struck by the enthusiasm of management and staff at Meath House in Trigg. The CEO of the organisation recounted to me a tale of a new resident who seemed less than happy to have moved in. She personally made the new resident the breakfast of his choice at a time of his choosing in an effort to make him feel at home. It is this willingness to provide a proper home for older Australians that continues to impress me as I move around my electorate.

In the diverse community of Stirling, aged care is an issue that people are passionate about. Children rightly want to ensure that their parents, when moving into care, are looked after as well as they would be if they were at home. In particular, we all want to make sure that people have access to the facilities and services that meet their individual needs and desires. The Aged Care Amendment (Extra Service) Bill 2005 is about ensuring that aged care is flexible enough to meet the needs and desires of particular individuals. It fulfils one of the Howard governmentâs commitments and also recognises that aged care providers need greater flexibility to respond to the growing demands of their clients.

Before I go into the specific provisions of the bill, I would like to comment on the value of extra service places to older Australians and their families. Essentially, extra service places allow people who are in aged care to access additional services above and beyond the excellent care already offered by nursing homes. In practical terms this means that a nursing home resident can pay additional fees if they want to access things like cable television, meals in a restaurant style environment, their own phone or tea and coffee making facilities, or to participate in activities that meet their interests. These are facilities and services not normally offered in nursing homes but are the kinds of things that many people want and are willing to pay their care service provider to arrange.

The electorate of Stirling is fortunate enough to have an aged care service, Shawford Lodge, run by Aegis Aged Care, which will be providing these extra levels of service to their residents. The facility has recently received an approval to offer service to 12 high-care places. Shawford Lodge is another example of excellence in aged care within my electorate. It is in the process of expanding what is already a first-class facility and I have been privileged to have spent time there on several occasions. It is another facility where I have hosted the Minister for Ageing.

Aged care is one of the great success stories of this government. Successive ministersâmost of whom are still members of the House todayâhave taken tough decisions to reform the sector and have provided massive further investments in infrastructure to cater for our ageing population. I acknowledge the members for Pearce, Mackellar, Menzies and now the member for Curtin for the part they have all played in creating better facilities for older Australians. Ageing is not an easy portfolio but the Howard governmentâs record on it is extraordinary, culminating in last yearâs budget when an extra $2.2 billion was invested in the sector and the process of implementing the recommendations from the Hogan review began.

Sadly, the Labor Party during the last nine years have shown absolutely no interest in this area, apart from the times they have exploited it for political gain. The Labor Partyâs neglect of ageing Australians comes despite the fact that we have an ageing population and that the issue remains one of the most important for Australiaâs future. They seem unaware that by 2040 there will be around seven million Australians over the age of 65, which will amount to 25 per cent of the population. It is therefore one of the most fundamental challenges that we as legislators need to address. Where we going to accommodate everyone? What services are going to be required? Where is the capital going to come from for the expansion of those services?

Fortunately, the coalition have not avoided these questions or shirked our responsibilities in this area. When we came to office in 1996, the government spent around $3 billion per annum on aged care. Next financial year we will invest well over $7 billion. That is an enormous increaseâalthough challenges still remain. One of them is to reduce the red-tape burden on providers and let them get on with providing care. The bill before the House today gives effect to that desire by removing the requirement to reapply for extra service status every five years. I know from discussions I have had with providers that they have felt that the high level of regulation of the extra service program has stood in the way of its expansion.

Under current arrangements providers need to reapply for extra service status every five years regardless of whether or not they have had any problems during that time. It is a time-consuming and expensive process and acts as a deterrent to raising capital for expansion. It is vital that we remove these barriers to expansion because investment in infrastructure will be a crucial element in catering for the future demand that will result from the demographic changes that I outlined earlier.

The Commonwealth is already doing its part and investing heavily in this area, to the tune of over $1 billion. But further investment through other sources will still be required to meet demand. We need to ensure that we give providers every opportunity to raise capital to build new facilities and to refurbish older ones. The passage of this bill is the result of a coalition government who are prepared to listen to providers and act when we identify changes that will be of benefit to our community. I commend this bill to the House.

talk.start.para: âin replyâThe Aged Care Amendment (Extra Service) Bill 2005 implements changes to the Aged Care Act 1997 announced in the 2005-06 federal budget. In summing up the debate this afternoon I can say it is evident, at least to the last two speakers, the members for Bowman and Stirling, that this legislation further demonstrates the governmentâs strong commitment to ensuring a robust and viable aged care sector for the future where the element of choice is a key ingredient for both residents and providers of aged care services. An aged care service with extra service status allows residents to choose and pay for a higher than average level of hotel type services, including in accommodation and food but particularly in non-care services. This legislation removes the requirement that providers of extra service reapply every five years for renewal of extra service status. In doing so it will both decrease the amount of red tape for providers and increase their ability to access capital for rebuilding or refurbishing, enhancing their ability to undertake long-term planning.

speech.para: Through this legislation, the Australian government will remove the expiry date for extra service status, remove provisions covering the renewal of extra service status and remove provisions covering the continuation of extra service for certain residents in services where extra service has expired, while ensuring that extra service continues to be provided for those residents who are in homes where extra service has been continued prior to 1 July 2005. This legislation will make consequential amendments to the provisions in the Aged Care Act 1997. The Australian government will also make similar changes to the extra service principles made under section 96.1 of the Aged Care Act. So we are decreasing the level of red tape for the providers of extra service aged care.

These changes will ultimately provide greater choice for aged care residents through expansion of the extra service program, but this does not come at the expense of those who cannot afford to pay. Residents who cannot afford to pay for extra services will still be able to access quality care because of the safeguards this government has in place. Only homes which have extra service status can charge extra services fees and a bond for high care. Extra service status is only approved where the provider can demonstrate that the home will offer hotel type services significantly above the average aged care home and where the provider has a very good record of compliance.

Other requirements for extra service homes include compulsory accreditation and certification. In particular, extra service status cannot be approved where it would unreasonably reduce access to residential aged care by concessional residents or other older Australians. A maximum of 15 per cent of all residential aged care places may have extra service. All other homes have their fees and charges capped under the Aged Care Act 1997 and cannot increase their fees for extra services.

This legislation delivers another measure announced in the 2005-06 budget which will have the dual outcomes of decreasing regulation and increasing the standards in residential aged care. I thank the speakers in this debate: the member for Lalor, for the opposition, and the members for Bowman and Stirling, both elected in October 2004, who have already demonstrated a great interest in aged care and aged care needs in their electorates in Queensland and Western Australia respectively. By their support of this bill, they recognise that this legislation further demonstrates the Australian governmentâs strong commitment to ensuring a robust and viable aged care sector now and into the future which provides a choice in high-quality care to older Australians.
Question agreed to.
Bill read a second time.

motion.para: That this bill be now read a third time.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 25 May, on motion by Mr Lloyd:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: âThe opposition supports the second reading of the Maritime Transport Security Amendment Bill 2005. It amends the Maritime Transport Security Act 2003 in respect of two issues which are summarised in the explanatory memorandum. First, the bill extends coverage of that act to offshore oil and gas facilities located within the territorial sea, in Australiaâs exclusive economic zone and on the continental shelf and ensures that all regulated offshore oil and gas facility operators and other prescribed offshore industry participants develop and comply with an offshore security plan based on a security assessment of each regulated facility. Second, the bill amends the act to allow for the introduction of maritime security identification cards. The cards will be introduced to cover unmonitored personnel who are required to access what are called maritime security zones, which may be areas in ports, areas surrounding ships or areas on ships.

speech.para: The card scheme will require the prospective holder to submit to a check of their background. These background checks will comprise a criminal history check undertaken by the Australian Federal Police and a security assessment by ASIO. If required, it may also be necessary to conduct an unlawful noncitizen check by the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs. These cards will only be issued to persons who have successfully met background checking requirements. Of course, members will be familiar, as a result of the debate in the chamber over the last two days, with matters concerning a similar security card scheme that applies in our aviation industry, but all members will be anxious to ensure that the scheme operates successfully and not, as we would submit in respect of the aviation industry, with so many flaws in it.

Before I begin a discussion of the bill, it is appropriate to appreciate the environment in which we are placed as a nation and, in particular, the significance of our maritime environment. The threat of terrorism to Australia and the perceptions we have of such risks have to a large extent been shaped by recent global events including the September 11 attacks in New York and Washington and the Madrid bombings in Spain, but it was of course the bombings in Bali that drove home the devastating reality and proximity of the threat of global terrorism to Australia and Australian interests. Unfortunately, subsequent to the events in Bali, we have seen that with the bombing of Australiaâs embassy in Indonesia.

To a large degree, Australiaâs unique geographic location in the world has shielded us from some of the excesses of interstate conflicts and acts of global terrorism but, again, with the Bali bombings as an indication of the activities of terrorist based organisations in our region, we cannot dismiss the prospect. Indeed, when I was in the United States last year the experts there repeatedly stated, âYou guys are living in a dangerous neighbourhood,â in terms of the prospect of exposure to terrorism in the South-East Asian region. But Australiaâs unique geography as an island continent certainly makes the maritime zone particularly important to us. Unfortunately, it is a zone that is particularly vulnerable.

One must always guard against inflating the reality of the threat posed by terrorism so that our response is reasonable, balanced and sensible and does not, by overreactionâeither by breaking down our systems, structures and rule of law and so forth or by imposing unrealistic and unreasonable expense on participantsâitself damage either our body politic or our economy. But it is worth noting that in April 2004 ASIO reported on the threat of terrorism to Australiaâs shipping and port infrastructure. They stated in that report, in summary, that the al-Qaeda network in South-East Asia have stated an intent to attack Australian interests and that they have the capacity to conduct acts of terrorism, including maritime terrorism. ASIO stated that al-Qaedaâs capacity to conduct terrorist attacks continues to develop, but they concluded that the threat to most of Australiaâs port facilities and infrastructure was rated as low, but that some, which for obvious reasons have been left unidentified, were rated at a medium level of threat. These are issues that cannot be ignored.

In terms of terrorism support and operational infrastructure in South-East Asia, it is unfortunate that terrorist organisations clearly still have access, as a result of their economic circumstances, to a population that is substantially underprivileged, has its own grievances and is openly exploited by those who promote extremist views. Unfortunately, they also have access to resources, frequently from other parts of the world. Those groups that we are familiar with include Jemaah Islamiah, which continues to flourish. Since 1997 the al-Qaeda network in South-East Asia has planned and conducted terrorist attacks against maritime personnel and infrastructure on land and at sea. Indeed, as I have mentioned, our embassy has been a target.

Since 11 September 2001, al-Qaeda and associated groups have consistently indicated that the energy sector in particular is a target. They see the energy sector as being particularly vital to world economic prosperity. Al-Qaeda have articulated plans to âcripple the petroleum industryâ with sea based attacks against oil tankers, and the maritime capabilities can be developed quickly. We recognise that the use of speedboats packed with weapons or explosives which can be used to evade law enforcement authorities and with a suicide bomber in control unfortunately has the potential to cause great destruction, particularly to our offshore oil and gas facilities. There have also been attacks on oil facilities and personnel in the Middle East, such as the attempts on the al Basra and Khor al Amaya oil terminals of southern Iraq on 24 April 2004.

Al-Qaeda has in fact identified Australia as a legitimate target on seven separate occasions and has carried out threats and actions intended to damage Western economies and in particular, as I have mentioned, the oil and gas industry as a vital part of Western economies. The oil and gas sector in Australia brings in excess of $18 billion annually into our economy. The predominance of a small number of offshore oil and gas installations supplying Australiaâs domestic and overseas energy markets makes these facilities critical elements of national security infrastructure and attractive targets for terrorists in the current security sensitive environment. Because of regional and global economic independence, terrorist events in one region can impose significant flow-on costs and cause damage to other areas of the global economy. Countries that fail to combat terrorism and ensure the safety of trade can expect to incur significant costs in trade and investment opportunities.

Numerous studies have been undertaken to assess the economic risks from maritime terrorism. In terms of maritime trade, for example, one study found that closing down all United States ports for a period of seven to 10 days would cost the United States economy some $75 billion. By way of comparison, Melbourneâs ports handle some $70 billion in trade every year and support some 20,000 jobs, while Sydneyâs ports handle in the order of $45Â½ billion in international and domestic trade and generate more than 17,000 jobs.

In 2003, the Economic Analytical Unit of the Australian Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade produced a report on the overall cost of terrorism, with particular emphasis on maritime terrorism. It found that, while the cost of unchecked terrorism is significant for all economies, terrorism could pose a disproportionately high cost for the economies of the countries in our regionâin particular, those that are continuing to develop.

The study found that most developing APEC economies depend more heavily on trade flows, particularly with the United States and OPEC economies; many regional developing economies rely on receiving strong foreign direct investment, which would be at risk from an increase in terrorist activities; and insurance premiums may be higher on cargoes and vessels travelling to and from developing countries because of uncertainty about the adequacy of local security procedures. We must bear in mind that the majority of our cargo comes through the regions which are exposed to those sorts of threats. The secure flow of maritime trade and production is therefore essential to the economic and national security interests of Australia, the region and indeed the globe.

Australiaâs offshore oil and gas industry is currently not covered by the act, and therefore is not operating in a manner that is consistent with Australiaâs maritime security regime. That regime requires certain maritime industry participants, such as ships and port operators, to develop and implement risk based security plans that contain details of access controls, maritime security zones and protocols for dealing with maritime security incidents and threats. At present, there are no formal mechanisms for responding to a potential terrorist attack. There are also no adequate mechanisms for dealing with unlawful access to offshore oil and gas facilities. The bill will bring the security of offshore oil and gas facilities in line with existing maritime security arrangements, providing a regime for these facilities to reduce the risk of unlawful interference.

There will be two main industry groups affected by the bill. The first are the operators of the offshore facilities. The second will be the various service providers to these facilitiesânotably, helicopter charter operators and ship based equipment stores supply services. Obviously, those services have access to these offshore installations. Under the bill, offshore oil and gas facilities will be required to develop security plans, as I have indicated, that consider the risk-assessed needs of the operators, including the special nature and location of the facilities.

The offshore facilities vary from conventional steel fixed platforms and concrete gravity platforms through to miniplatforms, monotowers, monopods and minipods, floating storage and offtake units and floating production storage and offtake units. These facilities will primarily be to the north and, in particular, north-west of Australia. These plans will be submitted to Department of Transport and Regional Services for approval, and they should complement existing safety plans that operate on those platforms. DOTARS will be responsible for regulating the offshore oil and gas industry security plans and for auditing these facilities to ensure they comply with the regulatory regime established by the act and the regulations. The bill puts in place the same risk based security planning for offshore oil and gas service providersâthat is, contractors of specialist offshore related services or port related services, as I have mentioned, such as helicopter and supply vessel service providers.

DOTARS have indicated that they expect to receive 40 security plans and that they anticipate the cost of developing a security plan will be in the order of $50,000 for each facility. In accordance with the stated government policy that security is the cost of doing business, DOTARS have confirmed that industry will bear the cost of preparing those plans and that DOTARS will recover the cost of dealing with them. DOTARS have also indicated that they expect to receive draft security plans from facilities by 1 July 2005 and expect to have the security regime in place by 1 October 2005. In that sense the government claimsâand the opposition recognisesâsome urgency in the passage of this legislation.

Under the bill, access to what are called maritime security zonesâwhich may be areas in ports, areas surrounding ships, or areas on shipsâare generally managed by each individual port or ship operator. However, there is no common legislative requirement for how these operators should ensure that only properly authorised persons can access these zones. At present, therefore, there is no regime in place that requires background checking of people working in Australian ports, ships and offshore oil and gas facilities, as is the current situation, as I have mentioned, in the aviation industry and in the maritime industry in comparable Western countries.

The security card identification scheme will be a nationally consistent identification card that states that the holder has met the background checking requirements to work in a designated maritime security zone. The card, however, is not an access control card. Anyone who requires unmonitored access to a maritime security zone will be required to have a maritime security card. They will include, among others, dock workers, truck drivers and rig workers. Applicants apply for the card from an issuing body. Private companies, employee trade unions or industry associations, among others, are entitled to apply to be an issuing body as long as they have the capacity to perform the regulatory function.

Through publicised fact sheets the department has indicated that the issuing bodies will not be given access to personal information gathered through background checking; rather, following the background checks conducted by the appropriate government agency, the relevant issuing body will only be advised as to whether the employee can be issued with an MSIC or not. We understand that the estimated cost of issuing the MSIC is in the order of $40 to $60, including the cost of conducting relevant background checks. The legislation provides that regulations will be made to enable the issuing body to recover the costs of issuing the cards. Although the framework for issuing the cards will be set out in regulations, these regulations, unfortunately, have yet to be issued. Despite assurances by the government that the opposition would be provided with, at the very least, a draft version of these regulations, we are yet to see the content or scope of the regulations. Obviously we would be assisted in the consideration of these measures if we could have access to at least the draft documents as expeditiously as possible.

At present, the bill merely allows the bodies that will be responsible for issuing MSICs to recover the costs involved in administering the process, including background checks. Again, however, we are yet to see how these costs will be passed on to employees who require security checksâmany of whom, of course, will have worked in these industries for some years. MSICs are issued after the completion of several background checks, as I have indicated, including a criminal background check by the AFP and a security assessment by ASIO. If required, an unlawful noncitizen check will be conducted by DIMIA. As yet, we have not been informed as to the level of criminality that will prevent an individual from receiving an MSIC or had a chance to consider the appropriateness of how this level of criminality is determined. Of course, today in question time there was controversy as to whether or not a person who has served some eight years in prison for drug trafficking should appropriately have been issued with an aviation security card. These are issues we would like to contemplate and explore with respect to the appropriate level of offence that applies to the issuing of the maritime security card.

While we understand that those unions that have predominant coverage of offshore platforms have been consulted, there are concerns that a number of smaller unions representing individual trades may not have been consultedâalthough we recognise that common issues will obviously arise with respect to all unions and their members. In the context of revelations emerging around security failings at airports this week, it is worth noting, however, that the mere issuing of these security cards is no panacea against the potential for unlawful interference at an Australian port facility, ship or offshore platform. If there is simple access by a swiping system without face-to-face verification, obviously the system will be exposed to the theft or transfer of cards.

Given the concerns that we have raised, it is the oppositionâs view that, while a second reading of the bill should be supported in the House, the bill should be referred to the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Committee for a short inquiry to examine, among other things, the concerns I have just raised. We will therefore be seeking a short turnaround time for the committee to conduct the inquiry so that we can ensure the expeditious passage of the bill, which we recognise is important legislation. Again, the inquiry itself and the resolution of these concerns would obviously be assisted by the government providing a copy of the draft regulations that will accompany this legislation as soon as possible.

The governmentâs principal approach to maritime security protection, it must be said, is by legislative and regulatory means. Essentially, it is a light-touch approach where the legislative and regulatory framework is set by the government, but how that is complied with is essentially up to the private operators. In 2003 the opposition welcomed the passage of the Maritime Transport Security Act in order that Australia could develop and implement a nationally consistent maritime security framework. However, a point we repeatedly make is that legislation and regulation alone are incapable of preventing security threats and breaches at our ports, on our ships and on our oil and gas facilities.

We note that in April this year the Australian Strategic Policy Institute published a damning report into the state of Australiaâs security arrangements entitled Future unknown: The terrorist threat to Australian maritime security. This report identified a number of failings: a lack of specialised port police as seen operating in the United States and United Kingdom; an absence of a comprehensive security framework for the supply chain of container transportation across the Australian continent; inadequate security checks of crews from foreign flagged vessels arriving in Australian portsâin 2002, a total of 115,000 foreign crew arrived; an absence of a nationwide approach to manage the security of high-risk ships, such as foreign naval vessels and ships carrying dangerous goods like ammonium nitrate and other petrochemical substances; a lack of coordination between relevant agencies including Customs, Navy, the Department of Transport and Regional Services and state agencies; a lack of consistency between state and territory jurisdictions and their legislation covering maritime security; and a lack of critical information and data to properly assess the vulnerability of Australian ports.

Despite its consistent and often shameless âtough on securityâ oratory, the government is undeniably failing in these key structural areas. The concerns raised by the ASPI are not new; federal Labor has been highlighting maritime security problems month after month, year after year, but the concerns are now clearly articulated by an expert body specifically established by the government to provide frank strategic advice.
The only response to this report that has come from the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Transport and Regional Services was:

quote.para: ... it was unlikely the Government would adopt the recommendations ... weâre continuing to look for any holes that might emerge in our maritime security net.

speech.para: We believe it is high time the government not only looked for these holes in our maritime security arrangements but acknowledged that the holes exist and that they constitute a significant threat to Australiaâs national security. The government must listen to this independent, expert advice and act swiftly to remedy the litany of threats to our maritime security. We need a commitment from the government that they will address these problems and assure the Australian public that their borders are secure and that the government are on the job.

In that context, we note that the Inspector of Transport Security, who was removed from office in February this year to conduct the Rau inquiry, also had responsibility in respect of maritime security when that office was originally established. As part of the national transport security plan it was stated that the mandate of that office would be to investigate major incidents and systematic transport security weaknesses to ensure security vulnerabilities were identified and addressed. That plan talks of a protective role and there is probably no-one better in Australia than former Federal Police Commissioner Mick Palmer to undertake that role, yet for the last four months, and despite the cost of his office being some $400,000 per annum, he has not been performing that function because he has been putting out other bushfires for the government in the form of the Rau inquiry and the immigration scandal that that matter involves.

Given that this regulatory regime is so light in touchâwith the obligation for implementing schemes being essentially on the operatorsâan effective inspection regime is absolutely crucial to security. Moreover it must be one that is at armâs length from the government. The minister can talk about the resources of the department of transportâs security wingâand certainly our inspection of that facility indicates that it is staffed by extremely competent peopleâbut the bottom line is that these are issues of immense concern to our national interest and should be investigated without fear or favour by an independent office holder such as the Inspector of Transport Security. If, as a result of political pressure, the minister has dumbed down or neutered that role to be a post-fact roleâthat is, investigating a terrorist event after it has occurredâwe sensibly ask the minister to revise his assessment. We ask the officials and experts that advise the minister to say, âListen, if we want to ensure that everyone is doing the very best they possibly can in this area we must restore that independence.â

There has been some progress in maritime security, with the creation of the Joint Offshore Protection Command. The Minister for Foreign Affairs seemed to have been given the brief, prior to the last election, of ridiculing, with all the fanfare that he could muster, Laborâs plans to establish an Australian coastguard. But irrespective of whether or not you agreed with Laborâs plan for a coastguard there was and there remains a need for greater coordination of our maritime security zone.

Currently we have eight Customs vessels and 15âit will be 14ânaval patrol vessels. Each of the eight Customs vessels comes under the command chain of the Australian Customs Service and obviously the naval vessels come under the command structure of the Royal Australian Navy. Essentially, under Laborâs plan they had their resources seconded from requests from the coastguard but in this case they will receive requests from the Joint Offshore Protection Command.Â If that structure is to work effectively as a joint offshore protection command it seems logical that it should be given statutory recognition, and any vessel, crew or officer seconded to undertake work for the command should sensibly be under the control of the command.

We recognise that the quality of senior officers in the Joint Offshore Protection Command is exceptional but they should be given the authority to have a system of protection. The fact that it is based on the fragmented laws and agency structures that we still have in our maritime zone is unsatisfactory. Whether or not the government, for political reasons, disputes the need for the establishment of a coastguard, this needs to be refined. It needs to be coordinated and responsibility needs to be given to an authority with independent statutory control and command. Unless and until we do that there is always going to be a risk that security incidents fall between the competing responsibilities of respective agencies. In summary, we are talking about words on pieces of paper. We support these measures but our point is that words are not enoughâwe need detailed coordinated action to protect our maritime zone.

talk.start.para: âI welcome the fact that the opposition sees the value of these proposals which, while they are fairly specific, are basically designed to address the problems of the enemy within. Of course, that is one of the most potent means of terrorist operations. If a single operative gets into a position of trust they can do immeasurable harm and undertake damaging activities, including destruction.

speech.para: The member for Barton made comments about other issues of security which are contemporary. In relation to Sydney airport employees, who are virtually totally unionised, it did strike me from the beginning how tight the issue was that months ago, maybe years ago, the ALP were unable to stand up in this place and advise the government of what was going on. It was people who were members of a union, whether or not they wanted to be or whether or not they were officials, who were dealing in drugs and other matters that could affect security at Sydney airport, because it is virtually a no ticket, no start environment. Somebody who was honest and certainly not a crook knew about this. But what is the culture in that place that resulted in nothing coming out?

I am not having a shot at anyone. The Labor Party might ask themselves why they didnât tell us, if only for the purpose of giving them a political advantage. Why is it that in that area of employment, where people could not possibly fail to know that serious laws of Australia were being brokenâlaws that might extend to issues of terrorismâa culture existed in which nobody dobbed anybody in? That issue has to be resolved. We are well aware that most state legislation still prevents universal use of video cameras in workplaces. This of course should be a proponent of the issues before us today, which specifically deal with the enemy from within. I would like to make a few comments in due course about the enemy outside. To quote from the explanatory memorandum:

quote.para: The Bill amends the Maritime Transport Security Act 2003 by:Â
extending coverage of the Act to offshore oil and gas facilities located within the territorial sea, in Australiaâs exclusive economic zone and on the continental shelf; and

ensuring that all regulated offshore oil and gas facility operators and other prescribed offshore industry participants develop, and comply with, an offshore security plan based on a security assessment of each regulated facility.Â Â Â
â¦Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â â¦Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â â¦

The second part of the bill is to amend the Maritime Transport Security Act 2003 to allow for the introduction of the maritime security identification card. The MSIC will be introduced to cover unmonitored personnel who are required to be in Maritime Security Zones and offshore security zones ...

speech.para: That second part more particularly deals with the enemy from within and raises all sorts of questions. A question was asked today as to whether it is appropriate to have a zip card entry to a secure area when the person carrying that zip card might not be the person to whom it was issued. I think that is a major issue where personal security is involved. Even a PIN is not appropriate, because it can be handed over. Maybe the tokens that we now have associated with our computers might go some way to answering that, although of course a person could even hand that over. So it comes down to the new biosecurity issues that are coming forward. I am reading a bookâit is fictitiousâin which someone who can use their eye to get through a particular door has his eye cut out and is killed. Is that practical? I donât know. Certainly the book suggests it was and the crooks got in.

One might wonder just where some of these security issues end. When there are people who are silly enough to blow themselves up, apparently to get an early pass into heaven, taking with them innocent people, one wonders where the next threat might exist in Australia. It is interesting to note that this legislation contains provisions for costs to be acquitted by the owners of particular facilities. I am surprised that legislation is required for the undertaking of these processes. In this day and age one would think that their insurance companies would be very interested in this situation and would demand extremely high levels of security to protect their investment in facilities of this nature and possibly their business cash flows. So I think it is quite appropriate that these types of security measures be paid for by those involved. Not only does it pose a very significant risk to national security and the national economy, but also in a purely business sense one would think that the operators would want to take every step to protect their interest. I did make a note to consider, as a broader comment on this legislation, that long-held Returned and Services League motto that the price of peace is eternal vigilance. I think this legislation is a progression of that in terms of the governmentâs intention.

Returning to identity cards, I have talked about compliance arrangements where a person might achieve access to a place through another person lending them their card, perhaps because they are running late or they do not want to turn up. That is the old time-clock syndrome. We also have to look at ease of identity theft issues. That has always worried me. I participated in the Australian identity card debate and pointed out just how simply people could steal your identity from an identity cardâcertainly as we knew them in those daysâand use it to access your creditworthiness, steal money from your bank account and break certain laws in presenting themselves as you. There are so many issues related to this matter.

I am also going to take this opportunity to talk briefly about external threats. The member for Barton talked about people loading up a speedboat with explosives. The typical freighter en route today would have perhaps one person on its bridge while it is on automatic pilot. I have had examples of crayfish fishermen nearly being run over in that circumstance, while they were at anchor. It means that only one person needs to be on the bridge and that person could decide to drive straight through an oil rig with a 100,000 tonne vessel.

These sorts of issues are also of grave importance. While I do not know the extent to which they are addressed in the north-west, I think some work is being done in Bass Strait where rigs have radar so they can have some idea of what is happening. Historically, there have been a couple of scares of a non-terrorist nature in Bass Strait. Again, what a worry it would be if the radio operator was not at work and you were screaming at them that they were on a course for your fixed asset.

These sorts of issues have got to be considered. I once visited some high-tech people in this town of Canberra who had invented and manufactured a phased radar for which they received a contract, I think in the Red Sea or from a nearby nation.
