subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 25 May, on motion by Mr Hardgrave:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: âFollowing the two-day National Reconciliation Planning Workshop held at Old Parliament House, todayâs debate certainly provides a timely opportunity to emphasise the role of education and training in promoting reconciliation and improving the lives of Australiaâs Indigenous communities. One of the hot topics of discussion over recent months has been the need to build the economic independence of Indigenous communities. Pat Dodson, the chair of the Lingiari Foundation and former chair of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation, wrote in the Age that Indigenous communities:

quote.para: â¦ must engage with industry and governments to guarantee a place for Aboriginal people at the economic table and an equal share in the prosperity that the nation enjoys.

speech.para: Our role in this place as policy makers and legislators is to force a realisation on this government that in order to share our prosperity we must make sure that all Australians are provided with the basic foundations to engage as economically and socially capable citizens. Education and training are key to building this capacity but, without a doubt, Indigenous Australians remain the most severely educationally disadvantaged people in this country.

The divergence between the educational outcomes of Indigenous Australians and those of non-Indigenous Australians is nothing short of an outrage. Young Indigenous Australians are twice as likely as non-Indigenous students to have left school before completing year 10 and half as likely to have completed year 12. Indigenous Australians aged 18- to 24 are less than a quarter as likely as their non-Indigenous counterparts to go to university. There has been a decline in the number of Indigenous students in vocational education and training for the first time since the 1990s. Almost halfâand this is the most damning of allâof 15- to 17-year-old Indigenous Australians in the labour force are either unemployed or on CDEP. Not only are Indigenous Australians dropping out of school at twice the rate of other students, but their rates of literacy and numeracy are far below national standards. Shamefully for this government, the number attending university has gone backwards since 1999.

This damning evidence points to a growing crisis in Indigenous education and training. Access to a decent education is absolutely critical to improving the lives of all Australians, and this is particularly the case for Indigenous Australians. This government should have Indigenous education at the top of its list of priorities. The government should be working as hard as it can to reduce the shocking disparities in the educational outcomes of Indigenous Australians but sadly, after nine very long years, they are still falling short.

The Indigenous Education (Targeted Assistance) Amendment Bill 2005 concerns appropriations for two government measures, which Labor will support. The first is a new tutorial assistance scheme for Indigenous students, and the second is a transfer of funds from the Indigenous Education Strategic Initiatives Program to the Commonwealth-State Training Funding Agreement. The first measure is a tutorial assistance program with $7.2 million in funding providing Indigenous students from remote communities with new tutorial support in their first year of schooling when they move to a non-remote location to continue their education. These students will receive up to four hours tuition a week for up to 32 weeks in their first year away from home. The second measure gives effect to a transfer of vocational education and training fundsâ$10.9 million in totalâfrom the targeted Indigenous Education Strategic Initiatives Program into the general Commonwealth-State Training Funding Agreement.

This transfer forms part of the reallocation of funding identified in the Commonwealthâs latest training agreement offered to the states and territories. Most of the money in this new offer is in reallocations of this sort. This funding is currently provided to four independent Indigenous vocational and technical education providers as transitional assistance under the Indigenous Education Strategic Initiatives Program. Under the proposed terms of the Commonwealth-state funding agreement, state and territory governments will be required to match the funding. According to the office of Minister Nelson, the Minister for Education, Science and Training, the $10.9 million has already been included in the $4.4 billion appropriations proposed in the Skilling Australia's Workforce Bill 2005, which is also currently before the House. Labor would certainly be seeking a guarantee from the ministerâand I hope he will give this guarantee in his response to the billâthat the level of spending on Indigenous training will be increased as a result of these changes.

The net effect of these two measures is, unfortunately, to decrease the moneys appropriated by the Indigenous Education (Targeted Assistance) Act 2000 by $3.7 million. This governmentâs performance in Indigenous education, as demonstrated in the outcomes I described earlier, has been nothing short of woeful. From this education minister, of course, we are used to hearing an abundance of platitudes but, I am very sorry to say, scant action. Given the governmentâs disregard for this important area, I move:

motion.para: That all words after âThatâ be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
âwhilst not declining to give the bill a second reading, the House condemns the Government for:

item.para: bungling the implementation of the new arrangements for Indigenous education programs, including swamping in red tape the Parent School Partnership Initiative (which is replacing funding to 3,785 Aboriginal Student Support and Parent Awareness committees), resulting in the failure to deliver urgently needed funding to Indigenous students;
bungling the delivery of vital tutorial assistance resulting in serious delays in providing support to Indigenous students;
an Indigenous Year 12 retention rate of 39.1 per cent which is barely half of that for the non-Indigenous community;
presiding over a 2.8 per cent decline in the number of Indigenous VET enrolments, from 59,763 in 2002 to 58,087 in 2003;
policy settings which have resulted in a 3.2 per cent decline in the number of Indigenous student commencements in higher education between 2002 and 2003; and
failing to take an evidence based approach to its new Indigenous education funding arrangementsâ.

speech.para: Minister Nelson, unfortunately, could not even make it into the House to introduce this bill, but more damning than that has been his complete failure to engage with the national agenda around Indigenous education. The last meeting of Australiaâs education ministers was in Canberra just three weeks ago. They dedicated an entire day to Indigenous education, but they had to proceed without the federal education minister. His nonattendance shows a shocking lack of commitment to Indigenous education. It was an insult to Indigenous Australians, despite this very special seminar having been planned for almost 18 months. The day took place only five minutes away from Parliament House but it seems it would have taken just too much effort for him to attend. And this is the minister who has presided over the following: the national school retention rate for Indigenous students is 39 per centâ39 per cent of Indigenous students stay on to year 12. Contrast that with the rate for the whole country, where 76 per cent of students stay on to year 12. What a shameful result from this education minister.

But, even when Indigenous students are at school, they are not reaching the standard of education that people need to survive and prosper in this country. Of course, for many Indigenous students and their families, half the battle is just getting to school. In January, the Productivity Commission published some shocking statistics. The results of the year 3 and year 5 reading, writing and literacy benchmark testing tells us that around 20 per cent fewer Indigenous students are meeting the benchmark than the community as a whole. Whereas 90 to 94 per cent of the community as a whole meets the benchmark, between 63 and 80 per cent of Indigenous students are getting there. In his media release yesterday, the Minister for Education, Science and Training asked:

quote.para: Why is it that our childrenâs reading and writing standards fall when they move from primary through to high school?

speech.para: This minister should stop asking these sorts of questions and start acting like a minister and address these enormous inequalities. Seventy-two per cent of Indigenous students meet the benchmark at year 3, but only 67 per cent are able to meet the benchmark two years later. The decline is even more pronounced for numeracy where 80 per cent of students are at the benchmark in year 3 but it falls to a staggering 63 per cent by year 5. This is a massive 26 percentage points behind the 90 per cent achieved by the population as a wholeâonce again a shameful result. It is a shameful result from this minister, who talks a lot but is clearly not able to achieve any improved results.

The government know that they have botched the changes to the Aboriginal Student Support and Parent Awareness program and the Indigenous Tutorial Assistance Program. These programs, which were providing important resources to Indigenous schools, have been affected by major changes introduced by this government in the very recent past. This has resulted in the stopping of the flow of funds to Indigenous students, which has meant funding cuts to Indigenous students in our cities and towns. So this governmentâs changes to these very important programs, the ASSPA program and ITAS, are seriously disadvantaging Indigenous students and their surrounding communities.

The governmentâs implementation of the ASSPA changes have stopped the flow of money to schools, leaving Indigenous students around the country stranded. These changes result directly from the government deciding to shift funding from a per student entitlement to a two-stage bureaucratic application process. That is why Indigenous students in our schools are currently missing out on much needed funding. This additional bureaucratic red tape is alienating Indigenous communities, which means that many school services and programs that are currently in place are unfortunately now under threat. It is just outrageous that this government is making it even harder for Indigenous schools and students to get desperately needed funding support. Why is it that they have to go through these bureaucratic hoops to get money that everybody knows they desperately need?

The governmentâs changes to the ITAS program will result in less funding and therefore fewer students receiving assistance. Students should not have to fail the year 3 benchmark test before they get literacy support. Yet, that is the direct result of this governmentâs changes to that program. Everyone in this House should know that early support is essential for any child who is having trouble learning to read, and this is particularly the case if we are to seriously address Indigenous literacy problems.

Less literacy support for Indigenous students, especially in their early years, will only increase the educational disadvantage that Indigenous Australians already grapple with. We know that the scale of odds stacked against Indigenous students is extraordinary. Even when young Indigenous people leave school to undertake further education and training, their situation is far worse than that of other Australians. As I mentioned before, the rate at which Indigenous students are entering vocational education and training has dropped significantly in the last six years. It is not only Indigenous students in schools but also young Indigenous people in vocational education and training who are losing out because of this governmentâs failure to do the really serious hard work that needs to be done to turn around this shocking level of disadvantage.

A national report to parliament on Indigenous education and training in 2003, released earlier this year, found serious problems in Indigenous vocational education and training, including the alarming fact that the overall number of Indigenous VET enrolments fell for the first time since the 1990s. Between 2002 and 2003, when the current education minister had the portfolio, the total number of Indigenous VET enrolments fell. It went backwards. There has been a fall in enrolments of 2.8 per cent while this minister has had the job.

We all know in this country how critical skills training is in developing the capacity of individuals; but, in Indigenous communities, it is so important for the community and the individual if they are to build a better future. For our most disadvantaged Australians we have to do more to improve their current and future prospects. The level and quality of Indigenous engagement in vocational education and training is unacceptably poor.

We all know on this side of the Houseâand we have known it for a very long timeâthat reconciliation is linked to economic prosperity. Advancing sustainable economic prosperity for Indigenous Australians requires a commitment to, and investment in, building a skills and knowledge base within Indigenous communities. One way the government can make a real difference is to boost the level of skill development within these communities through our vocational training sector. Increases in Indigenous participation and outcomes must be realised if we are to move our reconciliation agenda forward.

Not only have Indigenous VET enrolments fallen but Indigenous students are underrepresented in course completions. These figures are also just shocking. The pass rate in VET assessment for Indigenous students is 64 per cent compared to 77 per cent for the rest of the population. While making up 3.4 per cent of the student population, overall course completions by Indigenous students made up only 2.5 per cent of the Australian Qualifications Framework level course completions in 2003. The National report to parliament on Indigenous education and training 2003 revealed:

quote.para: One of the main measures of success in VET institutions in the IESIPâ

speech.para: the Indigenous Education Strategic Initiatives Programâ

quote.para: performance framework is the module or competency completion rate (MCR). In 2003 the overall MCR was 68.8% ... This compares to a non-Indigenous rate of 81.7%.

speech.para: That is a 12.9 per cent gap between module completion rates for Indigenous and non-Indigenous Australians. It is also the case that Indigenous students are much more likely than non-Indigenous students to be in AQF certificate I and II coursesâthe lower level courses. The comparison is 34.6 per cent for Indigenous students compared to just over 15 per cent for non-Indigenous students. The national report to parliament shows that, sadly, there has been little movement from lowerâthat is, certificate I and II coursesâto higher certificate III and above qualifications by Indigenous students. When Indigenous students are enrolled in higher level qualifications, their completion rates are drastically lower than the rest of the population. Completions of new apprenticeships at AQF III and IV were 49 per cent for Indigenous students compared to the non-Indigenous student rate of 74 per cent.

All of these figures show how this government has to get serious and back up its talk about getting young Indigenous people into TAFE with extra TAFE places and support. As the member for Lingiari will know only too well, there is absolutely no use in just giving a story to a newspaper as a cheap media stunt and not following it up with properly thought out and fully costed policy.

The governmentâs proposal, which was given to the Australian in early April, said that the Howard government wants young Aboriginal people who drop out of school to attend training courses. That sounds like a good idea. But, of course, the minister failed to specify anything. There was nothing specific. There was no new funding, no extra TAFE places and no tailored support for Indigenous studentsânothing. Nothing went with it. He just said, âThis should happen.â He seems to forget that he is the minister and he should take responsibility for actually fixing the inequality that exists in vocational education and training for Indigenous students.

So, for this to be anything more than just a meaningless thought bubble from the education minister, we need to see increased funding for vocational education and training, additional TAFE places and support for Indigenous Australians, especially those in regional and remote parts of the country. We know already that 15,000 young people are turned away from TAFE each year because there are not enough places. So where on earth does the minister think these additional Indigenous students are going to go when we already have 15,000 young people turned away? If this government wants to insist that more young Indigenous Australians occupy TAFE places, it has to actually make sure they exist; otherwise, it is just another thought bubble coming out of the head of this education minister.

We certainly support the idea of more young Indigenous students going into TAFE and training. We think it is a terrific idea. In fact, Labor put forward a policy before the last election that said all young Australians, including young Indigenous Australians, must be in work associated with subsidised training, in full-time training or at school. Laborâs view is that no young person should be unemployed. We want them all engaged in the community. But, of course, we did not just say it; we were proposing to provide additional TAFE places, mentors in our schools, subsidised training for young people at work and so many other additional practical things that would have made our policy a reality.

What do we get from this government? The latest training funding offer to the states and territories does not include growth funding for additional TAFE places. There is not any growth funding; there is just the reallocation of funding that is partly contained in the bill we are debating. Not only are 15,000 young people being turned away from TAFE but there is no effort by this government to expand funding for vocational education and training to make sure that Indigenous and non-Indigenous students get the training that they want.

The latest Australian Bureau of Statistics report on the population characteristics of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians showed that Indigenous Australians are severely disadvantaged when it comes to accessing employment, education and training. You would hope that this report would have been a wake-up call to this government. The report found that Indigenous Australians are twice as likely as non-Indigenous people to have left school before completing year 10 and half as likely to have completed year 12. Also, Indigenous Australians aged 18 to 24 are less than a quarter as likely as their non-Indigenous counterparts to go to university. All of these facts have come out of the Australian Bureau of Statistics report just released.

All of these things are the direct result of this government taking its eye completely off the ball when it comes to Indigenous education and training. Indigenous people are nearly five times more likely to be unemployed compared to non-Indigenous Australians when CDEP recipients are included. Between 1996 and 2001 the total number of unemployed Indigenous Australians increased by nearly 17.5 per cent when CDEP recipients are included. I hope the Minister for Workforce Participation, who is at the table, intends to do something about that.

Almost half of the 15- to 17-year-old Indigenous Australians in the labour force are either unemployed or on CDEP. That is the record of this governmentâhalf the number of teenage Indigenous Australians are unemployed. Over 40 per cent of 18- to 24-year-old Indigenous Australians in the labour force are either unemployed or receiving CDEP.Â The average weekly income of Indigenous Australians is $226 per week compared to non-Indigenous Australians who, on average, earn $380 per week. These outcomes are a disgrace and this government must know it has to do better.

Unlike this government, the Labor Party took to the last election many policies that demonstrated our very serious commitment to Indigenous education and training. I have already mentioned the youth guarantee. In addition to that our schools policy included an additional $179 million in targeted support for Indigenous school students. Our policy included programs to improve school attendance and basic skills. We wanted to support the development of culturally relevant curricula, teaching materials and multimedia. We wanted to support Indigenous languages in our schools.

Our approach of supporting education and training through mentoring is also very important in Indigenous communities. Our policy included special support for Indigenous teachers because we know that Indigenous people want more of their own people teaching their children and young people. I have no doubt that it would have an enormous impact on people to see the leaders of Indigenous communities in their classrooms. We also know that Indigenous teachers and teacher education students need support, especially if they are to return to their own communities. I thank the member for Lingiari for taking me to a number of communities in his electorate where that point was made very clear to me.

Labor included in our policy $46 million for new pathways for Indigenous teachers and professional support for those teachers, including the building of networks to recruit and support them. These are all practical initiatives that this government could pick up if they were serious about addressing these terrible inequalities. Laborâs policy included $87 million to improve capital and ICT infrastructure for Indigenous students. If you go out to some of the Indigenous communities in the electorate of the member for Lingiari you will see the state of some of the schools. They are a national disgrace. This government should be putting capital funding into them to make sure that the children in those schools get decent buildings in which to learn. In some places in the Northern Territory there are no secondary schools. The children have to go far away from home to go to a secondary school.

Those are the substantial commitments that the Labor Party made. They were substantial, detailed commitments to make a real start in addressing the crisis in Indigenous education. As Kim Beazley, the Leader of the Opposition, said earlier this week in his speech to the National Reconciliation Planning Workshop:

quote.para: Leadership means admitting that weâre still failing Indigenous Australians and we have to find a better way.

speech.para: I certainly hope everyone speaking here in this debate will admit that. I think the Leader of the Opposition is rightâwe have to find a better way. As a society we cannot keep ignoring the evidence that points to ongoing disasters in Indigenous education and training. This government is here now and it needs to find this better way; otherwise these horrific statistics, which indicate gross inequality in our community, will just get worse.

talk.start.para: (Mr Quick)âIs the amendment seconded?
âI second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

âIn her speech on the Indigenous Education (Targeted Assistance) Amendment Bill 2005 the member for Jagajaga made another contribution of the kind which we have come to expect from herâone of endless rhetoric and abuse. She has given us a 30-minute recital of statistics, cliches and shallow assessments but no solutions other than throwing money at endless programs. That is the only thing that the Labor Party have on their plate. It is the only answer they have. It is a further example of the policy laziness of the opposition. The Labor Party have a policy vacuum in this area and in many other areas. They have made no attempt, in this very critical area of our community, to ascertain why the Indigenous community is bedevilled with chronic societal problems which militate against successful education outcomes. We need to get beyond just throwing money at the problem. The Labor Party had 13 years of trying to find solutions, which involved throwing money at the problem. But that approach failed. This government are seeking to take a much wider view of the problems bedevilling Indigenous communities to see if we can come up with durable and effective solutions.

speech.para: Education is the foundation of freedom and personal development for Indigenous Australians, as it is for the broader Australian community. Without education the options open to people throughout life are invariably narrow and very limited. Without education, ignorance and lack of opportunity predominate. The lack of education becomes a breeding ground for low self-esteem and low self-discipline, prejudice, self-justification, antisocial behaviour, the growth of a victim mentality and the non-realisation of the potential that exists within each and every one of us. For this reason, quality primary and secondary education is fundamental to tackling the chronic disadvantage and aimless circumstance confronting so many in our Indigenous communities.

To begin with, the simple discipline of attending school five days a week for six to seven hours a day, taking some lunch, doing some homework, participating constructively in the classroom, playing some sport and participating in other non-academic activities for 10 to 12 years, slowly but surely instils in individuals the life skills, routines, self-confidence and reading and writing skills to go on to further study, or to take on a trade or generally enter the work force.

Sadly, many in our Indigenous communities have for a long time been denied the chance to develop these necessary life skills. While adequate resources are a necessary and very important part of dealing with thisâand the coalition government over 9Â½ years has massively increased the money going to our Aboriginal communitiesâin many instances, other factors are operating to prevent young Aboriginal people from getting a strong educational grounding and experience. Serious disruption in the home and community, substance and physical abuse, a mendicant welfare mentality which fosters an environment where self-responsibility and self-discipline is leached out of a community, very few good role models and many bad ones, and a corresponding disregard for one another are not uncommon. This environment makes it extremely tough for Aboriginal students not only to persist in education but also to reach a standard at primary school that gives them a chance to fit in and keep up at secondary school. The seeds of failure are sown early in the lives of so many young Aboriginal people, long before they have any real say in it.

There are no easy answers. One initiative worth watching is a trial project at the Coen State School in the middle of Cape York. The Computer Culture trial is being run by an Indigenous organisation, Noel Pearsonâs Cape York Partnerships, with the support of a range of government and commercial interests, including very strong support from Westpac. This program is directed at primary-age school children, using multimedia digital technology to capture stories and traditional cultures, and is a core component of the curriculum. This approach has resulted in the active and regular involvement of parents and grandparents in the classroom and has prompted excitement and engagement, which is extremely powerful and constructive.

In the process of capturing the rich inheritance of Aboriginal history and culture in a very interactive, creative and repeatable way, this program is giving primary school students at Coen a strong sense of history and identity while educating them in literacy, numeracy and technical skills; engaging and educating their extended families; encouraging them to complete major projects and homework; and exposing them and their families to the joys and very personal achievements of learning. This can set kids up to achieve their full potential and it enables them to have a good knowledge of the history, customs and languages of their own community, while giving them the educational basis and life skills to cope within the broader Australian community and, in doing so, have the best of both worlds.

Programs such as these are powerful and hold great potential, but they are not enough. Money alone is not the answer. In many cases, we are throwing good money after bad, because the causes of the social and cultural disintegration of many remote Indigenous communities are not being addressed and have failed to be addressed over decades. Restoring self-esteem and personal responsibility is the key. Participation in primary education is one of the basic means of building life skills and restoring a sense of personal responsibility and obligation. For starters, regular attendance at school is a must. Parents must take responsibility for ensuring the regular participation of their children at school. Many do not, because long-term welfare dependency has fostered a state of mind which is an anathema to personal responsibility and obligation. If they do not shoulder these fundamental parental responsibilities there need to be consequences through either denial of or restrictions on financial or other entitlements. The incentives must change if these parents are to shoulder these critical obligations to their children.

These are the sorts of deep societal problems that have driven the focus of this governmentâs approach to Aboriginal affairs. The problems are much too broad just to throw money at them. We have to engage with the Aboriginal community and try to deal with these underlying problems, the passive dependency that has grown out of many decades of welfare without obligation. The coalition government has embarked on a wide range of reforms, including the shared responsibility agreements, in close operation with the Aboriginal community to seek to deal with the chronic attitudinal problems induced by passive welfare over three decades.

The bill before the House is focused on the Indigenous children from remote communities who have had parental support and the opportunity to get through primary school and have reached a standard where they can hope to fit in at year 8 in a secondary boarding school. There are many primary kids who are still struggling to reach that standard. This bill is focused on those who have had the support and opportunity to get through primary school to reach a year 8 standard and who are well equipped to go on to secondary boarding school. At the moment, only 38 per cent of Indigenous students who commence secondary school continue to year 12, compared to 76 per cent of non-Indigenous students. That percentage could be expected to be much lower for Indigenous students from remote communities.

In the past, boarding schools have played a prominent role in the successful secondary education of both Indigenous and non-Indigenous students from remote areas of Australia. This has been the case because the financial and practical reality is that quality secondary education is extremely difficultâin nearly all cases, it is not possibleâin remote communities. As the primary school issue is progressively addressed by both state and Commonwealth governments with the communities themselves and the leadership of the Aboriginal communityâwho are very clearly coming to understand the importance of addressing the passive welfare problem, the gross dependence and the impact that this has on the lives, attitudes, motivations, self-confidence and self-esteem of individuals within these communitiesâpolicy will focus more and more on providing scholarships for Indigenous students from remote areas to attend quality secondary schooling in non-remote areas. In this way, students will have the teachers, the facilities and the exposure to the broader Australian community which will give them the chance to meet their full potential and to make the most of their lives by equipping them with the skills and education to move more freely and comfortably between their own communities and the broader Australian community and contribute effectively to both.

This bill seeks to assist this policy direction by funding tutorial support for an estimated 2,400 Indigenous students in their first year of boarding school. The aim is to help these students cope with their studies and ensure they reach a standard where they can fit in comfortably with others in the class who may have had a better basis of education in their primary school years.

It is an important piece of legislation to complement the raft of other initiatives that this government is taking and the efforts that are being made in close cooperation with the Aboriginal community. We are not just throwing money at problems. This has been the narrow focus and the way in which governments in the past have sought to shift responsibility back to others, to unload responsibility and not take responsibility for solving these problems. There are no easy answers in this area. This government has sought to do the hard things and work with the community to find the fundamental problems and causes of the real difficulties we have with ensuring our Aboriginal children have the same educational opportunities and make the most of education in the same way as the rest of the community. I commend the bill to the House.

talk.start.para: âI am somewhat surprised at the contribution from the member for Goldstein, partly because I thought he knew better. The attack he has made on the contribution of the shadow minister, Ms Macklin, demonstrates not only ignorance but also failure to even want to learn about the issues. He attacked the shadow minister for illustrating the parlous state of Aboriginal education in Australia and the very poor educational outcomes that they are achieving. She painted a word picture using data about this tremendous obligation that we have in this country to address the primary disadvantage of Indigenous Australians in educational achievement. What we got from the member for Goldstein was some sort of apology for the governmentâs failure to provide adequate resources to address the issue. Apologetically, almost, he said that the answer to this question was, largely, in the case of secondary kids, to send them away from their homes to schools. It is about time the member for Goldstein actually looked, listened and learnt. Walk around the country. Go to the communities that I work in and come back and then tell the story.
âI have been there.

âOh, you have been to these communities; you have obviously learnt nothing and understood nothing. What we know as a result of the contribution from the member for Goldstein is that the apologists of the government are saying that it is all someone elseâs fault. Let me ask the member for Goldstein this question: is it the responsibility of Indigenous parents who live in remote communities to provide access to schools in their communities? Whose responsibility is that? Who has the responsibility to provide Indigenous people with housing, health and education facilities? Who has that responsibility? Who has the responsibility to make sure every kid in Australia has access to a school or training opportunities? From the member for Goldsteinâs contribution, it appears that it is the responsibility of the parents.

speech.para: I live here in Narrabundah where I was brought up as a kid. There is a state school down the road and a Catholic school up on the corner. Those schools were provided. Yet in some communities in the Northern Territory we know there are 3,000 to 5,000 young people over the age of 13 who have no educational opportunities. No service is being provided for them. Is that their responsibility? Who must accept the responsibility for provision of these fundamental civic and human rights?

talk.start.para: âThe Territory government.

âI will come to that in a moment. What a lead-inâ27 years of CLP government in the Northern Territory and you know what the result was? Not one secondary school in any Indigenous community. Whose responsibility was that? CLPâyour mates, comrade. Conservative politicians.
âDonât have a heart attack!

âDo not take umbrage, my friend, just understand. The story is clear. You invited this. In the case of the Northern Territory there were 27 years of indolence and an absolute denial of the right of Indigenous Australians to educational opportunities. That is what happened. Not one state school in the Northern Territory had any secondary facilities when the CLP lost government in 2001. Minister, whose responsibility is that? You said it is the states. It might be the states. Who was in power at the time? Which state government? Which party was in power? The CLP. Look at meâthe CLP, the conservatives. They were responsible.
(Hon. IR Causley)âThe member for Lingiari will not intimidateâ

âMr Deputy Speaker Causley, you wonder, donât you? I do. The minister comes in here blissfully ignorant of what has been going on in the past and makes these absurd statements. Earlier this week we had the Prime Minister address a reconciliation conference down at Old Parliament House. He made a number of statements and I want to repeat some of them. He said:

quote.para: Reconciliation is about rights as well as responsibilities. It is about symbols as well as practical achievement.

speech.para: He said reconciliation must:

quote.para: ... harness our shared commitment to overcoming community disadvantage, dismantle the barriers that hinder indigenous Australians from sharing in the bounty that this great country has to offer, and of which our other young contributor spoke so eloquently just a few moments ago.

speech.para: He goes on:

quote.para: I simply, along with Iâm sure all of you, want an Australia where an Aboriginal childâwhether born in a remote community or in one of our cities or in regional centresâcan grow up and reach their full potential in life. I want that child to be loved and nurtured and morally guided, to be healthy, educated, optimistic, ambitious and to feel a full part of the Australian community.

speech.para: Hear, hear! Great. Tremendous. But what has he done about it? What have the government done about it? I can tell you what they have done about it: nothing. What have they done to address the parlous state of health, education, housing, employment opportunitiesâthe intrinsic thingsâfor Indigenous people in Australia? The answer is nought. They have said, âThese responsibility agreements known as SRAs will achieve everything.â They will not. I have been dealing with Indigenous Australians in the bush for nigh on 30 years and I can tell you one thing: most of the people I have met are committed to getting their children educated. There are all sorts of problems which they confront, and you illustrated some of them. But let me tell you: they are committed. They want their kids to learn. They may themselves, but in many cases do not, have an educational background. But what they do know is that they want their kids to be able to achieve. They want their kids to be able to live in the two cultures that they need: the dominant culture as well as their own culture. They understand the importance of education.

The member for Goldstein said words to the effect, âKids need discipline; they need to be able to go to school with lunch, to go home, to do a bit of homework and to play some sport.â Terrific sentiments. The Prime Minister went to Wadeye recently. At Wadeye, he waxed lyrical about the swimming pool that was built and that, as a result of the swimming pool, school attendance has gone up. Let me ask these questions: did he bother to look at the housing situation at Wadeye? Did he visit any of the homes where house occupancy is 17 or 20 people in a three-bedroom home? Did he then conclude that it was possible for the kids to go home and (1) to get well nourished and (2) to do their homework? Are you serious? The only way to address these issues is by dint of a partnership between the governments and the community. That is clear. The only way it will be achieved in the endâonce agreement is reached on what the solutions areâis for the government to put its hand in its pockets. Resources will be needed. You cannot provide an education without a school. You cannot provide an education without school books and teachers. You need to train these people. The member for Goldstein says: âThat is all right. We do not need them. We do not need resources.â

What we see in the Indigenous Education (Targeted Assistance) Amendment Bill 2005 is the government actually decreasing expenditure on its specific education programs. I raise this issue because I think it is extremely serious that we have this government talking about practical reconciliation and we have the member Goldstein, and no doubt other members of the government, talking about the need for people to take personal responsibility without understanding that they want to. I do not know of any community where people do not want to. But what they want is a fair share. They want their rights as citizens to the health, housing, education, and training and employment opportunities which I have spoken about and which this government is denying them. The problem for the member for Goldstein is that the word picture which was painted by the shadow minister adequately illustrates the failure of the government to address these issues.

You talked about personal responsibility and passive welfareâand I assume you were talking about CDEP. You may be. If not, let me give you a bit of history. CDEP was an effort by Indigenous Australians to say to the government, âWe do not like the idea of the dole. We do not like the idea of our people getting money for no purpose. We do not like the idea because we can see how people spend their money. They are not doing anything. They are indolent.â So what did the government do with a good policy response in the early seventies? It said, âLet us develop a program.â So it developed CDEP. What was it? It was an attempt by the community to accept its collective and individual obligations to the Australian taxpayers by saying to the government, âYou give us CDEP instead of unemployment benefits and we will work for the money.â Is that passive welfare? That is what the people did; that was their initiative. Let us not have any of this rewriting of history. Let us not have any of this parading of victimisation of Indigenous Australians. Let us not blame them for the governmentâs indolence, because it is the government that is responsible. We know about the responsibility of the minister.

The shadow minister talked about the changes to ASSPA, the Aboriginal Student Support and Parent Awareness program, and to ATAS, the Aboriginal Tutorial Assistance Scheme. Last year in this very same debate we discussed these issues. In the course of that debate I talked about the concerns the community that I represent has about the way in which the government is going about implementing these changes and what they would mean to the community. I said at the time, at least in part, that some of the parentsâ concerns were that they believed programs run by ASSPA directly affected student attendance, that parents would not have a voice in the new structure and that the new structure would not be user-friendly like the then current form in which the community was able to address issues as they arose.

How right they were. We know now that no funds have been released to any school in my electorate as a result of the substitute program for ASSPA this year. We know that the ASSPA committees do not operate. They are not funded to operate. So the resources that were going to schools for special programs agreed to in decisions made by the school community are no longer being funded. I ask the member for Goldstein: who takes responsibility for that? Do the parents take responsibility for that? After all, they were the ones making the decisions about how the money was to be spent. Now it is a two-stage bureaucratic process. And who makes the decisions now? Bureaucrats with no educational training, no educational background and no professional understanding of the conditions in which these kids live. Let us be very clear about it: this is what is happening. Not one of these schools has received funding this year. So the programs that were helping have now been cut.

Then we have the Aboriginal Tutorial Assistance Program, which is now called ITAS. We heard the shadow minister talk about the stupidity of only applying these funds after kids have failed tests at years three, five or seven. What giant brain worked out that the best way to fix the early educational problems of kids was to only give them additional resources for tutorial assistance after they have failed tests? What brilliant mind thought that up? I have been a teacherâthere are a number of teachers in this Houseâand I do not know one teacher or one person with any experience in the education system who would argue that the best way to provide early intervention is to wait until kids fail tests. What a ludicrous statement; what a ludicrous thing to even be contemplating. What we should be saying is that these children need assistance from the day they walk into the school and if the teachers identify the special need then those resources should be provided. I say to the member for Goldstein as he leaves the chamber: do not walk out blindly; listen and learn, because at some point in your life you might understand a few things.

The other point I want to make is about the educational framework which the government is intending to set up. I heard the minister talking in question time this afternoon about reporting on student achievements. We have had the shadow minister point out how low the achievement levels are in Indigenous communities. Let me ask this question: what contemplation has there been by the government of the cultural appropriateness of the programs they are operating? It is fine to talk about the need for mathematics and English literacy, but what about the cultural imperatives that exist in many of these communities? The tenor I get from the government is that they want Indigenous communities to suppress their cultural priorities and put them as a second-tier priority. The government want them to have the priorities that the government set, not the priorities the communities want.

We talk about these agreements between the government and communitiesâthis is extremely importantâbut one thing I am certain of is that the primary objective of people in the communities in which I work, in the bush, in Alice Springs and around the electorate of Lingiari, is to maintain their cultural integrity. They want to make sure that their kids understand their cultural obligations. It is very important that those people providing educational services to these communities also understand these cultural obligations. The fact is, of course, that the government show no appreciation of the cultural obligations or priorities of these communities. They say, âOne size fits all. If you want to apply for funds, then apply for themâwe will make a decision here in Canberra through the bureaucratic processes.â They will not be made at the community level. They will not be made identifying what the community sees as its priorities. They will be made by the government, 3,000 kilometres away from where the decision should be made.

I think it is about time the government re-examined its priorities and started to understand its obligations to these Australian citizens. It is no longer good enough to just lay blame. Yes, it is true that parents need to take greater responsibility and, yes, it is true that in many communities there are problems with substance abuse. I visit these communities regularlyâI have done so since 1977. I have seen people die from petrol sniffing. I have seen people die from alcoholism. I have seen people who were massively abused. There is no doubt that it is a sorrowful picture, but I do not think the way to achieve a better outcome is to just blame. The way to achieve better outcomes is through a partnershipânot an unequal partnership where the government comes in and says, âWe are happy to make an agreement with you and we are happy to provide you with resources, provided you do what we want.â That is not the sort of partnership that should exist. It is a very unequal relationship.

As Patrick Dodson said earlier this week on ABC TV and radio, he sees these SRAs as assimilationist. They are. They do what I said previously. They take no account of the cultural imperatives of Indigenous Australians, because they are a bureaucratic response to a problem which has been identified at the community level and is seen as a national concern. The bottom line is that, in the context of this bill, there has been no effort by the government to provide the resources to adequately address the educational deficiencies confronting Indigenous Australians across this nation. There has been no effort made and no additional resources put in. We heard the glib comments made by the Prime Minister at the reconciliation conference earlier this week, we will no doubt get comments from the Minister for Education, Science and Training about what he is doing to improve outcomes for Indigenous Australians, but we know they are doing very little.

On the other hand, there is an election coming up in the Northern Territory on 18 June. I pointed out earlier that in 2001, when the Labor Party won after 27 years of conservative government in the Northern Territory, there was not one Indigenous community with a high schoolânot one. I am pleased to be able to announce that as a result of expenditure and policy changes by the current governmentâand I say this to the Minister for Workforce Participation, across the tableâthey now have secondary school facilities at Minyerri, Kalkarindji, Maningrida, Shepherdson College and Manyallaluk. There will be significant upgrades of Pupanya and Utopia, and a secondary program is being operated at Yuendumu and other places. These were not being done under the CLP government

talk.start.para: âIt is still part of the problem, though. That is the point!

âIt may well be the point; but what the Northern Territory government are doing is ensuring that they address these issues in the Northern Territory contextâunlike their CLP counterparts, who ignored the problem for 27 years and took deliberate decisions not to provide educational services to the bush. That is what the CLP did.

speech.para: We as a nation have a responsibility to address the issues of educational disadvantage for Indigenous Australians. This government has a responsibility. The Prime Minister can talk about reconciliation, but the runs will be on the board only when he sets benchmarks and puts the resources in to achieve outcomes agreed upon in a partnership between Indigenous Australians and governments at all levels.

talk.start.para: âI must say I was absolutely appalled by the contribution made by the honourable member for Lingiari on the Indigenous Education (Targeted Assistance) Amendment Bill 2005. The Labor Party were in office for very many years and the situation of Indigenous disadvantage did not improve. We saw where a lot of money was wasted in the area of Indigenous Affairs. Their solution simply always was to throw money at the problem. Unfortunately there was not the same level of accountability with respect to moneys spent on Indigenous Affairs as in other areas, therefore that made it very difficult, when we were elected in 1996, for us to gain the community support we needed to improve Aboriginal health outcomes. This government has a very proud record in the area of Indigenous Affairs. All of us want to see Indigenous disadvantage removed. All of us want to see Indigenous males live for the same length of time as other Australian males. The Labor Party stand condemned.

speech.para: Debate interrupted.

talk.start.para: âOrder! It being 7.30 pm, I propose the question:

motion.para: That the House do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: âI am compelled to rise tonight because I am disturbed by an answer given by the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Transport and Regional Services in question time today when he was asked about overnight reports that a person who served eight years in prison for serious drug smuggling is working at Sydney airport. In his answer the minister said in part:

quote.para: ... I am advised at this point in timeâand I seek to make the point clear that I am advised and I can only report to the best of my knowledgeâthat there are potentially two individuals who might have fitted that category. One no longer has an ASICâ

speech.para: that is, an aviation security identification cardâ

quote.para: The other does. It relates to an offence committed in about 1980. The individual involved served his time and a number of years lapsed, resulting in that conviction having been spent. In those circumstances, under state and Commonwealth lawâas I think the Leader of the Opposition and, I hope, the shadow minister who asked the former question would knowâtheir previous misdemeanours must be overlooked. They cannot be used to discriminate against people in the workplace.

speech.para: The minister is wrong on that count. Spent conviction schemes allow criminal records of offenders to be amended after certain periods of timeâthat is trueâand the idea is that spent conviction schemes allow former offenders to wipe the slate clean after a certain period of time depending on the offence. In Australia, the Commonwealth spent conviction scheme was introduced in 1990. It is in the Commonwealth Crimes Act at page 425. But under the Commonwealth and Queensland legislation, only convictions to which a sentence of imprisonment of 30 months or less has been imposed can become spent.

Spent conviction legislation also exists in all states and territories except South Australia and Victoria, where there are administrative guidelines about the disclosure of criminal convictions. In all jurisdictions except Western Australia, spent conviction legislation applies only to less serious offences, not to offences that relate to eight years imprisonment in relation to drug matters. In Western Australia spent conviction legislation applies to all offences except those with a penalty which includes a sentence of life imprisonment. In Western Australia, serious convictions become spent only upon application to and approval by the District Court where the making of an order is at the discretion of the judge. In terms of New South Wales, the ACT, the Northern Territory and Tasmania, only convictions for which a sentence of imprisonment of six months or less has been imposed can become spent.

So the minister is wrong when he asserts in question time today that it is automatic in relation to Commonwealth and state law that convictions become spent and must be overlooked, especially when the factâand he admits thisâis it was a conviction in 1980. I practised in criminal law before I came into parliament. I am aware of the law. In Western Australia, in the only jurisdiction that could allow this, it needs to be applied for by a District Court judge and it is discretionary; it is not automatic.

I think the minister is confused. Indeed there is a wonderful report by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, a discussion paper issued in December 2004, that talks about discrimination in employment on the basis of a criminal record. At the moment the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General is considering the development of a national uniform model. But this minister is wrong as to what he asserts in question time today and he should come back into the House to correct the record, either tonight or tomorrow, because he is confused. Indeed there are differences as to spent conviction across the board. The facts as they are known are that someone has served eight years for drug offences and is still working at Sydney airport, and this minister asserts that it is a spent conviction. He is wrong, and I assert that he is wrong. He does not know the law when he tells this House in his answer that in effect it becomes a spent conviction and it must be overlooked.

I am not against rehabilitation. I am not against people getting jobs after they come out of jail. That is not the point that I am making. This is a serious matter and the minister needs to come back and tell the House which jurisdiction and what the penalty was that was served. The Minister for Workforce Participation, Mr Dutton, who is at the table, could do that in his stead, but the House needs to have it properly recorded. That is why I have risen to speak. I have not risen tonight on a spurious point. I think the minister is confused. I do not believe that someone who got eight years for drug offences has a spent conviction. That is just not the case. Do not confuse it with the other point about rehabilitationâthat is not what I am saying. I am saying the minister has to come back to explain. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âOnce more I rise in this place to illustrate the double standards of the Child Support Agency. I quote from a letter I received from Perth, Western Australia, from a person who is a constituent of one of my parliamentary colleagues, who is aware of the letter and is taking the matter up as his local member. I have spoken to the wife of the person who sent me this information and she and her husband are in concurrence with me raising this particular issue so that we can put on record just how bad the Child Support Agency is. The letter, dated 17 May 2005, says:

quote.para: Dear Mr Schultz
I am a 38 year old married man with Three children, prior to my current marriage I was a single parent for six years, with sole custody of my oldest son, James.

I met my current wife in 1996 and had a two year relationship before being married in 1998, we now have two children together. Myself, my wife and my three children lived together in our family home from 1998 until now.
James recently decided he wanted to leave home and live with his mother Christina. Christina has also re-married with two children with her current Husband.

After discussions with Christina it was decided that James could stay with her and her current family. James moved from our house to theirs on the 10th of April 2005. During my initial discussions with Christina she expressed that she didnât feel it was fair to take 18% of my salary. I told her I was willing to support James as I have done for the last 15 years and asked if we could agree on an amount to help her with James. Christina telephoned me on the 11th of April asking me to contact Child Support Agency as she had made an application to them. I am now expected to pay 18% of my gross income which was $106,000 in the 2003-2004 tax year.

This works out to be approximately $275 per week and after waiting for 1 month to have the payment set up I am now paying an additional $60 per week for amounts owing, bringing the total to approximately $335 out of my weekly salary for the next 14 weeks. As James is 17 this payment will continue for 1 year and total an amount of $14,300. I consider these amounts excessive for a number of reasons, the first being that I have supported James for the last 15 years, paying for all his education, private tuition for school, doctors bills, dental bills, clothing, food, karate lessons, football fees, a house for him to live in and supporting him as a parent should. Whilst in return Christina paid a total of $2,300 over a period of 15 years, which are figures I have received from the Child Support Agency. Secondly, the amount I am paying is a disadvantage to my current family that I also have to support and as my youngest child is only three and needs fulltime care from his mother, making her unable to work at this point in time.

Thirdly, as a woman, Christina has re-married, has a husband support her, works part-time, and also claims an excessive amount of child support, whilst only having paid $3.00 per week over 15 years to her first son. I have contacted the Child Support Agency regarding this issue and have pleaded my case to them, they seem to be under the impression I am trying to shy away from my responsibility to James, when in fact I never have in the past. The Child Support Agency have been very condescending to me over the phone, and the system seems to be out of touch with my case and with other people in my situation.

I am writing to you, asking for help with my case and hope you can see why I feel I am being unfairly treated. I have always taken care of my responsibilities and feel I am now being penalised. I hope you will consider approaching the Child Support Agency with my case and appeal for a fairer child support amount.
I await your reply.
Regards, Anthony Bell

speech.para: Mr Bell can be assured that I will approach the Child Support Agency. I will approach the minister and, once again, I will illustrate very forcibly to the minister the double standards of the Child Support Agency. This man supported his son for 15 years and received a measly $3 a week from his former partner, and he is now being asked to contribute $335 a week for the next 12 months to support his son. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âLike the member for Banks, I am compelled to rise tonight because I was appalled today at question time by the Minister for Foreign Affairs mincing at the dispatch box, vacillating between supreme arrogance and extreme unction. It was all about Vivian Alvarez Solon, an Australian citizen who lived here for 13 years and who was deported to the Philippines in July 2001. The shadow minister asked this question:

quote.para: Does the minister recall telling the Australian people on 16 May this year, in relation to the Vivian Alvarez Solon case, âI can only say to you that as far as my department is concerned we didnât know anything about her case until the end of last month,â meaning the end of April 2005? Is the minister aware of a letter from the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and tabled in Senate estimates today that says that the immigration department has now âlearned of an exchange between the Queensland police missing persons unit and DFAT in September 2003â and that the papers we have received from DFAT relating to this exchange show that Queensland policeâin providing DFAT with the context of their requestâindicated that Ms Alvarez was actually an Australian citizen? Minister, is it not the case that, at the height of the public debate in this country on the Vivian Alvarez matter, on 16 May you misled the Australian people about when your department first knew that Vivian Alvarez was an Australian citizen, and why have you not corrected the record?

speech.para: Mr Speaker, you witnessed the justification. There was no apology for the briefing note being wrong. The minister could not even say that he had launched an inquiry to find out why his department had misled him in that briefing note that he had relied on. This is all that the minister said:

quote.para: The fact is that I provided at that time the information that had been provided to me in a written submission from my department.

speech.para: Minister, it was wrong! It has been proven to be wrong. Your department knew 18 months ago that we had deported an Australian citizen but it did absolutely nothing about it. What did the minister say? âI provided all the relevant papers to the Palmer inquiry.â

We know that the Palmer inquiry will deal with only the one case. The minister cannot even table the papers in this House. Vivian is an Australian Filipina. I say in this House that I am very proud of the Filipinos that live in my electorate. There are a lot of them living in my electorate, as there are in the member for Greenwayâs. There are other members in Western Sydney who have lots of Filipinos living in their electorates, and they cannot understand how a citizen who has lived for 13 years in this country can be deported. The minister is so arrogant that he will not even apologise for the incompetence of his department or the fact that he misled the Australian people. He is so arrogant. He will not apologise. He has not said to the parliament, âLook, Iâm upset about this and I have launched an inquiry.â There is no inquiry, Mr Speaker.

No-one on the other side wants to stand up and talk about this case or about the Filipinos in their electorates who are upset, who may have come here a very long time ago as refugees from a corrupt Marcos regime and who now fear that the very thing that happened to Cornelia Rau or to Vivian Alvarez can happen to them. I say it is an outrage. No citizen should live in fear of being deported. They should not have to witness an arrogant minister who refuses to apologise, thinks it is a laughing matter and wants to make a mockery of this place. I think it is an absolute disgrace. I know that Vivian was not from the establishment. She did not belong to the Adelaide Club or the Melbourne Club. She was not born with a silver spoon in her mouth. She was a battling Filipina who married an Australian and came to this country. She was deported, yet there has not been one word of sympathy, not one word of apology, not one bit of humility and no determination to get to the bottom of it. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âTonight I rise to congratulate and thank the organisers of the Multicultural Family Festival that was held in Quakers Hill in Greenway over the weekend. Several communities were represented on the day, some of which were the Filipino, Indian, Lebanese, Chinese and Italian communities. The festival draws together ethnic communities to celebrate their diversity and to embrace life in multicultural Australia. I was privileged to be present at the celebration on Saturday and witnessed first-hand the connecting that was occurring.

speech.para: This was a celebration that drew together children and families. It was wonderful to see them laughing and enjoying their day together. The spirit of community was evident for all to see. It was an event that was free to families, and that was absolutely fantastic. Children were catered for with face painting, jumping castles, Chinese calligraphy and dancing. The atmosphere was fantastic, with a variety of stalls, international food and fine cuisine. The festival was an opportunity to acknowledge and recognise the richness of the past and the cultural heritage of our ethnic groups.

But it was also about living together in the broader Australian community in harmony. One incredible example was a display by Hindi schoolchildren who performed on the day. Their performance consisted of two parts: firstly, a wonderful performance of traditional Hindu song with the children in their traditional dress. Following this, they sang a song they had written about Australia. It was truly amazing, full of laughter and joy.

The Multicultural Family Festival receives support from a number of local community organisations that should be congratulated for this. Without the assistance of these groups the festival would not be the success I witnessed over the weekend. The Quakers Hill Family Centre have been working to reach out to the local area for over a decade now. Their connection to their community was obvious on the weekend and evidenced by the number of different cultural groups present. It is important to acknowledge the support given to this event by the Australian Chinese Community, the Australian Kurdish Association, Nirimba TAFE, Quakers Hill Uniting Church, the Australian Lebanese Welfare Group, the Philippine-Australian Community Services, and the Blacktown Migrant Resource Centre. I specially want to acknowledge the partnership between Wesley Mission and the Bharatiya Vidya Bhavan whose vision really has brought the community together. Their work in the area is truly worthy of commendation and I am proud to honour their work in this chamber.

Community is at its best when we all come together. Festivals such as this that draw together not just different community groups but, in particular, families are significant. These are projects and festivals that really define a community. It was wonderful to see the next generation participating. Often at these events the older generation are significantly more represented, but this was a festival that was truly family oriented. As a government we have acknowledged the importance that diversity plays in the Australian community and we will continue to support the work of such community based groups that provide such a valuable service.

Greenway, as I have mentioned before in this House, definitely has a vibrant, dynamic and exciting community. Community mindedness is part of what defines who we are. I am proud to support the work of the ethnic support groups in Greenway and I commend them wholeheartedly on the weekendâs Multicultural Family Festival. I look forward to many more events like this where the Blacktown Migrant Resource Centre, Quakers Hill Family Services and other significant ethnic groups and their leaders come together not just to contribute to one another and celebrate their differences but to celebrate harmony as well as looking to the future by providing an environment where the next generation can learn to value the diversity that we celebrate in this country.

talk.start.para: âOn behalf of my constituents in the inner west of Sydney and in my electorate of Lowe I raise yet again the very serious issue of aircraft noise emanating from Sydney airport. As this House is aware, Sydney Airport Corporation Ltd was sold to the Southern Cross Consortium, chiefly held by Macquarie Bank and affiliates, on 28 June 2002. Since that date Sydney airport has continued to expand beyond its ecologically sustainable limit. Principally, this fact is best demonstrated in the continuous failure of this government to fairly implement the long-term operating plan. I have spoken exhaustively on the failure of the Howard government to fulfil its promises to solve Sydney airportâs aircraft noise problems. The Howard government has not solved the problemâit sold the problem.

speech.para: I note that for the month ended 30 April 2005 aircraft movements to the north of Sydney airport were 28.21 per cent of total aircraft movements. The long-term operating plan target for total aircraft movements to the north of Sydney airport is 17 per cent. Movements to the north frequently reach 30 per cent and have been as high as 33 per cent, nearly double the long-term operating plan target.

Sydney airportâs aircraft noise problems continue unabated. I raise the issue in the context of a recommendation to the Minister for Transport and Regional Services by the Sydney Airport Community Forum, SACF, that requested him to draft terms of reference for the commission of a consultant to review the long-term operating planâs performance. Environmental consultants Airways International were retained to perform this work, and last March Airways International handed down its report.

I stand here tonight to record that the Sydney Airport Community Forum is very disappointed with this report for many reasons. The report does not make recommendations as to how the long-term operating plan may be achieved. Nor does the report shed any light on the reasons why the long-term operating planâs aircraft movement targets cannot be achieved. Rather, the consultants refer, dishonestly, to the long-term operating plan as a âcommunity expectationâ and not a statutory instrument carrying the full weight of ministerial direction.

The long-term operating plan is not a mere community expectation. The long-term operating plan and its movement targets are the result of the operation of a statutory power, being section 16 of the Air Services Act. The minister has issued a ministerial direction under that power when directing Airservices Australia to fulfil its terms of reference in the making of the long-term operating plan. The terms of reference are supplemented by further terms of reference of the Implementation Monitoring Committee in which reaching the long-term operating plan targets is a prescribed outcome. Interestingly, Airways International has no knowledge of the Implementation Monitoring Committee terms of reference and makes no reference to those terms of reference in its report. Point 1 of the Implementation Monitoring Committee terms of reference states:

quote.para: To assist the achievement of the integrity, intent and TARGETS of the Sydney Airport Long Term Operating Plan, the Committee shall ... monitor the distribution of noise, flights paths and runways movements which arise out of the implementation of the Long Term Operating Planâ.

speech.para: This House has heard enough of the spin, the obfuscation and glib terms of the minister and from the sculptured reports that fulfil his mission. He who pays the piper calls the tune. The minister is paying for the report, and the report predictably reports what the minister wants to read.

Thankfully, the Sydney Airport Community Forum is not blind, deaf or dumb. No, Minister, Sydney airportâs aircraft noise problems have not been substantially solved. No, Minister, the long-term operating plan targets are not mere community expectations. They are the result of ministerial direction on not one but two occasions in which the minister has exercised his statutory powers. It is upon these two well-founded facts that I can say in this House with absolute certainty that the community and constituents of Sydney have every legitimate expectation that the long-term operating plan must be implemented to its specifications.

That means the long-term operating plan targets must be reached. This is so, despite the fact that the long-term operating plan targets, to be fully implemented, may reduce the number of aircraft and ultimately the profitability of Southern Cross Consortium. Southern Cross knew of the long-term operating plan before they purchased the airport and cannot now deny its effectiveness or implementation. The real variable to implementing the long-term operating plan is not weather conditions, but aircraft demand. The long-term operating plan can be achieved, even if it means fewer planes. To put it bluntly, the government must honour its promises and put the citizens of Sydney first and the shareholders of Southern Cross Consortium and Macquarie Bank last. Moreover, it is time for a second airport for Sydney.

talk.start.para: âI rise this evening to make reference to how proud I am of an industry in Wagga Wagga called Kurrajong Waratah. As their patron, I was proud to launch a report titled Growing old with a disabilityâwho cares? For almost 50 years Kurrajong Waratah has provided services for people living with a disability. They provide employment, accommodation, day and early intervention services to more than 400 babies, children and adults with a disability and their families in the Riverina and Murray regions.

speech.para: This ageing concerns project was funded by Kurrajong Waratah due to concerns that they had about the ageing of many elderly parents who are caring for children and family members with a disability. Without action this is an issue that will only continue to worsen and result in a crisis for many of these families. I congratulate Kurrajong Waratah on taking this initiative. It is an issue that we do not like to discuss because it is very difficult, emotional and painful to have to embrace and confront these issues. But this report will assist families to have this discussion on ways in which assistance can and should be offered into the future.

It is only in recent years that we have seen this problem. People, including those with disabilities, are now living longer. Kurrajong Waratah has recognised that without research, discussion and early intervention a crisis will occur. This report includes a number of recommendations to address the needs of ageing carers and what needs to be done to ensure their children or family members are cared for into the future.

There are a number of surprising and startling results outlined in the survey. I would like to bring to the Houseâs attention that the average age of family members surveyed who were providing care was slightly over 65 years. The youngest carer was 42 and the oldest was 89 years of age. Of those carers surveyed, 75 per cent were over 60, with 22.5 per cent being over 70 years of age. Forty-two per cent of people surveyed lived with a family member. In relation to the access to respite services by a primary carer, just five per cent of the families caring for a loved one accessed formal respite services. Twenty-nine of the families surveyed do not, or are unable to, access any formal respite services because they are not available, or not available in a form that assists themâthey are too expensive or they are not available when needed and for the length of time needed.

In relation to future planning, the following facts are very interesting and very telling. Just less than 50 per cent of families had no plans for the responsibility for caring when they are no longer able to do so. According to the report, a number of carers will pass away in the next 10 years which, without planning and action, will mean a crisis for not only these families but also government and government services. One of the greatest fears of these carers, 80 per cent of whom are parents, is what will happen to their children when they are no longer there. Imagine not knowing what will happen to your children or where they will go when they have relied on you their entire lives and you are no longer there.

The results of this report indicate that for many families there is a crisis in care which will worsen in the next 10 years if planning and action do not occur on all fronts to better meet the needs of people with a disability, their ageing parents and family carers. A number of these current carers will pass away in the next 10 years. At the same time their sons and daughters with a disability will continue to ageâsome more rapidly than the general population due to the nature and type of their disabilities. It is with interest that I bring this matter to the House.
