The government should adopt our proposition of doing these tax cuts differently, giving a greater deal, a better deal, to those people on low incomes, with us at the top end of the income bracket saying, âWell, thatâs not unreasonable; thatâs a good thing to do.â We understand that families are struggling and we could hardly say we suffer from the same pressure on our family budgetsâeven though, in my case, we have a huge number of kids. There are families with an equivalent number of children who earn $55,000 a year or less. I think it is a bloody disgrace, frankly, that we should be countenancing pocketing our 40 or 50 bucks and giving these poor Australians $6 a week.

I have spoken in the past in this place about the cost of living in remote communities, butâleaving aside our differences over the tax issueâthis budget shows me that this government has no comprehension whatsoever of the needs of regional Australia, particularly remote Australia. It has no understandingâthat would be the polite way of putting itâat all of the costs and needs of those communities.

I have spoken in this place before about the plight of roads in the bush. Once again, the budget has let us down. The government talks about the need for infrastructure expenditure, but, once again, it has not addressed the infrastructure needs of Northern Australia. There are between 8,000 and 9,000 kilometres of unincorporated roads in the Northern Territory alone. These are largely used by the beef industry, the mining industry, the tourism industry and small communities. It is a severe cost to business and to those community members to travel on those roads.

With great respect to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, I notice we have in the chamber two members of the National Party, you and one of your colleagues. You understand, I am certain, the cost of transporting beef in road trains over large distances on bad dirt roads. Who bears that cost? Ultimately, the consumer, but directly bearing the cost in the first instance are the road transport industry and the beef producers. I would have thought that, in the context of making our industries more efficient, it would not be beyond the wit and wisdom of this government to recognise that, if you want to increase productivity and efficiency in the bushâthe real bush; not up and down here on the east coastâyou should address those infrastructure shortfalls. But do we get that from the government? No way. Instead we get a very distorted allocation of resources through the Roads to Recovery program. Where does that money go? Of course, in the pockets of National Party seatsâand principally that of the member for Gwydir, I might say.

In my communities we know the costs that are involved in not addressing this issue. A range of issues confront people who live in the bush, like roads and communication. The government is still going to sell Telstra. You chaps in the National Party understandâyou particularly, my friend, Member for Hinklerâthe telecommunication needs of people in the bush. In my communities people are underserviced and underresourced. That is not because Telstra Country Wide are not doing their job. In fact, I have nothing but the highest of praise for the Telstra Country Wide people who work in the Northern Territory. But they are subject to budget decisions made by a board. The majority of the decision-making power rests with the government, as the majority shareholder. The board has made decisions which will ensure that there will be no catch-up.

Despite the protestations of the government, blind Freddy knows what future-proofing means: âWeâll give you a set of standards which we think will work at the time, even though we know youâre behind the eight ball already. Youâll never get to catch up and youâll never get an equivalent standard of service to people who live in the major metropolitan regions.â That is what will happen. So we get a major communications disadvantage for people who live in the bush. That is not something which I think is acceptable, and I know it is not acceptable to the people of Lingiari. We deserve and we want something better from this government.

The people of Lingiari are the poorest of Australians. However, there are pockets of wealth in Lingiari. There is a large mining operation in Groote Eylandt, and there is wealth at Nhulunbuy and Ranger. There is a lot of wealth being developed, and a lot of taxes are being paid to the government, like company tax. There are a lot of export earnings coming into the Australian community. But we are not getting investment back in those communities or in that region by this government. It is about time we actually got a fair shake.

The bulk of the population who live in this community, 44 per cent or thereabouts of the voters in my communities, are Indigenous. They are at the very bottom end of the income scale. They live mostly in abject poverty. I will address this at another time. They are not regarded as being important enough to get the finances that are required to address their poverty needs. We heard the Prime Minister down at the reconciliation conference talking about how he wants to address Aboriginal disadvantage, Indigenous disadvantage, in this country, to meet Indigenous Australians halfway. He could start by addressing the major indicators of poverty. He could start by addressing the $800 million shortfall in Aboriginal housing in the Northern Territory alone, where communities have 17 and 20 people living per house. He goes on about the need for education. As I have said in this place on many occasions, you have to address the health of the whole person and the whole community. That means looking at all those indicators: health, housing, education, primary health care and environmental health.

All of these things cost money. We are seeing no benchmarking by this government of what it is proposing to introduce to these communities to ensure they get out of this poverty. We get a lot of platitudes and a lot of mutual responsibility, but no acceptance by the government of its responsibility to provide these Indigenous Australians with the rights that every other Australian would regard as fundamental to their living. These are rights which they should have, human rights, rights which are accorded to them by conventions which we are signatory toâa right to education, a right to housing, a right to employment opportunitiesâfundamental human rights which this government has failed to properly address. Instead, it talks about penalising people. It is about time we got rid of the penalties and started accepting our responsibilities as a nation to address their most vital needs.

In the few moments I have left, I want to remind the House that, of course, there is an election about to happen in the Northern Territory, on 18 June. The election will involve the Country Liberal Party, a conservative party which has two members sitting in this place, one with the National Party and one with the Liberal Party, I understand. They cannot make up their minds who they are. But we know they are not a Territory party.

âIt is a matter of choice. If they were really a Territory party, they would not sit with either of them, would they? They might vote with them, but they would not sit with them. But they do. Their comradesâconfreres, I might describe them asâin the Northern Territory are seeking election on 18 June, having left office in 2001 after being defeated by the Labor Party.

speech.para: I have to say: that was a great moment in time, one of those moments of history. I was asked to be one of the experts sitting on the ABC panel on the night of the election. Within 20 minutes of the numbers coming in, I was able to say, âI think weâre going to win this. Weâve got these six seats; it will be a Labor victory.â You should have seen their faces. talk.start.para: âToday I am speaking to Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 2005-2006 and the cognate appropriation bills. In doing so, I would like to compliment the Minister for Education, Science and Training, Dr Brendan Nelson, on some of the advancements and general improvements to be found in this budget. As the member for Kalgoorlie, I remind members that the electorate of Kalgoorlie takes up 91 per cent of the Western Australian landmass and by definition, therefore, it has a most sparsely distributed population. There are some 250 communities, approximately, spread across that 2.3 million square kilometres. When I speak in this place, I speak for genuine regional Australia. Any improvement in the education budget that reflects opportunity for regional and remote Australia is of interest to me, because it is of interest to my constituents.

speech.para: In the 2005-06 budget, the Australian government provides an estimated $28.4 million under the Country Areas Program which will benefit Australian schools and students in rural and remote communities. This is good news. It represents an estimated increase of $6.6 million, or 24 per cent over the previous year, to government and non-government education authorities. Of this $28.4 million, an estimated $23.9 million will be provided to state government schools and an estimated $4.5 million will be provided to Catholic and independent schools. The Australian government recognises that students attending primary and secondary schools in geographically isolated areas often have a more limited access to educational opportunities than do metropolitan students. Isnât that nice? The Australian government funds for CAP are provided to state and Northern Territory government and non-government schools. The funds are used to support projects which enhance the curriculum through excursions, visits, and attendance at cultural and sporting events; to assist with the transition to further education, training or work; and to provide access to professional development for teachers.

In addition to those changes, from 2005 the Australian government has significantly increased assistance under the Assistance for Isolated Children Scheme, the AIC. That scheme helps the families of primary and secondary students and tertiary students who are under 16 years old who are unable to attend an appropriate government school on a daily basis primarily because of geographic isolation.

The basic boarding allowance and the distance education allowance both received a significant boost from 1 January 2005. The basic boarding allowance increased from $4,446 to $6,000 per year from 1 January 2005 and will help around 7,500 students who have no choice other than to board away from home at a school, hostel or private home. This results in an estimated increase in funding of over $39.6 million over the four years to 2008-09.

The distance education allowance increased to $3,000 per year for students who study at home through distance education. The increaseâsome $1,759 for a primary school student and $1,140 for a secondary student in 2005âreflects the increased cost of new computer technology and communications infrastructure required by students. This results in an estimated increase in funding of $21.3 million over the four years to 2008-09.

The second-home allowance and the additional boarding allowance increased by the CPI from the beginning of 2005. Also, from 1 July 2005, the Australian government will extend eligibility for youth allowance, Austudy and Abstudy payments to eligible full-time new apprentices, who will be able to apply for the same payments currently available to full-time students. This will assist them in the early years of their new apprenticeship, when their wages are generally at their lowest.

But my main concern today is not the wonderful increases to government funding for rural and remote education, increases which are seriously and greatly appreciated; it is to highlight the fact that inequities still apply. I have a great concern in particular with the inequities that exist in the allocation of and entitlement to youth allowance. What I will endeavour to do today is to point out the contrast between a rural based family having a child who is of tertiary education age and about to leave secondary college, and a city family in exactly the same situation. My proposition is that the rural family, by the nature of their employment, happen to earn more than the allowable ceiling. To start with, the allowable ceiling is $28,850 per annum for the earnings of a family, if they are going to be entitled to the full entitlement of youth allowance for their son or daughter attending a tertiary institution away from their home.

The Youth Allowance program is primarily designed to support young people, but it ought to include country families whose means may be above the current threshold but whose income is not sufficient to enable them to rent or buy a metropolitan unit for their children to attend university. By making youth allowance available to this demographic, not only will the additional costs traditionally shouldered by country students be alleviated but a greater equity in access to educational opportunities will also be achieved. I commonly hear from families of country students who have no choice but to meet practically all of the costs of independent living for their child, while city families merely hand over a few bus or train fares.

If the high level of parental support is not available, accessing youth allowance for a regional student will entail at least a year of full-time work so that he or she can be classed as independent. Compare this to city students, who have the option of going straight to university, comfortable in the knowledge that they can live with their parents for as long as required or desiredâor, possibly, permitted. In terms of access to youth allowance, the parameters of independence represent an anomaly. Students from the city can be classified as independent when in fact it is regardless of whether they live at home or not; whereas, a student from the country has to leave home to study. If they have not taken a gap year to earn eligibility for independence, they do not qualify for youth allowance. This means that a city student can be eligible for youth allowance whilst living at home, whereas a country student has no such luxury.

Compounding this inequity is the fact that these payments can be spent on socialisingâand are very often spent on socialisingâand mere discretionary expenditure. By comparison, country students living in the city have to make ends meet and almost always have a part-time job to cover extra living expenses that youth allowance does not cover.

The amount for independence must be earned in 18 months. Therefore, the student does not receive payments until halfway through the first year of study. They must rely on their parentsâ income or part-time work to cover their living costs in the first five months, a difficult task when studying full time, with some of the biggest expenses, such as books and general setting-up fees, presenting themselves during the first semester. A student can easily be left having no means by which to pay for them.

Further, as most university courses cannot be deferred for more than a year, if a student needs youth allowance while studying, and is not eligible due to his or her familyâs means, they cannot participate in programs like Rotary Exchange, or even take that gap year off to travel, because there is a need to spend a year and a half earning the money to shore up their ability to pursue tertiary education.

I note that there is assistance available to children under 16 under the Isolated Children scheme, as I have just mentioned. It seems reasonable to me, because of the inequities I have pointed up, that this provision be extended to older tertiary students if they are from country areas where they are not able to live at home whilst accessing tertiary education. This was certainly the case for my own children in Karratha, where we lived for 20 years. Like hundreds of families in my electorate, I experienced first-hand this inequity. It is part and parcel of country students pursuing a tertiary education. It is with these hundreds of families in mind that I rise today to underline this anomaly to the House.

We are doing a great deal and achieving a great deal in this area, but still the inequities exist. In the 2000-01 budget we changed the situation so that from 1 January 2001 the government would disregard 75 per cent of the value of a familyâs interest in assets such as a farm or business. We changed that from the allowable 50 per cent, increasing the eligibility or the number of those that would be eligible for youth allowance. Those changes, although they are greatly appreciated, simply do not go far enough. I say again that the federal Youth Allowance system aims to support young people financially if they are unable to completely support themselves. But, with the anomalies that exist, eligibility for the allowance is very difficult to attain.

Parents must have a very low income for their children to be automatically eligible for the allowance. As I have said, young people must work for 18 months and earn $15,950 in that period to be declared independent. The strict limitations on that allowance make it very difficult for students from regional areas who must leave home to study. Obviously they require some form of financial assistance if their family has an income which is above the minimum threshold for eligibility but is unable to support their child. Young people are then forced to take at least that year off from study to become eligible. The current system states that, unless the annual family income is below the threshold for automatic youth allowance, students intending to study higher education must either rely on their parents for assistance during their course or work for that 18 months and earn the required amount.

When you analyse the very restrictive, very narrow terms that make that allowance absolutely available, it becomes obvious that a large number of issues highlight the anomaly and increase the frustration of the families and students that find themselves in this situation. If the regional studentsâ parents cannot support them, or if they already receive a youth allowance, country students must take at least a year off and earn the money for the independence. Alternatively, city students have the option of going straight to university. The comfort that they gain from living with their parents simply highlights, once again, the anomaly that exists. Country students are not able to have their university places held for more than 12 months. This is yet another hurdle in the road for a country student to achieve that diploma or that graduation certificate from a tertiary institution.

The youth allowance payment is not enough to cover college fees. College is an option taken by country students in order to meet new people and have the comfort of acclimatising with more ease to a city situation. That city environment is often most alien to country students. Unless they have the opportunity of the camaraderie that is offered by a university campus college, the achievement of that tertiary education is made more difficult than it ought to be. Because the youth allowance payment, if they are entitled to it, is not enough to cover college fees, the students need to work 10 to 15 hours a week in order to cover the fees. But the system does not allow students to earn more than $118 per week. As a result, the student does not have anywhere near enough funds to live a reasonable existence. If a country student is awarded a scholarship for course fees, they must attend university or TAFE the year after high school graduation. Scholarships cannot be deferred. These students are not supported for living costs and therefore must either rely on their parents for support or reject the scholarship and spend that year working to entitle them, eventually, to a youth allowance.

It is an unfair burden, as I have said, for parents to have to support the living costs of their offspring at university or TAFE. It is often much more than the family can afford. It is not reasonable to suggest that a family income of $28,850, which is in excess of that allowedâthe base limit that starts to disqualify payment of that youth allowance is as low as $28,850âinfers that these families are from some great wealth belt and can set up a son or daughter in a metropolitan or other area where they may attend a tertiary institution that exists. It costs a great deal of money. They will have to meet a weekly rental fee and will have to do something about the cost of food. Many people see that, in the long-term cost effectiveness, they have to go into a mortgage situation and purchase some sort of real estate in the metropolitan area to accommodate their student child. There is ample evidence to suggest that country families do not need this additional hazard to remain loyal residents of regional Australia.

In my 2.3 million square kilometres, I have but one centreâBroome, in the Kimberleyâthat has an increasing population. All the rest are declining. They are declining because of the tendency to empty out rural centres and migrate to city centres; if not city then certainly coastal. This is causing a problem. I am often heard to say that if we allow it to continue to happen we will have the eventuality that when Australians from the leafy suburbs decide to have their once a year, or once a lifetime, sojourn to the outback they will find no-one left to pour the beer or the petrol. It will change, for all time, their impression of the wonderful outback of Australia that has been so much our heritage.

I have, for six years now, contemplated solutions to the demise of populations in the bush. In this place, I have spoken frequently on the topic. I have illustrated today just one hurdle that exists for families residing in rural areasâthat is, the inequity that exists for a family that does not qualify for youth allowance in a rural area, in comparison with one that exists in the city and has all that public infrastructure in place to assist them.

The main solution, as I see it, is a dramatic increase in the taxation zone rebate system that was introduced back in 1945 and has undergone, for the last 10 years, no reasonable review or increase. I call again on my governmentâmy Treasurerâto seriously consider the increase in taxation zone rebates and do something now to change the situation of hurdles in the bush.

talk.start.para: âI rise to speak on the appropriation bills in response to the governmentâs budget for 2005-06. It is now three weeks since the Treasurer brought down his 10th, and the Prime Ministerâs 16th, budget. This budget does not serve Australia well. It does not serve Western Australians well and it does not serve my constituents in Swan well. This is a lazy budget. It depends on the rivers of gold from vast, unanticipated streams of company tax revenue emanating from the resources boom to fund a tax giveaway which is all about rewarding those on high incomes in the Liberal Partyâs natural constituency.

speech.para: In my response last week to the governmentâs legislation on the tax cuts, I outlined many reasons why these tax cuts are so inequitable and provide so little to help those families in Swan and the rest of Australia who continue to struggle to make ends meet. I do not propose to canvass those arguments again. It is sufficient to remind members of the House of the innate injustice of those tax cuts and of the fact that Laborâs tax policy is fair and provides a far better deal to those families in Swan on average incomes. The fundamental question is: why doesnât this budget serve Australia well? The fundamental answer is because it fails to use this revenue bonanza to put in place policies which will ensure Australiaâs future prosperity. We are enjoying the benefits of our abundant natural resources, particularly those from my home state of Western Australia, and a commodity price boom the like of which this country has not seen since the Korean wool boom in the early 1950s.

According to the Treasury, Australiaâs terms of tradeâthe relative value of our exports over our importsâare forecast to rise by 12.25 per cent in the 2005-06 year alone to reach their highest level since the wool boom of the early 1950s. Perhaps members of the House who are senior enough might remember those glory days. Certainly it has become part of the historical record that we received â¤1 for each pound of wool. I am sure the squatter from Corangamite will remember those days well. Just as the good luck which Australia enjoyed then fuelled prosperity for some time so the current good luck we are enjoying could secure higher rates of economic growth and higher living standards into the future for our children and grandchildren.

But, noâput simply, the government failed to put in place the necessary policies to dramatically increase infrastructure spending. This is not to say that tax cuts should not be part of this budgetâall Australians deserve a tax cut as part of this fiscal dividendâbut those tax cuts should be fair and focused more on improving incentives for low- to middle-income earners. There is no doubt that government coffers are oozing with revenue, which could have been used to fund tax cuts and to lay the groundwork for increased infrastructure spending, paving the way for a higher rate of economic growth than we would otherwise enjoy.

As the Leader of the Opposition announced in his budget reply, Labor plans to use the interest earned by the future fund to pay for national infrastructure projects. Unfortunately, the Liberal Party is obsessed with the public serviceâs unfunded superannuation liabilities and has earmarked the future fund for those. According to the Productivity Commission and the governmentâs own Intergenerational report, the superannuation liability of the Commonwealth Public Service is actually in decline as a share of GDP and will continue to decline over the next 40 years. The Liberals have created the superannuation liability argument as a straw man to stymie the attempts by the National Party to turn the future fund into a slush fund for traditional pork-barrelling. I can well understand the Liberalsâ efforts to keep the funds away from the profligate and irresponsible National Party, which regrettably has ministerial control of infrastructure spending.

The examples of rorts and unaccountability in programs administered by the National Party are so legion as to be totally embarrassing. I can hardly bring myself to repeat the alarming examples which have come to light in this parliament just since the last election. I know that the members from the Liberal Party back bench squirm almost as much as we do when the current Deputy Prime Minister is forced in the House to account for his dodgy ministerial practices. When the current Minister for Veteransâ Affairs is called on to explain her administrative misdemeanours it really seems kinder to just turn the microphone off at the dispatch box. For those reasons, I have a kernel of sympathy for the more responsible Liberals trying to keep those funds away from their coalition colleagues. But that does not negate the fact that a much greater focus on infrastructure was sorely needed in this budget, and that is where the government unambiguously failed to deliver for the future of this country.

While the Nationals like to shore up their own electorates with rort-ridden programs and funding allocations which would not pass any objective assessment of worth, many of these projects do not provide the real impetus to infrastructure across Australia that is sorely needed. It is vital for all Australians that our infrastructure, transport, communications, energy, water and so on are as efficient and effective as possible to ensure our international competitiveness. The framework used by the National Party in allocating such projects is not based on economics or sensible public policy; in fact âframeworkâ is too strong a word. The National Party approach is traditionally not rigorous as it has at its origins some of the flagrantly misspent expenditure of the Bjelke-Petersen government in Queensland. Under Joh, if you were a white shoe brigade friend of or a donor to the National Partyâoften with the appellation of âSirâ being put before such names as Bruce, Justin or Bazzaâthen you could have the hereto unsealed road to your property surfaced at taxpayersâ expense.

That is the type of approach the National Party apply to spending programs they administer. They allocate funds to projects involving their mates, bully local communities to make sure that only National Party members are associated with these projectsâjust ask the member for New Englandâand often do the paperwork assessing the projectâs eligibility for funding after the project has been approved, not before.

How many reports have been published over the last 10 years of this government which have highlighted the infrastructure gaps and the bottlenecks which our businesses and exporters have had to deal with to sell their product? Today the government released a long-awaited report by an eminent prime ministerial task force on ways to remove infrastructure bottlenecks that harm Australiaâs economy. This report has confirmed what the Labor Party has been saying: that the current transport infrastructure programs are a joke. The worst joke, of course, is the AusLink program. As eminent economic commentator Alan Wood of the Australian commented the day after the budget:

quote.para: Under AusLink, a lot of money is likely to be wasted without the check of any rigorous cost benefit analysis. It started in the election campaign and will continue, as will the now notorious Roads to Recovery program.

speech.para: As a Western Australian, I have long called for a better deal for Western Australia in terms of transport road funding. Unfortunately, my calls have fallen on deaf ears with this government. It is of little surprise that we in the west call the AusLink program âEastLinkâ, given its focus on the eastern states.

I have been calling for federal assistance under the national highway program for the upgrading of a section of the Great Eastern Highway in my electorate of Swan. The stretch that requires urgent widening and upgrading is between Redcliffe and Rivervale. As those who know Perth well will understand, the stretch of road not only is a major link between the Perth CBD and Perth Airport but also is the major arterial road linking Perth to the eastern states and therefore clearly forms part of the national highway.

As I informed the House earlier this year, it is not overstating matters to say that this section of the highway is the lifeblood of Perthâs transport industry. Yet, again, this sensible, cost-effective project, which ultimately would benefit not just those in my electorate but all Western Australian businesses and indeed national businesses and tourism, has been ignored. As the local member for the area, if the government were to approve this project I would be the first to recognise and acknowledge the wisdom of its doing so. But, yet again, Western Australians have been cruelly disappointed by a government which seems to believe the national border ends at the Nullarbor. Unfortunately it does not, but I am sure it thinks it does.

To add insult to injury, much of the revenue bonanza which this government has received comes from Western Australia in the form of company tax receipts from the mining boom. Is it too much to ask that some of this windfall gain be passed on to the state of origin for the benefit of its citizens and businesses in terms of better infrastructure? I am becoming very concerned about the lack of any advocate for Western Australia in the federal cabinet. While I know that Senators Ian Campbell and Ellison are ministers, I have to say that, if they are arguing as they should be that Western Australia is generating the bulk of the wealth on which Australian prosperity is riding and that therefore Western Australia deserves a better deal, they are being demonstrably unsuccessful in doing so.

Another vital aspect of infrastructure is telecommunications. Unfortunately I have previously had occasion to raise in the parliament the issue of the appalling standards of Telstra services in my electorate. In February and again in March I raised the issue of inadequate services and the broken promises of Telstra in regard to the access of several of my constituents to broadband services. On 17 March this year I wrote to the CEO of Telstra, Dr Ziggy Switkowski, and called on him to come to my electorate to see for himself the inadequacies of Telstra services. I explicitly asked for him not to palm me off onto one of his staff but to come and see these problems for himself. Lo and behold, on 24 March I received a letter not from Dr Switkowski but from Bill Scales, one of Dr Switkowskiâs underlings, informing me that Dr Switkowski had no plans to visit Perth and therefore would not be able to meet with my constituents or me to discuss these problems.

I was disappointed that the CEO of a still majority public owned company would treat the genuine concerns of the current majority owners of Telstraâfor example, my constituentsâwith such disdain and disregard. Imagine my surprise, therefore, when I noticed a few days ago in the social pages of the West Australian newspaper a picture of Dr Switkowski, dressed to the nines, tripping the light fantastic at a business school soiree at the University of Western Australia. It turned out that not only was Dr Switkowski in Perth, when I had been informed that he had no plans to visit the west, but, to add insult to injury, his presence at this function with the top end of town was advertised in November last year. I believe that my constituents deserve better than this blatant disregard from the CEO of a company still owned in a majority sense by the people of Australia.

I wrote to Dr Switkowski again on 12 May and explained my disappointment with him regarding the misleading information I had been given by Telstra about his travel plans. Last week on 26 May I was honoured to receive a reply from Dr Switkowski himself, telling me:

quote.para: A useful step might be for me to call you and discuss further your viewsâI will set this up for the days ahead when convenient to you.

speech.para: I must admit that I am a bit bemused and a little amused that so much planning and setting up is involved in the head of Telstra contacting a federal MPâparticularly by phone. In the time that it would have taken for Dr Switkowski to sign the letter, he could have just dialled my number.

Let me give the House yet another example of Telstraâs failure to meet and satisfy customer demands in Swan. In early April this year, Lynda, a constituent of mine who lives in Bentley, was contacted by Telstra, offering her Telstraâs latest promotion: a new fixed phone service with 50 free phone calls a month and 50 free SMS messages a month. Under her previous policy, Lynda was receiving a fixed number of free phone calls but, notwithstanding this, Lynda told the Telstra representative that she would convert to Telstra if she could also get broadband internet connection. Having received assurances from the Telstra representative that this would be the case, Lynda decided to subscribe to Telstra for a fixed home phone service and provision of internet services. She signed the necessary paperwork.

After not hearing from Telstra for some time, Lynda contacted the company herself, querying the delay. She was told that her phone service had been transferred to Telstra around 22 April, but they could not give her any information on the broadband connection. So, on 11 May, Lynda again phoned Telstra and was told that she would not be able to get broadband connection until mid-July, as there were no ports available to the local exchangeâand, because she did not have two or more Telstra services, she could not get the 50 free calls a month and the 50 free SMS messages that were originally offered as part of the deal. In other words, my constituent is currently financially disadvantaged, compared to her original arrangements with another carrier, because of misinformation given to her by Telstra.

Despite Telstraâs promises, Lynda will not get broadband internet access until mid-July. That is the date, I suppose, when Telstra will finally have signed up enough people in Lyndaâs street to warrant the cost of adding another port to the exchange. She has now been belatedly promised that all discounts and free calls will be backdated to April. I wait with great interest to see whether this promise eventuates. I believe the Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman had to get involved to make that happen.

This is but one of many similar issues raised with me by constituents. It is clear to me that many of Telstraâs broken promises to those in my electorate are due to the companyâs reluctance to invest in new networks and technologies because of its corporate desire to minimise expenditure and boost the sale price. I urge all of my colleagues in this House to take a serious view of Telstraâs behaviour and to document their constituentsâ complaints so that, like me, they can use the opportunities of this House to try and impose some scrutiny on Telstra.

Mark my words: although it is difficult to imagine, if Telstra is fully sold it will become even less responsive to customersâ needs. And once againâthey are at it againâthe National Party will have caved in and sold out its own constituents and all Australians. Given its ineptitude, it is not surprising that since 1996 the number of National Party members of this House has been reduced from 17 to 12. Little wonder that we have seen the Independent members for New England, Kennedy and Calare returned handsomely.

As I have mentioned in this House on other occasions, the current leadership of the National Party is bereft of political skill, basic competence and administrative ethics. Members of this House have only this week and last witnessed the unedifying spectacle of the Deputy Prime Minister trying to argue in this place that national transport security has not been undermined by the fact that Mr Mick Palmer and his staff from the Office of the Inspector of Transport Security have been transferred to other dutiesânamely, to investigate the appalling case of Cornelia Rau and many others who have been wrongfully detained or deported.

The Deputy Prime Minister is wriggling like a rat in a trap on this issue. Almost daily he demonstrates to the House and to the Australian public his unparalleled incompetence both administratively and politically. Yesterday in the debate on a matter of public importance it was not surprising that only 11 of his coalition colleagues were willing to sit in the House and witness his confusion. You can bet they were press-ganged into attendance by the National Party whip. In fact I think I only saw one or possibly two Liberal members there. I think one of them might have even had to speak, so he was stuck.

Another alarming failure of the Deputy Prime Minister concerns drought policy. It is almost beyond comprehension that the second most senior minister in the government actually sat around in the cabinet room in recent weeks and agreed to a budget falsely premised on an optimistic outlook for rural Australia. The Deputy Prime Minister, who, while he looks like a stockbroker from Double Bay, claims he has such an affinity with the bushâon our side of the House we call him the Liberal in gumbootsâfailed in the most fundamental way to inform his Liberal colleagues that the drought was getting worse. He has also agreed to a budget devoid of any additional measures for the drought. Within three weeks the government was forced to confront reality and change budget policy. The truth of the matter is that the Deputy Prime Minister got well and truly rolled by the Liberals on the nature and scope of the drought measures.

This is the same Deputy Prime Minister with the glass jaw who will soon roll over on the sale of Telstra. As someone who was once a farmer and who has lived in regional Australia, I know how important access to efficient, reliable and state-of-the-art telecommunications services is to regional Australia. As the federal member for an inner city electorate in Perth, I know that these issues are vitally important to urban residents as well. Country residents will ask themselves: why vote for the National Party when the National Party has sold Telstra and in so doing has reduced further the service quality in telecommunications? The simple truth of the matter is that the most profitable telecommunications services are located in Sydney and Melbourne and along the eastern coast and if you live elsewhere you are a marginal customer to Telstra, meaning they do not really give a toss about you.

As I draw to a close, I would like to leave the House with one clear message: this budget is a missed opportunity that fails all Australians. In years to come, we will look back at 2005 and know that, if only we had invested wisely in infrastructure now, we would be equipped to sustain higher economic growth. The Hawke-Keating government commenced the process of reforming the Australian economy through tariff cuts, tax reform and more flexible labour markets. They modernised the Australian economy and strengthened it to better compete in global markets. Those substantial and genuine reforms have stood the economy in good stead. The coalition has implemented some further policy reforms which have received the support of the opposition. This budget is not an example of the government grasping the nettle and implementing much-needed reform. We should have used our good circumstances to secure long-lasting investment in our infrastructure, which would enable us to sustain higher economic growth rates for the future. Unfortunately the coalition has squibbed this opportunity, to the detriment of all Australians, and in particular to the detriment of Western Australians, who have contributed so much to the national good fortune. I call on members to reject this budget and to put pressure on the government to address our infrastructure deficiencies as a matter of urgency.

talk.start.para: âThe member for Swan joins all those opposite in saying how he would spend the surplus. If they had been in government for the last 10 years, there would not be one. They would be scrabbling around having interviews with Middle Eastern money men, looking for some way of meeting expenditure. They would be grossly overspent. They are the ones that hollowed out the logs. They sold Qantas, they sold the Commonwealth Bank, they sold CSL and they want to come in here bleating about the sale of Telstra. If the member for Swan had represented his constituent in that Telstra matter, he would have gone straight to the telecommunications ombudsman and had it fixed immediately and had her returned to her situation prior to taking up Telstraâs offer or got Telstra to deliver.

speech.para: All of this reform of the regulatory environment of telecommunications has come about since Telstra has been partially privatised. When they owned Telstra and were running it, there was no telecommunications ombudsman to complain to. It was an appalling service. Everyone agreed about that. It was absolutely shocking, and there was nothing you could do about it. Now we have a responsive telecommunications giant. There are still some issues but, partially sold, it is a heck of a lot better than it was. Just imagine what it could be like if it were fully sold.

The member for Swan then continued to slur my good colleagues in the Nationals about their Roads for Recoveryâthe programs that they support that deliver infrastructure into the bush. Maybe that is the reason the coalition actually took seats in Western AustraliaâHasluck and Stirling were returned to the government. If the ALPâs representation of the rural constituency is so great, where are the extra seats for the ALP in this parliament? Our Nationals colleagues, compared to the ALP, are expert rural representatives. They do a great job representing the bush and its interests against the state governments that universally ignore their issues and do not deliver the infrastructure they need. The response to AusLinkâa very responsible national program about connecting our capitals and dealing holistically with the transport of goods and people around this countryâbasically ended up being Labor councils and Labor states squeaking out for federal funding for what are basically local government roads and state infrastructure.Â For goodness sake: not only do we have to fix all the major issues like industrial relations reform, waterfront reform and tax reform; now the state governments are calling on us to fix their hospitals, their roads, their police forces and their schools. The list is endless. Surely, if we were doing such a bad job at the federal level, the ALP would have picked up a few more seats in Western Australia, rather than having Stirling and Hasluck returned to the coalition.

Quite clear from the member for Swanâs speech is the fact that the opposition is about axing the Roads to Recovery program. It is about squandering any surplus in incredible ways. Where are the moneys they got from the sale of the CSL laboratories, Qantas and the Commonwealth Bank? This is the same party that rolled over DFRDB contributions of members and government into consolidated revenue. Now, when the members of our military forces come to call on their pensionsâand eventually this pension fund will have as much money exiting it as entering itâthey will find that there is no DFRDB fund to finance that liability. Those opposite want to say, âThat is all right. The current taxpayer can do that. We do not need a future fund. Let us blow this future fund on a whole bunch of things that the state and local governments should be doing but, because of their economic responsibilities, are not doing.â

The member for Swan was talking about the Nationalsâ support for our Deputy Prime Minister. The backbench of the ALP, behind the Leader of the Opposition at question time, is the most enervated, bored, restless, unmotivated group of individuals in any parliament anywhere in Australia. They are totally used to opposition. They totally lack ideas. They have nothing but a mantra of âSixty-five dollars is too much for politicians but $40 is okay.â If they really object to this tax cut for higher income earners, then they should negate the lot. They should have the courage of their convictions and say so.

The taxpayer is not buying Laborâs fiddling with the fringes. They understand that this government has consistently delivered tax cuts to the vast majority of Australians over the last 10 years. They understand that we stand for tax cuts. The message that they are getting from the ALP through its opposition to these bills is that the ALP stands for high taxes and huge expenditure. They do not see the benefit of that. Just look at the New South Wales state governmentâs budget, introduced a week after the introduction of this budget into the House. Clearly people can see that Labor governments take money from the taxpayer and we return it.

This 2005-06 set of budget bills builds on nine years of strong economic performance. We have had strong growth, low interest rates for home owners, record low unemployment and more incentives for people to benefit from our economy and contribute to our society. This budget now focuses on returning people to the work force. It addresses trade shortages. It seeks to improve parenting in separating couples, with a focus more on their children and a parenting plan rather than on the issues that that couple may have with each other. It delivers targeted funding to two of the most mysterious and devastating diseases in our population: dementia and cancer.

It also delivers on my election promise of $7 million for a library at UWS at Kingswood, for which I have received a thank you letter from my vice-chancellor, Janice Reid, which I appreciate. I hope this library will improve the experience of learning for students at the Western Sydney campus. It is particularly important that we have the types of resources that Sydney and New South Wales universities do. I am known to be a strong critic of UWS, but that is because I want it to be one of the sandstone eight. My vision for University of Western Sydney is a premier university, a university that will be top of the pick no matter what for every student in Western Sydney. It should not be a university of which students think, âIf I donât get the TER to get into New South Wales, Macquarie or Sydney, I will go to Western Sydney.â It is not acceptable. It is the only university in Western Sydney, for two million people in Sydney. It needs to start lifting its game and delivering to the section of people that it represents. It is far easier for students to stay at home in Western Sydney and go to university than try and attend one of the other universities where they have to make living arrangements away from home.

The other election promise that I have delivered on in this budget is $10 million for the Panthers stadium. While that stadium will predominantly still be for league, the new surface will mean that other sports, such as soccer, union and hockey, and non-sporting events, such as showjumping for horses, gymnastics and festivals, can all be held in that stadium with increased sitting capacity. The western grandstand will be upgraded to include an extra 2,500 undercover seats, and the corporate facilities will be upgraded to include an additional 300 seats, which will bring additional opportunities for sponsorship to the various sports. I understand Panthers have recently chosen the architect and that work will begin at the end of the league season this year in September. The work should be completed by June next year. I understand the NRL has agreed to a delayed series of games for the Panthers next year so that Panthers will get its fair share of home games in the new stadium when that facility is ready at the end of next season. I fully supported the Panthers submission by lobbying the Prime Minister and the Minister for the Arts and Sport to provide those funds. It is a project that the club has been working on for many years. Full credit to them for achieving that goal.

I would like to take this opportunity to acknowledge the great contribution of Roger Cowan, the CEO of Panthers for the last 30 years, who is retiring. He has a life of extraordinary achievement with Panthers. He has brought a number of facilitiesâsporting, cultural and otherwiseâand forms of entertainment to Penrith at a time when the private sector failed to deliver to the citizens of Penrith. Roger did nothing that was not allowed within the clubs act. If the New South Wales government want to destroy the club industry, do not take it out on Roger and Panthers. Regulate appropriately if you do not feel that it is appropriate for the club industry to extend itself with Panthers. I would like to remind everyone that Roger at all times saved clubs that were going into receivership and closing. At no time did Panthers take over a club that was already financial and that was not asking for assistance from Panthers. We have rescued a number of clubs that would otherwise have closed.

If the state government has issues with that, there are other ways of dealing with it rather than opening up pokies into the hotels sector and populating gaming throughout an industry in the private sector. For all of the tragedy and social ills that gaming causes, it has no returns to society. The club movement was, I think, an excellent and admirable worldwide example of how to control and contain gaming and to deliver some great outcomes for the community. I think that the state government could have worked better with the clubs industry for other outcomes rather than set about dismantling the clubs industry by arduous taxation, targeted inquiries and increasing competition in the private sector with the hotels. Roger has seen the club industry through some very hard and challenging times. I wish him the best in retirement. I know he and his wife will retire in our local area and will be active in a number of things in our local community. I wish them all the best and acknowledge the great job they have done.

talk.start.para: âAll the best in the west.
âI wish them all the best in the west, and I acknowledge the great job that Roger has done for our community.

speech.para: This budget also saw the setting aside of $8 million over four years for the National Community Crime Prevention Program in Western Sydney. The centrepiece of this initiative is a national community grants program, providing funds for grassroots projects, designed to enhance community safety and crime prevention by preventing or reducing crime and antisocial behaviour, improving community safety and security and reducing citizensâ fear of crime. I believe the closing date for the first round of grants in the Western Sydney program was 29 April. I hope that many community groups I approached did put their applications in and will be soon benefiting from those grants.

The other election promise I made was the offer of $1.1 million for a vermin proof fence on the ADI site. I am very concerned that the New South Wales government has failed to take up this offer. I received a letter from the New South Wales Minister for Environment, Bob Debus, proposing a macrofauna fence to restrict the movement of dogs and foxes. A macrofauna fence does not gel with all the environmental issues we looked at in that parkland and all the environmental issues that the residentsâ action group fought hard to deal with. There is no point having parkland in the middle of what is essentially an urban area without a vermin proof fence. There are houses all around that ADI site. The reason it is in such pristine condition is that it has been fenced, and once further housing encroaches on that site it really will need a vermin proof fence that will prevent cats, particularly feral cats, and other introduced species from harming the flora and fauna, particularly the bird life. If we can get the Cumberland Plain forests back to their pristine condition, the bird life that goes with that community should come back too. That will only be possible if their nesting areas are preserved from cats and whatnot. In that way a vermin proof fence that goes two feet underground and has wires and barbed wire at the top, to stop that entry, is critical for preserving that site, for all the reasons that we fought so hard to preserve it.

It does not appear that the fence is in any way included in the plan of management. The last meeting of this plan of management is tomorrow night and so far nothing has come out of it to indicate that the state government is taking the R and E values of the site seriously. They are really not protecting the Cumberland Plain woodland and the flora and fauna on that site. Again we are relying on the state government to pick up where the federal government has left off, and again we are sorely disappointed.

The state government has also failed the people of Lindsay by so far refusing to provide an after-hours clinic at the Nepean Hospital. This is something that I lobbied to have in this yearâs budget, but it is not accounted for in this yearâs budget because the state government has so far failed to say where this clinic could go.

In their budget, the Carr government budgeted $900 million in extra funding for hospitals but half of that would have had to have been spent anyway to cover wage increases for existing staff under new awards. So for $900 million we are not getting any more staff; we are just getting an increase in the pay of existing staff. With the extra 4,000 patients admitted to emergency wards across the state this yearâand that figure is quite consistent with expectations: you can imagine that emergency wards would see more and more people each year; that is a natural normal increaseâthe remaining money will barely cover increasing admissions and administration costs, let alone improving existing services at the Nepean Hospital.

When the Carr government introduced the pokies tax, they ran around quicklyânot at the time they introduced it but two weeks laterâand said, âWe will spend all this pokies tax on our hospitals.â I do not see that, I do not see anything in the state budget that remotely says there is an increase equivalent to the pokies tax revenue going to our hospitals for improved services and new services and more staff and more beds. There is nothing in this budget except normal increases, which any responsible state government would have had to fund. There is no real increase at all.

In August the federal government offered the New South Wales government the opportunity to establish an after-hours GP clinic located near the emergency ward of the Nepean Hospital to take some of the heat out of the emergency centre, which gets quite busy. We have seen a number of cases recently where Western Sydney hospitals have been on code red and patients have travelled many miles to be treated. Again, no effort has been made to take up this offer.

This budget has also established some health priorities, namely dealing with dementia and cancer. All too often we get the terrible news that someone we know has been diagnosed with cancer. It has deeply affected this side of the parliament at this time, with the death of Gary Nairnâs wife, Kerrie. Her funeral is on Friday, and I know that a number of people from this House will be attending. I believe Kerrie was diagnosed with cancer no more than five months ago. It is the number one killer of Australians. Everyone knows someone who has been affected by cancer.

I am proud that this government is delivering $189 million to strengthening cancer care over five years to try to lessen the impact of this devastating disease. The funding includes $4.1 million to develop and implement training courses for cancer nurses, $1 million to improve the support for women newly diagnosed with breast cancer and $4 million to improve the early detection of breast cancer. There is $17.6 million into cancer research, $21 million for cancer clinical trials, $5.5 million to establish a national research centre for asbestos related disease and $23 million to enhance palliative care programs. These are just some of the ways the money will be spent.

There is also $5.5 million to raise national awareness of skin cancer and $25 million over four years to discourage young people from taking up smoking. I am very disturbed by the fact that 25 per cent of 18- to 25-year-old females in my electorate in Western Sydney smokeâwell above the national average. This campaign will be targeting those young women and the reasons they take up smoking. Through a national awareness program, this campaign will be trying to deter them from taking up smoking. In Lindsay there are about 7,000 in this age group, meaning that about 1,750 young women in Lindsay are endangering their health.

I am always disappointed to see young women smoking. I grew up in an environment where we knew that smoking kills. There were big efforts by our parents to discourage smoking. It is quite disappointing to see it on the increase in young people. As a habit smoking really does not have much going for it. It is detrimental to your health, it is expensive and there is already sufficient pollution in Western Sydney without having smoking contributing to it. It is the largest preventable cause of premature death and disease in Australia. I hope that these initiatives will have some impact on the young women in my electorate to give up smoking or to never take it up.

I commend these bills to the House. They are yet another example of good economic management and strong reinforcement from a reforming government. They are a tribute to our Treasurer and to our leader. The ALP should be ashamed of the statements that I know the members opposite will be jumping up to make about how they will spend the budget or a surplus that they seriously would not have had. They certainly did not have one in 1996. There is no state budget anywhere in Australia demonstrating a surplus. This is the only government that has consistently demonstrated a surplus. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âIn this debate on the appropriation bills I want to focus on the attempt by the Howard government to laud itself as the friend of working families. It is true that since 1996 the Howard government has used a range of tactics to capture the votes of low- and middle-income families. It has revived this pitch recently in the Prime Ministerâs address to the Menzies Research Centre and the constant mantra at question time. The Prime Minister knows that to keep government he needs the votes of low- and middle-income Australians. He knows that, were this group to return to Labor, he would be out of office.

speech.para: At the same time the Prime Minister remains beholden to a set group of interests in the community, largely dominated by big interests but also those of independent wealth. Everything he does and says should be seen through the prism of these two interests: capturing the votes of middle- and low-income families and servicing his interest groups. It has been a fine balancing act, but when you bother to actually study the detail of what he has done and his policy approaches, you see that that is exactly what it is: an act. Far from being the friend of working families, this Prime Minister is more like the wolf in sheepâs clothing. In this debate I want to examine some of the key policy challenges facing families at the moment and the reality behind the myth generated by the Howard government that they support working families.

The self-proclaimed workersâ friend in this yearâs budget failed to deliver any real package to address skill shortagesâto train more Australians and to provide opportunities for the kids of low- and middle-income families to acquire a trade. He failed to actually assist people from the lowest income families from welfare to work and has presided over a growing inequality between high-income and low-income families. He failed to seriously tackle the propositions put by Labor for real tax reform, preferring to give the highest income earners a tax cut while not seriously tackling those in the middle. He has overseen a further erosion of the social wage through both his backflip on the Medicare safety net and now the introduction of his extreme industrial relations agenda.

I turn firstly to the issue of skill shortages. The most recent figures clearly show that the Howard government has presided over a massive skills crisis. Far from improving, the Department of Employment and Workplace Relations skilled vacancy index shows the shortage of skilled workers is getting worse. As with infrastructure bottlenecks, the shortage of skilled labour is restricting the economyâs productivity and its capacity to grow. In regional Australia we face a shortage in both the traditional and the professional trades. However it is in the area of traditional trades that the crisis is most acute. The Howard governmentâs new apprenticeship program is not offering a pathway to traditional trades to the unemployed. The only path many Australian companies can now take is to look overseas for skilled labour. Australia is already ranked third in the OECD for reliance on skilled migrants to address skill shortages.

The effect of this policy failure is that we now have around 200,000 teenagers not in education or full-time work. Government members may well point to the increase in the number of new apprentices in the retail or hospitality industry. Despite the governmentâs rhetoric, many of us on this side of the House value the skills and experience gained in these industry sectors. In fact many of us on this side of the House have worked pretty extensively in those sectors. However, these industries are characterised by part-time casual work and predominately employ kids after school. It is an important thing to do, but they are not trade apprenticeships. We know that 40 per cent of apprentices who commence an apprenticeship in a traditional trade drop out. The government has done nothing to actually provide incentives for apprentices to complete their trades. This means that of the 580 apprentices who commence a traditional trade in Ballarat each year 230 are dropping out. The government has dropped the ball on this issue. This is just another example of its complacency.

OECD studies consistently indicate that failure to make an early transition to permanent work or full-time study is associated with long-term risks of marginalisation, helping to trap people in a cycle of unemployment, part-time work and government schemesâwhich many of my constituents are, sadly, all too familiar with. This is also one of the reasons why Labor proposed providing more vocational options as part of school based apprenticeships. Nine long years of Howard government failure has created a skills crisis that is hurting Australian businesses and families. The Howard government has dropped the ball on training, and this yearâs federal budget clearly showed it has no idea how to pick it up again. Instead the Howard governmentâs response to the skills crisis was a quick fix, short-sighted approach. The only new skills initiative in this yearâs budget is an increase in skilled migration, with an extra 200,000 skilled migrants instead of focusing on training Australian kids first. This government has created not only a nation of unskilled workers but a nation living on the margins, struggling to make ends meet.

A study carried out by the St Vincent de Paul Society has exposed the reality of John Howardâs Australiaâor perhaps to be more precise I should say âAustraliasâ. We have become a more unequal society under this government, a chasm that will widen after the government implements its new tax cuts. The Prime Minister and the Treasurer continuously boast about the fact that their government has presided over the strongest growth in private incomes and that they have created the miracle economy. The Howard government has been trying to brand itself as a great friend of the average Australian worker. This is about as believable as saying that Tony Abbott is the best friend of Medicare or even that Brutus was the best friend that Caesar ever had. The claim that the Howard government is a friend of the Australian worker is a myth. The Howard government showed in this yearâs federal budget that it was no friend of the ordinary working family and especially of those low-income families struggling to move from welfare to work.

Over the last few weeks, the Howard government has laid claim to creating a more equal Australia. However, nothing could be further from the truth. The Howard government has cited NATSEM figures showing a 163 per cent increase in private incomes for the bottom 10 per cent of households over the eight years to 2002-03 compared to 38 per cent for the top 10 per cent. Suddenly, after years of denigrating NATSEM, the Prime Minister is out there discovering the âgoodâ Ann Harding. However, the St Vincent de Paul report The reality of income inequality in Australia highlights the fact that the actual increase for the bottom group was $26 a week, from $16 to $42, compared to $762 a week, from $1,989 to $2,751, for the top group. I can imagine speaking to a teacher, cleaner or child-care worker in my electorate and telling him or her that if they receive an income rise from $10 to $50â500 per centâit is better than a CEO income rise from $1 million to $1.5 million. It really does not add up.

After nine years of unbroken economic growth, far from making the lives of average Australian families more comfortable, the Prime Minister has plunged 30 per cent of households into poverty, and middle-income families are relying more and more on debt to keep their heads above water. In the electorate of Ballarat, over 14,000 people, including over 4,000 children, are living in poverty according to Commonwealth census figures that show huge wealth disparities across Australia. The research also showed that rural Australia has much higher rates of poverty than cities, with almost 12 per cent of rural people living in poverty compared with 7.6 per cent in inner suburbs.

It is widely acknowledged that work is the best way to get people out of the cycle of poverty and to re-engage them with the mainstream community. We know that many of the people on Centrelink payments such as the disability support pension and single parenting payments require additional training to move into the work force. A government serious about helping struggling families would not be spending three times more on compliance in this budget than they are on training measures. A real friend would give such people a hand up, but the Howard government has gone for the handball, shifting them from one welfare payment to another that is punitive and provides a lower level of financial assistance.

It is also a package that provides more cuts than carrots. While the $1.5 billion invested in child care, wage subsidies and employment assistance for people with disabilities is welcome, that is almost totally offset by the $1.4 billion of cuts to payments and employment assistance. We cannot actually get the figures on this because, despite the fact that the government has put its measures in the budget and it has calculated those measures in the budget, it is refusing to provide that information to one of the Senate estimates committees that has been holding hearings this week. I ask the government what it has got to hide.

Five hundred million dollars has been cut from Job Network employment assistance, which means that the level of help, training and work experience available to people who need to skill up to get back to work will be inadequate. The Australian Council of Social Service already considers the current level of assistance for training and other assistance for most job seekers as inadequate. Cuts to employment services will affect the most disadvantaged Australians, who have low levels of skills and education and who have little more than $200 a week to live on.

It is not only the lack of adequate skills training but also the lack of incentives to move from welfare to work that is such a shame in this budget. Raising the lowest marginal tax rate from 17 to 15 per cent will not be enough to move people off welfare and out of poverty into work. In fact, the Howard governmentâs Welfare to Work scheme actually decreases incentives for welfare recipients to engage in paid work. This is despite yet another OECD report highlighting the fact that stronger incentives are needed to move people from welfare to work.

This shines a light on the true motives of the Howard governmentâs move to force single parents from the single-parenting payment to enhanced newstart or the new dole, which will begin to be withdrawn earlier and at a higher rate than existing payments. Parents who move from the lower newstart payment will face higher effective marginal tax rates than they otherwise would have on the pension income test. That means that, under the new scheme, welfare recipients keep less private income earned than they would have under the existing system, robbing them of the incentive to work and the opportunity to become more independent of welfare payments. Again, as with tax reform, the opportunity for welfare reform has been squandered in this budget, as has the opportunity to assist low-income families into meaningful work.

Nothing shines a light more clearly on the true colours of the Howard government than the tax cuts contained in the budget. The tax cuts were for the top end of town, not for the nurses, policemen, teachers and tradespeople of Australia. The budget exposes the masquerade that the Howard government is the friend of ordinary Australian families. It openly celebrates the growing divide in household incomes in our communities. After becoming Australiaâs highest-taxing government, the Howard government has decided to provide $22 billion in tax relief, but it is unfairly skewed towards the top end of town and it is still the little people who are going to be carrying the burden.

This is a budget for the Liberal Party heartland, not a budget for the ordinary men and women of Australia. The Treasurer has been unable, in either his commentary in the media or the consideration in detail on those bills, to give any reason for not supporting Laborâs fairer tax package. He has never substantially addressed the amendments moved by Labor, preferring to hide behind a procedural debate rather than account for why he has skewed the tax cuts in this way. The reality is that, while the government knows that it needs to keep middle-income earners happy, two years before the election it is not that worried about wearing some flak over providing a small amount of tax relief to middle-income families while also providing substantially larger tax cuts to Liberal Party interest groups.

At the same time as providing tax cuts skewed to families on higher incomes, the âworkerâs friendâ has been busy eroding the social wage. What Howard has given in cash advances to low- and middle-income families he has taken back in increased medical costs. We have seen the Medicare safety net backflipâthe safety net that was supposed to fix up the mess that the Prime Minister had made of Medicare. He has gone back on that as well. Private health insurance premiums have been increasing. There is also the GST, which was the pride of the last two elections. There are also issues with the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, and petrol prices are increasing. Not satisfied with this, the Prime Minister wants to further erode working conditions for Australian families through an extreme industrial relations agenda.

History is a great teacher. The Prime Ministerâs record of opposing every minimum wage case since coming to office tells us how much the Prime Ministerâs friendship means to low-income families. In 1997 the government sought a wage increase that was $2 a week less than that awarded by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. In 1998, it was $6 less; in 1999, $4 less; in 2000, $7 less; in 2001, $3 less; in 2002, $8 less; in 2003, $5 less; and in 2004 it was $9 lessâtotalling $44 a week, or $2,300 a year, less if the governmentâs view had prevailed. Are these the actions of a friend? I do not think so.

Under the governmentâs new reforms, the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, the independent umpire, will be stripped of its powers in setting the minimum wage and award wages. The Howard government has reduced the role of the AIRC to that of merely a spectator of industrial relations. Can you imagine the umpire Dickie Bird being told that he had to sit in the stands and let the Australian and English cricket teams sort things out? That is basically what the Prime Minister has done in terms of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission.

The Prime Minister stood up in parliament yesterday and defended the independent umpire of the politiciansâ wages, the Remuneration Tribunal. The federal government wants to abolish the independent umpire for low-wage workers, and it is currently arguing against a $26.60 a week minimum wage rise in front of that umpire, the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. Why does the Howard government hate the independent umpire for minimum wage workers, the Industrial Relations Commission, but seem to think that an independent umpire is perfectly okay for politicians? These are double standards. Patrick Gourley summed this up well in yesterdayâs Canberra Times:

quote.para: Letâs be clear: the Government has knackered the Industrial Relations Commission because it has, since 1996, given those on a minimum wage $44 a week more than the Government wanted. The entire rationale for the FPC, about which the Government will not be frank, is to dampen the rates of increase in minimum wages so that pay for 1.5 million people dependent upon awards will increase at a slower rate than those on higher wages.

speech.para: It is not just the Australian Industrial Relations Commission that the Howard government is setting about dismantling with the awards system reforms. The number of allowable matters is being reduced from 20 to 16. Gone will be shift penalties, annual leave, long service leave, bereavement leave and jury leave, just to mention a few. While the impact of the Howard governmentâs reforms are unlikely to be felt by the Australian worker in the short term, there is no doubt that over time the Australian Fair Pay Commission will leave workers worse off, a fact confirmed by the Prime Ministerâs refusal to say otherwiseâhis absolute inability to give a guarantee that no Australian worker will be worse off under these changes.

I want to talk briefly about a case example from my electorate and about some of the things that can happen. In my electorate, Telstra Country Wide has a large call centre which is fantastic. It provides great employment for people in my district. However, Telstra has contracted out the employment for that call centre to a labour hire company. All of the workers under that labour hire company are not employed by Telstra and they are not subject to the EBA conditions to which other Telstra workers are subject.

Quite recently Telstra Country Wide wanted to change the shifts at the call centre. Without any consultation with the work force, which is what the EBA for Telstra workers required, Telstra decided to extend and change a shift, which would have required people who are now working a fairly reasonable amount of time during the day to work fairly late into the night. A large number of women in this industry work part time while their children are at school. They are supplementing the family income. The changes that were going to be forced on them by the labour hire company at Telstraâs behest meant that the workplace was no longer going to be family friendly. If this government thinks that implementing those sorts of changesâforcing people onto individual contracts, not allowing them to be part of enterprise-bargaining agreements and particularly agreements that cover companies such as Telstra, and allowing companies to suddenly change workersâ shifts without any consultation or without allowing them to put a case as to why it would be very difficult for that type of work force to comply with those changesâis being family friendly and being the friend of Australian families then the government is kidding itself.

The industrial relations reform agenda that the Howard government is bringing to this place is not friendly to families.
