If the government thinks it is, it needs to go out to Australian work forces and talk to people about their living conditions and their expectations of balancing work and family. If the government does that, it will see that its reform agenda is not family friendly.

The self-proclaimed workersâ friend has targeted low- and middle-income families as systematically and doggedly as he went after the Liberal Party leadership. It was a long-term agenda. He sees them as a group that has to be capturedâfamilies that have to be wooed and votes that have to be bought. He sees them as a commodity that is of use to him to be bought for the highest price. When we examine the Howard governmentâs record closely, we see that its claims and commitments to the Australian worker are little more than clever, deceptive marketing and spinâand it is spin that has worked: the broken promises, the Medicare safety net, interest rate rises, the never-ever GST, the unfair tax package, tax cuts for low- and middle-income families and larger tax cuts for high-income families, the erosion of the social wage and now the extreme industrial relations agenda.

This government is not a true friend to Australian families. Its friendship stems from political opportunism and self-preservation. As Australian families start to wonder why, despite the trappings of material wealth with which they have surrounded themselves, they find they have a creeping despair about their level of debt, the future of their children, whether their jobs are secure and whether they will have the resources ever to retire, perhaps it is time for them also to wonder whether the self-proclaimed workersâ friend, this wolf in sheepâs clothing, has all the time just been pulling the wool over their eyes.

talker.name: Cobb, John, MP
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Regional Services
talker.name: Mr JOHN COBB

talk.start.para: âWhen I came to this place we still had a debt of almost $40 billionâ
âIt was $90 billion.

âIt was actually $96 billion when the government came to power, but by the time I got here they had reduced that by $50 billion. When you consider the difference that made to the perspective of a small businessman, like me, who has owed money for most of his working lifeâand still doesâand who is paying interest, you appreciate what it means to have a government that was an active participant in the borrowing market.

speech.para: Think about what that $96 billion debt did to the rates around Australiaâand, I guess, beyond that, the world. When you have got a $96 billion debt, it has to be funded by interest repayments. The Treasurer has informed us that in another 12 months we will be down to a debt of around $6 billion. You have to be a borrower in the market to realise what an incredible difference that makes, not just as a borrower but as a person who continually deals with a market where interest and inflation are incredible factors. That affects people who borrow for business and people in the housing marketâanybody who owes money. That involves virtually all of us at some stage in our lives, especially when we are youngerâunless you are in an incredibly lucky position, in which case you thank your parents very much. Most of us are not in that position; most of us are borrowers. Those of us in businessânot just farming but small business all around Australiaâhave incredible reason to be wary of high interest rates.

This is the fourth or fifth budget that I have been involved in, and I am pretty proud to be part of a government that in another 12 months will reduce the debt it inherited from $96 billion to $6 billion. That is one hell of an achievement which every one of usâwhether we are borrowers like small business people or simply people who work and have a mortgageâhas to be incredibly thankful for. That can happen only because the government makes hard decisions and makes tough decisions and because it by and large makes decisions not for the moment but for the future of the country, decisions with long-term aspects to them.

It is only because of that situationâbecause we do have an economy that is strong because those decisions have been madeâthat we are now able to make the decision to add another $250 million to the governmentâs $1 billion cost for the current drought. You cannot do those sorts of things when you owe $96 billion, as our predecessors very kindly left us to deal with. You simply cannot do it.

Neither can you make one of the greatest foreign policy investments that we have made. Following the tsunami disaster, we will make available over the next five years $1 billion, in probably one of the biggest foreign policy decisions this country has made. We are part of South-East Asia. We are a nation that is part of a very distinct area of the world. That investment is something that upstaged countries with far bigger economies than ours, such as the US, which contributes one-third of the worldâs gross domestic product. For us to do that shows not only how much a part of this region we are but how much we accept our responsibilities within the region in which we live. I think that is one of the best policy decisions that have been made in my lifetime. But we are only able to do it because of the state of the economy and the way in which it is being run.

To have a $9 billion surplus says that we are running particularly well. When you measure it against the rest of the OECD, it is incredible. Most of them are running budget deficits and are certainly not in the situation that we are in. It means that the nation as a whole can start saving for the future. The only reason we are able to look after our ageing population, the only reason we are able to make forecasts about where that is going, is that we have put ourselves into that situation.

I would like to talk for a while about what has happened in my patch, the Parkes electorate in western New South Wales. I know the member for Lindsay next to me is probably thinking about Western Sydney. I too have a strong leaning towards that area, as I have driven through it for many yearsâover the Blue Mountains, down through Penrith et cetera. It is always a good place for St George to win the football. I would like to talk about the parts of the budget which are particularly relevant to my electorate of Parkes. AusLink is going to put nearly $100 million into the Newell Highway. Almost $20 million of that is going north of Parkes up to around Alectown, and $11Â½ million of that is going to be spent in the coming financial year. I am talking about an area between Parkes and Dubbo which, on a good dayâif you can put it that wayâcarries more trucks than the Pacific Highway. It is quite obviously an area that must receive that spending. The highway gets incredible haulage usage and we are doing our best to increase its capacity so that people can still use it as safely as possible.

The introduction of the rural medical infrastructure fund, a $15 million program through Regional Partnerships, means that medical centres in regional Australia that can show need can get up to $200,000 to help with outfitting. In my electorate, places like Tottenham and Tullamore could benefit from that. One would hope that if places like Cobar and Narromine, which are putting up medical centres, are unable to do it in their present circumstances the rural medical infrastructure fund would be relevant to them.

The whole of the Orana region of the west is incredibly pleased to see that provision has been made in the budget for the operation of a Medicare-licensed MRI machine for Dubbo. This means enormous things to our region. People from as far away as Bourke will not have to travel as far as Orange or Sydney to have access to an MRI machine. People all the way from Moree through to Ivanhoe and Condobolin will have access to an MRI machine in an area that is much cheaper for them to travel to. Dubbo is a natural centre for them. The Aboriginal population of western New South Wales in a lot of situations do not like travelling any further east than Dubbo. They see Dubbo as a natural hub. It does not seem to matter whether they come from Moree, Wilcannia, Walgett, Condobolin or wherever; they naturally gravitate to Dubbo. Our government has recognised this and has accepted the argument that Dubbo does need an MRI machine, from a geographical point of view and because it is a natural hub for western New South Wales.

The water-saving issues, while not specifically targeted just to our electorate, have huge ramifications. Think about the towns out there that in some cases are only a few months from having to deal with water situations they have not had to deal with before. The water infrastructure fund, with $2 billion in various sections and departments, must go a long wayâone hopes with state, local and business money going with itâtowards dealing with some of those issues. While this country can never protect itself entirely against drought, I do believe that with judicious use of that money and cooperation with state, business and local people, we will turn that $2 billion into far more money and to some extent proof ourselves against situations such as the one we are in at the moment. There is obviously the urban side of better water use, and there is money there to experiment with more efficient usage. It is a big thing for my electorate and it is a big thing for Australia.
For those of us in agriculture, the tax cuts may not be of enormous advantage today. One does hope it will rain again and we will return to profitability.

Labor have the opportunity over the next couple of sitting weeks to pass the legislation in the Senate and make that which is inevitable come true on time on 1 July, as the Treasurer has drawn to our attention. There are many people in my electorate who will take advantage of the threshold changes in that legislation. There is almost $20 billion in savings involved for taxpayers there.

It is not, as some people have pointed out incorrectly, just a $6 tax cut to low-income earners. Most people earning up to $45,000 with two children are not, as we have heard, really paying a net tax at all. In addition, what a lot of people forget is that it is not really in the interests of people who are currently on $50,000âand that is a lot of peopleâto earn any more at the moment. When these thresholds are raised, it certainly will be. Most of them will go to a 30c in the dollar tax level, and suddenly their whole attitude will change. They will have a reason to do overtime. They will have a reason to get ahead more and, obviously, they will take advantage of that, as indeed one would hope they would.

I mentioned the ability of a good, well-run economy, in the firm control of a government, to help. Having the most drought-affected electorate in Australiaâit gives me no joy to say that, but I have every reason to point out that fact, as I have done before in this placeâI am very grateful, as indeed all of us with rural electorates should be, that the government have listened. They have only been able to do that because of their good economic management: the extra $250 million that has come out has been made possible by the budget situation the Treasurer drew to our attention three weeks ago.

As well, in an area such as mine, there are towns, particularly ones like Cobar, Dubbo, Parkes and Forbes, where there are incredible skills shortages. Given that scenario, the Australian technology collegesâone of which, I am happy to say, is going into Dubboâwill allow people from all those regions to be able to make use of the enhanced youth allowance, living away from home allowance, apprentices allowance and other allowances that are all part of this budget.

It is a great problem to have, if you think back to the time 10 or 15 years ago when there was no shortage of skills in country areas like mine. That was not so much because there were people there. It is simply that now a demand for them exists that did not exist before. A budget like ours underlines the fact that we have made possible the decentralisation of industries in areas like the ones I have spoken about. It is a great problem to have this need for skilled people, a need that did not exist 10 or 15 years ago.

Like a lot of others I am very critical of the way in which academia got hold of the education curriculum in New South Walesâand around Australia, but I know more about what is happening in New South Walesâand seemed to encourage people to think that if they did not go to university they were dumb. That has been recognised by this governmentâby Brendan Nelson. What we are doing about the problem of skills shortages is recognising the problem and allowing industry to say, âThis is what we need,â rather than have TAFE colleges or someone say, âThis is what is here. Get used to it.â

Now that we are listening to industry, I believe the 300 places we can have as a maximum in Dubbo can be accessed. We can get people from places like Cobar, Forbes, Parkes, Condobolin and wherever it might beâout at Nyngan, perhapsâand they can come to Dubbo and make use of the allowances that have been enhanced, particularly the living away from home allowance. People from Broken Hill could go there, or they could go to Adelaide. But we need to train our own, and that is what our measures are designed to do, in conjunction with business. They are targeted and specific. In our region, it is obviously the heavy industrial and the heavy mechanical skills that are needed. Instead of having to go to New Zealand or elsewhere overseas to get them, one would hope that in another three or four years we will be able to get them locally. Also, to my surpriseânot having any argument with the restaurants we already have in Dubboâin that town in particular I am told that chefs are in short supply. So perhaps the catering industry may have some influence in where we go with our technology college in Dubbo.

Another thing that came through in the budget that was of particular relevance to the seat of Parkes and also to all of regional Australia was Bank@Post servicingâ266 post offices around Australia will receive Bank@Post. This gives people an opportunity to carry out financial transactions in areas where there is a lack of banking services that people can use. Over the next 18 months Bank@Post services will be introduced in 266 post offices, including those in Tullamore and Tottenham in the electorate of Parkes.

The Roads to Recovery funding is once again being put out, with another $1.2 billion over the next four years; and the black spot road safety program is also being extended, with another $340 million in 2005-06 in partnership with councils. There are also projects of strategic regional importance to make our roads safer, which is certainly relevant to those who live in those areas.

Funding for two new Sustainable Regions was announced in the budget, one of which involves all of the western division of New South Wales plus the Shire of Nyngan, in conjunction with south-west Queensland. There is $21 million to be spent over the next two years. I do appreciate those people like David Boyd, Steve Radford, John Williams, Howard Laughton and Jeff Wise, who have taken on responsibility in our region for sitting on the board, helping the government and the region to work out ways we can increase employment in western New South Wales.

In closing, there is nothing so important to a country like ours, with its growth rate and its population, who are so export orientated and small business orientated, for the government, whatever it does, to be as much as possible a debt free government that does not push interest rates up, that keeps inflation down and that makes it possible for those of us involved in small business to go ahead and borrow with confidence and expand with confidence. When you couple that with an industrial relations policy that allows you to employ people with confidence, I think the country can do nothing but go ahead further. I would add that I am very proud to be part of a government that is ensuring that that happens.

talk.start.para: âThere is no doubt that the political landscape and the discussion and development of public policy at the moment are regrettably littered with instances that display short-term vision when we should be displaying long-term vision; which display good politics rather than good public policy; and which display lack of balance on a whole host of levels. One example of that sort of outcome is this yearâs budget. Given the economic circumstances that Australia presently finds itself in within the global marketplace, this yearâs budget could have held so much promise. But it is an opportunity that has been squandered, for much of the reasons that I outlined from the commencement of my speech.

speech.para: Regrettably, this governmentâs actions over the course of its journey have been characterised by looking at what is just around the corner rather than thinking things through in the longer term. It has been characterised by the use of devices such as wedge politics and every form of political device that you can think of, rather than actually sitting down and talking about mechanisms that could ensure we are developing good public policy. When it comes to the lack of balance, it can be either not getting the balance right between expenditure and revenue on a financial spreadsheet, which is the budget; or it can be getting the balance wrong between the way in which people with different power and circumstances can operate together within the Australian community.

The previous speaker, the honourable member for Parkes, talked about the prospects for small business. It strikes me as strange if we look at industrial relations that what we are seeing from the Howard government is progression towards a scenario that puts people into conflict. The whole basis, especially for small business, in the change of the relationships between the power of the employer and the power of the employee dictates that that is what is going to happen. We have a set of principles for industrial relations which so emasculate the protections that employees have had that it makes it very difficult for them to enter into relationships of trust, which are very important in small business, between the employer and the employee.

A strange notion that has been rattled on about by this government over several years is that the panacea for continuing job growth is to ensure that unfair dismissal laws are struck from the law book. In fact, when you push this point and ask for any evidence that this is so, you find that there has been one study and nobody even now can suggest where the footnote comes from. One of the greatest urban myths ever is a magical figure that is from time to time plucked out of the air in the context of these types of discussions that says, âThis is what will happen.â

I am interested when there are debates about small business. If we look through a number of the studies and reports that have been mentioned, there are two that are very important to the Australian parliament. The first is the Reid report and the second is the report of the Baird committee. I happened to be an opposition member of both those inquiries. On the first occasion some people thought that I was a strange appointment but I was put on the committee for various reasons.Â I found that inquiry one of the most interesting inquiries that I have been involved in. It assisted me in my understanding and education of the problems that surround small businesses throughout Australia.

If you look through the submissions and the body of evidence, you will see that unfair dismissals and unfair dismissals laws are a very low order problem when presented by small business. Small business will always be concerned about issues that surround fair balanceâtheir ability to negotiate themselves, whether it be small business against big business, retail small business people against landlords in large shopping plazas, small business people that find themselves in difficult situations because of the imbalance of power by those that hold the licences for franchises; franchisees against the franchisor.

The Australian parliament has progressively tried to address these types of issues through amendments to the Trade Practices Act. That culminated early in this parliament following the election. We had the ludicrous situation whereby in amendments to the Trade Practices Act the Howard government recognised that one of the advantages that small business could have was if they were allowed to go forward under the Trade Practices Act and use collective action. Ah ha! The light switch is on and there is an indication of an understanding from the government that, in situations where there is an imbalance of power, if we are to assist those in a weaker position and if they are encouraged and allowed to take collective action that is something positive for them in advancing their cause.

When the legislation was reintroduced, there was one difference between the piece of legislation presented in this parliament and that which was presented in the last parliament before the election. What was that? In the particular amendment that talked about collective action there was one group of organisations that was unable to be involved in actions taken under the proposed amendments to the Trade Practices Actâand they were organisations registered under industrial relations law: trade unions and organised labour. Why did the government have to pursue its ideological hatred for organised labour in that manner? There were examples going on at the time the parliament was discussing this amendment to the Trade Practices Act which showed that, through the cooperation of organised labour with employer groups or industry groups, action could go forward. But, in that first blush of this parliament, we saw the government give an indication of its ideological bent against organised labour in the emergence of that piece of legislation.

We now have the principles set down for the proposed changes to industrial relations. All I can say is that they are simply based on winding the clock right backânot to last century, not to the 19th century but right back to the time of the Industrial Revolution. That might be overly dramatic, but that is a way in which you can look at the principles. You have to ask: is that really the intention? It is simply wrong to suggest that, even over the length of time that the Prime Minister has been a member of this parliament, organised labour has not changedâas all other areas of society have changedâand that the way we do industrial relations has not changed. It would be a different matter if in fact nothing had happened and it was all based on conservative action and the protection of the past. But that is a nonsense. There have been changes in the way in which production in workshops et cetera is carried out. There have been changes in managerial practices and administration. There have been changes in the relationships between employers and employees. In an overwhelming majority of cases these have been positive changes for all.

Last night in a contribution I reminded the House that in the Hawke-Keating years, especially in the early years under Prime Minister Hawke, the great revolution that occurred in the restructuring of the Australian economyâsomething that from time to time the Howard-Costello government wants to completely ignoreâwas only achieved because there was consensual agreement of a tripartite fashion between employers, employees and the government to move things forward. There was the give and take and the balance that I have talked about. To throw that away simply because people have a blinkered view of the way in which the world works is wrong. If there are excesses by any section of the community, we should deal with them. But, please, do not brandâas I believe the government isâthe majority on the basis of the actions of a minority. It does not make sense for me to come in here with a few horrid examples of the behaviour of employers and suggest that that is the way all employers act. If I illustrate the actions of some employers over which employees obviously need protection, I do it on the basis that it should be sensible legislation that enables appropriate protection in those cases. The principles set out in the industrial relations vision that the Howard government has just too dramatically change that balance.

To suggest otherwise is to not really look at the way in which this has been put to the Australian community. There is a need to have that underpinningâan underpinning that has been very important for the way in which Australia has moved forward and for the way in which Australia has been able to be a cohesive society. Let us not just say, âItâll make us more competitive,â and assume that in some way the industrial relations flick of the switch backwards is going to make us more competitive. Our competitiveness, as we know through the changes over the last 20 or 30 years, is more complex than that. Let us do it in a balanced way. Let us recognise that we will not continue to go forward if we do not have the necessary investment in physical infrastructureâbelatedly acknowledged by the release of the report into the infrastructure requirements for Australiaâs export efforts today by the governmentâand if we do not invest in the skills of our people through appropriate training and understand the way that fits into our economy. If we do not do that, we will get swamped by our competitors. Again, it is about balance.

Look at the way this government is developing its trading relationships. It has decided that the way that it will do this is by negotiating free trade agreements with individual countries. It is a much different approach to the multilateral approach of Labor in government and the approach which the opposition continues to support. We see a greater advantage in concentrating our efforts on a multilateral basis, looking at blocks of countries and looking at ways in which we can cooperate at a regional level. If we think it is going to be simple negotiating a China-Australia free trade agreement with China, I think we are kidding ourselves. There is a lot of nonsense going on now in the assessment of what has happened since the start of the year when the US-Australia Free Trade Agreement came into force. There is a body of evidence that suggests that, at this stage, overwhelmingly the advantage has been to American interests over Australian interests. One would hope that that is not to continue, but that was the warning that many people gave in the debate about that free trade agreement. Once again, it is trying to get the processes right. When we are talking about pieces of public policy believed to be for the long term, we need to get the balance right to go forward.

Look at the differences between the opposition and the government about tax cuts. Simply, what the opposition is putting forward is that the tax cuts be distributed more equitably. If you look at the comparison in a graphical manner, the tax cuts that are given under Labor have a much flatter gradient. We have tried to ensure that larger cuts at the bottom end of income levels are offset by making smaller tax cuts to the higher level. There is one element that the government has been strangely silent on when we have debates about tax levels at the federal level. The debate always concentrates now on income tax. It is as if that great phenomena, the goods and services tax, never happened. What we really should be doing when comparing tax levels at different income levels is layering the effect of a flat taxâthe GSTâbecause, regrettably, on the basis of the very sparse study that has been made of this phenomena, the impact of the GST is greater for those on lower wages than those on higher incomes.

Supposedly the GST was the âgreat revolutionâ, the âgreat reform of our tax systemâ. Let us not forget that. We have this hokey-pokey about it being a state tax: âThat doesnât have to be in our books, because that goes straight to the states.â Let us compare apples with apples. At the start of the Howard government, it was pure income tax. Since then, the GST has been introduced. So, if we are going to make the right comparisons, we should be looking at the combined impact of both those taxes. As I said, I hope that at some stage we will be able to look at a number of the questions that confront this parliament in terms of its long-term impact, in terms of what is good public policy as opposed to good politics and in terms of a more balanced approach.

I will give one further example, because it was something that struck me. When we looked at the budget this year and were told how much money was available to be distributed, the squandered opportunities were clearâopportunities like reinstating the Commonwealth dental health program. I will continue to challenge this government to have a direct involvement in the provision of public dental health. It is allowable under the Constitution. In the late forties, I think it was, there was a constitutional amendment that allowed it, and the Constitution specifically mentions it.

That is not the only reason I will state; the other reason is a point I will continue to return to. I have before me a national dental update from May 2005 from the Australian Dental Association which indicates that indirect expenditure by the Commonwealth government, through the 30 per cent rebate for private health insurance, accounted for 6.81 per cent of total dental expenditure in the year 2002-03. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI am delighted to rise in the cognate debate on the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 2005-2006, because I am a proud member of a government that has done more for the Australian people in the last nine years than the previous Labor government did in 13 years. How do I know that? I know that because wages under this government, in real terms, have grown by 14.7 per cent, but under Labor in 13 years they grew by only 2.1 per cent. So who has done more for the Australian taxpayers? The Howard government, because it is delivering in so many respects.

speech.para: You only have to look at these milestones: the lowest unemployment level in nearly 30 years; record low interest rates on home loans; low inflation; and high investment. This country is booming, but countries do not boom by themselvesâjust look at New Zealand. Today New Zealand announced that it is concerned about its growth and the downgrades in the forecasts. Yet Australia is booming, because it is being managed well by a strong and capable government led by Prime Minister John Howard and a good team in the Treasurer and the executive. I will also add that members of the government make a solid contribution. I often look across the chamber and wonder to myself how long the Labor Party, as the commentators say, can continue to thrive on dead wood. However, I should not really go into that.

This budget was a post-election budget, but what did it do? It gave tax cuts at both ends of the spectrum: it gave tax cuts to compensate for bracket creep in the higher brackets, and it gave tax cuts at the lower end of the spectrum. When I was first elected as the member for Canning, I said I would make it my business to make sure that the so-called working poor got to keep more of their money. Here is a genuine, gilt-edged case of those who are working being able to keep more of their money.

This is important to those who work at both ends of the spectrum but, because of the relativity of their wages, it is particularly important to those at the lower end. If they get to keep more of the money that they earn, the working poor, as they are called, are better off and as a result their families are better off. That is why, combined with low unemployment so that more people have a job and with low interest rates and low taxation, Australia has never been better off since the glory days of the sixties.

I could go into so many aspects of this great budget which my electorate of Canning has received warmly. I know the Australian people have received it warmly. The only people who have not received it warmly are those opposite, and that is because the budget is too good. They cannot match it. They complain and they talk about $12 tax cuts, yet Mr Beazley knows that when he was in the previous government, led by his great mentor Mr Keating, they promised things such as tax cuts in law which were never delivered. So the Australian people just do not trust them.

talk.start.para: âL-a-w tax cuts.
(Mr Baldwin)âOrder! The member will be heard in silence.

âThey just do not trust the Labor Party on economic issues. It was very clear in my electorate as I went around doorknocking before the last election that people were very concerned about what would happen should Labor ever regain the Treasury bench in this country because they know that Labor do not keep their word. Not only do we keep our word but we actually build on it as a government. Clearly, we are a government to be trusted, and that is why the people endorsed us in droves. Dare I say it about myself and others of us whom we may wish to mention, our margins went from very low margins to much greater margins because the people believed that we were in a government that would do more for them.

speech.para: One of the aspects of the budget which was heartening to see was the fact that AusLink was again in the forward estimates. The funding will now flow to the states, although only if they sign the bilateral agreement on the construction code and the road funding code. This code, as we know, has currently been taken up by Victoria. South Australia is in the loop, and I am told that Mr Beattie and Mr Carr are heading that way. In Western Australia I think we are nearly there, because they only have until the end of the month to do it. Dr Gallop has been a bit hairy chested since he won the election in February and he thinks that he can take until the last moment, but I have inside information that they are about to sign. It is cute, really, isnât it, because they are about to sign the code which, again, takes contracts on these roads in the AusLink program out of the hands of the union thugs and places them back in the hands of productive small businesses, contractors who want to get on and employ people and local people who want work. So, at the end of the day, Western Australia will sign before the end of the month.

In a very surprising development, I have been able to glean something from the Western Australian state government budget papers about one of the main projects that I have been pushing for ever since I have been the member for Canning, the Mandurah bypass. This is the extension of the Kwinana Freeway and the building of the Mandurah bypass, essential infrastructureâand there is much talk about infrastructureâfor the south-west and for the Peel region.

In the lead-up to the last election the state government were continually asking the federal government to cofund this. âWe want 50 per cent,â they kept saying. They originally asked for $150 million, and that was committed through AusLink. The then minister for roads, Senator Ian Campbell, was happy to announce that in the Peel region in Mandurah. With much fanfare, my opposition opponents on a number of occasions turned up with the then transport shadow spokesman, Mr Martin Fergusonânot Mr Laurie Fergusonâ

talk.start.para: âThe member will refer to members by their title.

âI refer to the member for Batman, not the member for Reid. My opponents announced that they would match that funding if they were elected. Then the state government got a bit cute and said, âLook, it is $170 million now, and we want an extra $20 million.â So the Prime Minister announced in Perth, with many present, that we would contribute the extra $20 million to build the Mandurah bypass. But he did put a condition on that extra $20 million, which was that construction would begin in 2006.

speech.para: He did that because, like me and the rest of the people in the region, he is suspicious about the state government not getting on with the job. We are suspicious because Alannah MacTiernan, the transport minister in Western Australia, is building a railway from Mandurah to Perth. We applaud her for doing that because it was an initiative of the coalition under the previous Court government. However, she changed the route and has done a number of other things that have now seen the cost of the project blow out from $900 million to $1.5 billion. What does that tell you about her ability to fund something like the Mandurah bypass? It makes it difficult, obviously, because the moneys that should be going into road infrastructure are being sucked into this rail infrastructure. I would like to put on the record that the $1.5 billion being used to build this 100 kilometres of railway is more than the cost of building the Alice Springs to Darwin railwayâI think that was $1.25 billion and this is $1.5 billion. You could call it the gold-plated Mandurah railway line. You can see that its cost is absolutely blowing out and as a result they are having trouble funding it.

So the condition is that they start in 2006. However, I have been made aware that before signing the bilateral agreement the state government have put a few conditions on it. They want to commit to â50 per cent fundingâ as the wording when they sign the bilateral agreement. Naturally they want to do that. Why? Because if it blows out and blows out and they do not build it until something like 2012, it will cost much more. If that is the case, it will cost much more well into the future, and if the federal government agrees to pay 50 per cent it will be paying much more than it expects to. My understanding is that the project has already been assessed by main roads and, while it is over $340 million already, it is going to cost an extra $100 millionâso it will be $440 million. Of course they want to set funding at 50 per cent rather than having a set figure.

But in the state budget the state government so far have only allocated $4 millionâ$3.3 million spent to 30 June 2004. The state government have allocated $82 million towards this project over the period from 2004-05 to 2008-09. Just understand this: if they have only allocated $82 million for that period which finishes in their forward estimates in 2009, they are only half funding it to 2009, given the fact that they have to start by 2006 to get the extra $20 million of federal government moneys. So they are not serious. If they were serious they would be allocating the whole lot. They have a sign on the end of the freeway saying construction will begin in 2007ânot 2006 by the wayâand yet they are only half funding it. Do they want to build half the freeway or the bypass or are they just putting it there so that they do not have to really start work until 2008-09, which is the time that Alannah MacTiernan has been talking about?

What is even worse is that the second tranche of funding of $82 million, which takes the total to $167 million, does not mature until the period 2009-10 to 2010-11. So that is the real time that these people want to build this road: in 2010 or 2011. I am going to expose them through their own budget papers in the local media and the Western Australian media. I am going to show that the state government are not serious about building the Mandurah bypass, because their own figures show that they are not funding it completely until 2011.

talk.start.para: âOoh!

âThe member for Reid has just shown his concern about this. He knows you have to keep a promise. If you promise something like that, you have to deliver on it. We are a government that deliver on our promises, unlike those opposite.
âI am seeking to intervene
(Mr Baldwin)âIs the member for Canning willing to allow the intervention?

âNo, because I have a lot to say. One of the other elements of the lack of state government funding on this is that the state government say that they have not had a decent response from the federal government. I have said this in this place a number of times, and I will do it againâjust very briefly, because I want to move on to something else. Minister Alannah MacTiernan says that we have been tardy in responding to her requests for funding for this essential piece of infrastructureâthe Mandurah bypass. Yet I have a letter sent from John Anderson, our Deputy Prime Minister, to Alannah MacTiernan, dated 13 February 2002, where he says in essence that the Peel deviation should be determined and there should be decent planning and infrastructure. His letter says:

quote.para: Further planning and design activities you propose for the Peel Deviation should provide necessary evidence for the Commonwealth in determining whether this project should be declared a RONI or not. In particular, detailed planning of these sorts of proposals allow the Commonwealth to prioritise projects with the largest benefit to the nation and provide an appropriate level of certainty in cost estimates for the Commonwealth to be confident of requiring funding levels.

speech.para: When he wrote that we were still on RONIs, so of course he could not respond under the Roads of National Importance program, because she did not reply until 29 June 2003, some 16 months later. So who is tardy in responding? A letter to me from John Anderson 16 months later says:

quote.para: I note your desire for funding for the Peel Deviation West Australian freeway. The West Australian freeway is not a Road of National Importance now because obviously that program has finished and it is a state responsibility. To date, the Western Australian government has not responded to my previous requests for a detailed project proposal and has not allocated any funds for this project.

speech.para: I rest my case. They have not even done the preliminary work. They took 16 months to respond. Is it any wonder that the project changed from Roads of National Importance to AusLink?

The state government have had record income through taxes and royalties. Their budget a few weeks ago showed how well-off they are. Yet the people of Western Australia cannot get this decent piece of infrastructure. As we know, if you can take their word for it, their half share is $170 million, yet their estimated bonus GST payment this year was over $200 million. They can get on and build it, and that is what I urge them to do.

Taxation is always an important issue to do with budgets, collecting moneys et cetera, but I am always very concerned when the tax office oversteps the mark, and it has overstepped the mark again. People in this House will know that I have been concerned about the way the tax office has treated people involved in schemes that it gave private and public rulings for. We went through the mass-marketed schemes exercise, and there are still people bleeding from that. They lost their houses, their families broke up and some even committed suicide. We have just recently gone through the latest exerciseâwhere the tax office has retrospectively applied rulings to employee benefits arrangements. It is the same storyâpeopleâs lives have been destroyed, because they have been retrospectively visited with EBAs. Currently, the taxation office is looking at being retrospective over a 20-year period. It is looking at service trusts established in 1983. There are companies that established service trusts in 1983 that are now under scrutiny from the tax office.

Last week, Mr Mark Konza, the Deputy Commissioner, Small Business, at the ATO, and Mr Michael DâAscenzo, the Second Commissioner of Taxation and Chief Tax Counsel, visited us. When we asked these two gentlemen how they could start visiting operations such as service trusts that have been established for more than 20 years, they said, âLook, some of them are out of hand.â If that is true, we do not want anyone to be rorting, but at the end of the day there is no ruling. They admitted themselves that the Tax Commissioner has only mentioned this in a speech and an article. There have been no rulings and no appropriate guidelines put out. They even admit that it is a grey area and there are no parameters or benchmarks that people can base their assessments on. There was a ruling some time ago called the Phillips ruling which somewhat addressed this. Most people operating in this area believe that they have a 50 per cent deduction and that there is a six per cent to eight per cent mark-up per annum on these service trusts. We know that they are usually used by tax accountants and professionals such as lawyers, doctors et cetera, where they run their office at arms-length.

It is absolutely indecent behaviour by the tax office to visit people in a retrospective manner. So when we asked these two gentlemen last week: âWhen are you going to start your retrospectivity? When does the clock start ticking?ââunder the new guidelines for self-assessment you are not meant to go back more than four yearsâthey could not say whether it was from Mr Carmodyâs speech or whether it was from his article, which was apparently only a one-paragraph article, or whether it was meant for some time in the future. How do these people know how to put their affairs in order? It should be prospective, not retrospective. To that end, recommendation 6 of the tax office, in the ROSA report, states:

quote.para: Where the tax office changes a public interpretation or long standing practice to the detriment of taxpayers, that change should become effective prospectively and, where necessary, from a future date that allows affected taxpayers reasonable time to become aware of, and act upon, that new interpretation.

speech.para: The ROSA case is currently taken as future direction. Yet one of the reasons why we have had trouble trying to convince the succession of ministers of this disgraceful behaviour by the tax office is that in some respects they seem to be prisoners of the tax office. I will not name him, but one of the current ministerâs staffers was a tax partner in KPMG; his position was national tax director of KPMG. In 1997 KPMG issued tax advice for two mass market arrangements, namely, Freedom Express and Interest Recount, and he was their head man. So why would he then be giving contrary advice to the minister if he has had that position?

talk.start.para: âWhat does the Assistant Treasurer say about retrospectivity?
(Mr Baldwin)âOrder! The member will be heard in silence.

âOn retrospectivity the Assistant Treasurer is mute. In fact, it is very hard to get him to address it. Originally he showed good signs in comparison with the previous minister, but currently he has again decided to be manacled by the tax office. The situation is very dangerous when you are taking advice from somebody who seems to be compromised. At the end of the day, I think the tax office is getting above its station in life when it decides to get involved in these sorts of rulings that affect so many peopleâs lives. In the case of this service trust there are 70,000 taxpayers involved. Seventy-thousand Australians thought they were doing the right thing, some of them for 20 years. Now they are going to be visited by the tax office, who do not even know what the parameters are. So we should be bringing these issues back into the House to be dealt with quite properly as legislation. (Time expired)

âPerhaps the most telling contrast about the realities of this budget was presented in the Sydney Morning Herald of 11 May when Matt Wade wrote an article with the headline âTheyâll be feasting at the top end of townâ. Alongside the article was a photograph of a hysterically laughing Peter Costello, obviously pleased with the inequitable taxâ
(Mr Baldwin)âOrder! The member will understand that you refer to members by their title or their electorate, not by name.

âThe photograph was of a highly amused Treasurer, hysterically laughing at the realities of the inequities in this budget, a Treasurer who, in his past life, had been a very important activist in reducing the ability of workers to negotiate collectively against employers. The same newspaper contained an article in which the contrasting view was presented, entitiled âPainting the town red is out for full-time mumâ. That was about a woman with six children who had been unable to obtain child support payments from her husband and who was living on $460 a week. The article was looking at the situation she would be in when her youngest child turned six years of age. That is the contrasting situation in the budget. We are all awareâit does not need regurgitating by each and every member hereâthat Labor has put up an alternative to the governmentâs proposal that the Prime Minister and members of this parliament should receive tax cuts of $65 a week. Under Laborâs alternative, large numbers of Australians would receive $12 a week rather than $6 a week. For some people that kind of figureâwhich seems paltry to members in this House, who are getting the $65 reductionâis indeed very important.

speech.para: We are all aware that under the governmentâs proposed package 45 per cent of the value of tax cuts go to the top 10 per cent of taxpayers while the remaining 90 per cent of taxpayers share the other 55 per cent of tax cuts. It is a question of tax cuts, a more equitable proposal by Labor so that the vast majority of Australians get a better deal and we do not have this elitist proposal by the government. I hate to offend those on the other side by quoting the ACTU, but they said:

quote.para: As a result of the last two Budgets high income earners stand to gain more than $130 a week in tax and superannuation relief while more than 75% of working peopleâeveryone earning less than $58,000 a yearâgets between zero and $6 a week.

speech.para: They also talked about the way in which these families have been hit by higher interest rates under the current governmentâthere has been a major effort by them to increase interest rates since the electionâhigher petrol prices, and increased medical and education costs. And of course we know of the particular changes on pharmaceuticals and Medicare that have occurred since the election.

ACOSS, the Australian Council of Social Service, made the point that 80,000 sole parents with children aged six to 16 who apply for parenting pensions will be put on Newstart payments and lose $20 a week over the next three years and that 70,000 people with disabilities will be deemed ineligible for DSP and lose $40 a week in payments. These people are already struggling on payments of just $200 to $240 a week, and they will receive even lower payments under the proposals of the peopleâs friend, John Howard. We should remember that 88 per cent of sole parent families are headed by women and 92 per cent of parenting payment single recipients are women.

That is the reality out there. It is not the conventional picture of the stereotypical analysis by people in backyards across Australia that it is all 15-year-old or 18-year-old teenagers who are having children. The reality is that single parents in Australia, predominantly women, are essentially in their 30s and 40s. That is borne out by the federal governmentâs own statistics. That is the reality out there: people on very low incomes trying to survive and look after their children. And now we are going to have a situation where they are essentially forced to go out to work as soon as their children turn six. We know there are going to be very unfortunate social consequences of this policy, because many of those people are concentrated in suburbs of very dense housing, transient population areas and housing department areas where virtually everyone has the same problem and social support is minimal. We are going to have very real social problems arising from this governmentâs policy.

It is very interesting to note this thrust against children and parents. One of the crises this country faces is the fertility rate. We lament the decline in the number of children in this country. We look at the overseas experience of countries like Japan and Germany which is much worse than ours. We complain about the ageing of our population. This policy is guaranteed to go further down that road. Rather than having a society which essentially encourages women to move in and out of the work forceâto not lose their employment but be able to return to their status in organisationsâand which supports them in bringing up children, these changes will worsen the situation.

In 2002, 49 per cent of children under 12 years of age, or 1Â½ million children, spent some time in child care. There is a chronic child-care shortage. The Australian Bureau of Statistics estimates that 175,000 miss out on child care needed by their parents. And what we are going to have is the offer of 84,000 out of school hours places, 2,500 day-care places and 100 at-home places, which is going to continue the chronic shortage. We are going to have a situation where there is no funding for long day care places. This means that parents with young children under five years of age will be unable to return to the workplace in a practical sense. We will have a situation where nearly 160,000 sole parents are forced to work and need child care. They will be competing for a minimal number of child-care places in this country. I think the obvious outcome for this is extremely negative. The Treasurer criticised the claim that some welfare recipients were âshirkersâ. He also questioned the growth in the number of Australians on disability pensions, declaring:

quote.para: Have we really had an outbreak of disability?

speech.para: In contrast, his brother Tim Costello of World Vision Australia said:

quote.para: I think that notion thereâs a whole big group out there who are taking taxpayers for a ride is actually profoundly untrue.
I think when you are trying and you are really giving it a go, that people assume when thereâs low unemployment that you must be a shirker, is disempowering.

speech.para: Those are contrasting views on these changes. The government argues some statistics, such as unemployment rates and interest rates et cetera. But all is not merry in the kingdom. I refer to an article by Tom Bramble in issue No. 54 of the Australian Journal of Political Economy which made a few other points about the reality in this country. He looked at part-time and casual employment. Whereas in 1984, 16 per cent of the Australian work force was casualised, today we see 27.9 per cent in casual employment and a further 28.5 per cent in part-time employment. Thirty-five per cent of new jobs are casualised. While everyone in this country is allegedly so happy, the Australian survey of social attitudes indicated with regard to working hours that two-thirds of people, who because of the power of employers have very little choice in life these days, said that they were working too many hours. In 1992, executive pay in this country was 22 times greater than average weekly earnings. A decade later, in 2002, it was 74 times greater.

In the housing market, we have a situation where, in 1996, 43 per cent of people in Australia owned their own house and 28 per cent were paying it off. Now the amount of people owning their own house has declined to 38 per cent of the population. Amongst people aged 25 to 39 years there has been a decline of 10 per cent in home ownership. In the period 1999 to 2004, total earnings in this country of $77 million have been countered by a consumption increase of $110 million. I turn to the household debt to income ratio. In 1996, it was 35 per cent; in 1990, 50 per cent; and, in 2004, 150 per cent. And I do not need to accentuate the foreign debt or the decline of Australiaâs trading situation in elaborately manufactured goods.

An article by Kenneth Davidson in Dissent magazine in the summer of 2004-05 made a few points about the great contrast with regard to the export of elaborately transformed manufactures from this country. There was an expansion in their growth rate over the decade to 1996 of 18 per cent. What has the figure been since 1997? Against that 18 per cent rise, there has been a rise of 1.7 per cent. The trade deficit has markedly blown out. We have seen a situation where:

quote.para: Behind the smokescreen supplied by the $8 billion budget black hole, Costello slashed $2 billion of R&D, business and export development programs plus funding cuts to universities and training programs.

speech.para: Talking about training, we have come to a very sad situation in this country. Todayâs figures from the NCVER on Australian apprentice and trainee statistics note that sad situation. In the 12 months ended December 2004, there were 133,000 withdrawals and cancellations compared with 139,000 completions of apprenticeships. The number of cancellations in the three months ended last December was the highest on record. Those statistics also indicate that the number of apprenticeship commencements fell from 277,000 to 263,000 over the 12 months to December 2004. So what we have in this country is a very serious problem with regard to training in the conventional trades.

I recently had the pleasure of attending Granville TAFE College in my electorate, the second oldest in the country and the second largest in Sydney. With the support of the CFMEU, the support of the state government and the interest of local employers and community groups, people were trying against all obstaclesâagainst inactivity and lack of interest by this governmentâto sponsor young people and get them involved in conventional apprenticeship areas. But it is going to be to little avail because of the stark lack of interest by this government in training. I have to admit: the government do have a solution. Since they have been in government, they have brought in over 400,000 people under the skilled migration category. They have brought 400,000 people into this country to fill the skill absences which they have created. That seems to be the limit of their thinking on this matter.

What do we see with the migration intake? When Labor went out of government the current Prime Minister was out there with subliminal messages to the electorate that Labor was a high-migration party, that Labor was dictated by ethnic vote buying, that this is what dictated immigration in this country. A decade later, the man who subscribed to views of a low-migration future for this country will have an intake next year of 137,000. If you look at the figures, you will see that the total of 137,000 is markedly higher than in most of the Labor Keating-Hawke years.

talk.start.para: âI think the biggest we ever got was 160 or thereabouts.

âI think that is correct. What has been the reality inside that intake? Next we have seen a decline in the refugee humanitarian intake in this country. When the Prime Minister came to power, this countryâs concern, involvement and interest in the world was such that 16 per cent of the intake was refugee humanitarians. In the coming year it will, sadly, decline to nine per cent. At the same time family migration has been starkly slashed back. In the current intake, out of that 137,000 next year, 97,000 will be part of the skills intake. If you are an employer, are you going to bother? Are you going to be interested in training anyone when you could just ring up the federal government minister a few days after you have been to the party fundraising function and say: âItâs dreadful in Australia. We canât get employees. Itâs really dreadful out there. Itâs so hard. When you advertise in the papers thereâs no interest. No-oneâs skilled enough. Please, please help us.â The government is so uninterested in our skills future that it thinks it can just turn on the tap. No employer is going to do any training under this government, because it is so inclined to see the short-term solution of migration.

speech.para: If we had any hope that it was going to improve under the Howard government, the last budget was very interesting. The initiatives are very minimal. I will develop this more in the exploration of the budget in detail. Most of the expenditure in this budget in the immigration portfolio is for various aspects of the skills intake, which is understandable. But this government has come up with a new and brilliant solution to how we are going to solve skills shortages in this country. It has come up with a new initiative. We are going to import not only labour but also people to do apprenticeships. This is the giant idea that has come out of this government. It will solve our problems by bringing in people to do apprenticeships here. We cannot encourage Australians to do it. We cannot give incentives to employers to make sure they do it. We cannot give benefits to people to finish apprentices. So now we are going to Timisoara in Romania and Timbuktu in north-west Africa to look around for people to come and fill these skills shortages in this country. What future does that indicate for young people in this country? That the government is so uninterested that it sees the future as bringing apprenticeships into the country.

They have talked about other initiatives such as these new colleges, which will not produce anyone with a trades degree until 2010. This government say: âThings are so desperate that we have to bring in an extra 20,000 people in the skilled intake next year. Itâs so desperate this momentânot next week, not in two yearsâthat that we have got to increase the intake at this level now.â They are bringing in a scheme that is going to bring in more apprenticeships in 2010. If you want any reason why this is happening in this country, look to the sad state of payments to apprentices. It is bad enough that the media promote competition with regard to the lifestyles of other people. It is bad enough that some areas of this employment have been decried and turned down for years by public debate. It is worsened by the amount of money that is paid to these people.

It is a concern to people that this is the governmentâs response. There has been very little research done. We know that one of the initiatives of the government when it first came in was to close down the independent research body which looked at settlement in this country. We have got no real evidence of the connection between the trades, occupations and supposed proficiencies of the people we import and where they actually end up in the labour force. We in Australia are asked to have faith in this budget, to have faith that the skills shortage of this country are going to be solved by a proposal which will bring out tradesmen in another five years time. We are asked to say that this government is going to solve the problem by bringing in people as skilled migrants, with great uncertainty as to whether they will actually work in that occupation. We face the reality that migration processing in these areas takes a year or so on average. So the chronic, immediate crisis which has to be solved tomorrow afternoon is certainly not going to be solved by this initiative.

With regard to immigration, I will also briefly talk about the refugee and humanitarian intake. Last year there was great fanfare about an increase in the money spent on the settlement of immigrants under the refugee and humanitarian intake. In reality, if you look at the figures, you see that per capita there was no increase. The only reason that there was a rise was that there was an increase in the intake from 12,000 to 13,000. This coming year we will see a focus on Africa in regard to our refugee and humanitarian intake, a government initiative that I support totally and absolutely. However, these people will cost the Australian taxpayers more money per capita because many of them have had very disrupted education, if any education. They have lived in dire circumstances in rural areas, and they have very major family dislocations. If you treat them with the same level of assistance per capita as before, it will not go very far.

In conclusion, there is an initiative by the opposition which encompasses a far more equitable tax option for the Australian people. It is a thrust towards doing something about the collapse of infrastructure in this country. There are measures that encourage people back into the work force. There is no stick; there is no persecution. There are no punitive measures to force them back but, rather, there are measures that give them incentives to empower themselves to become part of the work force. I commend Laborâs amendment.

talk.start.para: âI rise in support of the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 2005-2006 and related bills, and I congratulate the Treasurer on presenting his 10th budget and his eighth budget surplus, which for the 2005-06 year provides an underlying cash surplus of some $8.9 billion. Developing budget surpluses and paying back debt have helped to lower interest rates and to lower inflation. Economic reforms have made our tax system and our economy more competitive and have created some 1.6 million new jobs since 1996, bringing unemployment down to its lowest level in 28 years. This outcome has been achieved because of this governmentâs outstanding economic management and policy decisions that affect the lives of all Australians.

speech.para: The budget builds on previous budgets which sought to give particular support and assistance to families and small business in order to create greater productivity. It builds on the governmentâs record of being able to pay off Laborâs massive $96 billion debt, a debt that was costing the budget some $9 billion in interest payments.

Australians deserve the lowest possible tax, consistent with responsible budget management. This budget rewards hard work by delivering some $21.7 billion in personal income tax relief over four years, on top of the $14.7 billion delivered in last yearâs budget. These tax cuts will increase the reward from work force participation for all Australian taxpayers, assist low-income earners, boost disposable income and improve the competitiveness of our personal income tax system in comparison with those of other developed nations.

From 1 July this year, the 17 per cent marginal tax rate will be cut to 15 per cent. The 42 per cent tax threshold will increase from $58,000 to $63,000 on 1 July 2005, and to $70,000 on 1 July 2006. The 47 per cent threshold will increase from $70,000 to $95,000, and on 1 July 2006 it will increase again to $125,000. These changes will ensure that more than 80 per cent of taxpayers will face a top marginal rate of 30 per cent or less over the next four years, and from 1 July 2006 the top marginal rate will apply to only three per cent of all taxpayers.

Superannuation savings will also be given a significant boost with the abolition of the surcharge on superannuation contributions and relevant termination payments made or received from 1 July 2005. This measure will save taxpayers $2Â½ billion over the next four years and, together with the co-contribution scheme announced in the 2004-05 budget, demonstrates this governmentâs commitment to encouraging voluntary savings and boosting retirement incomes.

There are also additional benefits for seniors. Those who are eligible for the senior Australian tax offset will now pay no tax on their annual income up to $21,968âup from $20,500âfor singles and on a joint income of $36,494, up from $33,612, for couples with equal income. The Medicare threshold for senior Australians will also be increased to ensure that they do not pay the Medicare levy until they begin to incur an income tax liability.

With unemployment at its lowest level in 28 years, when more Australians than ever before are participating in the work force, it is now time to spread that participation further. We want to encourage more people to join the work force. The introduction of the largest ever Welfare to Work program designed to assist moving people who are capable out of welfare and into work is a commendable initiative and will further strengthen our economy in the longer term. Although costly in the short term, this $3.6 billion package provides more incentives for people to work. These are the long and hard decisions that the government is prepared to make for the future of all Australians.

If more people are able to move from welfare to work, this will help them with higher incomes and better participation in mainstream economic life. It will also reduce the obligation on other taxpayers, whose taxes pay for welfare support. There are many people of working age who receive income support without any obligation to look for work. I believe that those who are working deserve to know that others who are capable of work are at least looking for work in return for income support. I am sure they agree that the best form of income is from a job. We need to encourage as many people of working age as we can to join the work force.

At a time when unemployment levels are at their lowest and in fact businesses are crying out for more workers, it is essential that we invest in higher skill levels so that employers can obtain the skilled labour they need. This is important for the business sector, as upskilling our work force will increase the abilityâ

talk.start.para: âMr Deputy Speaker, I seek to ask a question.
(Mr Baldwin)âThe honourable member is seeking to ask a question. Will you allow the question?

âNo. Upskilling our work force will increase the ability of employees to find satisfying workâand the chances of doing that are better today than they have been for a very long time. This government is about facilitating good economic policies that will enhance this governmentâs decade of progress for the benefit of Australian workers, the Australian economy and our future.
âYou were a good minister for small business at the start of the government.
âThank you.
âThe member for Fisher will cease interjecting.

âAs our economy changes, the nature of work changes, but a strong vocational and technical education system will better equip workers to upskill and adapt. This budget delivers up to 4,500 prevocational training places for people interested in a career in a traditional trade and provides some $5.8 million towards an additional 7,000 school based new apprenticeships, so more students can begin their apprenticeships while continuing their school studies. A further $12.6 million has been allocated for an extra 5,000 New Apprenticeships Access Program places that will assist job seekers who experience barriers to skilled employment to obtain and maintain a new apprenticeship.

speech.para: As also promised during the election, this budget provides $351 million over the next five years to establish 24 Australian technical colleges for 7,200 year 11 and 12 students. This will allow young Australians an opportunity to learn the best trade skills. It will enhance the prestige of technical education. I believe we should recognise and value trade training as highly as we recognise other forms of postsecondary education.

This government has demonstrated that it is serious about catering to the needs of the 70 per cent of students who do not go on to university. We currently have 394,000 new apprentices in training in this country. The vocational and technical education system has grown by 35 per cent since 1995âfrom 1.3 million students to more than 1.7 million in 2003. This represents more than one-ninth of the Australian working age population.

At a time when we have such low unemployment and an exceptionally strong economy, we will need to meet immediate labour shortages by increasing our skilled migration intake by 20,000 places to 97,500 places in 2005-06. Business will be supporting and identifying their needs for skilled migration and identifying those who can provide it. This initiative will assist businesses in the mining and construction industry, metal trades and fabrication, earthmoving companies and abattoirs in my electorate in the south-west of Western Australia to immediately attract more workers with experience and skills to meet the growing demand for production.

In recognition of such areas of skills shortages, this government has demonstrated its support to strengthen efforts to address the current skills needs in some of our key traditional trades and will provide $106 million over four years for trade-learning scholarships in trades experiencing skills needs. This will provide a $1,000 tax-free scholarship from 1 July 2005 through the Commonwealth trade-learning scholarships and will ease the financial burden faced by new apprentices in their first years of training. This, coupled with the allocation of $120 million for new apprentices starting in specific trades experiencing skills needs to obtain tool kits to give them a financial head start in their new career, further demonstrates this governmentâs commitment to ensure a clever, skilled work force and our future prosperity. It is estimated that around 34,000 new apprentices will benefit from this tool kit provision, valued at some $800 per kit. Along with our $5 billion investment through vocational education and training agreements, these initiatives represent a comprehensive approach to meeting Australiaâs skills now and in the future.

This 10th budget has allocated record funding of an estimated $8.5 billion to Australian schools and students for the 2005-06 year, an increase of a staggering $589 million or 7.4 per cent over last year. This increase continues the trend of the past nine Howard budgets and highlights the national leadership shown by this government. This budget also commits over $635 million for school capital works, representing an increase of 29 per cent over the previous year, largely due to the roll-out of the Howard governmentâs $1 billion initiativeâInvesting in Our Schools program. A total of $163 million will be provided from the program in 2005-06 to fund state schoolsâ capital works that school communities have identified. Capital funding for Catholic schools and independent schools in 2005-06 will consist of an estimated $113 million provided through the capital grants program, plus an additional $80 million injected from the Investing in our Schools program. This is a great boost for many of our local public, Catholic and independent schools and addresses the needs that our state governments have tragically failed to address. The Howard government is strongly committed to ensuring that every child is given the chance to find and achieve their potential through choice and opportunity in education. I commend this governmentâs 2005-06 budget initiatives for schools that continue to strengthen the Australian governmentâs leadership role in schooling across Australia.

Last year the government introduced a $19 billion More Help for Families package. In continuing its strong commitment to families, this government will again increase family benefits. It is estimated that around 400,000 families will get an average boost of $24 a fortnight to their family tax benefit part A payments from 1 July 2006 as part of this budget. This boost is the result of an increase in the lower income threshold level to allow low-income families to increase their earnings without affecting family assistance payments. The threshold will be increased by $4,139 to $37,500 from 1 July 2006. It will not only put more money into the pockets of low-income families but also play a significant role in the governmentâs welfare to work policies and is a key part of a total budget package aimed at removing the barriers which are keeping welfare recipients out of the paid work force.

In recognition of the extraordinary effort and contribution carers make by providing constant and daily care for their relatives, friends and those who have disabilities or are frail aged, this government will once again provide a one-off carerâs bonus payment. A bonus of $1,000 will be provided to 90,000 current eligible recipients on the carerâs payment and a bonus of $600 will be paid to 300,000 people receiving the carerâs allowance. We value the work they do and they deserve this recognition. It will cost some $317 million in this year as a bonus is tax free and will not be treated as income when calculating the carerâs social security entitlements. This yearâs budget measures continue the Howard governmentâs strong commitment to carers and builds on last yearâs budget initiatives when carers were given more flexibility and support in their care arrangements.

Included in the budget is a commitment to Western Australiaâs transport infrastructure of over $223 million. This confirms that the Australian government has kept its election promise to contribute an extra $20 million to the Peel deviation, more commonly known as the Mandurah bypass. But the Western Australian state government must come to the party and start major construction works in 2006. I note that it has confirmed that the timetable is achievable. This government will contribute $170 million to the Peel deviation over five years, including $3 million in 2005-06 to continue preconstruction and planning. The extra $20 million has been allocated for 2007-08. When complete the 48 kilometre Peel deviation and the 23 kilometre extension of the Kwinana Freeway will provide a fast freeway link from Fremantle through to the south-west regional cities of Bunbury, Busselton, Margaret River and of course further south to Manjimup, Pemberton, Northcliffe and points south. It will provide better access for producers in the south-west to markets in the city and to export destinations. It will also provide faster access to boost tourism and allay the concerns of residents travelling to and from Perth.

Our Roads to Recovery funding program has been renewed for another four years as part of this yearâs budget with Western Australian councils receiving $45 million in the 2005-06 period and $76 million in untied local road grants. The Roads to Recovery initiative is important and has been a very successful program. The reason for its success is that it provides funding direct to councilsâmoney that they did not have before and money that is spent on worthwhile road repairs which otherwise they would not have the financial ability to do for quite some time. The budget confirms that $1.35 million will be spent on extending the Roads to Recovery program for Western Australia until 2008-09. It is a vital funding injection that the councils need. South-west shires in my electorate of Forrest will benefit from some $13.8 million in funding to address problems with local roads over the next four years.
